webTitle: Life in a goldfish bowl is OK! for Gary and Becks

fields.headline: Life in a goldfish bowl is OK! for Gary and Becks
fields.trailText: David and Victoria's story made for one of the most buttock-clenchingly embarrassing hours of television since Mike and Bernie Winters jacked it in.
fields.body:
I don't know whether you ever went to the Co-operative Insurance Society dance hall in Manchester in the 60s, but it was quite something. A huge glitter ball and vast acres of polished-wood sprung floor on which to stub out your fags. I only mention it so you get some idea of the dimensions of Gary Neville's kitchen.

Obviously Gary doesn't have a glitter ball in his kitchen, those not being among the recommended fixtures and fittings in Cheshire mansions this season, but there certainly was room for one. We got a close-up of Gary's lovely kitchen when his best chum David Beckham came round to cook for him, during The David Beckham Story on ITV, about which it is difficult to know what to think.

Any mention of how preposterous all these people appeared begins to look like snobbery, and I am the last person who would wish to sneer at the nouveau riche. But still, it has to be said that David and Victoria's story made for one of the most buttock-clenchingly embarrassing hours of television since Mike and Bernie Winters jacked it in.

As far as I could make out, Victoria and little Brooklyn live in Hertfordshire with her parents while David rattles around in some stately pile near Manchester, when he is not round at Gary's place getting his tea for him. The reason they live apart, said Victoria, was that they were both "really passionate about what we do", much of which in her case appeared to be having her picture taken for magazines. "I just wanna have a house, have dinner with him," lamented Victoria. "I would give anything for that."

Victoria, if that's what you want, what you really really want, the good news is it can be done. There are people all over Cheshire whose work takes them to London from time to time. They leave the house in the morning and catch a train, and they are in London sometimes the very same week. But not Victoria.

"We have responsibilities for our work," she said. "I wish I could be happy to be a housewife." And there, I think, we got to the nub of the problem. It is just so much more fun being fawned over by photographers and art editors than cooking, cleaning, and caring for a child. And she would have Brooklyn to look after as well.

Cheap shot, I know. David, bless him, whom we saw being photographed for Esquire, was at least honest about the fun of the photo-shoot. "You can order anything you want; pizza, McDonald's, and somebody brings it for you."

He was also photographed, in his lovely home, by OK! magazine, whose editor, my old friend Martin Townsend, suggested David do "the shaving thing" because the bathroom was "really cool". He also photographed Becks with his CD collection, doing the "music thing". This truly was life in a goldfish bowl, but a goldfish bowl of the footballer's own choosing. One assumes the thrust behind the TV show was flogging copies of Becks's book, but as a documentary - a soccumentary if you will - the programme was pointless. It showed us Beckham "doing the shaving thing", but not shaving.

It should be pointed out that Beckham is undoubtedly the most talented English footballer of his generation. Similar could not be said of Neville, a solid Premiership defender who has had the good fortune to find himself in an outstanding side in the charge of a uniquely gifted manager.

Neville was unwise enough to allow the cameras to keep rolling when they entered through his big wrought iron electronically operated gates. The gates were eerily reminiscent of the entrance to Orson Welles's gaff in Citizen Kane, although Orson, unlike Gary, never felt the need of a dalek to issue the following cheery greeting to all visitors: "You have entered a protected area and you are under surveillance. The authorities have been notified."

I gather from Neville's newspaper column that he has been the target of envy after his appearance on the programme. It could be that there are those who feel there is something wrong with a middling sportsman living like Barbra Streisand.

I am not one of them. Having seen Fletch in Sky's soccer soap Dream Team bearded in his den by a fan, I know there are crazy people out there in our celebrity-obsessed culture - which David, Victoria and Gary incidentally fuel, but that's another column, another time - from whom the famous and semi-famous need to be protected.

Dream Team, by the way, consistently tells you more about the Premiership and its dramatis personae than any other programme on TV.

When you see the Beckhams moving from photo-shoot to photo-shoot, with their ridiculous tattoos, and fawning reporters hanging on their every ludicrous word, the tendency is to say, "You couldn't make it up."

Dream Team does, and nearly always gets it right.

martin@kelner.demon.co.uk

webTitle: Third Division  round-up

fields.headline: Third Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Tony Cottee's first month as the Barnet player-manager has breathed new life into the London club, who are rapidly becoming the side to watch if you enjoy end-to-end action.
fields.body:
Tony Cottee's first month as the Barnet player-manager has breathed new life into the London club, who are rapidly becoming the side to watch if you enjoy end-to-end action.

So it proved again on Saturday when an exhilarating encounter at Cheltenham ended 4-3 in the home side's favour, despite Barnet twice taking the lead. A subdued Cottee admitted afterwards that his side need to find greater concentration away from home.

There were no such lapses for Brighton, who stayed second with 2-1 victory over Halifax. The division's leading scorer Bobby Zamora scored twice to bring his total to 14 for the season. Rochdale also remained in contention with a 1-0 home win over Blackpool.

Cardiff's Robert Earnshaw is the latest starlet to attract attention from Premiership clubs. Middlesbrough, Derby and Coventry are all apparently interested in the 19-year-old, who scored a hat-trick in his side's 4-1 win at Torquay that raised Sam Hammam's revitalised club into fifth place.

Carlisle finally enjoyed some good fortune as they battled to a 1-1 draw with Lincoln.

webTitle: Second Division round-up

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: Walsall are the new leaders of the Second Division following a 2-1 win over Port Vale. Vale's discontent continued after their midweek FA Cup defeat by Canvey Island. "We look a good side when we are ahead but one or two of the lads don't quite believe when they go behind," conceded the manager Brian Horton.
fields.body:
Walsall are the new leaders of the Second Division following a 2-1 win over Port Vale. Vale's discontent continued after their midweek FA Cup defeat by Canvey Island. "We look a good side when we are ahead but one or two of the lads don't quite believe when they go behind," conceded the manager Brian Horton.

Oldham inflicted a 16th defeat in 20 games on last-placed Oxford United. Carlo Corazzin's first goal in 13 games broke the deadlock in the second minute on the way to the Latics' 3-2 victory.

Third-placed Wigan were held to a 2-2 draw by managerless Brentford after Andrew Scott's late equaliser for the Bees, and Bristol City extended their run of league matches without defeat to 14 by overrunning Bury 4-1 at Ashton Gate.

Bristol Rovers ground out a goalless draw at Swansea while Wycombe lost 3-0 at home to Bournemouth, for whom Carl Fletcher scored two stunning goals.

Stoke, who conceded eight goals to Liverpool in midweek, suffered again with a 3-1 home defeat to lowly Luton, for whom it was a first away win in 10 attempts. Reading eased to a 3-0 triumph at home to Cambridge.

webTitle: First Division  round-up

fields.headline: First Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Despite seeing his Huddersfield team come from behind to end their desperate run of 19 home games without a win, Lou Macari is expecting to strengthen his bottom-of-the table team this week.
fields.body:
Despite seeing his Huddersfield team come from behind to end their desperate run of 19 home games without a win, Lou Macari is expecting to strengthen his bottom-of-the table team this week.

Huddersfield had not won at the McAlpine since Crewe last visited in March. Dario Gradi's team were again on the receiving end on Saturday, despite taking a first-half lead through Colin Cramb.

Simon Baldry, Martin Smith and Kevin Gallen got Town's goals, all of them in the second half. "We are going to need at least three or four [new players] to get out of the trouble we are in," Macari said, "and I will be disappointed if we don't have two or three in by the end of the week."

Five points ahead of Huddersfield but still in the relegation zone are QPR and Stockport. Several hundred fans at Edgeley Park demonstrated against the chairman Brendan Elwood after the 2-0 defeat by Sheffield United in which County had Andy Dibble sent off late on.

Elwood, who has proposed a move to Maine Road in three years' time, later hinted he may quit after 11 years in the chair. "The club need to go forward and I don't want to stay around for all the ructions that happened after the game."

QPR made it 12 games without a win with a 5-2 hiding at Sheffield Wednesday, for whom Gerald Sibon hit a hat-trick. "He has had his critics in the past and I have been one of them," said the manager Paul Jewell. "But he has produced and you have to pat him on the back for that."

Michael Jeffrey and Kevin Donovan earned Grimsby a point in the last five minutes of their visit from Crystal Palace, who had Neil Ruddock reported for misconduct for comments he made to the referee after the whistle.

Norwich went down to their fifth successive defeat - 2-0 at Portsmouth. Bryan Hamilton accused his players of "lacking character and attitude".

webTitle: Lennon to join O'Neill revolution

fields.headline: Lennon to join O'Neill revolution
fields.trailText: Neil Lennon expects his £5.5m move to Celtic to go through today after his transfer request was accepted by the Leicester manager Peter Taylor.
fields.body:
Neil Lennon expects his £5.5m move to Celtic to go through today after his transfer request was accepted by the Leicester manager Peter Taylor.

The deal ends Martin O'Neill's protracted attempts to sign the midfielder, whom he took to Leicester from Crewe for £750,000 in 1996. O'Neill first tried to take Lennon to Scotland in the summer and was invited by Taylor to make another offer last month.

"It's been playing on my mind a bit," said Lennon, who will take a wage cut to join Celtic and said that in addition he had agreed to waive signing-on fees he was due from Leicester. "It's been the hardest decision of my life but I'm leaving the club in really good shape.

"Peter Taylor has been absolutely brilliant about it. He's a great coach and I think he can take Leicester to another level. I love it here and it will be a wrench.

"You have to be Irish to understand the pull of Celtic. They are a massive, massive club. I'm 29 and I think the time is right for a new challenge."

Lennon's future team-mates extended their Bank of Scotland Premier League lead to 10 points before yesterday's games with a 3-1 win over Dunfermline on Saturday.

Celtic continue to try to level the playing field, however, as they once more conceded an early goal. But they responded to Jason Dair's first-minute strike with goals from Lubo Moravcik, Henrik Larsson and Tommy Johnson.

webTitle: Eriksson sends Lazio warning to Leeds

fields.headline: Eriksson sends Lazio warning to Leeds
fields.trailText:
Lazio record their first victory in a month as Sven-Goran Eriksson sent out a warming to Leeds ahead of their Group D Champions League match tomorrow.

while Bayern Munich will be without Carsten Jancker and Bixente Lizarazu for their Group C visit to Arsenal.
fields.body:
England's coach-elect Sven-Goran Eriksson warned Leeds to expect a rough ride from his Lazio side in Rome tomorrow after the pressure eased on the Swede with a 2-0 Serie A home win over Reggina.

"Leeds are a good team with great physical strength but we'll put in a very good display against them,' said Eriksson. "The game could be decisive to our hopes of progressing in the Champions League but the essential thing is that the team is regaining its best form."

Each of the South American front pair, Marcelo Salas and Hernan Crespo, scored as Eriksson's side recorded their first league victory in a month.

Eriksson is confident his captain and central defender Alessandro Nesta will play despite a back problem.

Bayern Munich will be without the striker Carsten Jancker and the French wing-back Bixente Lizarazu against Arsenal at Highbury tomorrow.

Jancker suffered back pain and was substituted after scoring in the 2-0 Bundesliga win over Bayer Leverkusen. Lizarazu tore a calf muscle while training for Saturday's match and will be out for around two weeks.

The Brazilian striker Elber also scored against Leverkusen as Ottmar Hitzfeld's team won after picking up only one point from their previous three league games.

"The pressure was extreme but the players did not crack and that is a good sign for me," said Hitzfeld. "They did what they had to do and hopefully they can do it again at Arsenal."

Paris St-Germain's former player and coach Luis Fernandez has returned to the club after Philippe Bergeroo was sacked following the 5-1 French League defeat at Sedan on Saturday. Fernandez starts his second stint today before Wednesday's Champions League match with Galatasaray.

webTitle: Bolton 2 - 1 Watford

fields.headline: Page follies leave Watford in tailspin
fields.trailText:
Bolton 2 - 1 Watford
Watford in a tailspin after fourth defeat in a row.
fields.byline: Richard Rae  at the Reebok stadium
fields.body:
A fourth defeat in a row for Watford left Graham Taylor lost for words - eventually. In the middle of a long and disbelieving exposition on how on earth his team had been unable to come to terms with Bolton's basic offside trap - 17 times the linesmen flagged - the manager stopped himself in mid-sentence. "Oh, what am I saying? We were crap."

It was not the most elegant choice of words but entirely appropriate to his team and the game as a whole, though Bolton will not think so. They go fifth, level on points with Watford as the First Division congests under Fulham.

There were moments of quality in the match but one could count them on one hand. All three goals were the result of errors that would have shamed a park team.

The first and arguably the worst, in that it was born of insouciance rather than inability, was made by Paul Warhurst. Barely four minutes had passed when, picking up the ball in his own half with no one within 10 yards, he looked up in search of a forward outlet.

Seeing none and with Tommy Smith closing him down, Warhurst half-turned and lazily flicked the ball back towards his goalkeeper Jussi Jaaskelainen. It travelled barely half the required distance, giving Smith all the time he needed to dribble round the keeper before finishing from a narrow angle.

It summed up an appalling first half of mistimed tackles, flying elbows, shirt-tugging, a poor surface, the sort of referee who insists on moving free-kicks back a yard but misses everything of consequence - in fact a lack of quality in every respect. "It took us the rest of the half to get over the early mistake," said the Bolton manager Sam Allardyce, barely exaggerating.

Up front they were awful, with their top scorer Michael Ricketts clearly out of sorts and Bo Hansen isolated and ignored down the right. Ricketts, who, Allardyce later admitted, had reported in with a migraine and temperature, was replaced at half-time by the old warrior Ian Marshall.

"I didn't want to start with him because he was our cover at the back as well," was the manager's less than convincing explanation.

A change of formation also helped. Hansen moved into the middle with Marshall alongside him and Gareth Farrelly and the skilful and industrious Ricardo Gardner in support. While they were never subtle, Bolton at least had a focus. Even then Watford were absorbing their thrusts until the captain Robert Page took a leaf out of Warhurst's book.

Trying to shepherd the ball over the byline for a goal-kick when he should have hoofed it into row H, Page robbed by Farrelly. Baardsen saved bravely but the ball fell to Gardner, who stroked it home.

The fight immediately went out of Watford. Bolton sensed it and both Hansen and Gardner had come close when Page, under no pressure at all and the ball at his feet in midfield, fell on his backside.

Hansen seized on the ball, drove into the area and, though Baardsen again saved, the ball slid into the path of Marshall. "I don't miss from two yards out," said the old pro. "As long as no one's on the line."

webTitle: Hearts 0 - 1 Rangers

fields.headline: Nine-man Rangers ruin Levein baptism
fields.trailText:
Hearts 0 - 1 Rangers
Nine-man Rangers ruin Levein baptism
fields.body:
This rabble-rousing affair nearly set fire to the skies above Edinburgh yesterday. Rangers endured a torrid closing 20 minutes with only nine men after Claudio Reyna and Arthur Numan were sent off in a demented five-minute spell in the second half. If this is the stuff of Rangers' defence of their title, tin hats should be issued.

Dick Advocaat, Rangers' robust Dutch manager, was prancing with agitation around his dug-out while all this was breaking out. He surely had a point in disliking the performance of the referee Stuart Dougal, who seemed a little card-happy in doling out nine bookings and two reds.

Rangers are now 13 points behind Celtic and still have two games in hand on the leaders. For this improved position, they also had to thank their goalkeeper Stefan Klos, who saved startlingly from Andy Kirk's header near the end.

A seething Advocaat spoke little later for fear of a Scottish FA fine. "I wish I could say something about the referee but I can't. You can do so in every democracy in the world except this one," he declared. Reyna and Numan were both dismissed for fouls that hardly seemed severe.

This was the toughest baptism for Hearts' likeable but alarmingly inexperienced new manager. Craig Levein, at 36 with fresh memories of 14 years as a skilful Tynecastle defender, had been learning his craft in the Scottish game's equivalent of Siberian exile, at Cowdenbeath for three years.

Levein took to the field for a bow before kick-off - the nicest moment before a long slog. So much of Hearts' hopes down the years have rested on the shoulders of near clapped-out Old Firm cast-offs, and the current scene is no different.

Except, perhaps, that Gordon Durie, a Rangers player for six years and now leading Hearts' line, still has a bit of puff left. Durie twice came close for the home team in the first half but each time was foiled by Klos. Hearts at this point were playing with passion but were already a goal behind.

They felt aggrieved at what they saw as a soft penalty for Rangers, but again they were made to pay for the lumbering style of their centre-back Gordan Petric. When Lorenzo Amoruso's raking pass found Barry Ferguson sprinting into the penalty area after 12 minutes, it was a sure thing that the big Serb would catch his heels. Ferguson tumbled and Jörg Albertz belted the penalty low to Antti Niemi's left.

webTitle: Rotherham 3 - 2 Millwall

fields.headline: Millwall crowded out at the top
fields.trailText:
Rotherham 3 - 2 Millwall
Millwall crowded out at the top.
fields.body:
The advertisements in The Lion Roars fanzine cover most contingencies for Millwall fans, from a company offering designer menswear to a financial adviser and a 24-hour law firm; and from a vintner offering discounted cases of a French white, complete with club crest, to an establishment offering "all your hydroponic growing needs under one roof".

Quite which one they might ring following a defeat which knocked their team off the top of the table after a single week in residence is anybody's guess but the 1,600 plus who helped make up Rotherham's biggest crowd of the season were entitled to feel mightily disappointed as they made their way south on Saturday evening.

"After we went 2-1 ahead the physio said there were 25 minutes to go and and I realised it was far from over," said Mark McGhee, Millwall's manager, who was particularly disappointed at the winning goal as his captain Stuart Nethercott was bundled to the ground in the build-up. "They are a big, strong, powerful team and you can see why they have had the success they are having."

That said, Millwall contained the hosts throughout a dull first-half and, though Rotherham's David Artell rose at the far post to glance in a free-kick soon after the interval, the visitors were quickly back in the game thanks to Steven Reid, who fired in two splendid goals - the first from 30 yards and the second from 25.

But, with the Rotherham manager Ronnie Moore imploring the hushed home fans to get behind his team, Millwall's problem at defending set-plays came back to cost them.

Alan Lee first steered the ball over the line after Artell headed on a long throw and, though Mark Ifill had a chance to win it for Millwall and shot instead at the keeper, Lee then decided it the other way from close range after Mark Robins's effort was blocked.

"The system they play, 3-4-3, gives you problems," admitted McGhee, who after a self-imposed moratorium in the market admits he is looking to bring in a couple of players. "Teams with a back four may end up getting their full-backs tied down and teams with a three [at the back] have to change because you can't play three against a three."

It must have been music to the ears of Moore, who led Rotherham to promotion last season and as a result of these three points saw his team, who have scored in every one of their league games, move above Millwall and into second place.

"When the season started we would have settled for coming fifth bottom," Moore said. "If we finish fifth bottom now we've had a nightmare."

webTitle: Wimbledon 0 - 1 WBA

fields.headline: Megson finds potion for Baggies' ills
fields.trailText:
Wimbledon 0 - 1 WBA
Megson finds potion for Baggies' ills
fields.body:
Gary Megson arrived at West Brom in March faced with a club in the throes of a relegation battle, supporters yearning for a return to the glory days and a squad of players whom he described as the laziest he had ever seen. Having suffered the pain of being sacked three times in three years, the challenge might not have been what his doctor would have ordered.

Yet the major surgery instigated by the manager seems to be working. Victory over Wimbledon on Saturday was West Brom's fourth successive league win, their best sequence of results for two years, and kept up their unlikely promotion challenge.

Last season the club only stayed up courtesy of a final-day win at Charlton. They are now aspiring to return to the top flight for the first time since 1986 and Megson, who parted company with Norwich, Stoke and Stockport before moving to the Hawthorns, is finally reaping the rewards for his perseverence.

"It's a big club who I knew shouldn't be vying with Walsall with a few games to go to stay in the First Division," Megson said. "By the skin of our teeth we managed to stay up, which gave us a chance to change the things that were wrong. We took a chance, a lot of players moved on, we've brought in better players, we've got a bit of organisation about us and they work their socks off."

None more so than the strikers Lee Hughes and Jason Roberts. Hughes's header, which deflected off Wimbledon's Mark Williams, earned West Brom the win and the pair's effort rubbed off on their team-mates.

Ruel Fox has flourished since joining up with his former Norwich team-mate Megson and credits the manager for the team's success. "When he joined, Gary felt he had a good bunch of young players who could either get better or go lower," he said.

"Because of their attitude they had got into a mould where they felt it was just a matter of turning up to games and if we win we win and if we lose we lose.

"The manager came in and said: 'Go out there with confidence and give 100% and afterwards, win or lose, at least the fans know you're trying hard and you're not kidding anybody.' That's what the players have done."

On Saturday, a fractious first half threatened to get out of control after Darren Holloway appeared to elbow Roberts in the face. It was as clean a connection as any Wimbledon player managed, with Marcus Gayle the most culpable when he missed a clear header after 56 minutes.

The Dons' play-off hopes remain on hold. West Brom's are growing all the time.

webTitle: Chesterfield 4 - 1 Leyton Orient

fields.headline: Kings of Orient overtaken by rejuvenated Spireites
fields.trailText:
Chesterfield 4 - 1 Leyton Orient
Kings of Orient overtaken by rejuvenated Spireites.
fields.body:
If Chesterfield were an ocean-going liner, they would go looking for icebergs. If they were not holed below the waterline, they would be lost. They prefer the world with a 40-degree list.

Saltergate is due to be scuppered and there are no rescuers in sight, but this lot can probably swim the Atlantic. This time last year they were deep into a 19-game winless streak that left them bottom of the Second Division. Now they are top of the Third after going unbeaten for 15 games.

Dai D'Auria should have been off the movie by now. Two months ago the stocky Welshman was told that he might never play again. On Saturday he was running around like a bit-part player in the Greatest Story Ever Told, and his tackle set up the equaliser.

The indomitable Spireites have fallen behind in nine of their 20 league games this season and lost only one. This time it took them less than a minute to equalise, and within 21 minutes they were 4-1 up.

"If we're on our game," said Luke Beckett, who scored his ninth goal of the season, "we're head and shoulders above anyone in this league."

Orient can play a bit too - their goal was set up by a 40-yard crossfield ball from Scott Houghton - but they were swept aside by confident passing and lively movement, devastating counter-attacking and even more devastating finishing. They never even won a corner.

Nicky Law's strategy of exposing the Orient wide midfielders' lack of defensive awareness worked a treat. Ian Breckin, known locally as Breckinbauer, was largely untroubled. Beckett made the Orient defence look leaden. D'Auria was effective, but Marcus Ebdon and Sean Parrish, the other Taffs in midfield, were outstanding.

Off the field, though, Chesterfield have been less efficient. They were supposedly within 24 hours of clinching the move to a new ground last month, after five years of feasibility studies and traffic reports, when the site was snatched from under their noses by two opportunistic builders.

First blood to the opposition? That's usually how Chesterfield like it.

webTitle: Liverpool 3 - 0 Charlton

fields.headline: Jury split over pushy Heskey
fields.trailText:
Liverpool 3 - 0 Charlton
Push came to shove ... and Liverpool won.
fields.body:
When Gérard Houllier invested £11m on the raw-boned Emile Heskey eight months ago those supporters who backed his judgment could have convened to discuss the transfer in a telephone box and still had room for a tray of sandwiches.

Thirty-one senior games and 15 goals later, Heskey has come to represent the sort of bargain one expects to unearth in a Tunisian bazaar, the sporting equivalent of a neatly woven hearth rug which is every bit as practical as it is aesthetically appealing.

But love, of course, is blind and on Saturday evening Liverpool's manager seemed willing, indeed anxious, to stand toe to toe with the world when he was required to sweep to Heskey's defence.

Twelve minutes into a soulless game of dubious quality, Heskey shoved his afternoon-long attendant Richard Rufus in the chest. Having raised his hands to an opponent, the striker was extremely fortunate to escape any form of punishment.

Strange, then, that less than two minutes later he repeated the offence, this time pushing Rufus to the ground after emerging from a challenge with the defender. It was extremely foolish of him.

The referee Rob Styles was moved to take action but the card he issued was yellow; it was not, in his view, a hanging offence.

Charlton's manager Alan Curbishley is hardly one to stoke up a controversy but he was peeved at Styles's leniency. "Heskey should have gone off," he said. "He should have been booked for the first offence and then sent off for the second one. What rubs salt into the wound is that it was him who scored the second goal, the one that killed the game off for us. That really hurts.

"If one of my players had twice pushed someone to the ground he'd have been sent off. If the law says you should go for raising your hands then it must be applied."

Houllier rather likes Curbishley, as a man and as a manager, but here was one disagreement which was not going to be bridged.

"I am surprised that a man who is going to be involved with his country's national team should have a go at a player who wasn't being protected," said the Liverpool manager. "I think his comments are distressing, out of order and over the top."

Interesting, knockabout stuff even if between them Houllier and Curbishley did transform a molehill into a mountain. Still, at least the afternoon had belatedly been given a competitive edge. "What we must do is forget that it was an average game and just remember it was a good win," said Houllier.

Despite scoring inside five minutes, Mark Fish turning a Christian Ziege cross into his own goal, Liverpool were ill at ease all the way up to Heskey's fine header from the substitute Vladimir Smicer's cross which signalled the end of Charlton's limited resistance.

Markus Babbel added a third with a close-range header in the final minute but by that point Curbishley was preparing his condemnation of Heskey.

webTitle: Ipswich 0 - 1 Derby

fields.headline: Ipswich haunted by ghost of midseason past
fields.trailText:
Ipswich 0 - 1 Derby
Ipswich haunted by ghost of midseason past.
fields.body:
As ghosts go, the spectre that haunts Portman Road is rather callow, only seven years old. But it has still given everyone the jitters. "Remember '93?" they say with a ghastly smile and a little shudder.

Ipswich were champions of the old Second Division in 1991-92. By January 1993 John Lyall's side were the fourth best side in the country.

They had beaten Manchester United, and on Match of the Day Trevor Brooking described them as genuine title contenders. But after that they dropped faster than Isaac Newton's Granny Smith and in the end only just avoided relegation.

That might explain why, on Saturday, they looked down when they should have looked up. Vertigo took over and they slumped, dizzily, from third to fifth in the table.

Despite the astonishing success of this essentially small club, winning the league championship under Sir Alf Ramsey and various cups under Bobby Robson, the memories of 1993 are more sharply etched on the memory. And they are approaching the halfway point in the season, the stage when everything went wrong before.

On Saturday they might have climbed to second in the Premiership. But their manager George Burley refuses to indulge the raised expectations of the club's supporters. He continues to insist that to finish fourth from bottom - 42 points will be enough, he reckons - would represent a successful season.

This result, though disappointing, has not totally dismayed everyone at Portman Road, especially if it helps to bring a few people down to earth.

Despite their lofty position Ipswich have won only three of their eight home games. But they have rarely played as badly as this, and this morning Burley must be reflecting on the curse of the manager of the month award.

Against Derby, their forwards David Johnson and Marcus Stewart failed to gel. They duplicate rather than complement each other; too often they are looking to make the same run into enemy territory.

It was in their build-up play, however, that Ipswich malfunctioned more seriously. It has been their passing and movement which have really caught the eye this season, especially down the left, where Hermann Hreidarsson, Jamie Clapham and Mark Venus have interchanged pleasingly. Not so here.

Derby, though, must take some credit for lifting themselves out of the bottom three with their first away win since January. They also have more clean sheets than your local launderette; this was their fourth in five Premiership matches. The return of Horacio Carbonari and the arrival of Taribo West have been crucial factors here, as has the presence of their new assistant manager Colin Todd.

"They never got in behind us, did they?" remarked the old miser of Brian Clough's successful Derby. "It was backs-to-wall stuff for a lot of the match because Ipswich put us under a lot of pressure. But we restricted them to two or three chances."

Derby scored their goal in the 28th minute. Rory Delap cut in from the left and beat Ipswich's stand-in keeper Keith Branagan with a shot that was deflected by Jermaine Wright.

After that Derby put even more players behind the ball. And Ipswich may yet have to call in the ghostbusters to banish the ghouls of '93.

It has been their passing and movement which have really caught the eye this season, especially down the left, where Hermann Hreidarsson, Jamie Clapham and Mark Venus have interchanged pleasingly. Not so here. Derby, though, must take some credit for lifting themselves out of the bottom three with their first away win since January. They also have more clean sheets than your local launderette; this was their fourth in five Premiership matches. The return of Horacio Carbonari and the arrival of Taribo West have been crucial factors here, as has the presence of their new assistant manager Colin Todd. "They never got in behind us, did they?" remarked the old miser of Brian Clough's successful Derby. "It was backs-to-wall stuff for a lot of the match because Ipswich put us under a lot of pressure. But we restricted them to two or three chances." Derby scored their goal in the 28th minute. Rory Delap cut in from the left and beat Ipswich's stand-in keeper Keith Branagan with a shot that was deflected by Jermaine Wright. After that Derby put even more players behind the ball. And Ipswich may yet have to call in the ghostbusters to banish the ghouls of '93.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Fulham are pass masters

fields.headline: Fulham are pass masters
fields.trailText:
Preston 1 - 1 Fulham
Preston make a point but Fulham are pass masters.
fields.body:
First the bad news. Preston's manager David Moyes has yet to detect a weakness in Fulham's relentless drive towards the Premiership. Now the good news. Armchair football fans are in for a treat when Jean Tigana's brand of Gallic flair goes on show on terrestrial television next season.

Moyes, tipped as a potential successor to Sir Alex Ferguson at Manchester United, is likely to be the only First Division manager to take four points out of the runaway leaders. But he was unable to offer much help to the others.

"I don't think they have a weakness," he declared with commendable candour after a game full of noisy passion that was dominated by the visitors after Michael Jackson's headed opener. "We won with a corner at Craven Cottage and we scored from a corner today but you can't read anything into that.

"We like to pass the ball but we had a job to get it off them. They will do well in the top flight. They keep doing the same thing from the first minute to the last and they don't panic."

Preston's biggest crowd of the season celebrated a point with as much fervour as a victory because Fulham are the Manchester United of this division. If the leaders displayed temporary fallibility over the goal their metronomic passing ensured that Preston saw precious little of the ball for the remaining 85 minutes.

Fulham's self-belief showed no signs of wavering even when the prolific duo of Louis Saha and Luis Boa Morte met their match, as they did here in the resolute defensive pair of Jackson and Sean Gregan.

The Frenchmen Saha and Fabrice Fernandes and the Portuguese Boa Morte got little change out of a rugged contest but they took it on the chin and came back for more.

Fulham's nagging persistence was rewarded when Sean Davis scored only the second league goal of his career - an emphatic 30-yard equaliser on the hour.

webTitle: Aston Villa 1 - 1 Newcastle

fields.headline: Familiar twist has Gregory bearing crosses instead of changing tactics
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 1 - 1 Newcastle
fields.body:
There are said to be only six plots for a novel. In football they would include the relentless walkover, the stirring comeback, the eternal blank. John Gregory is fed up with another - the one where Villa score early, waste their few chances from much possession and get caught late.

After Newcastle repeated Coventry's snatch of the previous week the Villa manager had nothing to say - or nothing new - and sent his coach as post-match spokesman. He might have sent the transcript from Coventry or his physio, more practised with flannel.

Gregory himself, if a Sunday newspaper is to be believed, was in discreet talks with Newcastle, who allegedly want him to work alongside Bobby Robson until Alan Shearer is ready. This may be sooner than they think. Shearer wants to play three more years but, already nursing back and hamstring problems, he missed Saturday with tendinitis and consults a surgeon today to see if his knee can take another steroid injection. Robson called him "a flogged horse".

Asked about money for players, the Newcastle manager produced one of the "£" signs Villa fans waved at their chairman Doug Ellis. Gregory might find all frying pans come alike.

At least Newcastle had spirit after their Worthington capitulation to Birmingham. They needed it after losing that goal and two centre-backs before half-time, leading to their 12th and 13th back-lines in 16 games. "The boys [Andy Griffin, 21, and Steve Caldwell, 20] knew they were on a googly wicket and put bat and pad together," said Robson. Warren Barton swept, a libero by latest yardsticks worth £30m.

Newcastle's goal was more a full toss, flicked on by Gary Speed and lobbed over David James by Nolberto Solano - reward for the Peruvian's deft footwork but also for Robson's half-time adjustments that imposed shape on dislocation and shut down Paul Merson with Robert Lee before he threw on an extra forward.

Gregory had said David Ginola was standing by for his first start in two months. Some would say he had been standing by, on or off field, all season. Free now from niggling injuries to everything from hair to foot, he set up the goal for Dion Dublin, his second in two games, and showed much of his old flair and hunger.

The crosses flowed - from Merson and Steve Stone on the right, Ginola and Alan Wright on the left, the fruits of good midfield understanding - but Dublin, alone to receive them, was regularly outnumbered. In the absence of a decoy it was unerringly senseless.

With Benito Carbone gone, Luc Nilis out for the season and now Julian Joachim injured too, Villa need an alternative idea or closer support of Dublin. Two golden chances fell to Lee Hendrie but, indecisive as a voter with no more liking for Gush than Bore, he purveyed pregnant chads.

For all Villa's position, players and fans are restless at a perceived lack of ambition. They could be more concerned at a lack of management. Gregory called this his "blueprint team". Tactically it was more of a misprint and Robson might have corrected it.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Man Utd 2 - 0 Tottenham

fields.headline: Easy ride no preparation for Europe
fields.trailText:
Man Utd 2 - 0 Tottenham
Easy ride no preparation for Europe
fields.body:
In the Premiership - otherwise known as the League of One - Manchester United are proceeding serenely towards their title destiny, the weekly praise of victims ringing in their ears. Tottenham's George Graham was the latest to pile on the plaudits. For the sake of competition, and possibly for United themselves, everyone must hope Europe is not listening.

The Sturm Graz spy probably went home knowing little more about United than his club did last season, when Sturm surrendered 3-0 in Austria. Sturm's preferred European strategy, at home and away, is to defend en masse and then counter. After this latest report they will realise they have no other choice. The hard part, as Jim Smith a week before and Graham now lamented, is getting the ball.

No one expects Sturm to be an impediment but there are better equipped teams lying in wait on the continent. These clubs will have noticed many more crumbs of comfort: Fabien Barthez's dangerously eccentric goalkeeping; a defence that rarely faces the subtlety of foreign forwards; and a tendency to over-elaborate in and around their opponents' penalty area.

Even if Sir Alex Ferguson bestowed praise on the United collective and individuals - notably the re-emerging Nicky Butt and Wes Brown - he is guarding against the enemy within. "They are all sharing responsibility in terms of guarding against complacency, I don't think there was any trace of that today. Anyway we tend to do better in the second half of the season."

If that was not disturbing enough for English opponents, then the chance, however remote, of United adding Lazio's Pavel Nedved to an already rich mixture of midfield options is a fear for the future. Reports that the Czech will become an £18m signing next summer were yesterday dismissed at Old Trafford.

For now both domestic and European rivals should take some heart from Tottenham who, after being tormented in the first half, confounded the logic of this game and the Premiership's worst away record by making a contest of it until Ole Gunnar Solskjaer terminated the affair six minutes from time.

"Irresistible," said Graham in tribute to United's domination of the first period, in which Ferguson's team demonstrated such discipline and awareness of team-mates' movement that an invisible string appeared to connect all in red. The team ethic, no doubt, had Totten ham's manager purring in admiration. Yet Neil Sullivan had little to do, even if he was picking the ball out of the net after Paul Scholes's curving shot. The opportunity, almost inevitably, was created by Teddy Sheringham's cleverly flighted ball.

For a further 45 minutes it was a fragile advantage and, Arsène Wenger will be pleased to note, Tottenham increasingly sensed it. Far from rolling over, they rolled forward and would have equalised after 79 minutes had Gary Neville not cleared and removed Barthez's embarrassment at being bypassed by Les Ferdinand's run to the far post and cross in front of an empty goal.

What the 33-year-old Ferdinand and an anonymous Chris Armstrong can do, surely more potent partnerships can do better, even if Brown showed why United do not need Sol Campbell, five years the United defender's senior. Spurs' front pair - featuring Willem Korsten for the last half-hour - were increasingly supported by Darren Anderton who, contrary to reputation, grew more vigorous as the game wore on.

Past statistics suggest United will become even stronger, deeply worrying given that Ferguson's team lead by eight points - double their advantage over Arsenal at this stage last season. Wenger has already suggested United enjoy another edge, that many opponents under perform in the face of the Red reputation.

Ferguson's response was caustic: "It's not even worth answering that," but then he did: "Anyone who comes to play Manchester United are in their biggest game of the season."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Chelsea 2 - 1 Man City

fields.headline: Chelsea shed the City slippers
fields.standfirst: David Lacey  sees a quality side going through a tricky transition make heavy weather of winning at home
fields.trailText:
Chelsea 2 - 1 Man City
Ranieri relief as Blues scramble home.
fields.body:
Officially there is no crisis but just in case there was Chelsea made a drama out of it yesterday. What appeared to be a straightforward home win by the better team became an undignified scramble for victory as Manchester City came close to forcing a draw in the closing minutes.

Not that beating City said a great deal about Chelsea's chances of turning their season around. Their ability to win at home has never been in doubt. It is their insipid away form that has dragged them into the bottom half of the table.

Chelsea's next away fixture is at Middlesbrough, where their credibility can hardly afford the sort of defeat they suffered at Bradford in August. Then they travel to Ipswich, West Ham, Arsenal and Leicester City, none of whom is giving away much.

This was Manchester City's sixth successive league defeat and they are now only two points above the bottom three. Though they arguably deserved one for effort yesterday, a draw would have been due as much to Chelsea dropping a gear as City raising their game.

Take away the critical froth that has followed the clear-out of Gianluca Vialli's staff by his successor Claudio Ranieri, and Chelsea are simply a good side suffering an indifferent patch. The quality has not disappeared but Ranieri has yet to achieve the consistency of performance needed to make Europe.

Even now a feeling of old-time music hall lingers on at Chelsea. The chairman and his gavel bang on about the press - "a mendacious, malevolent manifestation of muddled media muck-raking". All right, Ken Bates does not use quite those words but that is roughly the sense of it. The monologue, meantime, is provided by the managing director, Colin Hutchinson, who remains firm in his belief that Ranieri will get it right.

Ranieri has declared that if Chelsea are not champions by the time he has completed his three-year contract he will consider himself a failure, a rash pronouncement considering the title has come once to Stamford Bridge in 95 years.

City came having conceded 13 goals in their four previous visits to London this season, one of those a scoreless game at Tottenham. Much of their performance yesterday supported Joe Royle's claim that they had not been playing badly, just letting the opposition score.

Until recently Royle's side were doing better on their return to the elite than many predicted but newly promoted teams often start to feel the pressure once the clocks have gone back, and for City spring is beginning to look a long way. They are a busy-beaverish side, typified by hard-working footballers such as Danny Tiatto, Jeff Whitley and Shaun Wright-Phillips, yet make the sort of errors that are more likely to be punished at this level than they are in the Nationwide League.

Yesterday was a good example. For much of the first half Alf Inge Haaland and Whitley matched a Chelsea midfield lacking the suspended Dennis Wise but augmented by Ranieri's decision to move Marcel Desailly out of defence into the anchor role he filled at Milan.

Passing the ball neatly City dominated Chelsea territorially without creating a clear-cut opening. But they restricted the opposition to a header from Desailly, after a corner from Gianfranco Zola, that Tiatto nodded off the line.

Zola so clearly held the key to Chelsea's chances of breaking City down that it was surprising Royle's players allowed him so much space. On 27 minutes the Italian followed a run to the byline with a centre from which Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink's header skimmed the crossbar.

Another minute and Chelsea were ahead. Haaland, off balance as he received a throw-in deep in the City half, could only prod the ball forward to Zola, who steered it beyond Nicky Weaver's left hand and inside the far post. After this Ranieri withdrew Desailly to the back three, allowing Celestine Babayaro's forward runs to give Chelsea extra width on the left.

By half-time the contest looked over. In the 45th minute Zola's inspired through-pass released Mario Melchiot for the low centre from which Hasselbaink drove in his 11th league goal of the season.

But Chelsea were increasingly forced on the defensive in the second half and after the City substitute Paul Dickov had scored from the rebound when Ed de Goey blocked a drive from Kevin Horlock, Stamford Bridge lived on its nerves until the final whistle.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Arsenal 1 - 2 Southampton

fields.headline: Arsenal end the famine and prepare space probe
fields.trailText:
Arsenal 1 - 2 Southampton
Vieira ends the Highbury famine.
fields.body:
It is not often that Arsenal get excited about being able to beat Southampton at home. But after suffering three defeats in a row, failing to score in their three previous league games and allowing Manchester United to pull eight points clear, even a victory over Middlesbrough would seem like a breakthrough.

"The players had a psychological shock," said their manager Arsène Wenger. "It was important for them to win to get some relief and feel less frustrated. It takes a bit of pressure off them."

Not that Arsenal's steadying of the wobble should be interpreted as a reason for Manchester United or tomorrow's Champions League opponents Bayern Munich to start quaking in their boots.

Welcome as this victory was for Arsenal, there are still signs that all is not well. Not only is there a problem with their range-finding in front of goal but the understanding and cohesion which have been such a crucial cog in the machine also appear to have gone astray.

Time and again their full-backs were pulled out of position by intelligent running down the wings. And after a neat opening spell Arsenal's passes began to miss their connections with the frequency of a Connex commuter.

Then there was Freddie Ljungberg's habit of drifting inside instead of providing a reliable outlet on the right. On the opposite flank Robert Pires was determined to hold on to the ball longer than the now departed Marc Overmars.

But a win is a win even if the goal was a touch fortunate as Patrick Vieira's header, Arsenal's first headed goal this season, took a deflection off Claus Lundekvam's shoulder.

Arsenal's confidence has at least been improved. And yesterday Bayern Munich's coach Ottmar Hitzfeld claimed that his team will come to Highbury and look to attack.

That may sound ominous given Arsenal's 4-1 defeat at Spartak Moscow. But it will be pleasing for Wenger's players to know that at last there will be some space in which to play. As the manager pointed out: "Everyone comes here and defends deep, knowing we're not good in the air and we play it on the ground. So they keep it tight on a small pitch and it becomes difficult to score."

Southampton were no exception, playing with one striker and five strung across midfield in an attempt to stifle what Glenn Hoddle calls Arsenal's "eye-of-the-needle stuff".

It is a tribute to Hoddle's management that Southampton, even without the injured Dean Richards and Marian Pahars, are looking an increasingly solid team. And plans are afoot to spice up their squad by agreeing a deal with Santiago's Club Deportivo Universidad Catolica which will allow Saints to take a look at the Chilean club's youth players.

Southampton might have won here, nevertheless. Lee Dixon cleared off the line from the impressive Jo Tessem, Vieira did likewise after a wayward punch by Alex Manninger and Kevin Davies hit a post.

But Arsenal always looked the more likely victors, even if their finishing displayed all the hallmarks of a team who had scored only one in their previous five games. Pires, Dennis Bergkamp and Thierry Henry all hit posts and the struggling Sylvain Wiltord missed a sitter when one-on-one with Paul Jones.

But in the end Arsenal avoided the embarrassment of another 0-0 home draw against a lowly side, and Wenger will pray that the victory is a turning point.

Optimism should be tempered, though, and not just by doubts concerning Arsenal's cohesion. Silvinho picked up a calf strain and is very doubtful for tomorrow, and Wenger hopes to learn today whether Vieira faces a further ban for his behaviour in the recent Leeds game after the FA reviews a video of an incident with Olivier Dacourt.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

Then there was Freddie Ljungberg's habit of drifting inside instead of providing a reliable outlet on the right. On the opposite flank Robert Pires was determined to hold on to the ball longer than the now departed Marc Overmars. But a win is a win even if the goal was a touch fortunate as Patrick Vieira's header, Arsenal's first headed goal this season, took a deflection off Claus Lundekvam's shoulder. Arsenal's confidence has at least been improved. And yesterday Bayern Munich's coach Ottmar Hitzfeld claimed that his team will come to Highbury and look to attack. That may sound ominous given Arsenal's 4-1 defeat at Spartak Moscow. But it will be pleasing for Wenger's players to know that at last there will be some space in which to play. As the manager pointed out: "Everyone comes here and defends deep, knowing we're not good in the air and we play it on the ground. So they keep it tight on a small pitch and it becomes difficult to score." Southampton were no exception, playing with one striker and five strung across midfield in an attempt to stifle what Glenn Hoddle calls Arsenal's "eye-of-the-needle stuff". It is a tribute to Hoddle's management that Southampton, even without the injured Dean Richards and Marian Pahars, are looking an increasingly solid team. And plans are afoot to spice up their squad by agreeing a deal with Santiago's Club Deportivo Universidad Catolica which will allow Saints to take a look at the Chilean club's youth players. Southampton might have won here, nevertheless. Lee Dixon cleared off the line from the impressive Jo Tessem, Vieira did likewise after a wayward punch by Alex Manninger and Kevin Davies hit a post. But Arsenal always looked the more likely victors, even if their finishing displayed all the hallmarks of a team who had scored only one in their previous five games. Pires, Dennis Bergkamp and Thierry Henry all hit posts and the struggling Sylvain Wiltord missed a sitter when one-on-one with Paul Jones. But in the end Arsenal avoided the embarrassment of another 0-0 home draw against a lowly side, and Wenger will pray that the victory is a turning point. Optimism should be tempered, though, and not just by doubts concerning Arsenal's cohesion. Silvinho picked up a calf strain and is very doubtful for tomorrow, and Wenger hopes to learn today whether Vieira faces a further ban for his behaviour in the recent Leeds game after the FA reviews a video of an incident with Olivier Dacourt.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Bradford 2 - 1 Coventry

fields.headline: Beagrie rewards Big Jim's desire
fields.trailText:
Bradford 2 - 1 Coventry
Beagrie rewards Big Jim's desire.
fields.body:
Jim Jefferies belongs to the Teddy Roosevelt school of football management, which believes in speaking softly and carrying a big stick.

Away from the action the big Scot is quiet and polite but cross him and it spells big trouble. His ruthlessness is legendary north of the border and he is renowned for gutting and rebuilding sides to his own exacting specifications. Any player not pulling his weight in a Bradford shirt is likely to receive a P45 in the Christmas post in place of the traditional club card.

On Saturday his unyielding intensity and the way he transmitted it to his team was clear to see. The technical area reaches almost to the touchline at Valley Parade and such was Jefferies' unbending desire to win he regularly ventured beyond it and appeared as a 12th man for the Bantams - much to the chagrin of the fourth official who continually had to shepherd him back.

Jefferies' commitment was reciprocated by his players who showed exceptional strength of character to fight back from a goal down. None was more desperate to succeed than the 34-year-old Peter Beagrie, who expected to play and had been left on the bench but whose introduction midway through the second half turned the game for Bradford.

"I was just looking for an opportunity to show what I can do and the manager gave me that chance early enough for me to have a bearing on the game," he said.

In the 83rd minute Beagrie launched an astonishing dribble that saw him beat two players, shoot, get the ball back, lose it, get it back again and fire just inside the post to win the game. His trademark back-flip was stifled by a blanket of claret and amber shirts. "We'll take every ounce of luck that comes our way," he said.

Coventry City, who are in freefall after one point in seven games, had taken the lead in the 64th minute when John Aloisi got in behind the defence and chipped the goalkeeper Matt Clarke.

In a tight game that should have been enough but Bradford fought back. Stan Collymore, whose bulky appearance alone justified Jefferies' hiring of a fitness trainer, had already tested his own fragile confidence when he put a free header wide. But in the 80th minute he rediscovered his predatory sharp ness by appearing from nowhere to divert Windass's shot into the net.

Jefferies admitted he was a fan of Collymore, having tried to sign the misunderstood striker for Hearts at the beginning of the season. "Stan's been fine," he said. "Everything he does is magnified and you can't blame him for that. He's living in a house here, he's got his partner with him and he looks to be settled. Obviously he plans to help us get out of this situation."

Escape from the relegation zone may be sooner than later. "What was pleasing for me is that when you're a bottom-of-the-table side, to come from 1-0 down is a great psychological boost. Instead of settling for an equaliser we had the will to win it," said Jefferies. Four points from two games for Big Jim. Bring on Spurs next weekend.

webTitle: From: Brook Nymark (4 Dec)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Brook Nymark
fields.trailText: Vancouver may be quite rainy now, so my ultimate advice is to have a couple of nights drinking and dancing. Having shaken your booty, you will want to go directly to Whistler. Here you can sample skiing, hiking and shopping, and hang out with three or four thousand other 18-23yr-olds
fields.body:
Hi Milly, congrats on the trip around the world.
You'll have to forgive me as this message may not be the most exciting you receive; it is 9am here (Toronto) and I am half-dead from a busy weekend of "stress-relief." Having been to and lived in Vancouver on a number of occasions, I have to say that that December is not the best time of year to be there. There are, however, a number of fun bars in the downtown core. Ask around at any of the downtown hostels you stay at. If you aren't staying at a hostel (you don't really need a membership) then arrange to do so. This is where you will meet the most interesting people. Stanley Park is quite nice, and the area nearby (English Bay) has some nice walks (you could also rent roller-blades). Take a look at Grouse Mountain (there may not be much snow yet, but the view is nice). Vancouver may be quite rainy now, so my ultimate advice is to have a couple of nights drinking and dancing. I recommend "Celebrities" (the gay bars are the best dance-clubs in Vancouver - everyone is there to dance, although you may have to choose carefully if you're hoping to take a guy home!).

Having shaken your booty, you will want to go directly to Whistler. Here you can sample skiing, hiking, shopping for stunningly expensive, yet equally tacky, tourist things, and hang out with 3 or 4 thousand other 18-23yr-olds who are there to have a good time with the assistance of the delights Whistler has to offer. These delights range from holistic (stunning mountain views, fresh air, classes in thai massage, and hippy-dippy happenings) to the libidinous (vicely pleasures, be they smoke-, drink-, or flesh related, can be found in abundance). I could be wrong in this, but dedicated gear smokers will want to bring supplies from Vancouver as it is a bit cheaper there.

I have to start my workday now, so I'll postpone advice on Asia.

Have a great time.

webTitle: From: Susie Powell (4 Dec)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Susie Powell
fields.trailText: When you're in New Zealand, visit Tiritiri Matangi island; an idyllic reserve just a few minutes from Auckland central. The flightless birds are so sleepy, you could practically catch them for dinner - if they weren't protected, that is. If you arrange in advance, the old sailor who keeps the lighthouse might let you stay.
fields.body:
Sue,
I took almost the same route in 1998-1999. You will have a wonderful time. I note that you are disappointed not to be going to Tahiti. Take heed. I squeezed in a short package trip to Vanuatu in the South Pacific for under £500. New Caledonia is apparently in the same price bracket. If that's out of your budget, you should visit some of the islands off Australia - the Whitsundays spring to mind.

My best memories of New Zealand are of the islands in the Hauraki Gulf. Waitemata Harbour is a short and scary $1.20 bus ride or a helter skelter walk down Queen Street in hilly Auckland. State-of-the-art ferries like Jet Raider whisk visitors and lifestylers to the islands. If you take the slower mail boat, which costs $30, you can help the post man deliver mail to some accessible and inaccessible islands.

Waiheke is an island suburb populated by artists, writers and wine makers. You can catch the Jazz Festival in March/April. The visitor centre is on 09 372 9999. I recommend Hekerua Lodge where the hosts bake cakes and steaks. Great Barrier Island is paradise; at the end of a long tramp through the forest, hot springs burble up into the streams for an impromptu soak and sauna. The Stray Possum Lodge (09 429 0109) runs a package including ferry, the rickety Possum Bus, beach trips, walks, BBQ and an option to sea kayak into the sunset.

Rangitoto, the youngest volcanic island at 700 years old, is a strenuous climb but worth the view both down into the crater and back to the city. If you are inclined to put something back into Godzone, as NZers call their country, (you will probably buy more Maori souvenirs than you meant to) tree planting on Motutapu island is organised by the Department of Conservation. Spades and BBQ are thrown in for all volunteers. In one back-breaking day, I planted 400 saplings which eased my conscience when I took home carved wooden souvenirs. The Conservation Department is on 09 372 5560.

Tiritiri Matangi island is an idyllic reserve, again just a few minutes from Auckland central. The flightless birds are so sleepy, you could practically catch them for dinner - if they weren't protected, that is. If you arrange in advance (like now), the old sailor who keeps the lighthouse might let you stay. Email tiritirimangifb@doc.govt.nz. There's a big waiting list.

Rakino island is very friendly, with unspoilt everything. I visited on the day of the AGM and ended up taking part in a debate on conservation on the Wharf. Take plenty of food and water as the relaxed shopkeeper is often asleep. Out of Auckland, White Island is a popular active volcano but boats don't always go to schedule for obvious reasons. Before you head down there, it costs about $200 by boat/helicopter.

I spent last new year at Pitt Island, which is accessible by ship with award winning Heritage Expeditions (check out their website) and was one of the first people in the world to see in 2000. I also visited Bounty Islands, The Antipodes, The Chathams, Stewart Island and The Snares.

If you don't find the time to go to any of these islands, Auckland hosts an event called PASIFIKA the first weekend in March. It is a family-oriented free music and culture festival where you can learn the Haka, make flower leis, tropical shell necklaces and dance with Taihitians, with genuine Samoan food to sustain you and legal herbal substances like tea to get you in the mood. The children's singing competition is wonderful and I anticipate you could take back some fantastic ideas for your local education department. In 1998 a record 100,000 people flocked to Western Springs Park - all enjoying the best of the Pacific for the price of a bus fare.

Don't fret over Taihiti a moment longer - there are beautiful islands off New Zealand for under a tenner.

PS You can learn how to make a grass skirt at Whaka Rewarewa thermal and cultural reserve in Rotorua. Have fun - let me know!

fields.body:
I'm so excited for you. I work in education (at Lancaster University) and am close behind you at 46... I've done some travelling - I went to Peru for 2 months when I was 30, and have been back - once with my 3 year old daughter! Have a wonderful time, get out of the internet cafe and into the world!!!! My niece is in India at the moment, on a gap year, having a ball. Great to hear people our age can too!

Love, Fiona from Lancaster (a melodeon player as well as a Basic Skills in the Workplace specialist)

I'm nearly 51, I've only been abroad once, and you're my heroine.

fields.trailText: You absolutely have to check out The Peculier Pub on Bleeker Street in the West Village when you're in New York - more beers than you can shake a stick at, including more than a few from Blighty.
fields.body:
Hey there Sam -
Glad to hear you're joining the exodus of ex-pats over here to the Big Apple!! You absolutely have to check out The Peculier Pub on Bleeker Street in the West Village when you're here - more beers than you can shake a stick at, including more than a few from Blighty. Also, it's right next door to Terra Blues, so if you're into blues grab yourself a skinful at the Peculier, and head next door. And if you're into seafood head to the upper east side to Mo's Carribean (Second Avenue on the corner of 76th Street) - frozen margaritas and popcorn shrimp to die for!!
Have a great holiday!!

webTitle: US supreme court blow for Gore

fields.headline: US supreme court blow for Gore
fields.standfirst:
 Florida high court's deadline extension 'set aside'
 Gore's recount vote gains in jeopardy
 Gore's Tallahasse legal bid to force recounts 'on hold'

Special report: US election
fields.trailText: The US supreme court today set aside the Florida supreme court decision that had let  hand-counted ballots narrow George W Bush's lead over Al Gore in the state that will decide   who wins the White House.
fields.body:
The US supreme court today set aside the Florida supreme court decision that had let hand-counted ballots narrow George W Bush's lead over Al Gore in the state that will decide who wins the White House.

In an unsigned decision, the justices said there was uncertainty about the Florida court's grounds for issuing its ruling that allowed hand-recounted votes to be added to the total.

The justices said: "This is sufficient reason for us to decline at this time to review the federal questions asserted to be present.

"After reviewing the opinion of the Florida supreme court, we find that there is considerable uncertainty as to the precise grounds for the decision."

The action was not a ruling for Mr Bush on the merits of his appeal but by setting aside the Florida supreme court's ruling, it could place in doubt the gains Mr Gore made through the hand recount in the days after November 14.

The decision may appear on the surface to be a major setback for Mr Gore but there is a prospect the Florida supreme court may still stand by their decision to allow hand-counted ballots.

Mr Gore also has other legal avenues which he is pursuing, although the consensus among commentators is that the longer the contest drags on, the more acute the pressure on him to bow out becomes.

The vice president is hoping today for a victory in the Florida courts where a ruling is pending on whether to overturn Mr Bush's certified win in Florida and order manual recount of thousands of ballots.

Circuit judge N Sanders Sauls promised to rule quickly on Mr Gore's legal bid which was expected around 5.00pm GMT. However, the state case is "on hold," Terre Cass, a circuit court spokeswoman told reporters in Tallahassee, Florida.

On today's supreme court ruling, Fred H Bartlit, a lawyer for Mr Bush, said he had not yet studied it but added: "Apparently what they said as near as we can make out is that they can't figure out what the Florida supreme court based its decision on, whether constitutional grounds or Florida state laws."

The court held a dramatic argument session on Friday after agreeing a week earlier to hear Mr Bush's appeal of the Florida court ruling, which extended the deadline for reporting recount results from November 14 to November 26.

The justices had appeared deeply divided over whether there were grounds to overrule the state court.

Another lawyer for Mr Bush, Theodore Olson, argued that the Florida supreme court's decision to allow the extended recount "overturned the carefully enacted plan" by state legislators for resolving election disputes.

He contended the state court violated the constitution and an 1887 federal law that makes states' choice of presidential electors binding on Congress as long as disputes were resolved under laws enacted before the election. Laurence Tribe, a lawyer for Mr Gore, said the recount process merely was "like looking more closely at the film of a photo finish. It's nothing extraordinary." He added, "Why tell people the count if you won't count it?"

Mr Gore's advisers were telling allies after the argument that the vice president would continue pressing his election contest in Florida courts regardless of what the supreme Court decided.

Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, certified Bush the winner in Florida on Nov. 26 after manual recounts in a few Democratic-leaning counties that Mr Gore had sought. The state supreme court had ordered those recounts to proceed beyond the November 14 date that Harris cited as the deadline fixed in state law.

A key issue before the supreme court was whether the case involved any federal issue that warranted overturning Florida's highest court.

In recent years, the supreme court has carried out what some observers call a states' rights revolution, tilting the federal-state balance toward the states in a series of 5-4 votes with the chief justice, William Rehnquist, leading the majority.

The decision may appear on the surface to be a major setback for Mr Gore but there is a prospect the Florida supreme court may still stand by their decision to allow hand-counted ballots. Mr Gore also has other legal avenues which he is pursuing, although the consensus among commentators is that the longer the contest drags on, the more acute the pressure on him to bow out becomes. The vice president is hoping today for a victory in the Florida courts where a ruling is pending on whether to overturn Mr Bush's certified win in Florida and order manual recount of thousands of ballots. Circuit judge N Sanders Sauls promised to rule quickly on Mr Gore's legal bid which was expected around 5.00pm GMT. However, the state case is "on hold," Terre Cass, a circuit court spokeswoman told reporters in Tallahassee, Florida. On today's supreme court ruling, Fred H Bartlit, a lawyer for Mr Bush, said he had not yet studied it but added: "Apparently what they said as near as we can make out is that they can't figure out what the Florida supreme court based its decision on, whether constitutional grounds or Florida state laws." The court held a dramatic argument session on Friday after agreeing a week earlier to hear Mr Bush's appeal of the Florida court ruling, which extended the deadline for reporting recount results from November 14 to November 26. The justices had appeared deeply divided over whether there were grounds to overrule the state court. Another lawyer for Mr Bush, Theodore Olson, argued that the Florida supreme court's decision to allow the extended recount "overturned the carefully enacted plan" by state legislators for resolving election disputes. He contended the state court violated the constitution and an 1887 federal law that makes states' choice of presidential electors binding on Congress as long as disputes were resolved under laws enacted before the election. Laurence Tribe, a lawyer for Mr Gore, said the recount process merely was "like looking more closely at the film of a photo finish. It's nothing extraordinary." He added, "Why tell people the count if you won't count it?" Mr Gore's advisers were telling allies after the argument that the vice president would continue pressing his election contest in Florida courts regardless of what the supreme Court decided. Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, certified Bush the winner in Florida on Nov. 26 after manual recounts in a few Democratic-leaning counties that Mr Gore had sought. The state supreme court had ordered those recounts to proceed beyond the November 14 date that Harris cited as the deadline fixed in state law. A key issue before the supreme court was whether the case involved any federal issue that warranted overturning Florida's highest court. In recent years, the supreme court has carried out what some observers call a states' rights revolution, tilting the federal-state balance toward the states in a series of 5-4 votes with the chief justice, William Rehnquist, leading the majority. webTitle: Better maternity services equal better public health

fields.headline: Better maternity services equal better public health
fields.standfirst: Julia Drown, who chairs parliament's new maternity services group, explains how improving support to pregnant women and new mothers will have far-reaching effects on the health service
fields.trailText: Julia Drown, who chairs parliament's new maternity services group, explains how improving support to pregnant women and new mothers will have far-reaching effects on the health service
fields.body:
The all party parliamentary group on maternity services, which was launched at the House of Commons last week, has been set up to improve maternity services and to raise the awareness of the role that maternity services can play in improving public health.

We want to see a national service framework for maternity services in place in the next parliament so that good practice is shared across the country and to ensure that care in maternity is evidence based.

At the moment many women don't get all the support they need in childbirth or in pre and post-natal care, whilst others experience unnecessary medical interventions.

We will be particularly keen to question the rising rate of caesareans - currently as high as 22% in some regions when the World Health Organisation says that a rate higher than 15% cannot be justified.

Our breastfeeding rate is one of the lowest in Europe, yet breastfeeding has positive health consequences for women and babies. Women who have breast-fed are at lower risk of pre-menopausal breast cancer, ovarian cancer and osteoporosis.

Breastfed babies are half as likely to develop respiratory illness in their first seven years. Babies breastfed for 13 weeks are 20% less likely to need hospital admission for gastro-enteritis in their first year. Yet women do not get all the support they need to help them breastfeed - a recent survey showed one quarter of women receiving conflicting advice on breastfeeding.

A third area of concern is post-natal support. Studies in America show that proper post-natal support reduces child abuse later. And studies in Britain have shown that better support can reduce post-natal depression.

Currently there are serious shortages of midwives in many parts of the country. There is evidence that money is not used as effectively in this service as it could be.

As a leading midwife put it: "Midwives struggle to perform a set of rituals of unproved value while failing to provide the support women really want or need."

Midwives want to provide a good quality service for women and we want to help them to do so, backed up by medical interventions when necessary and by social support, so that all families can make the very best start.

As chairperson of the group, I have been known for my campaign on breastfeeding. As vice chairpeople, we have Sandra Gidley, Liberal Democrat MP for Romsey, a former National Childbirth teacher, and Baroness Cumberlege, who as a Conservative minister produced the groundbreaking report Changing Childbirth in 1993, which called for the introduction of woman-centred maternity care across the country.

More than 100 MPs and peers have already taken an interest in the group.

The group is supported by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, the Royal College of Midwives, the National Childbirth Trust, the Association for Improvements in Maternity Services, the Maternity Alliance and the NSPCC.

 Julia Drown is Labour MP for Swindon South

fields.body: Hi Milly, it's great to see that my ambitions are shared with so many other people. I totally envy you at the moment but know that next year I'll be packing my rucksack and heading off into the same sunset, although not with quite so much panache. I'm a fellow Devonian and just about to start my treks around the world, although unlike you I'll go where the wind takes me. What I would like, though, is your opinion on your destinations from an 18 year-old's point of view, as I too will be off jetsetting with restricted cash flow, no children, an open mind and just out to have a lot of deserved fun after a slogging for the last two years at what I agree are bloody difficult A Levels that aren't getting any easier!! Thanks for listening, and I would be really grateful for any advice. Once again, it's fab to know my ultimate lifelong dreams are shared with another 'gap year, soon to be a student, fellow Devonian'. Thanks for listening, Milly, and have a wicked time, you lucky sod!
