webTitle: Analysis: Hume quits without fuss

fields.headline: Hume quits without fuss
fields.standfirst:
The SDLP leader may be walking away from Ulster politics, but he will remain active at Westminster and in Europe, writes Derek Brown, Northern Ireland correspondent for the Guardian 1971-77

Full story
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Analysis: The SDLP leader may be walking away from Ulster politics, but he will remain active at Westminster and in Europe, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
John Hume, who has done as much as any man to shape the politics of Northern Ireland, has stepped down from the province's assembly.

He did so in his customary quiet, undramatic way, sending a simple letter to the assembly speaker.

There is no underlying drama. Mr Hume made it known at the end of August that he wished to leave the assembly to spend more time on his roles as MP in Westminster and Europe. He has had health problems for some time, and last year underwent surgery for a ruptured intestine.

There is little question, however, of Mr Hume retiring from the public life he has pursued for more than 30 years.

He was first sucked into the maelstrom of Northern Irish politics in the late 60s, when he was a young French teacher in his beloved home city of Derry. As an ardent nationalist, Mr Hume plunged into the front line of the civil rights campaign. But when that campaign degenerated into violent clashes with the police and then the British army, he continued to press for political reform rather than revolutionary change.

It was, to put it mildly, a turbulent time, and Mr Hume was in the thick of things. He was regularly seen in the heart of the Derry action, striding through the tear gas or dodging rubber bullets; never afraid to confront the security forces, but always urging peaceful protest.

He was a regular at the City Hotel, home and headquarters to the burgeoning press corps. Sometimes he would turn up drenched in the purple dye used by the army to identify rioters, and always he would be loquacious, passionate and eager for debate.

He was also given, late at night when even he had wearied of the incessant talk, to spirited renditions of "Danny Boy" and other favourites in the hotel bar.

In 1970, together with the young Turks of the civil rights movement Austin Currie and Ivan Cooper, and veteran socialist activists Paddy Devlin and Gerry Fitt, he helped found the Social Democratic and Labour party, to bind together the various strands of non-militant nationalism in the six counties.

Mr Fitt was elected the first leader of the party, with Mr Hume as his deputy. There followed the frightening and frustrating tumble of events which brought down the old Unionist provincial government at Stormont, the introduction of direct rule by London, and the first doomed attempt to set up a power-sharing devolved government.

Mr Hume was tireless. His ponderous public style betrayed a quicksilver ability to analyse the issues, and a tireless capacity for dialogue.

The power-sharing experiment collapsed and as the province seemed to slide towards an uncontainable civil war, Mr Hume scoured the wreckage, looking for pieces to rebuild into a coherent strategy.

He played a leading role in the constitutional convention and other attempts to put some wheels back onto the wreckage of local politics. He also patrolled Dublin and London, lobbying and manoeuvering and nudging the British and Irish towards a new cooperative approach.

In the mid-80s that process was well under way, but it seemed incapable of producing any lasting benefits to a province exhausted by 15 years of communal violence. Mr Hume, typically, thought through his analysis and came up with a radical new line.

He decided that Sinn Fein, the political label used by the Provisional IRA, should be engaged in the political process. To that end, he set up a series of cloak-and-dagger meetings with Gerry Adams, a pivotal figure in both the political and paramilitary wings of the republican movement.

When the Hume-Adams dialogue, as it was labelled, became public knowledge in 1993, there was a storm of protest. Much of it, predictably, came from unionists and loyalists scandalised by any dealings with republican "terrorists". But Mr Hume was also savagely attacked by members of his own party, who felt that in lending credibility to Sinn Fein, he was electorally sabotaging his own party.

With typical tenacity, Mr Hume persevered in his confidence-building mission, and the wheels of negotiation began to turn. In the mid-90s came the important breakthrough of the IRA ceasefire; wobbly at first and still flawed, but holding nonetheless to this day.

Anglo-Irish cooperation, together with US mediation, eventually produced the momentous agreement known as the Good Friday deal, allowing for power-sharing, new all-Ireland bodies and verification of paramilitary disarmament. It's shaky still, but it survives, resting on the foundations built very largely by Mr Hume.

In 1998, he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize jointly with the Unionist party leader David Trimble. Long before that, as a Euro-MP and as an inveterate builder of political deals, he had developed a great taste for international politics. From the outset of the Good Friday process, he eschewed any role in the provincial shenanigans of Belfast, preferring the wider stages of Dublin, London, Brussels and beyond.

webTitle: Venables joins Boro, but only as coach

fields.headline: Venables joins Boro, but only as coach
fields.trailText: Terry Venables was today appointed coach of Middlesbrough until the end of the season. Venables will work under Bryan Robson, who remains manager despite his side's 1-0 defeat at West Ham on Saturday which left them second bottom of the Premiership.
fields.body:
Terry Venables was today appointed coach of Middlesbrough until the end of the season. Venables will work under Bryan Robson, who remains manager despite his side's 1-0 defeat at West Ham on Saturday which left them second bottom of the Premiership.

The former England boss thrashed out the compromise with Boro chairman Steve Gibson over the weekend after his commitments in the media initially appeared to have killed off the deal.

Venables admitted: "It's going to be a tough job ahead for everyone at the club. It's a big challenge and it's one we've got to get stuck into.

"I think it is fair to say that we were going on a longer-term arrangement but it became evident that that was going to be difficult.

"I will continue to the end of the season and reassess the situation. Bryan will remain in the same situation at the club and I will be coaching the team."

When a deal was first mooted last week, it was expected that Robson would work as a coach with Venables taking the managerial role, the opposite of what appears to have happened today.

Chairman Steve Gibson insisted that all final decisions with regards to transfers and team selection. He also said however that the next six months would be a time for Robson to "take a step back" and that the former Manchester United captain would resume full duties next season..

"Bryan's had six and a half tremendous years at this football club," he said, "and I think it's very easy to find a scapegoat. It's time for Bryan to catch his breath, take a step back, learn from Terry, and then come back in the summer refreshed."

Robson himself said of the news: "I'm happy in the sense that Terry has come in in the short term at the moment. I feel that it worked very well when I worked with Terry with England and I just feel that if it was good enough for England I want what's best for this football club. And at this moment in time this is the best we could do for Middlesbrough Football Club."

webTitle: Vieira charged with misconduct

fields.headline: Vieira charged with misconduct
fields.trailText: Patrick Vieira has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association following two incidents during Arsenal's Premiership match with Leeds at Elland Road last month.
fields.body:
Patrick Vieira has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association following two incidents during Arsenal's Premiership match with Leeds at Elland Road last month.

The decision was made after the FA's Video Advisory Panel independently viewed the fixture, in which seven Gunners players - but not Vieira - were booked.

The panel quickly came to the conclusion to recommend charging Vieira, who has been sent off six times during his Arsenal career and could now face a three-match ban. Vieira has 14 days to appeal against the charge.

The VAP were called upon after referee Dermot Gallagher admitted he failed to spot the two separate incidents involving Olivier Dacourt and Eirik Bakke.

The FA issued a statement which read: "Following the recommendations of the Video Advisory Panel, the Football Association today charged Arsenal's Patrick Vieira with misconduct.

"Three members of the VAP independently reviewed two incidents from the Premier League fixture between Leeds United and Arsenal at Elland Road on Sunday, 26 November. The referee has confirmed that he saw neither incident during the course of the game."

Meanwhile, Norwegian midfielder Bakke has accused Vieira of being malicious and stupid. "The head-butting was not the only thing Vieira did to me in that game," Bakke told Norwegian newspaper Dagbladet.

"He also elbowed me in the face. I think he totally lost it in that match. That kind of behaviour in a football match is just stupid."

Dacourt, however, has already said that Vieira, did not intend malice with a kick which caught the Leeds midfielder in the throat.

webTitle: Costner hopes Broadway musical will revive career

fields.headline: Costner hopes Broadway musical will revive career
fields.trailText: With his film career in severe decline, Kevin Costner is said to be writing a musical set in Cuba that he hopes to star in on Broadway
fields.body:
In a desperate attempt to boost his flagging career, Kevin Costner is writing a Broadway musical for himself to star in, according to Fox News, which is worrying news for anybody who heard him warbling in his last vanity project, The Postman.

The 45-year-old actor, who hasn't been in a big box office smash since The Bodyguard in 1992, is said to be working on My Cuba in his spare time. The musical tells the story of: "A young Miami doctor who travels to Cuba to bury his grandfather and becomes ensnared in exile, intrigue, romance and a high-stakes showdown between Washington and Havana. A political thriller with topical heat."

Meanwhile, Costner's ego doesn't seem to be diminishing despite his reduced box office appeal. The rumour magazine today reports that the actor refused to play John F Kennedy in the film Thirteen Days because he claimed that he was too well known

"It was clear that I shouldn't play Kennedy," he said. "In my mind I've had too much interface with my public to play such an iconic personThe appetite that exists would be a gigantic criticism, maybe positive or negative but it would've focused on how I played him. And, to me, the vanity of that would've outstripped the importance of the movie and that's why I didn't want to play that role and that's why I didn't want to direct the movie."

The role instead went to Double Jeopardy actor Bruce Greenwood with Costner opting to play the special assistant to the president, Kenny Doyle.

Thirteen Days is scheduled to be released in the UK on 23 March 2001.

Introduction

You've seen the TV and print ads extolling the virtues of Thailand, 'The Land of Smiles', and Bangkok, 'The City of Angels'. But is life as an English teacher as idyllic as these slogans suggest? Well, I've been here for three and a half years so it can't be too bad. Hopefully the following article will equip you with enough basic information to ascertain whether you are ready for Thailand and whether Thailand is ready for you.

Background

Thailand has never been colonised, unlike most Southeast Asian countries. While Thais are justifiably proud of this fact, it does mean that there is not a long history of English teaching and, as a consequence, English teaching methodology has not developed over a long period of time. Indeed, in the majority of Thai schools and colleges, English is taught in the same manner as every other subject - by the rote learning method.

The average student in Malaysia, Singapore and the Philippines all have a much higher standard of English than their peers in Thailand. In an effort to correct this imbalance and make up lost ground on fellow ASEAN countries, the government has recently tried to introduce new leglislation to try to replace the old 'chalk and talk' teaching methods with more student-centred activities. While this idea is commendable, schools and individual teachers have been quick to point out obstacles rather than channelling their thoughts constructively.

As with many good ideas, implementation is often delayed indefinitely and/or the original proposal/law altered beyond all recognition or scrapped entirely. From comments in the local press the Education Reform Bill 2000 appears, unfortunately, to be heading for oblivion.

Jobs

With respect to the availability of jobs in Thailand, teaching in Thailand equates to teaching in Bangkok. I'd estimate that over 90% of the foreign teachers working in Thailand are working in Bangkok. It's best to think of Bangkok and the rest of Thailand as two separate entities when it comes to teaching opportunities, salaries, job prospects, standard of living etc.

If you have a notion of coming to Thailand, heading down to the beaches of Phuket or Samui or up to the hills in the North and getting a job teaching to finance your stay in paradise - forget it. Job vacancies and opportunities are very limited in these areas. It is possible to find work if you have the right connections but, if you're reading this and not already there doing the job, then you don't have the right connections.

If you prefer the quieter life, then both Chiang Mai, in the north and Hat Yai in the south offer some possibilities - however the competition, particularly in Chiang Mai can be fierce, and the pay is often much lower than in Bangkok.

Living in Bangkok

First impressions of Bangkok? A sprawling, polluted, overcrowded city with one foot in the past and another, attempting to stride into the future. However, once you've been here a while you discover that the city does have quite a few redeeming qualities :

 It's much safer than any western city - its very rare to hear of any muggings or see any fights in bars (the ones that do occur usually involve a well known politician's sons - but that's another story).

 The friendly people - Thais are more willing than most to make you feel at home in their country. Their natural, relaxed lifestyle makes life here less hectic and stressful than, say, Japan, Taiwan or Hong Kong.

 The cheap food - 20 to 30 baht (35 - 50 pence) will buy you a simple meal at a roadside food stall - of which there are thousands in Bangkok. Dining out is a way of life here - very few people cook their evening meal, preferring instead to either eat with their friends after work or buy something on the way home.

 The Skytrain - the elevated electric railway opened in December 1999 and, although underused by Thais, is very popular amongst the teaching community. If you're lucky enough to live and teach on or near either of the two lines, your commuting time will be measured in minutes rather than hours.

 The nightlife - one of the big attractions of Bangkok is its varied nightlife. For many teachers this is the deciding factor in the choice whether to come to Bangkok or go elsewhere. There's something for everyone from arty, stylish bars and bistros to the occasionally more dubious delights of the Patpong road and Nana Plaza.

One final comment, from Phillip Williams, Academic Director at the Asia Institute of English, sums up life in the City of Angels: "Bangkok is just about as teacher-friendly as a city can be. It offers a relatively low cost of living, affordable entertainment and, most importantly, teachers are always in great demand."

Thai students

The vast majority of Thai students have been taught by using the rote learning method. Anything the teacher writes on the board is automatically copied into your book. The information passes straight from the eye to the hand, bypassing the brain entirely. Students rarely question the teacher - that's tantamount to having doubts about the teacher's knowledge and, as we all know, what your teacher says is always correct. This results in the average Thai student being able to cope with a multiple choice exam, which requires the memorisation of facts, but having a great deal of difficulty with any exam that requires a written answer, especially one requiring a personal opinion or giving a reason why something happens.

Historically the Thai people are farmers and the economy largely based on agriculture. During labour intensive periods, planting and harvest time, families will pool their resources to help their neighbours. Nowadays, the attitude on lending a helping hand is carried over into schools, colleges and the workplace. Weaker students are given a lot of encouragement (usually in the form of the correct answers) by their classmates. Teachers give students every opportunity to pass an exam, which manifests itself in the form of multiple retakes until the student passes. Co-workers help each other produce reports for their bosses to ensure that even those staff who would be considered a liability stay in a job. Therefore, if you are teaching a class, never expect Thai students to work on their own. Everything must be done in pairs or groups. If you specify that a certain report or piece of homework must be done individually, you could count on at least 70% still being done as a group effort.

This may seem very negative about Thai students. Not so. It's as well to be aware of the differences between British students and Thai students. Knowing about these differences before you start teaching will save you a great deal of head shaking and hand wringing. On the plus side the students respect their teachers, and Thais are talkative, but you won't have any verbal or physical abuse from any students. As I mentioned earlier, your students will enjoy a laugh and a joke. They won't expect you to be serious.

In a Thai classroom

From an academic point of view, teaching ability isn't really valued or regarded as high as it should be. There are many well-qualified TEFL/ESL teachers who have left Thailand in despair, because their abilities aren't recognised by fellow Thai teachers and/or their students. Succeeding in Thailand isn't a matter of having a list of academic qualifications as long as your arm. What is important is that you can understand your students and know what they expect from you. For many career teachers, especially those used to teaching more dedicated students in, say, Japan, this aspect of Thai life can be particularly frustrating.

Anyone who is governed by absolute obedience to rules and regulations, timetables, strict adherence to contracts, the need to be involved in decisions that affect you and the belief that displays of anger will get conflicts resolved will not enjoy their time here.

Get used to 'going with the flow', 'rolling with it' and any number of other phrases that could be used to describe the notion that if something goes to plan then that's an unexpected bonus and not something to be taken for granted. Thai students want to be entertained as well as educated. Therefore the successful teacher has to bear in mind what I like to call the 4 Ss of Thai society. These are :

 Sanook (fun). If it's not 'sanook', then why do it? Listening to a teacher drone on, copying from a board, mindless choral repetition etc aren't considered fun activities. First thing to remember then is to make your lessons fun, include a couple of games and keep things moving along. Don't get bogged down - it's not 'sanook'.

 Suay (beautiful). All the best things in life are 'suay'. Outward appearance is of the utmost importance to Thais, especially personal appearance. Whilst teachers in the USA and Europe may be used to teaching classes in jeans and a t-shirt, that kind of attire is frowned upon here. Get a hair cut, and you'll need to wear a shirt, tie, trousers and polished shoes. Female teachers should stick to knee length skirts and non-revealing blouses. 'Suay' carries over into any homework/reports you'll give your students. Style is always placed above substance. Trying to convince your students otherwise will result in a look of disbelief upon their faces.

 'Suparb' (politeness). This covers everything from the way you dress and speak to having respect for your elders. Everyone knows their place in the social structure and addresses each other accordingly. Elders are addressed as 'Pee', those younger than yourself as 'Nong'. Elders, bosses, teachers and monks are all 'wai'd' (the traditional Thai greeting - hold your hands as though praying and bow your head slightly). This is just the tip of the politeness iceberg.

A couple of things for teachers new to Thailand to remember are - never to perch on the edge of a desk (as I remember my old high school maths teacher doing every lesson) and don't touch your students, especially if you're a male teacher and have female students.

 'Serious'. OK, it's an English word but all Thais know it. This is something you shouldn't be. It's almost as bad as being boring. God help you if you are boring and serious, because no one else will. In a practical sense, try to treat everything with the same lack of importance, for example if someone doesn't do their homework, give them more time, if they copy - no problem so long as they only copy a little bit. You'll find your students are only serious around exam time - and then for only a very brief period.

In a nutshell, dress the part, clean, smart and professional- if you look like a teacher Thais will treat you like a teacher i.e. with respect. Be friendly and polite, stay calm, don't raise your voice, have fun, laugh at yourself and laugh with your students. This isn't a license to spend all class playing games but it does allow you to be creative and not be ruled by the constraints of a rather dull course book.

Is Thailand for me?

You've read some background information. Now ask yourself this question: 'Why do I want to come here to teach?' Here are three possible scenarios:

 You plan on backpacking around the world and you need to earn some cash during your trip. The large language schools are always looking for teachers, qualified or not. This, coupled with Thai students' fun loving and forgiving attitude towards their teachers, means that it's not hard to get work, even if you only plan to stay a few months. You will be on a relatively low hourly rate, but a couple of months work will enable you to save enough to pay for a month chilling out on Koh Pha Ngan.

 You've finished university and it's time to take a year out before starting life as a corporate slave. Ideally you'd like to spend a year experiencing life in a country with a different culture and climate from what you're used to. However, you also have the reality of the student loan officer to face, so you need to make sure that you're overseas experience pays for itself and doesn't drain your overdraft further. Any evidence of a degree, and that you had the presence of mind to take a TEFL qualification, will show employers that you are serious about teaching and will ensure a better rate of pay and more job opportunities than if you'd arrived totally unprepared.

 The experienced teacher. If you're financially minded then you will probably want to avoid Thailand. Sure, there are well paying jobs available at international schools and private universities, but on the whole, the availability of these jobs is pretty limited. Even if you worked as the director of studies of a language school you might find that your 10 years plus of experience only results in a salary a few thousand baht higher than a new teacher with little or no experience. In general, experience isn't well rewarded financially. However, if you're looking for a less stressful atmosphere than say, Japan or Taiwan, then Thailand offers the chance to earn a decent salary in a more easy going atmosphere.

The future

A recent US state department report concluded that the market for English language teaching was far from saturated and would continue to grow. The demand for both qualified and unqualified teachers would therefore remain high for the foreseeable future.

But what about the conditions for teachers in language schools? Back to Phillip Williams, who, having been here for over ten years, has noticed the impact the internet is having on the standard of teaching and the attitude of schools towards their teachers: 'What is very worrying for the poor quality schools is the number of times their name gets dragged through the mud on the internet. Their dirty laundry is hung out for all to see.'

Schools now realise that they are being held accountable for their actions. Mr Williams continues: 'Many schools are waking up to the fact that proper teachers want proper jobs. They want a competitive salary, access to modern teaching materials, a worthwhile training programme and an employer who values their contribution to the education of Thailand's new generation.'

Useful websites

Ajarn.com - all the information a prospective teacher needs about living and teaching in Bangkok. Jobs, language schools, accommodation, red tape, discussion board etc.
Asia Institute of English - a new, forward thinking language school, also offers courses for those wishing to learn Thai.
Ethailand.com - an English language business portal for expats. Extensive information about living and doing business in Thailand

webTitle: Hamilton leaves Norwich

fields.headline: Hamilton leaves Norwich
fields.trailText: Bryan Hamilton has resigned as manager of Norwich City.
fields.body:
Bryan Hamilton has resigned as manager of Norwich City.

Hamilton, the former Northern Ireland boss, took charge at Carrow Road following the resignation of Bruce Rioch in March, but has been unable to turn around the fortunes of the East Anglian side, who slumped to their fifth successive defeat at Portsmouth on Saturday.

Assistant boss Nigel Worthington will take charge of the team for Saturday's match against Gillingham at Carrow Road.

Chairman Bob Cooper said in a statement: "Despite all his hard work, results just haven't gone his way. He needed time to bring about the necessary changes to the playing side, but time hasn't been on his side.

"Throughout the season, the Press and other commentators have increased the pressure in a job that was difficult enough to do."

webTitle: RAE rule turns into bureaucratic nightmare

fields.headline: RAE rule turns into bureaucratic nightmare
fields.trailText: A rule intended to compensate university departments for the loss of researchers in the academic transfer market is turning into a bureaucratic nightmare for officials preparing for the next Research Assessment Exercise.
fields.body:
A rule intended to compensate university departments for the loss of researchers in the academic transfer market is turning into a bureaucratic nightmare for officials preparing for the next Research Assessment Exercise.

The RAE team overseeing the exercise has told university officials that they have to list research assistants leaving during the year before the RAE deadline date, if they were supervised by academics who have also left during this period.

University planning officers say that the ruling will be near impossible to enforce, as there are no easily accessible lists of the academics supervising the hundreds of research assistants in universities.

Under the 'double counting' rule, academics leaving one university for another in the year from 1 April 2000 to 31 March 2001 (called category A* staff) will count in the judgement of research quality for both institutions. They will only be counted however for funding volume purposes (proportional to the size of the department) in the employing institution at the RAE census date, 31 March 2001.

But the implications of this new rule for research students and research assistants are only now becoming completely clear.

"None of this has been in the guidelines," said Charles Christacopoulos, from Dundee university.

In volume terms, research assistants only count for about a tenth of one full time academic in the assessment.

Special report on the RAE

webTitle: Oxford likely to reject prince

fields.headline: Oxford likely to reject prince
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Oxford college which rejected the state school student Laura Spence is looking unfavourably on an application from another aspiring, but considerably richer, teenager.
fields.body:
The Oxford college which rejected the state school student Laura Spence is looking unfavourably on an application from another aspiring, but considerably richer, teenager.

The university has said an application from Prince Azim, 18, the son of the Sultan of Brunei, who is the world's third richest man, for a place to read law at Magdalen college is likely to be rejected because it does not believe that he is sufficiently qualified.

Downing Street fiercely denied a newspaper report yesterday that the government had asked Magdalen to accept the prince.

A Foreign Office spokesman said the royal family of Brunei had sent the prince's application to the department, and officials had forwarded it to Oxford. But the spokesman said: "We didn't seek to influence the outcome of the application in any way.

"The Foreign Office did speak to Oxford university when the application was sent. Oxford explained that the application was not likely to be successful. They looked through the papers and decided he was unlikely to fulfil their entry requirement."

According to the Sunday Express, a former college member working at the Foreign Office had followed up by telephoning to tell the officials at Magdalen that the prime minister, Tony Blair, was "personally concerned" with the outcome of the application because he was anxious about relations with Brunei.

But a Downing Street spokesman said: "The suggestion that the government in any way would seek to influence Magdalen's decision on the application is completely and utterly wrong."

The spokesman could not say whether the prime minister knew of the application by the prince, who is keen to follow in the footsteps of his brother, crown prince Al-Nuhtadee Billah, 24, heir to the Brunei throne, who studied at Oxford.

A final decision on the application has yet to be made. The prince, currently studying in Singapore, is a music fan and has been to see the television show Top of the Pops recorded in Britain.

Magdalen's president, Anthony Smith, led the counter-attack against the chancellor, Gordon Brown, after he accused the college of being elitist in refusing a place to Ms Spence, who applied to read medicine.

Mr Smith, who is known to be furious about the story, referred all calls to the university press office yesterday. "We don't talk about individual applications. All applications are assessed on their individual merits," a spokesman for Oxford said.

The university has said an application from Prince Azim, 18, the son of the Sultan of Brunei, who is the world's third richest man, for a place to read law at Magdalen college is likely to be rejected because it does not believe that he is sufficiently qualified. Downing Street fiercely denied a newspaper report yesterday that the government had asked Magdalen to accept the prince. A Foreign Office spokesman said the royal family of Brunei had sent the prince's application to the department, and officials had forwarded it to Oxford. But the spokesman said: "We didn't seek to influence the outcome of the application in any way. "The Foreign Office did speak to Oxford university when the application was sent. Oxford explained that the application was not likely to be successful. They looked through the papers and decided he was unlikely to fulfil their entry requirement." According to the Sunday Express, a former college member working at the Foreign Office had followed up by telephoning to tell the officials at Magdalen that the prime minister, Tony Blair, was "personally concerned" with the outcome of the application because he was anxious about relations with Brunei. But a Downing Street spokesman said: "The suggestion that the government in any way would seek to influence Magdalen's decision on the application is completely and utterly wrong." The spokesman could not say whether the prime minister knew of the application by the prince, who is keen to follow in the footsteps of his brother, crown prince Al-Nuhtadee Billah, 24, heir to the Brunei throne, who studied at Oxford. A final decision on the application has yet to be made. The prince, currently studying in Singapore, is a music fan and has been to see the television show Top of the Pops recorded in Britain. Magdalen's president, Anthony Smith, led the counter-attack against the chancellor, Gordon Brown, after he accused the college of being elitist in refusing a place to Ms Spence, who applied to read medicine. Mr Smith, who is known to be furious about the story, referred all calls to the university press office yesterday. "We don't talk about individual applications. All applications are assessed on their individual merits," a spokesman for Oxford said.

webTitle: University staff say enoughs enough - the UKs first e-strike?

fields.headline: University staff say enoughs enough - the UKs first e-strike?
fields.trailText: NATFHE, Unison, EIS, MSF, TGWU and GMB recently balloted their 100,000 HE members, and all six recorded majorities of 75% - 80% for action. Higher education staff want to achieve fair pay, fair workloads and a fair deal for students.
fields.byline: Tom Wilson, Higher education officer for Natfhe
fields.body:
NATFHE, Unison, EIS, MSF, TGWU and GMB recently balloted their 100,000 HE members, and all six recorded majorities of 75% - 80% for action. Higher education staff want to achieve fair pay, fair workloads and a fair deal for students.

This is possibly the first UK industrial action to deserve the title of "e-action". Judging by the success of e-techniques it wont be the last. E-mail and use of union web sites has proved invaluable. Latest news, for example on extra government funding for pay, was communicated to almost all Natfhes 18,000 members within 24 hours.

On pay, it is extraordinary that the employers, who offered only 3% (less than FE or teachers who were awarded 3.3%), still refuse to negotiate even though this years HE funding was the first to halt the cuts, and next years level of funding will mean actual growth - with an additional £330M Government funding only last week earmarked specifically for pay. David Blunkett has publicly called for the employers to return to talks and said he supports the principle of national pay and conditions bargaining. Low pay is a scandal. Of course funding remains a problem but something now can and must be done.

On conditions, a majority of HE employers, apparently, have said that they wish to end our right to national bargaining, by excluding national conditions issues from the remit of the new bargaining machinery proposed in the Bett Report, the recommendations of the independent inquiry into HE staffing, chaired by Sir Michael Bett, published in 1999. Excluding conditions is flatly contrary to the Bett recommendations. Details of the Bett report are on Natfhes web site: www.natfhe.org.uk

That matters. Failure could mean lecturers losing the protection of the National Contract, which guarantees certain basic working conditions and employment rights, and could see teaching hours soar to 800 or more per year as they have in FE. A small number of institutions have already said they want to do that. If they are allowed to do so, many others will feel driven to follow. The dispute and our action have the full support of the National Union of Students. HE employers are saying different things. Many say they want to scrap Natfhes national contract because it is a relic of the binary divide - but they dont want to merge pay scales or tackle the absurdly low New University Research Scales. All agree on the need to end discrimination - indeed government funding will depend on demonstrable progress in doing so - but many are reluctant even to measure the race or sex pay gap.

Our action clearly helped secure the recent funding increase - and the pay earmarking. Vice Chancellors have no excuse for not returning to talks. Our action will continue until we negotiate a settlement which is both fair to all staff and preserves quality for students.

For the future, the dispute has shown just how helpful e-tools can be. They will never substitute for taking action but rapid and wide scale communication is exactly what successful action needs.

webTitle: No more money says pay chief

fields.headline: No more money says pay chief
fields.trailText: There is no more money for the pay rise the trade unions are seeking, insists Peter Humphreys, chief executive of the Universities and Colleges Employers Association.
fields.body:
There is no more money for the pay rise the trade unions are seeking, insists Peter Humphreys, chief executive of the Universities and Colleges Employers Association.

Additional funds for pay promised last month by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary -- £330 over three years  would not be available until August 2001 while the year in dispute was 2000/01. For this year the employers have offered a 3% rise with 4% for manual grade workers.

The minimum salary for a newly-appointed lecturer in a new university was raised 20% to £17,912. That was rejected by the unions who held ballots on industrial action. Although there was a vote in favour of action short of a strike Humphreys argues they did not get the decisive vote for a strike they wanted. Members of Unison voted against a strike although nearly 80% of lecturers balloted by Natfhe were in favour. The other teaching union, the Association of University Teachers, did not hold a ballot.

The money announced for the next three years is not to fund a general increase  it is on a something for something basis. The Bett report highlighted the shortcomings of the higher education sector in inequalities for female staff and Humphreys said they hoped to tackle that from August with the funds made available.

Funding per student had almost halved over the past 20 years putting pressure on staff pay. It is not the fault of individual institutions. We have got a complex pay structure with roots going back into the mists of time. Humphreys said he had no plans to meet the unions for more talks. It is not clear what will happen.

webTitle: What about tax incentives for parents paying university fees?

fields.headline: What about tax incentives for parents paying university fees?
fields.trailText: The introduction of tax incentives for parents contributing to university fees should be considered as part of the review of the funding of universities, student leaders of the UK's large research universities have said.
fields.body:
The introduction of tax incentives for parents contributing to university fees should be considered as part of the review of the funding of universities, student leaders of the UK's large research universities have said.

The 20 members of the Aldwych group say that university chiefs failed to include such a scheme as part of their review. They also argue that the newly named Universities UK has failed to canvass the views of students, and exists only as a voice for academic administrators.

University heads are considering various options for increasing fees for students to address a funding shortfall in academic budgets estimated to be £1bn a year by 2004. One proposal is to charge £3000 a year for students in subjects such as medicine, where graduate earnings are extremely high, and £2000 a year for other subjects.

Hamish Common, co-Chair of the Aldwych Group and president of Imperial College Union, said: "It is important to remember that "Individual contributions" [to fees] also include parental contributions, but this is not mentioned in the report. Germany compels parents to pay their contributions, with suitable tax concessions, a policy which could be adopted here."

The Aldwych students say that university heads are not considering any options taken from the student viewpoint. They would like to see more options discussed.

"The report gives examples from "4 families of universities". We'd like to see them based on "4 families of students" as well," said Common. "We see universities as a partnership of university administrations and students: "the voice of UK Universities", as Universities UK and their reports want to be, should include the student view as well, so it isn't just "the voice of UK University Administrations".

The group supports the abolition of up-front tuition fees and re-introduction of targeted maintenance grants. They would also like to see more emphasis in the discussions on widening access and participation and minimising student hardship. "We strongly disagree that the Australian experience should be adopted here as it benefits richer students and has been shown to damage participation," said Common.

The Aldwych Group last week met up with representatives of the Russell group, which represents the heads of the UK's large research universities. Apart from the fees debate the groups discussed the social role of universities. The Aldwych students believe that universities could do more for local communities.

webTitle: Implementation and assessment of the mental health NSF

fields.headline: Implementation and assessment of the mental health NSF
fields.standfirst: In the last of four articles, Sophie Petit-Zeman looks at the implementation of the mental health national service framework
fields.trailText: In the last of four articles, Sophie Petit-Zeman looks at the implementation of the mental health national service framework
fields.body:
How is the NSF being implemented?
Local health and social care agencies in England are responsible for implementation. Local implementation plans (Lips), addressing issues across the seven standards of the NSF, have recently been published by county councils and health authorities. A second set of Lips, reflecting progress and revised priorites, will be issued this month.

Local milestones, identified in the Lips, will help to meet initial national milestones. These range from agreeing protocols for primary care and the specialist management of mental illness by April 2001 to getting rid of mixed-sex wards from 95% of health authorities and providing an extra 300 secure beds by April 2002.

The new duty of partnership, placed on health and local authorities by the Health Act 1999, provides for pooled budgets and integrated provision and commissioning. Targets will only be achieved through better cooperation between all parties, including the independent sector and user-led organisations.

Practical support will come from the national mental health implementation group, led by the Department of Health and supported by a national implementation team. The NHS mental health modernisation funds will provide £5m to help teams implement the NSF at local level. Assistance will also be provided for organisational and professional development across the NHS and social care.

The five national underpinning programmes - finance; workforce planning, education and training; research and development; clinical decision support systems; and information strategy - will all support implementation. They will also help to adapt milestones in response to need and progress - under the lead of the national mental health implementation group - and play a strong part in ensuring that good practice is shared. The developing NHS learning network, the National Institute for Social Work's electronic library and a national database of NHS service delivery and practice will all help here, too.

How will it be assessed?
It is already acknowledged that too many indicators might overburden services, diverting resources from patient care. However, social services, the NHS and their joint initiatives will all be monitored.

Performance assessment frameworks (PAFs) for the NHS and the personal social services will be used to monitor implementation. PAFs are based on principles of best value. Since April, this duty has underpinned all local government services. Each local authority will publish best value plans annually.

The commission for health improvement, the social services inspectorate and the audit commission will also keep tabs on each NSF.

NHS and social services joint working is vital to the success of the NSF. This is most likely to be reflected by general progress, but it will also assessed by "interface indicators" built into performance assessment frameworks for both the NHS and the social services. For the time being, these will specifically monitor emergency psychiatric readmission rates, to get an idea of the efficiency of care planning and alternatives to hospital.

Plans are also afoot to establish "high-level performance indicators" within the PAFs. These relatively quick assessments, in use from April 2001, will look at input, process and outcome - what resources are going in, what they are used for and whether they are having the desired effect.

What is the role of the workforce action team?
The multidisciplinary team began work in December 1999, its interim report was published in September and its final report is due in spring 2001. It is looking at developing the workforce in order to implement the NSF and, to date, many of its recommendations mirror those of the Department of Health's recent consultation document.

The roles of staff working across mental health - and their interaction with one another - are extremely complex. The action team's key message stresses the need to promote flexibility and innovation in workforce planning, education and training.

The action team has also welcomed various sums of money, allocated for specific purposes:
 £1m to support training of community psychiatric nurses and community nurses in mental health
 £2m to support clinical psychology training in 2000-01
 £2.5m for psychiatry training, increasing consultant numbers by 230 by 2007
 £3.9m to boost social work training
 £4m for mental health nurses in 2000-01

webTitle: Changing the face of the health service in Norfolk

fields.headline: Changing the face of the health service in Norfolk
fields.standfirst: A team in Norfolk is adapting the national service framework for mental health to suit the needs of the local population, writes Rachel Newson, health improvement manager for the Norfolk health authority
fields.trailText: A team in Norfolk is adapting the national service framework for mental health to suit the needs of the local population, writes Rachel Newson, health improvement manager for the Norfolk health authority
fields.body:
In Norfolk, like everywhere else, we have to implement the national service framework for mental health (NSF) to meet the needs of the local population. A local implementation team, with a multi-perspective membership, has developed a way of adapting services to match people's requirements.

Rather than trying to represent all service users and staff, we created a team that was small enough to work effectively, but also brought diverse perspectives to the debate.

The team started by bringing together users, carers and interested agencies from across Norfolk to think about what was required from services. People were asked to imagine themselves in real situations - for example, hearing voices in the middle of the night - and to consider what they would want from services in those circumstances.

Most people said they wanted to be able to contact one central place and have someone take responsibility for getting them the right service. We also asked more general questions, such as what helps you to have a good day? People identified basic things, including having enough money, a job and a home they liked.

The team decided to look at the system of services as a whole, with a view to developing services based on actual needs - rather than forcing people to fit in with what was available and making them navigate a complex collection of organisations to find care to suit.

The system, as it stood, was too disjointed to patch up. Agencies were already overworked - co-ordinating with other organisations was therefore impossible. And the funding system, with agencies being forced to bid for funds for new projects, had led, over time, to services being "bolted on". Existing, good quality services would have a place in the new system, but others would have to be reshaped.

A whole new system of care needed to be mapped out. We developed a model of what needed to be done and how it all fitted together, but allowed for flexibility on the actual delivery of services. Flexibility is particularly important in Nofolk, a county that has urban, rural, deprived and affluent areas within it.

Norfolk, with its dispersed population, presents challenges to the NSF standards. For example, having assertive outreach teams is not always practical - in certain areas, there might only be sufficient levels of need to warrant one outreach worker.

One of the key changes will involve replacing generic community health teams with a larger number of highly focused services. There will now be separate teams, or individuals, to provide different aspects of mental health care - such as care co-ordination, support, crisis resolution, assertive outreach and early intervention.

We have already conducted an informal consultation to allow people to comment, and our model is about to go out for formal consultation. Both consultations aim to reach as many people as possible - we are circulating the document through statutory and voluntary organisations. The formal consultation is based on a six-page summary of the strategy, but full-length copies of the document are readily available.

Formal consultation is also being carried out via a widely circulated service-user newsletter. The costs associated with consultation have been minimised by creative use of resources, such as providing a telephone contact point for people to give their views. The costs of consultation, both in terms of time and finance, were shared among organisations.

There is great enthusiasm among local agencies to proceed with implementation of the mental health NSF but there is also some trepidation, as the changes will affect a lot of people.

webTitle: The mental health national service framework explained

fields.headline: The mental health national service framework explained
fields.standfirst: In the first of four articles, Sophie Petit-Zeman gives the background to the mental health national service framework
fields.trailText: Sophie Petit-Zeman gives the background to the mental health national service framework
fields.body:
What is it?
The national service framework for mental health (NSF), launched by the government in September 1999, is the first comprehensive statement describing what's expected of health and social services in England. It sets out how they will be planned, delivered and monitored, until 2009. Similar documents have, or will be, produced in other healthcare specialties. Mental health and coronary heart disease, as significant causes of illness and disability, are the first two.

What does it say?
Seven standards set targets for the mental health care of adults, aged up to 65. These span five areas - health promotion and stigma, primary care and access to specialist services, needs of those with severe and enduring mental illness, carers' needs, and suicide reduction. The standards are relevant to all providers: the NHS, social services and the independent sector.

Improving services for people with severe and enduring mental illness is the first big milestone. Full implementation across the NHS and social services, and throughout other relevant agencies, could take up to 10 years.

The NSF gets a big boost from the new NHS plan. Local milestones for each standard will be reached in timescales agreed with the NHS executive and social care regional offices. Progress will be monitored, milestones will be reviewed and new ones will be set regularly. Five underpinning programmes will support change: these cover finance, workforce, research and development, clinical decision support, and information strategies.

How did the NSF come about and how will it go forward?
The NSF was developed with the advice of an external reference group chaired by Professor Graham Thornicroft of London's Institute of Psychiatry. The group included health and social care professionals, managers, service users and carers. A wide range of evidence was drawn together and graded, using systems such as Bandolier (an evidence-grading system).

The NSF fleshes out policies announced in Modernising Mental Health Services, a government white paper. Some £700m has been allocated over three years to help it meet its early targets.

From this budget, £40m will go via the NHS modernisation fund, mainly to promote services for the severely mentally ill, such as assertive outreach, 24-hour access and secure beds. £106m will go to social care in two sections: £22m will go via the mental health grant to the target fund to improve services in areas of poor provision, to help the homeless mentally ill outside London and to boost social care partnerships. The remaining £84m will support core services.

Change in mental health services is overdue. According to Frank Dobson, secretary of state for health when the NSF was launched, many people who suffer from mental illness "have not been getting the treatment and care they need". Dobson said that: "The government is committed to do whatever is necessary to deliver a modern and dependable health service for the new century. Mental health services, and the professionals who provide them, will get the attention and resources they deserve."

How's it going?
One year on, the NSF has been complemented by, and will now move ahead in parallel with, the NHS plan. The national service framework for mental health (NSF), launched by the government in September 1999, is the first comprehensive statement describing what's expected of health and social services in England. It sets out how they will be planned, delivered and monitored, until 2009. Similar documents have, or will be, produced in other healthcare specialties. Mental health and coronary heart disease, as significant causes of illness and disability, are the first two. What does it say? Seven standards set targets for the mental health care of adults, aged up to 65. These span five areas - health promotion and stigma, primary care and access to specialist services, needs of those with severe and enduring mental illness, carers' needs, and suicide reduction. The standards are relevant to all providers: the NHS, social services and the independent sector. Improving services for people with severe and enduring mental illness is the first big milestone. Full implementation across the NHS and social services, and throughout other relevant agencies, could take up to 10 years. The NSF gets a big boost from the new NHS plan. Local milestones for each standard will be reached in timescales agreed with the NHS executive and social care regional offices. Progress will be monitored, milestones will be reviewed and new ones will be set regularly. webTitle: Blair launches pre-emptive strike against NHS winter critics

fields.headline: Blair launches pre-emptive strike against NHS winter critics
fields.trailText: The government has launched a pre-emptive strike at its NHS critics, outlining details of the health service's plans to cope with winter pressures and reassuring the public that the NHS is not in crisis. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
The government launched a pre-emptive strike at its NHS critics today, outlining details of the health service's plans to cope with winter pressures and reassuring the public that the NHS is not in crisis.

Prime minister Tony Blair admitted that the NHS would face pressures and problems during the winter, and that some patients would not get optimum care. But he emphasised that after decades of under-investment the health service was "going in the right direction".

Mr Blair's comments were supported by health managers' leader Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation. He said: "The entire NHS is under real pressure but it is not in a crisis."

The prime minister made his admission - heavily trailed over the weekend - in a Downing Street press conference called to announce the government's plans to cope with winter pressures on the NHS.

His speech is seen as a way of preparing the public and NHS staff for the almost inevitable problems - bed shortages, patients waiting on trolleys, and cancelled operations - that will affect the NHS over the winter.

Last February, the government and the NHS were caught wrong-footed by a flu epidemic which generated damaging headlines, dented Labour's opinion-poll standing and ultimately led to Mr Blair's announcement of extra millions for the NHS.

Mr Blair said: "During the winter, just as during any other part of the year, a massive organisation, dealing with a million people a day, will face problems.

"Under-investment over decades is not put right in three years. It takes years to train doctors and consultants and indeed nurses. Until we have delivered, therefore, the increases in capacity, year on year, for several more years, there are bound to be pressures, as there are indeed in healthcare systems right around the world in winter."

Mr Blair announced that there were 3.2m more doses of flu vaccine available than last year. The NHS Direct advice line had been expanded to cover 16m more people, and there were 2,900 more intensive home care packages on top of the extra 8,000 from last year. The number of acute hospital beds had risen by 1,350, while critical care beds had gone up by 445, around 100 more than had been planned.

The increases were being matched by improvements in service in many areas, the prime minister said. He thanked NHS staff for their hard work in preparing for the winter pressures. "We are trying to match that effort with increased resources, over £300m on winter pressures alone," he said. "The effort, the money and the reforms are starting to produce results."

Waiting lists fell by 7,000 in October, the eighth successive month to show a fall, Mr Blair said. He conceded that during the winter waiting list numbers were likely to increase, but stressed that "the underlying trend is now firmly downwards". There was "still a long way to go", but the "brilliant" NHS staff were working with the government to give the country the health service it deserved.

"So to sum up, there is more money, more nurses, more beds, there has been far more preparation but there will be pressures and difficulties," Mr Blair said. "But let us get a sense of balance, support the NHS staff who give a wonderful service to the majority of patients, and not fall into the trap of saying that every time something goes wrong the NHS is in crisis or on its knees."

Earlier, health secretary Alan Mr Milburn acknowledged that the NHS faced real pressures during the coming winter. But he insisted that considerable progress had been made and the "glass is half full rather than half empty".

"What the public will see this winter is certainly some problems in some parts of the NHS, that is undoubtedly true," Mr Milburn said. "But I also think that people will see progress overall across the NHS.

"The truth about the NHS today is that it is a service in transition. We have had ... decades of neglect and under-investment, we are beginning to put that right, but yes of course it does take time, that is absolutely the case," he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

Full text of Tony Blair's speech

webTitle: Man arrested over Suzy Lamplugh murder

fields.headline: Man arrested over Suzy Lamplugh murder
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A 46-year-old man was today under arrest in connection with the murder of estate agent Suzy Lamplugh who disappeared 14 years ago.
fields.body:
A 46-year-old man was today under arrest in connection with the murder of estate agent Suzy Lamplugh who disappeared 14 years ago.

John Cannan is being quizzed by detectives at a police station in London on suspicion of kidnapping and murdering the 25-year-old.

Ms Lamplugh vanished after going to show a property to a man called "Mr Kipper" in Fulham, south-west London, in 1986.

Her body has never been recovered despite reports that she may have been buried under an army barracks in Norton, Worcestershire.

Several suspects have been questioned in the last 14 years.

A 1995 book by crime writer Christopher Berry-Dee claimed that Michael Sams, who murdered prostitute Julie Dart and kidnapped property consultant Stephanie Slater, killed Ms Lamplugh, but the theory was discounted by police.

Five months after her daughter's disappearance, Diana Lamplugh founded the Suzy Lamplugh Trust to campaign for better protection for young people against sexual and other violence.

The trust campaigns to educate working women and others on how to avoid becoming crime victims.

Suzy Lamplugh was officially declared dead in 1994.

webTitle: Rural group gives in on fox-hunting

fields.headline: Rural group gives in on fox-hunting
fields.standfirst:
Alliance faces split after deal with Labour

Special report: the hunting debate
Full text: see the leaked memo
fields.trailText: The Countryside Alliance has said that it will accept  the abolition of blood sports and has reached  agreement with the government on a range of other  rural issues after a charm offensive by ministers and  Labour backbenchers, according to confidential  documents seen by the Guardian.
fields.body:
The Countryside Alliance has said that it will accept the abolition of blood sports and has reached agreement with the government on a range of other rural issues after a charm offensive by ministers and Labour backbenchers, according to confidential documents seen by the Guardian.

After more than three years of harrying Labour and organising nationwide protests including the countryside march in London and demonstrations outside party conferences, leaders have privately admitted that they will have to accept the will of parliament if there is a vote to ban fox-hunting.

Confidential minutes obtained by the Guardian of a private dinner held last week with eight Labour backbench MPs reveal that the organisers were prepared to "roll over" to government ministers on the issue in return for millions of pounds of new investment in rural Britain.

They even welched on their strongest supporters - the farmers - by backing the phasing out of billions of pounds of European Union subsidies in return for new investment in farming.

The revelations could cause a split within the alliance as other leading figures are likely to reject these concessions.

Leaders of the alliance at the meeting praised Michael Meacher, the environment minister, for "a full grasp of the crisis" affecting rural Britain.

They also apologised to Labour MPs for using offensive posters attacking the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, during demonstrations outside the last two party conferences.

Richard Sturge, chief executive of the Countryside Alliance, is minuted as saying that after meeting Mr Meacher he realised "Labour and the CA had more in common" than expected.

The minutes also record that Mr Sturge was "surprised and pleased that the prime minister devoted an hour and a half to a meeting with a group of countryside leaders" that morning in connection with the rural white paper.

The meeting was hosted by Helen Brinton, Labour MP for Peterborough, who "had been working for many months to find the common ground between Labour and the Countryside Alliance".

Seven other Labour MPs attended - Diana Organ, MP for the Forest of Dean; Bob Laxton, Derby North; David Kidney, Stafford; Christine Russell, Chester; Jane Griffiths, Reading East; David Lepper, Brighton Pavilion; and Mark Todd, Derbyshire South.

The Countryside Alliance was represented by Mr Burge, Alan Armstrong, its deputy chief executive, Maurice Askew, a board member, and Phil Royal, an adviser. The minutes record Mr Burge as a member of the Labour party and Mr Askew as "a substantial member in South Yorkshire [who] owns his own printing company".

Mr Sturge is quoted as saying that the government's rural white paper was "very, very good indeed...highly ambitious".

He said that the aim of the alliance was "not to bring the government down...rural people area are a minority ...we seek to influence only...minorities required to influence majorities".

Later, Mr Armstrong told the MPs that, on the hunting issue, they would "accept the view of parliament but would like an informed debate".

He added that the Countryside Alliance march on London, scheduled for March 18 next year, would go ahead. "It was unrealistic to pull it," he said.

Mr Sturge had told MPs of his "deep regret" with regard to "the offensive posters about Nick Brown".

He explained that the poster stewards had failed on that occasion, and affirmed that the vetting of posters would be strengthened. He hoped and expected "never to see the like again".

Ms Griffiths was told by Mr Sturge that the alliance's solicitors had forced a British National party fuel protest website to drop its cyber link to the group.

Last night, one of the MPs present at the meeting, Mr Kidney, confirmed that the minutes were an accurate account.

After the Guardian read them to him, he said: "I had no idea that minutes were being taken - unless someone was hiding under the table - but they are very accurate, even down to my colleague Mark Todd turning up late. I'd love to know what they're saying to the Tories."

Anti-hunting groups were delighted about the comments made by alliance organisers in the minutes.

Steve Rackett, spokesman for the League Against Cruel Sports, said: "The Countryside Alliance have realised that a hunt ban is inevitable.

"They are aware that the forthcoming march will have no effect and is only being organised to placate their own supporters."

Full text
See the leaked memo

webTitle: Comment: Political life begins at 60

fields.headline: Political life begins at 60
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: What is wrong with Britain's politicians? At a time when life expectancy is getting longer, political life expectancy is getting ever shorter. Yesterday, Chris Patten ruled out a return to UK politics because, when he completes his stint as a European commissioner, he will have reached the grand old age of 60 and plans to write, make television programmes and do some "serious gardening". "I don't want to hang around in politics forever," he told David Frost, a sixtysomething who shows no sign of heading for the arboretum.
fields.body:
What is wrong with Britain's politicians? At a time when life expectancy is getting longer, political life expectancy is getting ever shorter. Yesterday, Chris Patten ruled out a return to UK politics because, when he completes his stint as a European commissioner, he will have reached the grand old age of 60 and plans to write, make television programmes and do some "serious gardening". "I don't want to hang around in politics forever," he told David Frost, a sixtysomething who shows no sign of heading for the arboretum.

Patten's preference for petunias over politics is a blow not just to the beleaguered sensible wing of the Conservative party, which recognises that the Battle of Britain ended 60 years ago, but to the rest of British politics too. Our political system relies on the existence of a robust opposition, a government in waiting. The excesses of Thatcherism can in part be blamed on the wreckage of the Labour party in the mid-80s: with an emasculated opposition, there really was no alternative.

As the shadow international development minister, Gary Streeter, admitted last week, the current Conservative frontbench are a bunch of no-hopers who have made little impact on the country. They have wasted three years in opposition, hoping that an appeal to prejudice and selfishness would close the gap on Labour. Happily, the public is proving more tolerant and less self-serving than Conservative central office imagined. The party is unelectable; the election, as prominent Tories concede, is as good as lost; Blair wins unopposed. That is bad for democracy.

Patten should be encouraged to rethink. He is intelligent, experienced and much more politically sophisticated than William Hague, who will reach 40 just before the likely election in May. Choosing the youthful Hague was a major error for the party: committing itself to a politician with a limited track record, no philosophy beyond becoming prime minister, and a penchant for leaping on every passing bandwagon. There should be no mourning when he ends up under one on election night. Kenneth Clarke, recognised as one of the most successful post-war chancellors, was deemed too sensible on Europe to lead the party, and consigned to kick his heels on the backbenches, another 60-year-old spending time with his jazz records and pints of Theakston's Old Peculier (preferable, perhaps, to the young peculiars who sit in front of him).

A Clarke-Patten Conservative party would be a far more formidable opponent for the government than Hague's hapless Little Englanders. Clarke still seems to have the stomach (no pun intended) for the fight; Patten, sadly, doesn't. "Hanging around in politics" is the giveaway phrase. Surely no true politician hangs around in politics; they live and breathe it. Tony Benn has never hung around in politics; it has animated his whole life. Likewise Michael Foot and Margaret Thatcher. Real politicians don't retire or get their own chat shows; they go on fighting for what they believe in.

In the past decade or so, because TV gets bored with the same old faces and society appears to idolise youth, politicians have been getting younger. We are encouraged to associate elderly politicians with the old Soviet Politburo or the Chinese communist party: sclerotic, outdated, self-perpetuating.

Oddly enough, I always think of Gladstone: far more radical in his 80s than his 20s ("old, wild and incomprehensible", Queen Victoria called the 82-year-old). Gladstone was almost 60 when he became prime minister for the first time; over the next 25 years he went on to form three more administrations. In his 70s, he was still combining the posts of prime minister and chancellor (no problem there with rivalries between the two great offices of state). He finally retired at the age of 85, which still left him time to campaign against Turkish atrocities in Armenia and - Chris Patten take note - to write. A choice between the 80-year-old Gladstone and any of the current crop of presentable fortysomethings would be no contest.

Michael Portillo, a 47-year-old apparently experiencing a mid-life crisis, might leave politics because he no longer enjoys it; Patten reckons you've had it at 60; William Hague could go from young hopeful to old has-been in the course of one long night. It is the fate of the career politician. Naturally, pursuit of office motivates any politician, but when it matters more than principle, Enoch Powell's dictum that all political careers end in failure becomes self-fulfilling. Politics is for life, and the gardening has to be fitted in around it. Ask Gladstone.

fields.headline: Practise what you preach
fields.standfirst:
A black Chris Evans. A white Scary Spice. The latest campaign for the Commission for Racial Equality is striking. But it is time the industry that produces the images improved its own race record. Belinda Archer reports

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A black Chris Evans. A white Scary Spice. The latest campaign for the Commission for Racial Equality is striking. But it is time the industry that produces the images improved its own race record. Belinda Archer reports.
fields.body:
Last Friday the Commission for Racial Equality unleashed its latest salvo in the battle to eradicate racism from British society. The race-relations watchdog launched a new 60-second TV commercial on Channel 4 starring a range of top-flight celebrities, from Lennox Lewis to Chris Evans, Scary Spice and even Ken Livingstone, all made (via a combination of make-up and special effects) to look as though they have different coloured skin.

Thus Lewis and Scary Spice appear as white people, Evans is black and Livingstone is transformed into an Asian. "Would you think differently about me ... if I was white?" challenges Lewis at the beginning, as his familiar features visibly, well, blanch, while Livingstone goes on, "Would I have won if I was Asian?" and Evans chirrups: "Would I be more annoying?"

The startling film, created by Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper and produced by RSA Films, ends with the provocative line: "The only thing we need to change is the way we think."

But as this commercial is busily garnering spin-off media coverage and triggering debate about racial prejudice in British homes and pubs, it also serves as an opportunity to re-examine racism within adland itself.

To be blunt, there is still a striking lack of ethnic minorities both employed in the ad industry and represented in adverts and commercials generally. The number of non-whites working in the industry is minimal, and those that do are far from senior. There is no official data available - the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising's annual census records sex and not ethnic origin - but agency estimates suggest that black people, Asians and other minorities represent less than 1% of those employed in the business.

Kai-Lu Hsiung, the producer of the CRE spot at RSA Films (who happens to be half-Chinese, half-English), says: "When we shot the ad it made us really think about the lack of minorities in the industry. Crews are predominantly white. We actually used a black make-up artist, a black sound woman and a black runner, but they were just three out of a total of 140 crew members - we couldn't have got 140 ethnic minority people even if we had tried."

When challenged on their employment mix, most agencies and production companies rather lamely insist that they do indeed have "one black copywriter" or "a black runner". Tales even abound of one agency expressly recruiting an Asian trainee as it prepared to pitch for the CRE account itself (in case of any embarrassing client questions), but the overall industry number is "woefully low", admits one Top 10 agency chief.

Winston Fletcher, a director at FCB Europe, says: "It's a disgrace, particularly because most agencies are based in central London which is where there is the highest concentration of ethnic minorities. I think we should make much more effort to recruit and promote people of different origins. There are excuses, but none of these are acceptable."

Tim Mellors, executive creative director of Grey, adds: "It's a ludicrous situation. Just like with women creatives, there are really not enough ethnic minorities working in the industry. How conscious it is by agencies, I don't know - I would say it's unconscious, it's not a nefarious plot, but that's still not good enough."

Seyoan Vela, a creative director of Sri Lankan parentage at St Luke's, says: "Advertising is very much a middle-class, looks-based industry, and when agencies recruit, after establishing whether someone has a degree or went to Oxford, say, it is then down to the way they look, and race falls into that. It might be cool to have a black creative, but it is no coincidence that there are a lot of pretty girls and very few black or brown people in the industry who are account handlers."

The situation slightly improves when looking at the ads themselves, but prejudice still lingers. Thankfully the industry has progressed from those early days when people from ethnic minorities were not depicted at all. It has also moved on from the times when they were used, but only in a patronising, tokenist way, clumsily plonked in any given commercial. Yet even given the increased casting of ethnic minorities, it still tends to be stereotypical, with black people largely being used in sports ads, say.

Gerry Moira, executive creative director of Publicis, says: "We are no longer short of minorities in advertising generally, but we still do not see black families or the black bank manager or the black Kwik Fit fitter. In quantity terms there are lots of them, but they tend to be confined to roles such as sport or fashion or entertainment."

Some observers insist that the industry itself is liberal and forward-thinking but remains thwarted by clients who still err on the conservative side, stubbornly believing that their consumers would consider a black boss or black dad unrepresentative.

Another explanation is the dreaded R word - research. A combination of agency anxiety and increasingly nervous clients means that most ads are now almost researched to death before being officially released. And, generally, any depiction of a character other than adland's typical white north European is greeted by focus groups with the question "why is she black then?"; or "what exactly are you trying to say by using an Asian?".

There is also a fundamental societal truth facing ad agencies. Fletcher explains: "Most advertising is still national, so for people in East Anglia or the west of England to see a black or Asian bank manager, that would seem incongruous. Advertising generally reflects what is happening in society - it doesn't take the lead in terms of social engineering."

Perhaps more depressingly, RSA came up against a "three-mile long list" of celebrities who refused to be involved in their CRE film, although some had legitimate misgivings about their famous faces being doctored in any way.

Laurence Dunmore, who directed the spot, reveals: "Prince Naseem was initially really unsure about being changed into a white man. He is very proud of his nationality and his religion, but in the end I managed to convince him. I said that I have been white for 35 years and it hasn't done me any harm - couldn't he just try it for 35 minutes?"

As well as the public at large and possibly even celebrity circles, perhaps this latest CRE film might serve to shake up the advertising industry. And maybe adland has come a long way from the client who notoriously refused, around 10 years ago, to cast a black person in his toiletries ad "because black people don't use soap". But clearly there is still progress to be made.
