webTitle: TV soccer host robbed during filming

fields.headline: TV soccer hosts robbed during filming
fields.trailText: Monday 5.15pm Presenters Gabby Yorath and Barry Venison were robbed while hosting their Saturday football show, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Presenters Gabby Yorath and Barry Venison were robbed while hosting their Saturday football show.

Ms Yorath and Mr Venison both discovered cash was missing when they returned to their dressing rooms at the London Studios after presenting ITV's On the Ball on Saturday afternoon.

Thieves took £250 from Ms Yorath's purse and £150 from Mr Venison's coat pocket.

LWT bosses are studying close-circuit TV to try to find the culprit, whom they suspect is an insider.

Thieves took £250 from Ms Yorath's purse and £150 from Mr Venison's coat pocket. LWT bosses are studying close-circuit TV to try to find the culprit, whom they suspect is an insider.

webTitle: Blair spells out NHS winter plans

fields.headline: Blair spells out NHS winter plans
fields.trailText: The government launched a pre-emptive strike at its NHS critics today, outlining details of the health service's plans to cope with winter pressures and attempting to reassure the public that the NHS is not in crisis. By Patrick Butler
fields.body:
The government launched a pre-emptive strike at its NHS critics today, outlining details of the health service's plans to cope with winter pressures and attempting to reassure the public that the NHS is not in crisis.

Prime minister Tony Blair admitted that the NHS would face pressures and problems during the winter, and that some patients would not get optimum care. But he emphasised that after decades of under-investment the health service was "going in the right direction".

Mr Blair's comments were supported by health managers' leader Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation. He said: "The entire NHS is under real pressure but it is not in a crisis."

The prime minister made his admission - heavily trailed over the weekend - in a Downing Street press conference called to announce the government's plans for how the NHS will cope with winter pressures.

His speech is seen as a way of preparing the public and NHS staff for the almost inevitable problems - bed shortages, patients waiting on trolleys and cancelled operations - that will affect the NHS over the winter.

Last February the government and the NHS were caught wrong-footed by a flu epidemic which generated a damaging series of headlines, dented Labour's opinion poll standing and ultimately led to Mr Blair's announcement of extra millions for the NHS.

Mr Blair said: "During the winter, just as during any other part of the year, a massive organisation, dealing with a million people a day, will face problems.

"Under-investment over decades is not put right in three years. It takes years to train doctors and consultants and, indeed, nurses. Until we have delivered, therefore, the increases in capacity, year on year, for several more years, there are bound to be pressures, as there are indeed in health care systems right around the world in winter."

And Mr Blair said there would be "cases where patients do not get the care that they should". But he insisted that the NHS was performing better, adding: "The health service is going in the right direction."

Mr Blair announced that there were 3.2 million more doses of flu vaccine available than last year. The NHS direct advice line had been expanded to cover 16 million more people and there were 2,900 more intensive home care packages on top of the extra 8,000 from last year. The number of acute hospital beds had risen by 1,350, while critical care beds had gone up by 445, about 100 more than had been planned. The increases were being matched by improvement in service in many areas, the prime minister said.

He thanked NHS staff for their hard work in preparing for the winter pressures. "We are trying to match that effort with increased resources, over £300 million on winter pressures alone," he said. "The effort, the money and the reforms are starting to produce results."

Waiting lists fell by 7,000 in October, the eighth successive month to show a fall, Mr Blair said. He conceded that during the winter those numbers were likely to increase, but stressed that "the underlying trend is now firmly downwards".

It would take years to put right the decades of under-investment the service suffered under Conservative governments, the prime minister said. But he added: "The health service now is going in the right direction. It does have more money. It does have more doctors and nurses, with more on the way. It does have more beds. It does have better management. It does have detailed and well-worked-out plans for the winter."

There was "still a long way to go", but the "brilliant" NHS staff was working with the government to give the country the health service it deserved. "So to sum up, there is more money, more nurses, more beds, there has been far more preparation but there will be pressures and difficulties," Mr Blair said.

"But let us get a sense of balance, support the NHS staff who give a wonderful service to the majority of patients, and not fall into the trap of saying that every time something goes wrong the NHS is in crisis or on its knees."

Earlier, health secretary Alan Milburn acknowledged that the NHS faced real pressures during the coming winter. But he insisted that considerable progress had been made and the "glass is half full rather than half empty".

"What the public will see this winter is certainly some problems in some parts of the NHS, that is undoubtedly true," Mr Milburn said. "But I also think that people will see progress overall across the NHS.

"The truth about the NHS today is that it is a service in transition, we have had ... decades of neglect and under-investment, we are beginning to put that right, but yes, of course it does take time, that is absolutely the case," he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

Winter crisis programme in brief
"The NHS has detailed and well-worked-out plans for the winter," said Mr Blair:
 There are 3.2 million more doses of flu vaccine available than last year.
 The NHS Direct advice line has been expanded to cover 16 million more people.
 There are 2,900 more intensive home care packages on top of the extra 8,000 from last year.
 Acute hospital beds have increased by 1,350.
 Critical care beds have gone up by 445.
 Waiting lists fell by 7,000 in October, the eighth successive month to show a fall: "the underlying trend is now firmly downwards", said Blair.
 The NHS has more money, more doctors and nurses, and more beds, the government claims.

webTitle: Politics, not health, at the heart of Blair's speech

fields.headline: Politics, not health, at the heart of Blair's speech
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's speech on winter pressures today was a signal that the government will not be caught napping on the NHS as it was over September's fuel protests, writes Patrick Butler
fields.trailText: Comment: Tony Blair's speech on winter pressures today was a signal that the government will not be caught napping on the NHS as it was over September's fuel protests, writes Patrick Butler
fields.body:
Tony Blair's speech on winter pressures today revealed nothing new in policy or strategy terms; it was a pre-emptive strike, a signal that the government will not be caught napping on the NHS as it was over September's fuel protests.

Health policy was not really at the heart of this speech. Instead, it was about government presentation - and public perception - of health policy. It was also about countering the toxic blasts that will emanate from the media on "the state of the NHS" in the next few weeks.

Blair knows that however successful any number of essential, but low-profile, modernisation initiatives to improve services such as mental health might be, it is the view from casualty, as reported by the media, that most people will use as an index of NHS health.

Hence his plea: "Let's not continue the nonsense of saying the NHS is 'on its knees' or in 'crisis' every time a mistake happens. Of course it is terrible for that person. But those who believe in the NHS should not let individual cases be used as a battering ram, by those who do not believe in the NHS, and want to see it dismantled."

The message was aimed in part, we can surmise, in the general direction of the Daily Mail and its political allies, purveyors of "NHS in crisis" headlines to middle England, and notoriously loathe to pass up an opportunity to knock the health service. As the Power 90 survey by SocietyGuardian.co.uk revealed, not for nothing is the Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre regarded as the 10th most powerful and influential person in the health service. His paper's NHS headlines, it is said, cause shock waves across Whitehall.

With a general election just around the corner, and Tony Blair's credibility tied firmly to the success of his very personal crusade to improve the health service, "a good winter" for the NHS is politically essential.

Bad NHS winters come and go - last year was a bad one, and the government was on the skids for a while. It was saved, dramatically, by Tony Blair's stunning pledge to invest billions more in the health service. The move knocked out his critics for a while, but the extra billions won't make an immediate difference to the structural causes of the winter crisis - lack of nurses and shortage of beds - and yet the public will have high expectations of big improvements.

Blair hopes that his speech will dampen public expectations of what the NHS can deliver, and outflank the Daily Mail. Not a lot to do with health "on the ground", but that's politics.

webTitle: Ex-Loaded editor plans hip money mag

fields.headline: Ex-Loaded editor plans hip money mag
fields.standfirst: Former Loaded editor seeks multimedia funding
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: Former Loaded editor Tim Southwell has joined the ranks of the grown-up lads' mag editors with an idea for a magazine about money management, writes Jessica Hodgson
Dec 4: Ex-Loaded editor seeks multimedia funding
fields.body:
Former Loaded editor Tim Southwell has joined the ranks of the grown-up lads' mag editors with an idea for a magazine about money management. But he wants it to be "rock 'n' roll money".

Mr Southwell, who last week lost his job on broadband and new media start-up Switch2, said he would be working to get funding for a cross-media venture called The Player, which would be "a cross between Which? and Vanity Fair".

Mr Southwell told MediaGuardian.co.uk that there was a gap in the market for a magazine teaching people how to look after their cash which wasn't "totally dry".

"There's this closed shop as regards improving your standards of life and of succeeding," he said.

"This is going to be like Everyman's version of Forbes magazine. It could cover your average Joe who earns £50,000 a year or it could be for your Bill Gates figure.

"There's nothing less sexy than being skint".

Mr Southwell was unwilling to give away details about potential backers for the project, which will include former Loaded staffer Ben Marshall and former Disney head of programming Simon Weiszman.

webTitle: You bet your life: week sixteen, the expert's view

fields.headline: You bet your life: week sixteen, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Betting expert Patrick Murray gives his latest verdict
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £199.83, Sean Ingle = £95.15, Football Unlimited punters collective = £59.99, Paul MacInnes = £46.20
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £199.83, Sean Ingle = £95.15, Football Unlimited punters collective = £59.99, Paul MacInnes = £46.20

Scott Murray: Ipswich v Derby - Derby to win. £10 @ 4/1
Bet wins £40

He's just too good. If I didn't know better I'd think he wrote his column after the matches, there really is no excuse for the number of good-priced winners he picks. Value is supposed to be a long-term strategy - the few winners more than making up for the many losers - but Scott somehow manages to cut down on the loser side of the equation and to concentrate on the winner one. There's little doubt that a lot of his success is down to good old-fashioned luck but, to an extent, you make your own luck and behind it all there lie sound punting principles.

Let this man be an example to you. Week after week he searches for value not for winners, he looks to oppose bad favourites or to back underrated underdogs or better still both, and he doesn't get greedy and do multiples.

If I have one criticism of him it would be his tendency to pick selections in relatively high-profile matches rather than scouring the more obscure games where value is more likely to lurk. But then again why change a winning formula, less than halfway through the season and Scott's already doubled his money.

Of course, the minute any of us start backing his selections they'll start losing, so maybe we should just remember the principles behind the bets and use them to make our own selections. It's just an idea.

Sean Ingle: One 50p accumulator and 4x £1.50 trebles: Crystal Palace to win at Grimsby @ 7/4, Bayer Leverkusen to win at Bayern Munich @ 10/3, Oviedo to win at home to Malaga @ 4/5, Milan to win at Udinese @ 7/4.
Bet loses

I've always felt schadenfreude was a singularly unsavoury emotion (as well as being a long and impressive sounding word guaranteed to cause a stir at all the best wine and cheese parties) but somehow Mr Ingle brings the worst out in me. I want him to lose. I delight in his losses. I metaphorically tear up his betting slips, throw them in the air and dance joyously as the shreds of his dreams cascade down upon me. And it's nearly Christmas too, how mean-spirited am I?

But he deserves it. I do my best, give him the full benefit of my years of betting wisdom garnered at no small personal and financial expense, and he just throws it back in my face with obscenities such as this week's little offering.

Yet again Mr I has turned a winning week into a losing week by his insistence on multiples. Doubtless he will protest that he had to do multiples because of the minimum trebles rule for Nationwide matches but that doesn't cut the mustard frankly: for the greater good of his bet, Crystal Palace should be mercilessly cast aside. Let's face it, regardless of his bet, Crystal Palace should be mercilessly cast aside.

Perhaps one day he will repent of his sinful multiple-worship and realise the beautiful and profitable simplicity of singles. He has before him, after all, in Mr Scott Murray a shining example of what can be achieved by following the righteous path of singles. One can but wait and hope; patience is a vital trait in every gambler but I fear Mr I would try the patience of a saint.

Paul MacInnes: Strasbourg to beat Monaco. £5 @ 5/1
Bet loses

Paul, Paul, Paul, one has to feel sorry for him. He tries, Lord knows he tries, but however hard he tries nothing seems to work.

He's done everything right here - trawled through an obscure European League looking for value, thoroughly researched the recent form of the two sides and then backed a good-priced outsider against a bad favourite. All that was missing was a vital piece of late injury news to complete the jigsaw - but he just doesn't seem to have the Scott Murray knack of picking winners.

All I can say, once again, is patience dear chap. Persevere and you will be rewarded. Honest. The bookmakers can be beaten by those with discipline, patience and a willingness to put in the research and you've shown all those traits this season (though not necessarily at the same time).

Jonathan Eggleton of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Trebles from 4 (Four lines @ £1.50): Rangers to win at Hearts @ 8/15, Hibernian to win at Motherwell @ 5/4, Fulham to win at Preston @ 10/11, Birmingham to win at Gillingham @ 6/5
Bet wins £5.39

Regular readers of this column need not read on as I'm sure you all know the next bit off by heart, one shower of opprobrium is much the same as another.

What have I done to deserve this, oh Mr Guardian? There we were, me and the FUPC, getting along famously - sensible guest readers picking sensible singles and finally making inroads into the FUPC budget deficit - when suddenly we're flung once more into the swirling maelstrom of mindless multiples. This week's hapless guest punter Mr Eggleton (surely another invention of the ever-mischievous Mr Ingle) offends the sensibilities in too many ways to list here but let's just look at some selected highlights.

Mr E (how apt) claims to have chosen his selections, among other reasons, because "these four teams usually win every week". You and ten million others have noticed this, Mr Eggleton, and the bookies know it, and you can be pretty damn sure they're going to quote such teams at overly short odds in the certain knowledge that you and your ilk will be backing them week in, week out. Next Mr E admits to being "unsure" about Fulham and yet includes them anyway despite them being one of his shorter priced selections at 10/11. Why?!? Aren't three selections enough? It's two too many in my book but what a very dull book that is apparently.

Perhaps I should just mention that Mr Eggleton's bet did, in fact, return a profit with three selections winning, the aforementioned Fulham being the team that failed, but please let's not let that pull the wool over our eyes. Let's just file this one away under 'fun bet' and be done with it. 'Fun bets' are fine by me (as I say most weeks before launching into a rant against them) but I'm here to tell you how to win, dear punter, and bets like this are most assuredly not the way forward.

Value not winners - chant it as a mantra everyday and ignore the funny looks you get, you know you're on the path to riches and enlightenment. Happy punting.

webTitle: Lame-duck manager, Ruggedly handsome superhero, and Deranged fan

fields.headline: Lame-duck manager, Ruggedly handsome superhero, and Deranged fan
fields.trailText: VEN WILL I BE FAMOUS?
fields.body:
VEN WILL I BE FAMOUS?

So there's a press conference being held at Middlesbrough's training ground at 4.30pm this afternoon. As the Fiver will be slumped under a table at our local lapdancery by that hour, we are left to have a quick guess at what it's about. Could it be that Bryan Robbo has carried out a bloodless coup, ousting Steve Gibbo and seizing control of Boro for his own ruthless ends? Perhaps the club have finally completed the signing of Ally McCoist. Or perhaps they've cobbled together some hotch-potch deal to get Terry Venables to spend six months in the north-east.

Obviously, the last time we left it, Boro had stood firm (hem hem) and, despite spending days looking for some sort of compromise from Venables, announced they could accept no compromise and that any deal was dead. Then Robbo announced that, with Venables out of the way, there was nobody else in the world good enough to replace him. Then a toothless Boro lost 1-0 to West Ham. Then Venables made some conciliatory noises through his friends in the press, and before you know it Boro are tearing down the A1 for more talks - as if the thought of Robbo remaining in charge scared them witless.

"I would put the club in front of any individual," Gibbo said today. "If somebody needs to be sacrificed - it doesn't matter whether it is me or anyone else - that sacrifice will be made." Tough words, but it does sound awfully like Boro have capitulated and accepted whatever offer Venables was prepared to give them. "I said to Bryan Robson, 'I will take it to the end of the year'", Tel revealed. "'You have a break for six months. I'll deal with the press and the team.'" What a nice man. But remember, if Tel doesn't take the job this afternoon, and Gary Pallister announces a revolutionary new orthopaedic treatment instead - you heard it here first.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 2: click here

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

LENNON VS LENNON

It was twenty years ago next Friday that John Lennon was gunned down by a deranged fan outside the Dakota building. Spooky huh? But it gets weirder. Because if, by next Friday, Neil Lennon hasn't shot off up north to join a deranged manager outside the Parkhead building in Glasgow for £20,000-a-week, then the Fiver's a Wings fan.

Yes, the Northern Ireland international whose life has eerily echoed that of his namesake - they both changed their hairstyle, they have both been to Liverpool, not to mention spending three months in bed with long hair doing psychoactive drugs with bonkers Japanese women (probably) - is likely to join his mental mentor, Martin O'Neill, at Celtic. Lennon announced after Leicester's 3-1 win over Leeds on Saturday that it would be his last game as a Fox, adding: "You have to be Irish to understand the pull of Celtic." Which doesn't say much for the Scots.

No deal has been struck just yet, because the Foxy Foxes are holding out for more money than Celtic have been prepared to offer so far (Lennon's old club Crewe stand to earn a percentage of any transfer fee). But with Peter Taylor imposing a deadline of 5pm tomorrow for any improved bid, you wouldn't bet against something happening soon. "This has dragged on for too long," Taylor said today, although he said he understood why Lennon would want to play for Celtic. "It has always been his dream," he said. Whether it was dream number nine remains to be seen.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I was in defence as much as in attack. I was always coming back to mark Steven Pressley. For me the tempo of the game was far too high. That's why it wasn't a good football game" - Welcome to Scotland, Rangers' £12m striker Tore Andre Flo.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE NAME'S TAYLOR, PETER TAYLOR

The world of international club football is a world of intrigue and secret machinations. Sure as eggs which are actually hand grenades is eggs, you can be sure that the really successful managers are up to no good. They're all spies, y'see. So it's just as well the in-no-way-paranoid Fiver is on the ball: we've got our hands on a secret report which reveals that England caretaker-manager Peter Taylor has been plotting the downfall of Leeds with Lazio boss Sven-Goran Eriksson ahead of tomorrow's Big Cup tie.

"To say I have helped Sven in providing information about Leeds is totally wrong," insisted Taylor as he sipped on a suspiciously shaken martini. "Nothing, in fact, could be further from the truth," the square-jawed Leicester boss continued. "When I went to Rome last week to see Sven I did say to him that Leeds United are a very good team. But that was the extent of our conversations as regards Leeds United."

And that's supposed to convince us? You're probably wearing a tux under that tatty tracksuit, for a start. "I was there to talk to him purely about England matters and nothing else," Taylor insisted. "Nothing was said about Leeds. It is an understatement to say that I am annoyed about what has been suggested," the ruggedly handsome superhero concluded, before asking us if we wanted to slip into something more comfortable.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Middlesbrough striker Alun Armstrong is in talks with Ipswich after the two sides agreed an £800,000 fee. The former Stockport striker has failed to make an impression since joining the club for £1.5m in 1998.

Benni McCarthy wants to complete a move to Aston Villa this week. "Benni has told me that he thinks this is the week it either gets done or is finally killed off", his agent Rob Moore said today. "He is still convinced he will be a Villa player, but it is disconcerting that Villa are being linked with names left, right and centre."

Manchester City have had a £6m bid for Eidur Gudjohnsen rejected by Chelsea.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Rangers have signed 20-year-old Finnish midfielder Jani Kauppila on a two-year deal.

A documentary about Ajax will not be screened in certain Dutch cinemas after threats from rival soccer fans. Ajax, daar hoorden zij engelen zingen - Ajax, they heard angels singing there - was to have been shown in The Hague and Utrecht, but cinema managers caved in to threats from Feyenoord and Utrecht fans who demanded the film be removed.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Big Cup Special (11.30pm) Only to the teams who are in it.

Football Extra (12.30am) Only if you've had some already.

Channel 5: Dutch Football (4am) So skilful they could even trap an unravelling edam.

Sky Sports 1: Live Monday Night Football (7pm, 12midnight) Sunderland play Everton in one of those matches you try so hard to love

You're On Sky Sports! (10.30pm, 2am) but there's no need to try hard here. Because love grows where McCaffrey goes!

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11.30pm SS1) Re-re-view. The crowd say Boa Morte.

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm) Peter Cormack talks for ages about his days at Liverpool and Forest, with a small nod to his time at Hibs. Or is that the other way round?

British Eurosport: Eurogoals (10.15pm) If you take the countries and continents out of it, we're left with sport and goals. Which doesn't mean very much to us.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (8pm) An Ulsterman embarks on a two-hour rant against Manchester United.

webTitle: Industrial action hits universities

fields.headline: Industrial action hits universities
fields.trailText: University staff will begin an industrial action campaign tomorrow over pay and working conditions. Lecturers will withhold student marks, and there will be an exam board boycott. University workers will also work strictly to contract.
fields.body:
University staff will begin an industrial action campaign tomorrow over pay and working conditions. Lecturers will withhold student marks, and there will be an exam board boycott. University workers will also work strictly to contract.

Members of lecturers' union Natfhe, and a host of other unions including Unison, MSF, EIS, TGWU and GMB, will begin the action tomorrow with campus demonstrations. The National Union of Students has pledged support for the campaign.

While not agreeing to all-out strike, union members voted to take industrial action in protest at the refusal of university chiefs to negotiate on pay, workloads or working conditions. The unions' 100,000 members also feel betrayed by the vice chancellors' rejection of the recommendations of the 1999 independent Bett Report, set up by university employers to modernise staffing arrangements.

The final straw for staff has been the vice chancellors' continued refusal to return to negotiations despite the recent announcement of £330m earmarked by the government for pay.

Education secretary, David Blunkett, last week told universities to reach a fair settlement with staff.

In Scotland, a 8% improvement in government higher education funding has also been announced.

webTitle: Virgin Radio to launch four digital online stations

fields.headline: Virgin Radio to launch four digital online stations
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Virgin Radio is launching four digital online stations in a bid to diversify its digital radio content. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Virgin Radio is launching four new digital online stations in a bid to diversify its digital radio content.

First to launch is Virgin Classic, which will be followed by Virgin Lite, Virgin Modern and Virgin Wheels of Steel.

The move has been designed to "develop the Virgin brand and also go after new audiences", without launching new analogue stations.

In a unrelated move, Virgin Radio will start selling ad space on the digital audio channels separately from its existing analogue station.

webTitle: Wheels: The new Ford Mondeo

fields.headline: Berth of a salesman
fields.standfirst: Can the Ford Mondeo regain its iconic status? Giles Smith hangs his jacket in the back and hits the road to find out
fields.trailText: Can the Ford Mondeo regain its iconic status? Giles Smith hangs his jacket in the back and hits the road to find out.
fields.body:
The Ford Mondeo is a triumph of niche marketing despite itself - a car so embedded in the culture that it ended up, through no apparent plan of its own, with a social subgroup named after it. You will recall Mondeo Man, who played such a crucial role in Tony Blair's rise to power. Mondeo Man was the disenchanted, lower middle class professional, targeted by vote-chasers before the last general election, who could be nudged to set aside the habit of a lifetime and vote Labour.

These days, for better or worse, the Mondeo's reputation inevitably precedes it. It is the only vehicle - apart from a tank - that has overturned a government.

You don't, however, tend to hear much about Mondeo Man these days. He appears to have withdrawn quietly into his house, appearing only briefly on his drive to wax his car. For all we know, he may be having fond thoughts about William Hague by now. It's even possible that he's driving a Vauxhall Vectra.

You hear a little less about the Mondeo, too, and, unless the newly released models go well, historians may eventually conclude that the car enjoyed its golden age in the mid-90s. In 1994 and 1995, the second and third years of the Mondeo's life, during which it reigned as Europe's Car of the Year, it accounted impressively for almost a quarter of British sales in its very crowded sector.

Since then there has been, inevitably, a fall-off: last year the Mondeo had a 15.3% share of the market. Nevertheless, there are more than 750,000 Mondeos on British roads. It remains a hit, even as a sleeper. And now here comes a remix, looking to stoke up the interest levels and get the punters dancing the way they did in the glory days.

Here are some of the key features of the new Mondeo: more airbags; stronger, safer brakes; snazzier headlamps; and increased legroom for passengers in the back. I'm not sure how much there is on that list to set one's heart fluttering, but the Mondeo is equipped with a new family of Ford engines that might work a little harder to entertain you.

On the other hand, being Fords, they might not. I can only report that the Duratec HE 1.8 in the car I drove rendered it quick enough to get your jacket flapping on the hanger in the back.

But whatever the tempting extras, for the unconverted there will be the usual prejudices to overcome, not just about the Mondeo label but about the whole Ford brand.

Say "Ford" and a whole crop of unfortunate associations comes wriggling to the surface, including: the firm's association with cut-price fleet cars (and, by extension, its association with chippy, middle-ranking sales executives with their jackets flapping on hangers in the back); the fact that it once produced the Capri and still produces the Fiesta; the erosion, in Britain, of the company's lustrous historical connection with the pioneering Henry and, in place of that, its somehow significant association with Dagenham (which houses its plant) and Brentwood (which houses its offices).

Before Mondeo Man there was Essex Man, and his spirit appears to breathe deeply wherever Ford cars are owned and driven.

But over and above these general, abstract and, in some cases, plainly ungenerous feelings, there is also the fact that Ford has produced some of the most sleep-inducing cars ever to leave a factory, and has placed within them some of the most taste-challenging plastic interiors since the launch of Barbie's first house.

The Mondeo does not deserve to be gathered in with this history. This is a new-era Ford - a Ford from the age of the Focus and the Ka, stylised vehicles from somewhere way out to the left of Ford's traditionally bland remit. That said, the Mondeo has a less colourful market in mind, and car designers understand that you can reinvent neither the wheel nor the sales executive. Accordingly, the new Mondeo seems carefully conceived not to startle its constituency.

It appears to have turned for inspiration and succour to the VW Passat. The Passat may not be the most sense-awakening car in the world but, being built by VW, its furniture tends at least to feel reassuringly weighty and firm. The Mondeo follows its cue. The indicator and windscreen-wiper stalks, for instance, don't - as they do in older Fords - feel like the boom on a balsawood model of a yacht.

Even the plastic fascia on the dashboard doesn't seem quite so overwhelmingly plasticky as one expects from Ford. Interestingly, the plastic on the driver's side is differently stippled from the plastic on the passenger's side. Two different kinds of fascia grain! Now there's a unique selling point, and one strangely underplayed in the car's advertising.

Overall, the interior is modestly stylish - a quiet advance on its predecessor. Only two things leap out: the oval clock makes the whole central panel look like an in-car Teasmade; and does that irritating "boing" noise have to accompany the winking of the indicators? In the torture chambers of the future, you may well be offered the choice between having water dripped on you and listening to the sound of a Mondeo waiting to turn right. My advice would be: go with the water. Still, it's the only thing about the car that is painful. The price certainly isn't.

The lowdown

Ford Mondeo LX 1.8

Price: £14,595

Top speed: 127 mph

Acceleration: 0-62 in 10.2 seconds

Consumption: 36.6mpg (combined)

At the wheel: Dave Bassett

On the stereo: Whitney Houston

En route for: Southend

webTitle: United teams up with Creative Planet

fields.headline: United teams up with Creative Planet
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: United News & Media has linked up with US company Creative Planet to launch a global business aimed at the TV and film industries. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
United News & Media has linked up with US business-to-business service provider Creative Planet to launch a global online and offline business aimed at the TV and film industries.

As part of the deal, United will invest $30m (£21m) into Creative Planet and merge its UK film production information service, The Knowledge, into the US outfit.

In return, United is taking a "significant" equity stake in Creative Planet. It will also act as exclusive UK and Ireland sales and marketing agent for the US firm and will be the lead agent for Creative Planet services in Europe.

Clive Hollick, United's chief executive, said: "Creative Planet shares our vision for revolutionising the provision of services to the film and TV production industry, and together we will make this a reality."

Creative Planet's proprietary software, databases and services are used by US clients including CBS, Fox, NBC, Dreamworks SKG, MGM, Paramount, J Walter Thompson and McCann Erickson.

webTitle: Killer to face police over Lamplugh case

fields.headline: Killer to face police over Lamplugh case
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the abduction and murder of the estate agent Suzy Lamplugh are preparing to question a convicted killer in connection with the 14-year-old case, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the abduction and murder of the estate agent Suzy Lamplugh are preparing to question a convicted killer in connection with the 14-year-old case, it emerged yesterday.

Scotland Yard will question John Cannan, currently serving three life sentences for murder and rape, in connection with one of Britain's longest running murder inquiries.

Lamplugh disappeared in July 1986 after leaving her office to show a client, known as Mr Kipper, around a house in Fulham, west London. The inquiry failed to find her body and eventually her family accepted she had been murdered.

Several suspects were questioned, including Cannan, formerly a Bristol car dealer, who was last interviewed about the Lamplugh case in 1990. He has denied involvement.

The case was formally reopened earlier this year and several new witnesses came forward, some claiming to have seen Lamplugh with her abductor. A jogger reported seeing a woman struggling with a man in a car, close to the spot where Lamplugh's Fiesta was found abandoned. Another witness claimed to have seen a woman driving her car erratically, with a male passenger in the vehicle.

Detectives have prepared a file on the case in co-operation with the crown prosecution service. Cannan may take part in an identity parade.

Diana Lamplugh, mother of Suzy, founded the Suzy Lamplugh Trust to campaign for better protection for young people against sexual and other forms of violence.

webTitle: Patience is a virtue - but not for US pundits

fields.headline: Patience is a virtue - but not for US pundits
fields.standfirst: Are Americans getting bored with the election saga? Don't believe everything you hear, says Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: Are Americans getting bored with the election saga? Don't believe everything you hear, says Martin Kettle.
fields.body:
The next time that you read or hear that the American public's patience is running out for Al Gore's efforts to overturn the November 7 presidential election, beware - because, so far at least, it just isn't.

This is not to say that some people's patience isn't stretched to breaking point.

Many Republicans, for instance, are almost beside themselves with exasperation at the vice-president's temerity in asking for all the votes to be counted. The longer this goes on, the more outraged they have become.

Something similar is also true of the American media. The battle of the dimpled chads has outstayed its welcome with some of the American political class.

In a nation with a short attention span, the editors think it's time to move on. They want a president, and they want him now.

Anyone who has spent the past few years in the United States will be familiar with American journalistic impatience, and with the demands for constant novelty that have been generated by the 24-hour rolling news culture that thrives on big stories - providing they don't go on too long.

America's punditocracy is notorious for its consistent inability to read the political mood correctly. In January 1998, when the Monica Lewinsky story first broke, some of them had Bill Clinton out of office by the end of the week.

A few months later, when Clinton finally admitted his relationship with Lewinsky, the same wiseacres had him out of the White House within days.

A month after that, as the Starr report exploded across the airwaves, they said his days were numbered yet again.

But in each case, as some of us saw at the time, Clinton was able to hang on in there. As a matter of fact, he's still president today, though he keeps such a low profile that most Americans could be forgiven for having forgotten the fact.

In fact, there is almost an iron law of American perversity. If the pundits say something, then you can be pretty confident that the reverse is about to occur.

In November 1998, America's talking heads queued up to predict catastrophe for the Democrats in the midterm elections. As we now know, they were wrong then, too.

The voters punished Newt Gingrich not Clinton. Did the pundits apologise? Well, what do you think?

So now, when the overpaid, overexposed, overrated American political knowalls tell us that time is running out for Gore, the sensible thing is to assume that Gore still has some time on his side.

On the front page of the New York Times last week, the paper carried the results of an opinion poll that certainly seemed to confirm this view.

"Do you think the fact that we do not yet know who the next president will be is a big problem or not really a problem?" the pollsters asked.

The result was as close as the election itself. Some 48% thought it was a big problem, while 49% thought it was not.

A succession of other questions produced similarly close results. When Katherine Harris certified the results last weekend, were they fair and accurate or not? Fair and accurate, 47%. Not fair and accurate, 47&.

Should Gore concede now? Yes, 42%. No, 48%.

The mood, in other words, is deeply divided, just like the election. But the people whose support Gore needs as he continues his legal challenges still seem to be pretty much onside.

The polls confirm it. The public utterances of the party leaders confirm it. And one's own experience as a reporter confirms it, too. Conclusion: Democrats are giving Gore a fair wind to see if he can turn it round in the courts.

Will he manage it? That's a different question altogether. The going is getting ever more tangled in the Florida court. Today is more than a week on from the moment when Florida's secretary of state Katherine Harris officially certified Bush as the winner there.

Yet not one of the votes on which Gore's challenge is focused has been counted, never mind added to the Harris totals.

There is a mounting sense that the Bush team will be able to play out the clock, as they say in American football.

A month after the election took place, the probability is that Bush will win. When all is said and done, courts don't much like the responsibility of overturning elections.

Yet Gore and his people remain utterly certain that they won more votes in Florida, and they are probably right, as a fascinating Miami Herald analysis suggested on Saturday.

In the end, the election counting mechanism and the court process for supervising it have combined to let the American people down.

A lot of Americans are content to look in the other direction, but a lot of others are not - and there's no reason why the media should be among them.

webTitle: December 2-3 ratings

fields.headline: Channel 4 opera sees viewers tune out
fields.trailText: TV overnights: C4 nearly fell off the ratings map on Saturday night after its filmed version of Glyndebourne youth opera Zoe drew only 300,000, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4 nearly fell off the ratings map entirely on Saturday night with its filmed version of Glyndebourne youth opera Zoe.

The programme was watched by a mere 300,000 viewers, one of the broadcaster's worst prime-time audiences ever.

The audience share for the channel went down to 1% - a tenth of the channel's average.

Channel 4's brave scheduling for a Saturday night proved an alternative for the minority not watching the live final of Stars in their Eyes .

It crowned a barnstorming week for ITV, according to unofficial overnight figures, with just over 10m - 43% of the audience - tuning in to see the hit show presented by Matthew Kelly.

And 11.3m tuned in to see Nicola Kirsch's impersonation of Maria Callas voted the winner at an updated 15-minute show at 10.15pm.

A rare Saturday night outing for Coronation Street had 11.8m and half the available audience from 9.15pm.

Then Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? continued the good work from 9.45pm, averaging 11.9m and a 53% share.

Overall, ITV had its third best peak-time performance of the year last week, with a little help from the David Beckham documentary, the Full Monty terrestrial premiere and Coronation Street every night.

The broadcaster averaged 42.1% of peak-time viewing ( 7pm-10.30pm), 16.5 percentage share points ahead of BBC1, between Monday November 27 and Sunday December 3.

The BBC1 Ten O'Clock News had its worst week yet, averaging 4.2m and a 20% share.

On Sunday night, ITV's Cold Feet clawed back some viewers from BBC1's Kingsley Amis adaptation Take a Girl Like You.

Cold Feet averaged 8.8m, up by 600,000 compared to last Sunday, while Take a Girl Like You was down by 1.3m, to 4.3m, on its second outing.

Elsewhere on Sunday night, Channel 5 documentary The Third Reich in Colour, presented by Evening Standard editor Max Hastings, took 1.3m and a 5% share from 8-9pm.

webTitle: Paratroopers charged with Kosovo killing

fields.headline: Paratroopers charged with Kosovo killing
fields.trailText: Three British paratroopers have been charged with killing two Albanians in Kosovo last year, the ministry of defence said today.
fields.body:
Three British paratroopers have been charged with killing two Albanians in Kosovo last year, the ministry of defence said today.

The soldiers, from the 1st battalion of the parachute regiment, allegedly shot two men during a Kosovo Albanian victory parade in Pristina on July 3 last year.

Fahri Bici, 20, and Avni Dudi, 24, the dead men, were believed to be members of the Kososvo Liberation Army.

The soldiers were charged by the army's legal service following an investigation by the royal military police. However, the final decision involved local prosecutors in the Kosovan capital, Pristina, appointed by the United Nations.

The men, who have not been named, will remain in service pending a court martial.

Iain Duncan Smith, the Tory defence spokesman, said it was "an utterly disgraceful move" to charge the soldiers.

The MoD are unable to specify what charges the men face.

webTitle: The NHS winter crisis explained

fields.headline: The NHS winter crisis explained
fields.standfirst: The government is giving details of its battleplan for averting a shortage of beds and health workers. Simon Jeffery explains why.
fields.trailText: The government is giving details of its battleplan for averting a shortage of beds and health workers. Simon Jeffery explains why.
fields.body:
What crisis?
The prime minister, Tony Blair, has joined health experts in predicting that the health service faces a "tough" winter. Many fear it will be unable to cope with the expected level of illness.

Is it anything to do with the flu?
Partly. Last winter's bout brought the NHS to a near standstill - and last January, there were reports of less than 30 emergency beds across the country. But the problem is the lack of beds as opposed to the people who fill them.

So how few beds are there?
Hospitals operate close to full capacity. A decade ago, about 75% of beds in emergency wards were regularly occupied. Before the last crisis more than 95% were and, thanks to funding cuts, London had lost approximately 40% of its acute beds since 1982 - a figure reflected nationwide. Overall, the average daily number of available beds continued to decrease, falling by 2.0% from 190,000 in 1998-99 to 186,000 in 1999-00.

Is the government doing anything about it?
Yes. There are 6,000 more nurses and just under 1,500 more acute beds than this time last year but, as Mr Blair points out, capacity needs to increase "year on year" to really make a difference.

It sounds like a perpetual crisis. What makes it worse in winter?
Old people struggle in winter. The poorest cannot afford to adequately heat their homes and even those with a higher standard of living are susceptible to flu, which can prove fatal in the elderly and infirm.

What about immunisation?
The government has offered a flu vaccine to all people aged 65-plus and to those with underlying conditions such as respiratory, heart and kidney disease. However, flu is a virus and if it mutates into a new strain this winter the vaccine (which protects against Panama A, Caledonia A and Yamanashi B on the world health organisation's advice) will not work. To this end, the Department of Health's winter and emergency services capacity planning team has been making contingency plans since May.

Critics claim that the health service is hampered by an inefficient internal market. But the NHS is also held back by a lack of cooperation with other care organisations. For example, some elderly patients who medically fit for discharge stay in hospital beds longer than they need because there is a lack of funding for residential care.

More money and more resources have been allocated in an unprecedented effort to stave off the annual crisis but it takes several years to change an organisation as huge, vital and underfunded as the NHS.

Last winter's bout brought the NHS to a near standstill - and last January, there were reports of less than 30 emergency beds across the country. webTitle: Milburn warns of winter crisis despite plans to ease NHS strain

fields.headline: Milburn warns of winter crisis despite plans to ease NHS strain
fields.trailText: The Health Secretary, Alan Milburn, yesterday braced the nation for another winter crisis and will announce plans to delay non-emergency surgery, increase the number of hospital beds and deploy the private sector to take the strain.
fields.body:
The Health Secretary, Alan Milburn, yesterday braced the nation for another winter crisis and will announce plans to delay non-emergency surgery, increase the number of hospital beds and deploy the private sector to take the strain.

Mr Milburn said: "There will undoubtedly be problems in the NHS despite our best efforts."

Tony Blair will be presented with the plans by the new NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp at a meeting in Downing Street attended by doctors and nurses. Mr Crisp will report that an extra 343 critical care beds have been made available to deal with the crisis, a reversal of the trend over the past 20 years. Britain still has the one of the lowest numbers of hospital beds - at fewer than five per 1,000 population, half that of France and Germany.

Mr Crisp will also report on the impact of the agreement to cooperate with the private sector. Plans have been made for home care packages to reduce the number of elderly people staying in hospital.

Ministers will also announce plans to give flu jabs to over 60% of 65-year-olds. They will also highlight the recent decision to allow the anti-flu drug Relenza to be prescribed as a sign of their determination to tackle the crisis.

However, the government also admitted yesterday there was a shortfall of 9,800 nurses. Plans to increase the pay of some nurses by £1,000 a year will not come in time for winter.

Labour regards the coming crisis as the probably last big political hurdle to overcome before it can confidently plump for a spring general election.

Senior strategists are terrified of stories of patients again waiting on hospital trolleys, fearing it could irretrievably damage the perceived competence of the government. The Conservatives have sent surveys to NHS trusts to find out whether they expect a crisis.

Speaking on the Dimbleby programme Mr Milburn said: "It takes three or four years to train a nurse, it takes a lot longer than that to train a doctor, it takes time to reverse what has been decades of neglect and under-investment."

He also admitted: "The waiting lists will probably rise over the winter [as] there are more emergency pressures, not just in this health care system but in every health care system in the world."

webTitle: Prime minister's speech on preparations for the NHS winter crisis

fields.headline: Blair: 'The NHS is going in the right direction'
fields.standfirst: The NHS is better prepared to deal with a winter crisis than ever before, says prime minister Tony Blair in a speech he gave today
fields.trailText: The NHS is better prepared to deal with a winter crisis than ever before, says prime minister Tony Blair in a speech he is to give today
fields.body:
Today Nigel Crisp [the NHS chief executive] has set out for people the comprehensive plans the NHS is taking to prepare for this winter.

Those plans involve:

First, a huge programme of health prevention with millions of the most elderly and vulnerable people getting flu jabs.

Second, the promotion of self care, with NHS Direct now national, giving everyone the chance to get free information and advice over the phone from a qualified nurse enabling more of us to look after ourselves at home.

Third, better working between hospitals, GPs and social services to improve rehabilitation services and provide more support for people to be cared for at home.

Fourth, increased beds in hospitals.

Fifth, extra nurses to staff the extra beds and services.

We are doing all in our power to see that the NHS doesn't just improve on last winter's performance, but reacts quickly to any problems that may arise.

Already compared with last winter we have:

 3.2m more doses of flu vaccine
 16m more people covered by NHS Direct
 2,900 more intensive home care packages on top of the 8,000 from the previous year
 1,350 more acute beds
 445 extra critical care beds
 over 6,000 more nurses, giving a total of 16,000 more since the election in 1997
 thousands more operations carried out in the private sector.

These increases are all the more welcome because I know that in very many areas they are being matched by improvements in service, as I saw for myself last week.

Specialist GPs in Bradford providing a wide range of diagnostic services and minor operations for their patients without them ever having to go near a hospital. The hospital in North Tyneside that is revolutionising the way that we provide emergency care in this country and slashing waiting times in the process.

I want to thank the staff in the NHS and social services for their commitment. I value the effort you put in day and day out and I recognise all the hard work that has gone into preparing for this winter.

We are matching your effort with increased resources, over £300m on winter pressures alone. And together, the effort, the money and the reforms are starting to produce results.

Today we are releasing figures that show waiting lists for October are down by 7,000. This is the eighth month in a row that that we have maintained our manifesto commitment. Of course, as we have said before, over the winter period there will be a switch of focus to treating emergency medical cases, which impacts on waiting lists for elective surgery. But the underlying trend is now firmly downwards.

Today also sees the publication of the latest figures on breast cancer referrals. 95% of women - over 5,500 a month - are now being seen within two weeks, when their GP decides that they need to be seen urgently.

None of this is easy. None of it will be perfect. During the winter, just as during any other part of the year, a massive organisation dealing with a million people a day will face problems. Under-investment over decades is not put right in 3 years - it takes years to train doctors and consultants. Until we have delivered the increases in capacity year on year for several more years there are bound to be pressures. And there will be cases where patients do not get the care they should. Medicine is not an exact science and sometimes mistakes will get made.

But let's praise our staff not demoralise them. Let's tell patients how good parts of the NHS are, not only how bad.

What I say to people is that the NHS is going in the right direction. It does have more money. It does have more doctors and nurses, with more on the way. It does have more beds. It does have better management. It does have detailed and well worked out plans for the winter. But inevitably the NHS is not yet the service patients would like it to be.

There is still a long way to go. But we will work with the brilliant staff of the NHS to give the people of Britain the standard of health care they deserve.

This winter whilst most of us are sitting down for our Christmas meal with the family, thousands of dedicated doctors, nurses, consultants, porters, cleaners, ambulance staff will be giving up their Christmas, missing their family, in order to serve the public and save lives.

They deserve our support and thanks.

So to sum up: there is more money; more nurses, more beds; there has been far more preparation; but there will be pressures and difficulties. But let us get a sense of balance, support the NHS staff who give a wonderful service to the majority of patients and not fall into the trap of saying that every time something goes wrong, the NHS is in crisis or on its knees. The glass is half full, not half empty.

webTitle: Hume quits assembly seat

fields.headline: Hume quits assembly seat
fields.standfirst:
Analysis: Hume goes without fuss
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The SDLP leader, John Hume, today stepped down from the Northern Ireland assembly.
fields.body:
The SDLP leader, John Hume, today stepped down from the Northern Ireland assembly.

The assembly's speaker, Lord Alderdice, confirmed that he had received a letter from the Nobel peace laureate announcing his decision.

The nationalist leader is expected to be replaced as the Assembly member for Foyle by Annie Courtney.

The assembly speaker told MLAs: "I have received a letter from John Hume, a member for Foyle, that he intends to resign his seat. Accordingly, as required by the Northern Ireland Act 1998, I have written to the chief electoral officer to inform him of the vacant seat."

Mr Hume had signalled earlier this year his intention to step down from the assembly when he believed its future was secure. He also explained that as an MP for Foyle and a Northern Ireland MEP, he needed to scale down his workload.

Mr Hume had been the MP for Foyle since 1983, when the constituency was created.

webTitle: Kosovo's love affair with Nato keeps tempers down

fields.headline: Kosovo's love affair with Nato keeps tempers down
fields.standfirst: With three British soldiers undergoing investigation for the deaths of two Kosovans, there's potential for more tension in the region, as Nicholas Wood explains from Pristina
fields.trailText: With three British soldiers undergoing investigation for the deaths of two Kosovans, there's potential for more tension in the region, as Nicholas Wood explains from Pristina.
fields.body:
When Avni Dudi, 24 and Fahri Bici, 20 were shot dead during street celebrations in Pristina, there was little doubt among the Kosovan Albanian majority population that British troops were responsible.

The pair were members of the Kosovo Liberation army and had been celebrating the ninth anniversary of universal declaration of independence.

The deaths came in both euphoric and chaotic aftermath of the end of the war in Kosovo.

Local journalists say that the men's commander, Remi Mustafa, was furious at the time, and demanded a full inquiry into the killing.

Sixteen months later, three men serving with the first battalion of the Parachute regiment are being investigated for the murder of the two men and malicious injury of three others. They have not been charged.

In spite of the criticism by the KLA of the deaths at the time, the reactions of most Albanians to the fact that an investigation is now under way seems to prove that respect for the Nato-lead force in the province remains high.

A team from the ministry of defence special investigation branch was in Pristina over the weekend to speak to witnesses. The three soldiers had the right to cross question those giving evidence, but Kfor spokesman have yet to confirm if the men were present.

At the time witnesses said the two men were shot after they were seen firing into the air in crowded street.

The three soldiers who are alleged to have fired at them, were over 100 metres away at the time.

Reaction to the investigation among Kosovo's Albanian press has been mute. No articles could be seen in today's papers. The view on the streets of Pristina was similary indifferent, with few people offering a comment.

Gazmend Syla, a reporter for the daily Kosova Sot says he remembers one of the victims' parents describing the deaths as tragic, but saying that Kfor was not to blame.

"Nato came here to liberate us and we have faith in them," says Syla. "Like the parents, I forgave them. I also have friends who were in the KLA and they had the same opinion."

His view is widely held in Kosovo. While many Kosovan Albanians have become increasing critical of the UN administration in the province, they are still grateful for Nato's intervention in the 1999 conflict with Serbia.

Much of the investigation will rest on the soldiers' rules of engagement, the code that is given to all troops operating in a situation where they are allowed to use their weapons.

The rules are printed on green card that dates back to March 1999. It says that soldiers can "open fire against an individual you believe is about to commit or is committing an act that is endangering life and there is no other way to prevent such an act."

The rules also state that soldiers should give a warning if the situation permits.

While the MoD has said that the investigation is politically sensitive, Syla maintains that interest in Kosovo is unlikely to be strong.

"It is a different time now than at the end of war, but still people are not too critical of Kfor." And he mentions the continuing popularity of US troops in the south east of Kosovo, despite the murder and rape of an 11 year old girl by a US army sergeant.

But he says that, if United Nations police were involved, the investigation might be more controversial. "People do not get too angry with Kfor, but with UNMIK police it is different" he notes.

It's a delicate situation that still has the potential to become even more fraught.

webTitle: Men on the verge of a nervous breakdown

fields.headline: Men on the verge of a nervous breakdown
fields.standfirst: Sid Lowe sees Luis Aragones lose his rag, Geremi lose favour, and Barca's comedy keeper lose the ball - on several occasions
fields.trailText: Sid Lowe sees Luis Aragones lose his rag, Geremi lose favour, and Barca's comedy keeper lose the ball - on several occasions
fields.body:
Luis Aragonés is what's known in the trade as 'a bit of a character' - in other words, he's a headcase. Throughout his coaching career, which has spanned 27 years and eight clubs, the Mallorca boss has never ceased to entertain. And this Sunday he was at it again when Mallorca travelled to La Romareda to face Real Zaragoza.

Alberto Luque had just scored a fabulous goal for the visitors to level the score at 1-1 when Aragonés struck. The veteran boss decided to replace Samuel Eto'o with Iovan Stankovic. The Cameroon forward - who's been pulled off more times than (actually, let's not go there) ... erm, has been subbed a lot this year - stomped off in a bit of a huff. Aragonés rushed over to the dug-out, grabbed the unhappy striker, and proceeded to shake him violently, screaming obscenities into his face from point-blank range. Unfortunately, CanalPlus couldn't get a microphone into the dug-out in time and Aragonés hasn't yet revealed exactly what he said. It's safe to assume, though, that the Mallorca boss - as swearing in Spain dictates - defecated on the striker's mother who, in his opinion, resorts to the oldest profession in order to make money.

Eto'o has since told the press that his days at Mallorca are over. Bizarrely enough, though, the forward - who claims to have been substituted when he "hasn't even been tired" (yes, there's a reason for that, Samuel) - attributed his decision to his lack of minutes, not his manager's all-too-public outburst.

Luis Aragonés isn't the first coach who's needed to deal with internal disputes this year. Earlier in the season, the Man in the Moustache was faced with a dressing room rebellion over Real Madrid's treatment of Steve McManaman. And just a couple of weeks back Deportivo La Coruña's Moroccan centre-back Nourredine Naybet responded to accusations of laziness by telling coach Javier Irureta to "go and take it up the arse." The coaches' reactions have been getting progressively funnier: del Bosque rather boringly backed down, Irureta responded by saying "No, you go and take it up the arse", and now this. Whatever next? Lorenzo Serra Ferrer finally losing his patience and attacking comedy keeper Richard Dutruel with a pair of scissors? Poor old Dutruel. The man whose dreadful hairstyle is matched only by his goalkeeping skills has had a terrible season. And just when it looked like things couldn't get any worse, they did - Barcelona travelled to Vigo on Saturday night to take on Dutruel's ex-club, Celta.

But for the lone Galician with a megaphone and an inexhaustible reserve of energy chanting "Vee-go, Vee-go" throughout, the Balaídos crowd was unusually subdued. Except, that is, whenever the French keeper - who agreed to go to Barça last year despite being under contract at Celta - got the ball. Then the crowd erupted into whistles and boos. The whistles turned to howls of laughter just before half time when Dutruel challenged Catanha for a cross, dropped the ball (no surprise there), and twisted his knee - falling to the floor in a ridiculously exaggerated and delayed fashion - a la Paul Alcock. The ordeal didn't end there, either. Over-zealous officials insisted on carrying Dutruel off on one of those electric car-type 'stretchers'. And they took the long way round the running track, too, kindly giving every single Celta fan the chance to have a good laugh at the forlorn figure from close-up.

Surprise, surprise - the departure of Dutruel heralded a significant improvement in Barcelona's fortunes. 3-1 down to a Catanha hat-trick when he left, Lorenzo Serra Ferrer's side threw caution to the wind in the second half and managed to bring the score level at 3-3, Rivaldo setting up both for Patrik Kluivert. Best of all for the culés, though, was the return from injury of inspirational captain Pep Guardiola. Meanwhile, teenage keeper José Reina was delighted to make his Barça debut, and told the press that his "dad'll be pretty pleased too." His dad might get to see a bit more of him, Dutruel is out until February at least.

Another injury returnee delighting fans is Deportivo La Coruña's Brazilian superstar Djalminha. Last week's hero turned in another sensational performance as Depor ran out 2-0 winners at the Olympic stadium against Espanyol - the Brazilian creating the second for Roy Makaay with yet another sublime touch. Djalminha's return is bound to be a huge boost for Depor as they prepare for this week's trip to Milan. An even bigger boost came in the shape of draw specialists Valladolid, who held Mendieta-less Valencia to 0-0 at the weekend. The result leaves Depor top, two points clear. Valencia boss Héctor Cúper admitted that his side "missed" their captain, but insisted that his absence was no excuse enough for such a "poor performance".

Samuel Eto'o isn't the only unhappy Cameroon international in Spain. Real Madrid full-back Geremi bore the brunt of the criticism after his side's Intercontinental defeat in Japan on Tuesday and claims that the constant attacks have left him feeling like the club's "ugly duckling". Luckily for Geremi, the Man in the Moustache has shown his caring side, refusing to join the chorus of abuse and insisting that "I still believe in him as a person and as a player". Kind words, but they didn't prevent Geremi from turning in another dreadful performance against Osasuna in Vitoria on Saturday night. To be fair, the "bull", as Martín Posse so eloquently put it last week, wasn't alone. Madrid were uninspiring throughout, but were rescued by Iván Helguera's last-minute goal and ran out 3-2 winners. Fernando Hierro breathed a particularly big sigh of relief - the Madrid captain had missed his second (and Madrid's third) penalty of the season. Spot-kicks may well be yet another responsibility dumped on Luis Figo's increasingly over-loaded shoulders.

The defeat leaves Osasuna bottom, just one point behind Racing Santander - who were beaten 4-1 at fourth-placed Rayo Vallecano - and three behind Real Sociedad, who drew 1-1 with Las Palmas. The day's Basque derbi was a typically bruising encounter - two red cards (including Bilbao's physio) and nine yellows. It finished with Alavés beating Athletic Bilbao for the first time in 70 years by 2-1. It wasn't quite so much fun over in Villarreal, where Numancia drew 0-0, but there was plenty of excitement in Oviedo. Radi Antic's side remain invincible at the New Carlos Tartiere - 2-1 down with two minutes to go, goals from Victor Onopko and a sensational free-kick from Djorje Tomic brought their sixth win in seven home matches.

Meanwhile, in Guatemala, Spain have just won the Fútbol Sala World Cup. Now, for the uninitiated, Fútbol Sala is basically indoor football with handball-style goals and a ball that doesn't bounce - indeed, ex-Real Oviedo brummie superstar Keith Thompson once aptly described the ball as being "like a pudding." Anyway, Spain ran out 4-3 winners against three-times world champions Brazil, with a goal 29 seconds from full time by Javi Rodríguez. The real star of the show, though, was Spanish goalie Jesús Clavería, whose display was described by sports daily Marca as "providential" (Jesús, providential, geddit? ho ho). With two keepers out injured and the transfer window fast approaching, Lorenzo Serra Ferrer might just have taken note.
fields.bodyText: Luis Aragonés is what's known in the trade as 'a bit of a character' - in other words, he's a headcase. Throughout his coaching career, which has spanned 27 years and eight clubs, the Mallorca boss has never ceased to entertain. And this Sunday he was at it again when Mallorca travelled to La Romareda to face Real Zaragoza. Alberto Luque had just scored a fabulous goal for the visitors to level the score at 1-1 when Aragonés struck. The veteran boss decided to replace Samuel Eto'o with Iovan Stankovic. The Cameroon forward - who's been pulled off more times than (actually, let's not go there) ... erm, has been subbed a lot this year - stomped off in a bit of a huff. Aragonés rushed over to the dug-out, grabbed the unhappy striker, and proceeded to shake him violently, screaming obscenities into his face from point-blank range. Unfortunately, CanalPlus couldn't get a microphone into the dug-out in time and Aragonés hasn't yet revealed exactly what he said. It's safe to assume, though, that the Mallorca boss - as swearing in Spain dictates - defecated on the striker's mother who, in his opinion, resorts to the oldest profession in order to make money. Eto'o has since told the press that his days at Mallorca are over. Bizarrely enough, though, the forward - who claims to have been substituted when he "hasn't even been tired" (yes, there's a reason for that, Samuel) - attributed his decision to his lack of minutes, not his manager's all-too-public outburst. Luis Aragonés isn't the first coach who's needed to deal with internal disputes this year. Earlier in the season, the Man in the Moustache was faced with a dressing room rebellion over Real Madrid's treatment of Steve McManaman. And just a couple of weeks back Deportivo La Coruña's Moroccan centre-back Nourredine Naybet responded to accusations of laziness by telling coach Javier Irureta to "go and take it up the arse." The coaches' reactions have been getting progressively funnier: del Bosque rather boringly backed down, Irureta responded by saying "No, you go and take it up the arse", and now this. Whatever next? Lorenzo Serra Ferrer finally losing his patience and attacking comedy keeper Richard Dutruel with a pair of scissors? Poor old Dutruel. The man whose dreadful hairstyle is matched only by his goalkeeping skills has had a terrible season. And just when it looked like things couldn't get any worse, they did - Barcelona travelled to Vigo on Saturday night to take on Dutruel's ex-club, Celta. But for the lone Galician with a megaphone and an inexhaustible reserve of energy chanting "Vee-go, Vee-go" throughout, the Balaídos crowd was unusually subdued. Except, that is, whenever the French keeper - who agreed to go to Barça last year despite being under contract at Celta - got the ball. Then the crowd erupted into whistles and boos. The whistles turned to howls of laughter just before half time when Dutruel challenged Catanha for a cross, dropped the ball (no surprise there), and twisted his knee - falling to the floor in a ridiculously exaggerated and delayed fashion - a la Paul Alcock. The ordeal didn't end there, either. Over-zealous officials insisted on carrying Dutruel off on one of those electric car-type 'stretchers'. And they took the long way round the running track, too, kindly giving every single Celta fan the chance to have a good laugh at the forlorn figure from close-up. Surprise, surprise - the departure of Dutruel heralded a significant improvement in Barcelona's fortunes. 3-1 down to a Catanha hat-trick when he left, Lorenzo Serra Ferrer's side threw caution to the wind in the second half and managed to bring the score level at 3-3, Rivaldo setting up both for Patrik Kluivert. Best of all for the culés, though, was the return from injury of inspirational captain Pep Guardiola. Meanwhile, teenage keeper José Reina was delighted to make his Barça debut, and told the press that his "dad'll be pretty pleased too." His dad might get to see a bit more of him, Dutruel is out until February at least. Another injury returnee delighting fans is Deportivo La Coruña's Brazilian superstar Djalminha. Last week's hero turned in another sensational performance as Depor ran out 2-0 winners at the Olympic stadium against Espanyol - the Brazilian creating the second for Roy Makaay with yet another sublime touch. Djalminha's return is bound to be a huge boost for Depor as they prepare for this week's trip to Milan. An even bigger boost came in the shape of draw specialists Valladolid, who held Mendieta-less Valencia to 0-0 at the weekend. The result leaves Depor top, two points clear. Valencia boss Héctor Cúper admitted that his side "missed" their captain, but insisted that his absence was no excuse enough for such a "poor performance". webTitle: Easing the pressure on Managers Day

fields.headline: Easing the pressure on Managers Day
fields.trailText: Perhaps the Italian government should give some thought to sponsoring a national Managers Day. Just 24 hours where the tifosi can give thanks to the men they spend the other 364 days of the year lambasting. Every family could have a meal, for example, with a joint of meat in the shape of their local coach, and at the end of the meal, a toast: "Here's to Marco Tardelli, and all who train with him!" It would be lovely.
fields.body:
Perhaps the Italian government should give some thought to sponsoring a national Managers Day. Just 24 hours where the tifosi can give thanks to the men they spend the other 364 days of the year lambasting. Every family could have a meal, for example, with a joint of meat in the shape of their local coach, and at the end of the meal, a toast: "Here's to Marco Tardelli, and all who train with him!" It would be lovely.

Being realistic, however, this past weekend's activity is about as close as calcio's under-pressure coaches will ever get to a day of back-slapping. The bosses under most pressure in Serie A all managed a result of some sort, with Tardelli leading the way. His Inter side came back from two goals down to grab a draw with Juventus in the San Siro.

The bianconeri established their lead early on. David Trezeguet, recalled at the expense of Filippo Inzaghi, opened the scoring in the seventh minute, finishing well from a through-ball by Alessandro Del Piero. Zinedine Zidane doubled the score only three minutes later, punishing a weak clearance from Matteo Ferrari and firing in from 25 yards.

But within another three minutes Inter were back in it as a third French international, Laurent Blanc, headed in an Alvaro Recoba corner. In the remainder of a frenetic first half, Christian Vieri had a goal disallowed and Del Piero had two good chances for the visitors. But Inter finally levelled the scores in the 68th minute - Luigi Di Biagio smashing home a free kick from 30 yards.

After the game, Tardelli was upbeat. "For some periods of the match I finally saw a good Inter," he said. "I'm happy with the reaction I got, and I was sure my team could get something out of the game, even after Zidane scored." The result moves Inter up to ninth in the table, four points behind Juve.

Another coach savouring the moment yesterday was Napoli boss Emiliano Mondonico, who saw his team, rock bottom of Serie A at the start of the weekend, record their first league win of the season. Admittedly it was only a 1-0 win at home over second-bottom side Bari, but Nicola Amoruso's decisive strike on the stroke of half-time was greeted rapturously by over 40,000 fans at the San Paolo stadium. Unfortunately, the same crowd subjected Bari's Phil Masinga to racist abuse throughout the game, not the first such incident this season.

With his Milan team still in the Champions League, and only a few points off leaders Roma, Alberto Zaccheroni might not be the most obvious candidate for the sack, but the pressure is on the Rossoneri boss after a string of indifferent league results. So it was with some relief that he welcomed Andrei Shevchenko's eighth league goal of the season, which proved enough for an away victory over high-flying Udinese.

"This was our best match of the season!" said an excited Zacc, who also saw Shevchenko become the second player in a week, after Celta Vigo's Valeri Karpin, to gain the status of an EU national.

Shevchenko's rival for the Serie A golden boot, Gabriel Batistuta, failed to make his mark this weekend as Roma could only draw 0-0 away at Perugia. Parma closed the gap at the top on Saturday, beating second-placed Atlanta 2-0 with goals from Sabri Lamouchi and Sergio Conceicao.

Lazio also recorded a Saturday win, defeating Reggina 2-0 at the Olympic Stadium. It's Leeds next for the embattled Sven Goran Eriksson, but on national manager's day, who cares?
