webTitle: Analysis: BSE causes rare agreement in Europe

fields.headline: BSE causes rare agreement in Europe
fields.standfirst:
European Union agriculture minister seldom agree about anything but action against BSE is an exception, writes Derek Brown

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: 4 December: European Union agriculture minister seldom agree about anything but action against BSE is an exception, writes Derek Brown
fields.body:
European Union agriculture ministers are meeting in Brussels today against a familiar background of crisis but in a rare spirit of agreement.

They are expected to approve tough controls to quell public anxiety over the spread of BSE, mad cow disease, and its human equivalent, new variant CJD.

The ministers are already broadly agreed on the main measure needed to reassure the public: a ban on animal feedstuffs containing meat and bonemeal (MBM). They will also bar all cattle over 30 months old from the food chain, unless rigorously tested for BSE. A third measure will specify the material which must be removed from carcasses before sale: the intestines, brain, spleen and spinal cord.

The 15 farm ministries represented at the meeting are all subject to vociferous lobbying by their own national farm organisations. But on this issue they have been driven by a common interest in damping down the near-hysteria which has swept the EU following the latest discoveries of BSE-infected cattle in France, Germany, and Spain. In health-obsessed France in particular, there has been a widespread boycott of all beef products.

The new regulations provide an interesting illustration of how the EU can, occasionally at least, subordinate narrow national interests to the common good. The proposals were drafted by the European commission's veterinary committee, drawing on expertise from throughout the union.

They have been minutely examined by the national delegations in Brussels as well as ministries in the member states' capitals. There will have been hours of detailed bilateral and multinational negotiations among Brussels-based diplomats, as they honed the proposals to be put before their ministers and ironed out any differences of views in advance.

Such delicate diplomatic manoeuvres are frequently clouded by national interest, and naked political opportunism. During the Thatcher years in particular, diplomats of UKREP - the inelegantly titled UK representative office in Brussels - lived in dread of appearing to cooperate too closely with their continental colleagues.

More recently, the British government has resisted strident Tory and tabloid calls for a retaliatory unilateral ban on imports of French beef. Had it given way to that pressure, the government would have almost certainly sparked a series of national bans and boycotts, and made today's agreement impossible.

As it is, the likely common stance on regulation of the trade is a rare example of agreement across the spectrum of European interests. It is also an illustration of how real power in the union lies not with the commission, but with the council of ministers - that is, in the national capitals.

webTitle: How older people benefit from the NHS plan

fields.headline: How older people benefit from the NHS plan
fields.standfirst: Plans to revamp the health service focus on improving life for the elderly, writes Sophie Petit-Zeman
fields.trailText: Plans to revamp the health service focus on improving life for the elderly, writes Sophie Petit-Zeman
fields.body:
At the heart of the NHS plan is its aim to improve services for older people, as one in five people in England is over 60, and over-60s are the largest users of the health service.

How will older people benefit from the plan?
A new tier of services called "intermediate care", which focus on rehabilitation and home care, is to be delivered jointly by health and social services. An extra 6,700 hospital beds are to be available by 2004.

In Yorkshire, councils and health authorities have a pooled annual budget of £681,000 to support rehabilitation units such as Scarborough's Homeward unit. Rosemary Archer, social services director at North Yorkshire county council, said: "Older people made it clear they wanted us to help them return home. These schemes help avoid unnecessary admission to hospital or permanent residential and nursing care."

However, for those who do need those services, the plan pledged that "funding of long term care is fair and promotes rather than obstructs good partnership working across health and social services".

What are the changes?
 From April 2001, means testing will disregard property value for three months after admission to residential care, so that people can return home
 Capital limits set in 1996 will dictate how much older people can contribute to residential care. Councils will not contribute to care if patients have assets worth more than £18,000
 Councils will standardise the cost of home care
 A national service framework is to regulate services from 2001. A national care standards commission will take over in April 2002
 Residential allowance for new care home residents will be stopped and resources will be transferred to local councils
 Local councils become responsible for assessment, care management and financial support of anyone who went into residential care before April 1993. Only in exceptional cases will people be moved against their wishes and councils will be able to protect against eviction those who can't pay fees
 A new grant supporting local authority loans aims to avoid the politically sensitive issue of houses being sold during people's lifetime to meet long-term care costs
 The government plans to consider regulating long-term care insurance
 By April 2002 there will be a single assessment for health and social care agreed locally. This will initially be for the most vulnerable such as those living alone, recently bereaved, recently discharged from hospital or entering residential or nursing care. During 2002, personal care plans will be agreed for everyone in this group. The plans will detail health and social care packages, care coordinators, monitoring arrangements and a list of key contacts. Providers, users and carers will be involved in agreeing the plans and there is talk of coordination by nurse consultants or specialist nurses

webTitle: Christmas rail schedules still mired in doubt

fields.headline: Christmas rail schedules still mired in doubt
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: The complete Christmas rail timetable - due to be published in its entirety today - will be delayed for up to a week, it has been announced.
fields.body:
The complete Christmas rail timetable - due to be published in its entirety today - will be delayed for up to a week, it has been announced.

The Great North Eastern Railway (GNER) and the two Connex companies have failed to meet the deadline to publish details of their holiday services.

GNER, which runs trains from London to Yorkshire, Newcastle and Edinburgh, says it needs another week to produce its Christmas timetable. The company has suffered some of the worst track-replacement problems since the fatal Hatfield derailment involving one of its trains.

Connex says that details of its South Eastern services to Brighton will be only partly available, as will those of South Central trains into London.

"The Brighton services are still a bit iffy, but as you don't have to book in advance like the long distance journeys they don't pose such a problem for people planning their Christmas travel arrangements," said a spokeswoman for the Association of Train Operating Companies (ATOC).

Other train companies, such as Virgin and Midland Mainline, will be offering a comprehensive timetable, allowing passengers to plan their travel arrangements in good time.

George Muir, ATOC's director-general, acknowledged that the Christmas timetable was not complete. "It's not a full timetable, but my information is that all train operators, all mainline inter-city train operators have their timetables in the systems, and it is possible to book for all the inter-city operators now for Christmas," he said.

Mr Muir warned that the current problems might drag on into March but added that the bulk of repairs should be finished by the end of January. "The critical thing I think when we look forward is the January timetable, because that is going to show the extent to which we have been able to get back to normal."

The Christmas period covers trains running up to January 7. Information will be posted on ATOC'S rail enquiries website and be available on its phone line.

Journey times for up to the end of January are not expected to be available for another couple of weeks.

fields.body:
Tim Southwell, the former editor of Loaded, is seeking funding for a new venture called Keep Yourself Nice (KYN), encompassing magazines, internet and TV.

L90, the US online advertising outfit has parted company with its UK managing director Jane Henley.

Former Vogue associate publisher Tess Macleod-Smith has been appointed commercial director of the National Magazine Company.

Dene Stuart has resigned as The Mirror's sales director to joint the internet outfit Yava.

ClaraNet, the free internet service provider, is holding discussions with agencies about its media contract.

Real Media is to jump on the email marketing bandwagon by launching a European service in January.

NTL has made 40 staff redundant from its 200-strong standalone interactive division.

Adlink has landed the advertising sales contract for Autotrader.com.

Emap Advertising has hired Manchester-based Media Sales Network to manage its agency sales activities in regions outside London.

Michael Winkler, European media director of Gillette Group, has launched an attack on the internet as an advertising medium, at Adlink's European Online Planning seminar.

Optimedia has snapped up the £3.5m media planning and buying account for Think Tools.

The Economist is launching a bound-in supplement called Technology Quarterly (TQ) to give its readers information on emerging technologies.

Manning Gottlieb Media has won the account for coffee-shop chain Starbucks.

webTitle: Voluntary sector hit by skills shortage

fields.headline: Voluntary sector hit by skills shortage
fields.standfirst: National voluntary body calls for a new approach to training if government demands are to be met
fields.trailText: National voluntary body calls for a new approach to training if government demands are to be met, writes Liza Ramrayka
fields.body:
Voluntary organisations desperately need access to low-cost and flexible training if they are to continue to meet government demands, says a consultation paper from the national body set up to identify and meet training needs for the voluntary sector.

The government's social inclusion agenda looks to voluntary organisations to involve marginalised groups. Yet many voluntary organisations are finding that lack of resources - both human and financial - combined with the demands of service provision prevent them from developing the staff skills and providing the personal development opportunities which are key to meeting the government's goals.

The draft workforce development plan, produced by the Voluntary Sector National Training Organisation (VSNTO), outlines the skills shortages and recommends how to address these problems.

According to the report, one pressure point has been the government's increasing emphasis on partnership work to deliver initiatives in the fields of social care, health, regeneration and employment. Another is the trend for income to be related to specific, often short-term, projects which results in organisations having to meet differing demands from funders in terms of quality and monitoring systems.

Research by the VSNTO shows that the biggest skills gaps for paid staff relate to fundraising, management and IT. Communication skills and IT are the main skills gaps among volunteers. In a separate study by London Boroughs Grants, 84% of organisations identified cost and 65% identified lack of time as a barrier to learning.

The draft plan is out for consultation until December 22 and comes in advance of the new national and local Learning and Skills Councils. From next year, these will encourage new types of learning providers - including the voluntary and community sectors - to apply for funding to deliver solutions based on learning. These could include on-the-job or internet-based training. The plan also recommends that regional development agencies provide funding to support skills development managers in each region, who will promote development and accreditation.

Ben Kernighan, head of the VSNTO in England, is keen for the sector to feed into this process and respond to the plan. "This is a window of opportunity to influence people in new roles by making them aware of the barriers to training, and highlighting the sector's role in promoting equality of opportunity and social inclusion," he said.

One initiative aimed at addressing these skills shortages is Project 2001. Set up in 1998 by the Royal Society for the Encouragement of the Arts, Manufactures and Commerce, the project provides small voluntary organisations with financial support and advice to enable them to recognise and accredit the skills of their paid staff and volunteers.

More than 200 organisations in the pilot regions of London and Yorkshire and Humberside have benefited from contributions of up to £1,000 towards training costs, access to up to three days' worth of advice from an accreditation adviser or information about qualifications.

Key partners in the project include the VSNTO and the National Association of Councils for Voluntary Service, which supports the network of more than 250 councils for voluntary service responsible for developing the sector at local level.

A survey of participating organisations shows the positive impact of intervention with financial and other resources. One in nine say they now have more motivated staff and volunteers, while a similar number say that their customer service has improved. Significantly, one in eight have developed new links as a result of working on training and accreditation, and many have been able to access further grants as a result of receiving one from Project 2001.

Project 2001 director Janet Fleming believes this evidence makes a persuasive argument for funding learning in the sector, and adds that funders should be willing to support these costs as part of their project funding. "It is essential that money is spent on giving structured support to the sector through training," she said.

webTitle: Tough competition for graduates

fields.headline: Tough competition for graduates
fields.standfirst: Radhika Holmstrom reports on graduate training opportunities in the voluntary sector
fields.trailText: Radhika Holmstrom reports on graduate training opportunities in the voluntary sector
fields.body:
If you're in further education, the voluntary sector is one of the hardest areas to find your first job. Big commercial companies run well-advertised, well-funded graduate trainee schemes. The public sector is working hard to attract graduates to train as nurses, teachers and police officers. But very few charities offer a similar combination of placements, support and pay.

A couple of voluntary sector organisations do have direct access schemes, although they can be quite hard to find. Christian Aid has been running one for over three years, paying around £8,000 (plus London weighting) over 11 months. Degrees are not always required, but in practice it's pretty well a graduate scheme. Specific posts are advertised directly, and competition is stiff - there are usually more than a hundred applications for each placement.

Most of the nine current placements are in the charity's international department, where the scheme started off. Others are in the Ireland team and the library. Christian Aid aims to give interns "broad experience" and a "solid work foundation" that they can build on. They each get a mentor, an individual work plan, regular reviews and help with moving on afterwards. Previous interns have mainly stayed within the development field, at this or other organisations.

The Imperial Cancer Research Fund runs two schemes. One is specifically for scientists. The other, which only started this year, is in ICRF's fundraising directorate. This is a two-year programme with a salary that staff describe as "comparable to other graduate schemes in the private sector". It, too, is hard to get onto. ICRF has put a lot of effort into attracting applicants, with comprehensive, glossy publicity targeted at "high-calibre, business-minded individuals". The five graduates now in place were picked from hundreds.

Training programmes are tailored "as far as possible" to individuals. ICRF's fundraising directorate includes communications and PR, regional fundraising, marketing and retail. Each trainee does several placements, of a few months each, in different departments. The charity aims to offer permanent posts to "successful" trainees.

Apart from these two schemes, there's very little funded training on offer. The NSPCC has run graduate fundraising traineeships in the past, which were paid "at the lower end of the scale" (the NSPCC pays pretty well, compared with other charities) but these are on hold at the moment.

If you have previous work experience, especially if you are a mature student, the South Bank University's part-time postgraduate degree courses (charity marketing and fundraising, charity accounting and financial management, and charity management) may be an option. The organisation Working for a Charity offers training and placements. The Open University also has courses on voluntary sector management, ranging from certificate level through to an MBA. Otherwise, most careers and recruitment offices recommend building on your existing degree and interests with volunteering.

Volunteering can be a very good way to build up your skills, but only as long as you are somewhere that takes volunteers seriously. Look for an organisation that employs a "volunteer co-ordinator" if possible. Oxfam's "trainee programme" only pays expenses, but it aims to take between 40 and 60 trainees, both current students and graduates. They work part-time or full-time for four to 12 months in a wide range of areas. Some placements are advertised externally, but it is worth contacting the personnel department directly as well.

Because so many people want to work in this sector, all types of placements are intensely over-subscribed. However, students are under increasing pressure to move straight from university to a well-paid job with some security. Other sectors offer access, training and transferable pay scales. If graduates decide to go down these routes, many will stay there. And, in the long run, the voluntary sector may well lose out.

webTitle: The NHS winter crisis explained

fields.headline: The NHS winter crisis
fields.standfirst:
The government is giving details of its battleplan for averting a shortage of beds and health workers. Simon Jeffery explains why

Society Guardian
fields.trailText: The government is giving details of its battleplan for averting a shortage of beds and health workers. We explain why.
fields.body:
What crisis?
The prime minister, Tony Blair, has joined health experts in predicting that the health service faces a "tough" winter. Many fear it will be unable to cope with the expected level of illness.

Is it anything to do with the flu?
Partly. Last winter's bout brought the NHS to a near standstill - and last January, there were reports of less than 30 emergency beds across the country. But the problem is the lack of beds as opposed to the people who fill them.

So how few beds are there?
Hospitals operate close to full capacity. A decade ago, about 75% of beds in emergency wards were regularly occupied. Before the last crisis more than 95% were and, thanks to funding cuts, London had lost approximately 40% of its acute beds since 1982 - a figure reflected nationwide. Overall, the average daily number of available beds continued to decrease, falling by 2.0% from 190,000 in 1998-99 to 186,000 in 1999-00.

Is the government doing anything about it?
Yes. There are 6,000 more nurses and just under 1,500 more acute beds than this time last year but, as Mr Blair points out, capacity needs to increase "year on year" to really make a difference.

It sounds like a perpetual crisis. What makes it worse in winter?
Old people struggle in winter. The poorest cannot afford to adequately heat their homes and even those with a higher standard of living are susceptible to flu, which can prove fatal in the elderly and infirm.

What about immunisation?
The government has offered a flu vaccine to all people aged 65-plus and to those with underlying conditions such as respiratory, heart and kidney disease. However, flu is a virus and if it mutates into a new strain this winter the vaccine (which protects against Panama A, Caledonia A and Yamanashi B on the world health organisation's advice) will not work. To this end, the Department of Health's winter and emergency services capacity planning team has been making contingency plans since May.

Could the NHS organise itself better?
Critics claim that the health service is hampered by an inefficient internal market. But the NHS is also held back by a lack of cooperation with other care organisations. For example, some elderly patients who medically fit for discharge stay in hospital beds longer than they need because there is a lack of funding for residential care.

More money and more resources have been allocated in an unprecedented effort to stave off the annual crisis but it takes several years to change an organisation as huge, vital and underfunded as the NHS.

webTitle: Charities the Guardian is supporting: Refuge

fields.headline: Charities the Guardian is supporting: Refuge
fields.standfirst: Income faltering as demands grow on mid-range charities
fields.trailText: Refuge is a lifeline for thousands of women and children in Britain for whom emotional and physical abuse is part of everyday life.
fields.body:
Refuge is a lifeline for thousands of women and children in Britain for whom emotional and physical abuse is part of everyday life.

Since opening the world's first women's refuge 29 years ago in London, the charity has led the struggle against domestic violence, providing support and raising awareness.

One in four women will experience physical abuse at the hands of a partner during her lifetime. Five thousand women seek help from Refuge every week by calling the charity's 24-hour National Domestic Violence Helpline. The service, which costs £550,000 a year and depends on charitable donations, is stretched beyond its limits. It is able to deal with just a fifth of the calls it receives each week.

Refuge also operates a network of safe houses and provides outreach services for women from minority ethnic groups.

 Refuge has no website; its telephone number is 020 7395 7700

fields.standfirst: Sophie Petit-Zeman looks at how the NHS plan fosters the relationship between health and social services
fields.trailText: Sophie Petit-Zeman looks at how the NHS plan fosters the relationship between health and social services.
fields.body:
The NHS plan pledges to join up health and social services by "removing the outdated institutional barriers between health and social care which have got in the way of people getting the care they need when they need it".

The Health Act 1999 removed legal obstacles to joint working and thus underpins much of the plan. For the first time, social services and the NHS are expected to have pooled budgets for a variety of services. Schemes covering budgets of more than £200m are already up and running but these benefit only a small minority of patients.

The plan requires that joint budget powers are applied across the country. Social care will be delivered in new settings such as GP surgeries. "Local care networks" of social service staff, GPs and other primary and community health teams will jointly assess patients' needs. An extra £900m has been allocated in 2003-04 for personal care plans, espcially for older people.

The plan also picks up recommendations in the act to merge the commissioning services of local and health authorities. Either authority can now take the lead to provide "one-stop care packages" on behalf of both services.

The commission for health improvement, the audit commission and the social services inspectorate will monitor health and social care organisations, charting the progress of joint working. The targets include reducing delays in discharging older patients from hospital, reducing preventable emergency hospital admissions, readmitting older people and people with mental health problems and assessing older people's needs more rapidly.

Authorities which work together successfuly are given incentives to keep up progress. In social services, £50m a year will be available from April 2002 to reward improved joint working in 2001. From April 2003 this will rise to £100m. Grants will initially focus on intermediate care performance: those services which promote independence and improve quality of care for the elderly.

What are care trusts?
The plan expects all primary care groups to become trusts by Aprl 2004. Care trusts will be set up in areas where health and social services want to forge close partnerships. Single, multi-purpose legal bodies would be formed to commission care, and councils would be authorised to oversee the care trusts and decide where they are needed. The model for this idea is being enacted in Somerset, where the joint service provides a single care plan, a single key worker and a unified multi-disciplinary team to address the needs of each client.

webTitle: Charities the Guardian is supporting: Field

fields.headline: Charities the Guardian is supporting: Field
fields.standfirst: Field
fields.trailText: Formed in 1989 by a group of international lawyers to protect the global environment, Field recruits and trains young lawyers from around the   world and provides legal assistance to governments and non-governmental organisations.
fields.body:
Formed in 1989 by a group of international lawyers to protect the global environment, Field recruits and trains young lawyers from around the world and provides legal assistance to governments and non-governmental organisations.

For developing countries much of this legal support is free, the main aim being to protect a country's ecosystem from damage through commercial exploitation or pollution.

The legal team are drawn from a range of backgrounds and share the belief that the most pressing global environmental problems - climate change, loss of biodiversity, pollution of shared water resources and the thinning of the ozone layer - can best be tackled through development and implementation of international law.

Field programmes promote long-term strategic research and advice on biological diversity and marine resources, climate change and energy, and trade investment and sustainable development.

Its lawyers provided legal back-up for 42 countries from the Alliance of small island states (Aosis) at the Hague summit on climate change last month.

Field is holding a London briefing on 19 December on what really happened at the summit. Call 020-7637 7950 for details.

fields.headline: Charities the Guardian is supporting: Add
fields.standfirst: Action on Disability and Development
fields.trailText: When Lao Son was injured by a landmine, he lost much more than his sight and job. He was abandoned by his wife and children and he lost his name. To everyone in his village, he became "Avka" - blind man.
fields.body:
When Lao Son was injured by a landmine, he lost much more than his sight and job. He was abandoned by his wife and children and he lost his name. To everyone in his village, he became "Avka" - blind man.

But his skills and knowledge survived. His job as a surgical assistant in Kampong Speu, west Cambodia, allowed him to contribute to a tuberculosis self-help group. It changed the way the villagers saw him and they sought his advice. He is no longer called Avka.

The group was just one of thousands supported by Action on Disability and Development, which helps poor, disabled people improve their lives and society's attitude towards them in 12 of the poorest African and Asian countries. Founded in 1985, ADD helps disabled people's groups with equipment, training and seed money - there is a strong focus on disabled women, many of whom have been victims of sexual abuse.

Add also assists in lobbying governments to improve disabled people's rights. It supports groups such as Sudan's Kassala Society of the Disabled, which runs an orthopaedic workshop for landmine victims, staffed by disabled people.

fields.trailText: Founded in 1994, Place2Be offers emotional and therapeutic support to children in schools. Counsellors give private assistance to children with a wide range of behavioural problems. They offer children an adult to talk to who is neither teacher nor parent.
fields.body:
Founded in 1994, Place2Be offers emotional and therapeutic support to children in schools. Counsellors give private assistance to children with a wide range of behavioural problems. They offer children an adult to talk to who is neither teacher nor parent.

Counsellors help children with their emotional reactions to the trials of school years, including divorce, deprivation, abandonment, long-term illness in the family, domestic violence, homelessness, physical or sexual abuse, and the trauma of being a refugee.

Of the children seen last year, the charity reported a positive change in 82%, and no school dealing with Place2Be excluded a child.

By next September the charity hopes to be represented in 40 schools in the boroughs of Brent and Enfield in London, Medway in Kent, and in Nottingham.

Place2Be was a winner this year of the Guardian charity award for smaller organisations.

webTitle: Disasters spread as locals flout Beijing's law

fields.headline: Disasters spread as locals flout Beijing's law
fields.standfirst: Selfish interests cause deaths and damage the environment damage
fields.trailText: Selfish interests cause deaths and damage the environment damage
fields.body:
A series of disasters in China during the past week is further evidence of how local authorities flout Beijing's authority, often with fatal results.

Two mining accidents killed more than 60 workers in Yunnan and inner Mongolia, the latest in an industry which has defied repeated efforts by Beijing to close down dangerous locally owned mines.

Last year nearly 1,200 miners were reported killed in more than 70 recorded accidents. The full total is thought to be much higher.

Yesterday four people were arrested by the police in Dongguan, across the border from Hong Kong, after at least eight people died and 32 were injured when a shopping mall collapsed on Friday. Workers were allegedly illegally adding two more floors. The owner of the mall was among those detained, the local media reported.

The official Xinhua news agency said that the local authorities had not approved the building work and neither the designer nor the contractor had a licence. Initial investigations suggested that the foundations, built over a drainage ditch, subsided under the weight of the extra storeys, other state media said.

Building standards are often ignored in an industry notorious for what the prime minister, Zhu Rongji, calls "beancurd construction."

Beijing's efforts to tackle "localism" - the way in which municipal and county officials ignore national laws and directives - have had only limited success. Much of the damage to the environment is blamed on local interests only concerned with short-term gain.

The latest alarming example is provided by county authorities along the Yangtze river excavating huge quantities of sand from the river bed, undermining dykes and increasing the risk of floods. Big dredgers with suction hoses can collect sand worth 100,000 yuan (£7,800) in a day. It is transported to the cities and sold to building companies.

On Saturday a passenger boat sank near Chongqing after colliding with a craft carrying rocks and sand. At least nine people drowned.

Since a ban was recently imposed on illegal sand-extraction in Jiangsu, Anhui and Jiangxi provinces, some dredgers have moved upstream to Hubei province.

Many local authorities ignored Beijing's ban on dredging during the high-flood season of June to September this year. The city of Guichi in Anhui even staged a "sand auction" in this period.

Recent research shows that local authorities have become much more assertive in the past 20 years.

Beijing complains that even when laws are enforced by the courts, local authorities refuse to accept their decisions. More than 850,000 court rulings involving more than 250bn yuan have been frustrated by local action in recent years, a politburo member, Luo Gan, has complained.

Local defiance is blamed for the persistent manufacture of pirated products which has marred China's reputation abroad. National inspectors were harassed and beaten up during an attempted crackdown last month.

A drive to shut small heavily polluting oil refineries has also met with local obstruction. Last year China Environmental News commented: "Localism is behind the operation of some small refineries . . . and many wonder whether the crackdown will be effective."

Local interests regularly deprive the state of vast quantities of tax revenue. In a well-publicised case in 1998, Jinhua county in Zhejiang province was found to be the centre of a ring issuing fake VAT invoices over a period of four years.

Parliament has approved a plan to standardise laws throughout China so that local authorities cannot protect their interests by special legislation. But many in the countryside quote the familiar saying: "Heaven is high and the emperor is far away."

webTitle: Building a bond between health and social care

fields.headline: Building a bond between health and social care
fields.standfirst: The government's plans for health see it regaining touch with changes in society by working more closely with social services, writes Sophie Petit-Zeman
fields.trailText: The government's plans for health see it regaining touch with changes in society by working more closely with social care, writes Sophie Petit-Zeman.
fields.body:
What is the NHS plan?
On July 27 2000, the government published The NHS Plan: a Plan for Investment. A Plan for Reform. Billed as the most radical reform ever of the partnership between the health service and social care, it sets out a 10 year programme for change in England (Wales and Northern Ireland are developing their own, probably similar, plans).The programme brings money, staffing and organisational changes to health and social services. A key target is that the two sectors start working together much more closely.

While the NHS gets £19bn over the next five years, social care gets £1.5bn by 2004. Changes will be driven forward by a new modernisation board and assessed through indicators such as the social services performance assessment framework. Judging by 1999/2000 results, things are getting better but need to improve for the plan to meet its targets.

Why and how did it come about?
The plan notes that: "Despite its many achievements, the NHS has failed to keep pace with changes in our society." In March, prime minister Tony Blair set out five challenges to health and social care to be addressed over the next 10 years. Broad areas were patients, performance, prevention, professions and partnerships. The last two highlight the need to break traditional barriers between professions and get local councils and the NHS to collaborate to provide the best care.

Six "modernisation action teams", made up of senior social service professionals, met for the first time in April. Their brief was tough - wide-ranging national consultations leading to recommendations by June, and a plan by July 2000.

What are its implications for social services?
The Health Act 1999 removed barriers to joint local council and NHS working. The plan takes this further by:
 improving the integration of local health and social services in local care networks
 improving services for older people, whose needs often bridge health and social care
 implementing inspections of joint working by the Commission for Health Improvement, Audit Commission and the Social Services Inspectorate
 providing incentives and rewards for joint working
 facilitating integration through primary care trusts and new care trusts.

The reform programme needs to be phased to be realistic. Targets have been set, forming the Department of Health's public service agreement with the Treasury.

There are currently two joint social service and NHS targets. The first is to provide high quality pre-admission and rehabilitation care for the elderly, promote independent living and reduce hospitalisation. The second is to increase the participation of problem drug users in treatment programmes 55% by 2004 and 100% by 2008.

Social services must also improve lives of children in care. Four areas are addressed over four years. Education, training and employment outcomes for care leavers should be at least 75% of those of other children by age 19. The number of children in care achieving 5 A-C GCSE grades should increase to 15%. Guidance should be provided to "narrow the gap" between numbers of those in care and others who are cautioned or convicted, and the contribution of adoption to providing children with permanent families be maximised. This last target will be firmed up in light of the government's adoption services review.

How has it been received?
The plan has had a very mixed reaction, with some fearing that little will change. Others, like Jo Williams, a former president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, are optimistic. "The plan's proposals give us a real chance to make a better, more effective service that really focuses on the people we are trying to help," she says.

The country's first joint care trust, the Somerset partnership NHS and social care trust, has already illustrated what joint working can achieve. Established in April 1999, chief executive Paddy Cooney says: "We use resources in a more co-ordinated way through providing integrated care packages. We are managing and supervising across discipline boundaries and the relationship with primary care groups is more straightforward."

Stuart Etherington, chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, is cautious. He agrees with the plan's principles but sees an important role for voluntary organisations. "Government policy places great emphasis on engagement and involvement of communities," he says. "Voluntary organisations can help ensure that involvement actually happens. I strongly believe that if the new trusts don't engage with local communities and are not demonstrably accountable to them for their decisions as well as their actions, health services reform will not meet the needs of the wider community."

He is also unhappy that while, linking social and health care, the plan focuses too much on treating illness rather than its underlying social causes.

webTitle: Venables back with another offer for Boro

fields.headline: Venables back with another offer for Boro
fields.standfirst: West Ham 1 - 0 Middlesbrough
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough's desperate approach for Terry Venables, apparently dead in the water last week, now looks likely to have succeeded in some form after the club announced that they will hold a press conference at their Rockcliffe Park training ground, at 4.30 this afternoon.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough's desperate approach for Terry Venables, apparently dead in the water last week, now looks likely to have succeeded in some form after the club announced that they will hold a press conference at their Rockcliffe Park training ground, at 4.30 this afternoon.

It was only last Friday that he Teessiders withdrew their offer of an 18-month contract, the deal scuppered by Venables's role on ITV's Saturday highlights programme to be launched next season. But the 1-0 defeat at West Ham 24 hours later prompted another twist in this increasingly farcical saga.

With Boro slipping to joint last in the table, Venables contacted their chief executive Keith Lamb and offered to become first-team manager at the Riverside for six months, combining his coaching post with that as a pundit on ITV's Champions League coverage.

"I have contacted ITV and put to them the possibility of me working at Middlesbrough until the end of the season," he said. "There did not seem to be any problem about that, but no agreement has been reached with the club.

"I could help Boro out for six months. I said to [the manager] Bryan Robson, 'I will take it to the end of the year. You have a break for six months. I'll deal with the press and the team'."

Robson, who was willing to become first-team coach under the 57-year-old, is reluctant to work with Venables on a short-term basis but, with one point from the past 24, may be persuaded by his chairman Steve Gibson that fresh impetus is desperately needed.

"Bryan wanted me there for much longer and I respect that," added Venables. "He wasn't convinced it was a good idea. He didn't think it was settling to his players and staff with no one knowing what was going on. I understand that . . . but we will talk about it.

"I will be discussing all this with my advisors and would expect to have talks with the club if things can be sorted out. Then it will be seen how far this idea can be taken."

Whatever the result of today's discussions, the pantomime season has clearly begun early on Teesside. It is 12 days since Venables was first offered a route back into management and, after his procrastination saw Boro withdraw their initial bid, he admitted: "It looks like the end of my football career; in fact, I've already decided in my own mind I'm not going to do the job any more."

Now, with a lucrative new ITV contract waiting to be signed and Boro hanging on his every word, it appears he might end up with the best of both worlds.

webTitle: Former Loaded editor looks to set up multimedia venture

fields.headline: Former Loaded editor seeks multimedia funding
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Former Loaded editor Tim Southwell is seeking venture capital funding for a new multimedia venture, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former Loaded editor Tim Southwell, one of the higher profile victims of the closure of new media and broadband venture Switch2, is seeking venture capital funding for a new multimedia venture.

Keep Yourself Nice, which will encompass magazines, the internet and television, will also rope in another ex-Loaded journalist Ben Marshall, infamous for taking speed and heroin for the sake of a magazine feature.

Also joining will be Simon Weiszman, the former Disney head of programming at Buena Vista UK. It is understood that Tony Cross, former editor of More! magazine, will be working for the business on a consultancy basis.

Switch2 closed down last week, making 30 people redundant.

The company is to close down all but one of its 'lifestyle portals' allowing it to focus on its most successful brand, Done and Dusted.

webTitle: AvantGo launches UK office

fields.headline: AvantGo launches UK office
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: AvantGo, the US company that allows publishers to expand onto mobile platforms, has opened a UK office. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
AvantGo, the US company that allows publishers to expand onto mobile platforms, opens the doors of its UK office today.

Having spent six months signing deals with UK publishers, AvantGo launches in the UK with some 125 content channels.

These include cut-down versions of the Guardian, the Financial Times, the Times, BBC Online, Sports.com, ShopSmart and Lastminute.com.

Commenting on the BBC's move, Ashley Highfield, BBC director of new media, said: "Mobile communications is the growth market for the distribution of internet content and the BBC has made it a priority to be the lead player in delivering information in this exciting environment.

"Working with AvantGo helps us to achieve our aim and reach the widest possible audience, 24 hours a day."

To access the free service, users of hand-held organisers simply have to register at avantgo.co.uk, select their preferences and connect their PDA or personal digital assistant to their computer.

The rest of the process is automatically synchronised every time registered users rest their PDAs in the connected cradles.

A Wap service has also been developed, although, according to AvantGo's European managing director Dave Rice, it will only work properly on the new Ericcson R380 smart phone.

AvantGo is the market leader in the PDA content market with some 1.4m users globally, of which 250,000 are based in Europe.

As it expands into Europe, however, Avantgo will find competition in the form of Aladdino, a similar service that is currently engaged in its own European expansion plan.

Mr Rice maintains that Aladdino has a completely different strategy to AvantGo in that Aladdino aims to be a consumer portal, while AvantGo says it prefers to provide only the technology and platform for publishers.

webTitle: Ned Kelly's last testament

fields.headline: Ned Kelly's last testament
fields.standfirst: The reappearance of Kelly's last letter has sparked debate about his iconic status, writes Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: 4 December: The reappearance of Kelly's last letter has sparked debate about his iconic status, writes Patrick Barkham
fields.body:
The first and last testament of Ned Kelly, Australia's iconic criminal, was recently handed over to the State Library of Victoria and posted on the internet. The Jerilderie letter's belated placement in the public domain has reignited a passionate debate in Australia about the elusive bushranger and why he means so much to the country.

A priceless, scribbled polemic, it is practically the only surviving fragment of evidence of the short life of Kelly, who was hanged in 1880. Souvenir hunters have decimated the remains of some of Kelly's childhood homes. His haunts, such as Stringybark Creek, where his gang shot dead three policemen, go unmarked. Even Kelly's skull is missing - stolen from Old Melbourne Gaol in 1978

"I wish to acquaint you with some of the occurrences of the present, past and future," is Kelly's opening line. What follows is a passionate, hand-written 8,300-word rage against the authorities' treatment of him and other, similarly impoverished, Irish-Australians, struggling to escape their convict histories and survive in the country's hot, harsh environment.

Kelly dictated the Jerilderie letter to his friend Joe Byrne, when they, along with Ned's younger brother Dan and Steve Hart, were holding up the entire town of Jerilderie in 1879. With rumours of the exploits of the "Kelly Gang" rife in Victoria, Ned displayed an early grasp of the need for good PR, giving the letter to an accountant with the order that it be printed and published. But the authorities stepped in, denied Kelly publicity, and the incendiary letter never saw the light of day.

Kelly only had a few more months on the run before he was captured and killed. The letter went missing for 90 years, while the Kelly legend slowly grew.

Kelly was not simply famous for outwitting the police and committing several audacious robberies, before being captured after a dramatic shoot-out during which he protected himself in a striking, hand-forged metal helmet and body-armour.

Word also spread of his generosity, after he gave money he robbed to impoverished settlers. He was famed for his good manners as well, at a time when the Australian authorities - the judges and the police - were corrupt and oppressive, particularly in their treatment of the Irish Catholics descended from convicts, of which Kelly and his large, unruly family, were an example.

For some contemporary commentators, the Jerilderie letter is aggressive self-aggrandisement; for others it is a proto-republican document, almost a Communist Manifesto for the poor settlers of Australia.

"It contains the available fragments of a rebel manifesto that underlay his attempt to proclaim a republic in the north-east [of the Australian state of Victoria]," Kelly scholar Ian Jones says. The letter's survival owes much to Jones, who was tipped off about its existence in 1969 and watched over it as it passed through a series of private owners. "It presents the Kelly voice - passionate, vivid, sometimes poetic, often funny," Jones adds.

The letter inspired Peter Carey's novel, The True History of the Kelly Gang. Published in Britain in January, the ironically named "True History" has been a bestseller in Australia this autumn. Carey writes in the stream-of-consciousness style of the Jerilderie letter, imagining Ned's emotional life - a mystery to this day.

"When I was about 20 I first read the Jerilderie letter and loved it so much that I sat down and typed it all up and carried it with me for years and years," says Carey. "He's very passionate, he's very Irish, he's very funny. It's filled with rage and vindictiveness." For instance, Kelly describes the police as "big, ugly, fat-necked, wombat-headed, big-bellied, magpie-legged, narrow-hipped, splay-footed sons of Irish bailiffs or English landlords".

Kelly's passion is reciprocated. Today, opinions of him remain fiercely polarised. For some, he was a latter-day saint, fighting the tyranny of Australia's upper class, the English settlers. For others, the continuing veneration of Kelly and Australia's convict classes is an indictment of a nation short of real heroes. One commentator in The Australian newspaper recently predicted that had Kelly not been hanged at 25, he "would have become the Pol Pot of north-east Victoria".

But Kelly historian Jones is fighting against such extreme views. "To dismiss Kelly as a horse thief and cop killer is on a par with seeing Jesus as an executed rebel who doesn't seem to have got on terribly well with his mum," he says.

"He was of convict stock and he proved himself to be more decent than the police," says Carey. "I think his wit, his decency and his courage showed that we were not to be the victims of our past, that we could, given the right circumstances, be an amazing people and I think that's why we continue to value him."

webTitle: Casting news: Diesel set to return in Pitch Black 2

fields.headline: Diesel set to return in Pitch Black 2
fields.standfirst: Plus: Angelic lead for Resident Evil; Jada Pinkett Smith slots into Matrix 2; Eddie Murphy to reteam with old collaborator; When will Goss be famous?
fields.trailText: Plus: Angelic lead for Resident Evil; Jada Pinkett Smith slots into Matrix 2; Eddie Murphy to reteam with old collaborator; And when will Goss be famous?
fields.body:
 Dark Horizons suggests that the first thing that Universal executives will be doing in 2001 is looking over the script for a Pitch Black sequel, which is due to hit their desks in January. Vin Diesel's character Riddick (pictured), by all accounts the best thing about the film, may be about to receive top billing - the thinking being that his name may be used somewhere in the title.

 Videogame adaptation Resident Evil has found its leading man, according to Ain't It Cool. David Boreanaz, star of the TV's vampire hit, Angel, is due to take up a central role in the film, provided his commitments to the spin off from Buffy, the Vampire Slayer, allow him to make a break for the big screen.

 Jada Pinkett Smith is a dead cert for the Matrix 2, says Ananova. The actress, who is married to Will Smith, confirmed her involvement in the two-month shoot in Australia on the Oprah Winfrey Show.

 Eddie Murphy, currently at work on a sequel to his 1998 hit Dr Dolittle, is thinking of reteaming with the original's director, Betty Thomas, for another project. Mr Showbiz reports that the pair may work together again on espionage comedy, I, Spy, in which Murphy will play an athlete who teams up with a government agent to find a missing jet.

 When, oh, when will he be famous? The Luke Goss rumour mill just won't stop, according to Dark Horizons. We will not see the chiselled ex-Bros boy as a blank-faced agent in the next Matrix film, but the budding thespian recently dropped hints that he might shortly be seen in another sci-fi sequel: Blade 2. He edged around questions about the project, filming next year in Prague, in a radio interview - but did promise he'd be playing the "main bad guy".

webTitle: Bizarre 'grows up' to boost market share

fields.headline: Bizarre 'grows up' to boost market share
fields.trailText: 12pm: Bizarre magazine has admitted it needs to 'grow up' to survive in the cut-throat men's magazine market, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Its cover is emblazoned with a warning that it contains material that could offend.

But now Bizarre magazine has been forced to admit that it needs to "grow up" and shed its soft-porn image if it is to survive in the cut-throat men's magazine market.

The magazine is to be relaunched on December 12 in a bid to grab readers from style magazines The Face and i-D.

Editor Joe Gardiner said publisher John Brown Publishing wanted the magazine to "grow up" a bit, and said the magazine's design would rely less heavily on the soft-porn focus that has established it in the men's sector.

"Behind the images in Bizarre there's a story and strong editorial," he said. "We will still be covering weird, twisted sexuality, but in a more stylish way."

Bizarre will overhaul its design with new fonts and photography and will contain new sections including 'Murder File', in which crime writers will focus on real-life crimes, and 'Dope Scope', monitoring world drug laws.

This month's issue is blatantly crude, with coverlines including 'More Balls, Less Bollocks' and "Whip 'em off! On the lash with the Marquis de Sade".

Next month's coverlines are less provocative although just as explicit: 'Sex change', 'Japanese bondage' and 'Backyard autopsy'.

Bizarre's founding editor, Fiona Jerome, announced two weeks ago that she was leaving the magazine to go to the Ministry of Sound's Ministry magazine.

The magazine, launched four years ago, sells 117,439 copies, lagging behind the big sellers in the men's section, FHM, Loaded, GQ and Front.

Mr Gardiner said he hoped to boost circulation by 10% within six months.

webTitle: Ex-City Slicker  in talks about job at the Star

fields.headline: Ex-City Slicker  in talks about Star job
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Anil Bhoyrul, the journalist at the centre of the Mirror share dealing scandal, has been approached by the Express's Richard Desmond, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former City Slicker Anil Bhoyrul has been approached by new Express owner Richard Desmond about launching a new column in the Daily Star.

But the job offer is dependent on Mr Bhoyrul being cleared by the Department of Trade & Industry, which is investigating his role in the Mirror share dealing scandal.

The DTI is expected to conclude its investigation into Mr Bhoyrul's role in the next couple of weeks.

Mr Bhoyrul, along with the other City Slicker, James Hipwell, and Mirror editor Piers Morgan, is being questioned as part of an inquiry by the DTI into alleged insider dealing.

Mr Desmond has made it clear that he intends to invest heavily in the Star, which he wants to line up as a serious competitor to the Sun and the Mirror.

Mr Bhoyrul resigned from Punch magazine last week amid speculation that his column faced the axe.

It is understood that Mr Hipwell has not had an approach from the new Express boss.

webTitle: Assam secessionists intensify bloody campaign

fields.headline: Assam secessionists intensify bloody campaign
fields.standfirst: Despite declining popular support, Assam separatists ULFA are showing no sign of curbing their campaign of terror, explains Luke Harding
fields.trailText: Despite declining popular support, Assam separatists ULFA are showing no sign of curbing their campaign of terror, explains Luke Harding.
fields.body:
As 19 people die in violent incidents on the same night in the Indian state of Assam, it is clear that separatists are focusing on a new target - the local immigrant minority

Escalating violence and new ethnically motivated tactics are causing an exodus from the Indian state of Assam

On Thursday evening (Nov 30), labourer Khelka Burman was having tea at a crowded roadside stall. Three youths pulled up on a motorcycle. Nobody paid them any attention at first.

The middle youth then got down. He produced an AK47 and started firing. By the time he stopped firing, at least eight people were dead.

As the youths sped off, a wounded Mr Burman realised he was one of the few people at the stall still alive. "I do not know how I saved myself," he said last night, recovering in hospital.

The same evening in the state of Assam, three other massacres were taking place. Militants in a car gunned down five workers at the Bishjora tea estate and Chitkagaon areas, while five more people were executed at nearby Lamati.

A local councillor was also shot dead. The death toll for one evening was 19, bringing the total over the last three months to 83.

Almost all of the victims had one thing in common: they had originally come from Bihar. They were members of one of Assam's minority communities and, as such, easy targets.

Assam is in India's restive north-east. The state is connected to the rest of the country by a narrow threadlike corridor. To the north, beyond the Himalayan state of Bhutan, is the vast bulk of China, and to the south Bangladesh.

Assam's geographic remoteness from rest of India, the continuing expropriation of its natural resources, principally oil, and the fact that many of its tribes are ethnically Burmese, have created a climate in which insurrection has flourished. Last week's massacres were nothing new.

The killings were almost certainly carried out by the United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA), a separatist militant group which has been fighting for an independent Assam for the last 15 years.

In the early days of the insurgency, ULFA's armed struggle against the Indian state enjoyed much success. Then in 1991 the Indian army started fighting back.

Latterly ULFA's popular support has been falling away. Earlier this year, several hundred militants abandoned the struggle and gave up their weapons.

By way of response, remaining ULFA militants have engaged in a deadly new tactic - to target Hindi-speaking Bihari labourers who form only 6% of Assam's polyglot population.

Already hundreds of Bihari families working in the interior have fled their homes in panic. Dozens have been spotted at Guwahati railway station trying to escape.

"When we heard about the massacre we immediately packed up and rushed to Guwahati," quilt-maker Aslam Khan said yesterday. "I am now waiting for a ticket."

Back in the 19th century, when they first annexed Assam, the British replaced the opium plantations with a new, more demure commodity: tea.

But they found the local Assamese population unwilling to abandon their smallholdings and pick the crop. And so a century ago they imported workers from the impoverished state of Bihar, many of whose descendants are still employed on tea estates.

Since then other migrants having come to Assam, including - overwhelmingly - Bengalis.

The Indian government is used to dealing with insurgencies. But in Assam the authorities have not just one but several.

The tribal Bodo community has also been fighting its own battle, not for an independent Bodoland but for a separate state in the north of Assam within India's federal system. They have killed around 300 people in the last seven years.

Encouraged by the recent creation of three new Indian states, the Bodo Tiger Liberation Front (BTLF) is now in peace negotiations with New Delhi.

The various armed rebellions in Assam have also placed India's relations with its neighbours under strain. ULFA operates from a series of jungle bases across the border into Bangladesh, and in the forests of neighbouring Bhutan.

Bodo rebels also have several camps in Bhutan. One of ULFA's top leaders was recently arrested in Dhaka, the Bangladesh capital. Two satellite telephones and $25,000 in cash were found in his room.

India has also accused Pakistan's intelligence service, the ISI, of aiding the insurgents.

Given Assam's ethnic complexity, it seems that no solution can be found that is likely to satisfy any of the rebel protagonists.

Some 40% of the state is now made up of non-Assamese. ULFA has deliberately avoided targeting Bengalis, the most numerous minority, because it knows that Bengalis are likely to fight back.

The Biharis, by contrast, are a soft target. As ULFA's grip on popular sentiment slips still further, the prospects for Biharis who stay on in Assam are increasingly grim.

They were members of one of Assam's minority communities and, as such, easy targets. Assam is in India's restive north-east. The state is connected to the rest of the country by a narrow threadlike corridor. To the north, beyond the Himalayan state of Bhutan, is the vast bulk of China, and to the south Bangladesh. Assam's geographic remoteness from rest of India, the continuing expropriation of its natural resources, principally oil, and the fact that many of its tribes are ethnically Burmese, have created a climate in which insurrection has flourished. Last week's massacres were nothing new. The killings were almost certainly carried out by the United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA), a separatist militant group which has been fighting for an independent Assam for the last 15 years. In the early days of the insurgency, ULFA's armed struggle against the Indian state enjoyed much success. Then in 1991 the Indian army started fighting back. Latterly ULFA's popular support has been falling away. Earlier this year, several hundred militants abandoned the struggle and gave up their weapons. By way of response, remaining ULFA militants have engaged in a deadly new tactic - to target Hindi-speaking Bihari labourers who form only 6% of Assam's polyglot population. Already hundreds of Bihari families working in the interior have fled their homes in panic. Dozens have been spotted at Guwahati railway station trying to escape. "When we heard about the massacre we immediately packed up and rushed to Guwahati," quilt-maker Aslam Khan said yesterday. "I am now waiting for a ticket." Back in the 19th century, when they first annexed Assam, the British replaced the opium plantations with a new, more demure commodity: tea. But they found the local Assamese population unwilling to abandon their smallholdings and pick the crop. And so a century ago they imported workers from the impoverished state of Bihar, many of whose descendants are still employed on tea estates. Since then other migrants having come to Assam, including - overwhelmingly - Bengalis. The Indian government is used to dealing with insurgencies. But in Assam the authorities have not just one but several. The tribal Bodo community has also been fighting its own battle, not for an independent Bodoland but for a separate state in the north of Assam within India's federal system. They have killed around 300 people in the last seven years. Encouraged by the recent creation of three new Indian states, the Bodo Tiger Liberation Front (BTLF) is now in peace negotiations with New Delhi. The various armed rebellions in Assam have also placed India's relations with its neighbours under strain. ULFA operates from a series of jungle bases across the border into Bangladesh, and in the forests of neighbouring Bhutan. Bodo rebels also have several camps in Bhutan. One of ULFA's top leaders was recently arrested in Dhaka, the Bangladesh capital. Two satellite telephones and $25,000 in cash were found in his room. India has also accused Pakistan's intelligence service, the ISI, of aiding the insurgents. Given Assam's ethnic complexity, it seems that no solution can be found that is likely to satisfy any of the rebel protagonists. Some 40% of the state is now made up of non-Assamese. ULFA has deliberately avoided targeting Bengalis, the most numerous minority, because it knows that Bengalis are likely to fight back. The Biharis, by contrast, are a soft target. As ULFA's grip on popular sentiment slips still further, the prospects for Biharis who stay on in Assam are increasingly grim. webTitle: In brief: Lara Croft brings boost to Cambodia

fields.headline: Lara Croft brings boost to Cambodia
fields.standfirst: Plus:John Woo-ed for Superman; Chow Yun-Fat takes a tumble; Clinton makes Eastwood's day; Turkish Film Festival grows in size; How to cook Cornflakes a la Cleese.
fields.trailText: Plus:John Woo-ed for Superman; Chow Yun-Fat takes a tumble; Clinton makes Eastwood's day; Turkish Film Festival grows in size; How to cook Cornflakes a la Cleese.
fields.body:
 The Cambodian economy has been hit by the "Croft effect", reports IMDb.com. After a 36-year-hiatus in foreign film activity (the last project filmed in the country was 1965's Lord Jim, with Peter O'Toole), the $100m (£69.3m) production of Tomb Raider, starring Angelina Jolie (pictured), is pumping cash into the local economy. Roads and bridges ravaged by the civil war are being rebuilt to allow director Simon West easy access to the Angkor Wat temple complex. "There is not a single person in or around the temple complex who does not know that Hollywood and its big bucks have arrived in Angkor Wat," gushed the Singapore Straits Times.

 The long-languishing next Superman film may be about to be revived, reckons Ain't It Cool. John Woo is apparently in talks to bring his post-Mission: Impossible II clout to a new script currently favoured by studio types. Previous names attached to the next Man of Steel outing include Nicolas Cage, who was touted to play the clean-cut saviour of Metropolis, director Tim Burton and Dogma writer-director Kevin Smith, whose Superman Lives! script was knocked back by executives.

 Reaping this month's Jackie Chan award for least insurable male lead and continuing a venerable martial arts acting tradition of noble self sacrifice is Chow Yun-Fat. PageSix.com says that while the star was filming Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, his wife was not too impressed when he volunteered to perform a stunt that required him to be suspended upside-down in a harness and plunged 60ft to within inches of the ground. She apparently had a lawyer send a letter to director Ang Lee, but later relented when she saw the astonishing result on screen and sent Lee a bottle of whiskey. Presumably to give to the next actor he decides to drop from the top of a 12-metre high bamboo forest.

 Clint Eastwood became a Kennedy Centre honoree at a White House awards ceremony presented by Bill Clinton this weekend. According to Ananova, the audience went wild when the on-stage projector showed a picture of Eastwood as a baby, accompanied by his trademark "Go ahead, make my day" line. Other honorees for achievement in the arts included Placido Domingo and Chuck Berry.

 Screendaily reports that the London Turkish Film Festival has doubled in size this year. Now two weeks long, running from Friday 8 to Thursday 21 December, the event will feature Nuri Bilge Ceylan's praised Clouds of May and Gani Mujde's Turkish box-office smash Byzantium among the films that will tour London and regional cinemas. Turkish film luminaries are expected to be in attendance as well.

 John Cleese, when asked to submit a recipe for Margaret Simpson's The Celebrity and Churches Cookbook, came up with something unexpected. IMDb.com reports that Cleese proffered instructions on how to make a bowl of cornflakes. Condescending? Apparently not. 65-year-old Simpson was delighted. "The John Cleese recipe made my day and I wasn't surprised it was a funny one. I can imagine him serving that to guests at Fawlty Towers. I like cornflakes myself and I have them every morning, though I never expected it to end up a dish in a recipe book."

webTitle: Make your voice heard in the corridors of power

fields.headline: Make your voice heard in the corridors of power
fields.standfirst: A government insider advises charities on campaigning at the top. Nicola Hill reports.
fields.trailText: A government insider advises charities on campaigning at the top, Nicola Hill reports.
fields.body:
Carey Oppenheim, a special adviser to No 10, gave delegates at NCVO's lobby conference an insight into the workings of the inner sanctum of government. She explained that there are more than 150 staff working at Downing Street, and that charity lobbyists should find out which researchers and special advisers are concerned with their cause.

Contrary to popular belief, the most important person to contact is not Tony Blair but whoever replaces Geoff Mulgan in the Downing Street policy unit. Although No 10 would not confirm it, Ms Oppenheim let slip that Mike Emmerich, currently at the Treasury, would be taking over shortly.

David Milliband is the top person at the policy unit, and another key contact. He has 11 special advisers working for him. Ms Oppenheim explained that these advisers are political appointees and can have more influence over Labour policy than ordinary civil servants.

"Despite the media hype of an expanding empire, each special adviser has a huge brief and their work shadows a secretary of state," said Ms Oppenheim. Each special adviser has a researcher working part time for them. The special advisers put together a range of policy options - on issues such as pensions - and present them to the PM.

"It is very important for advisers to look at long-term strategy, so your role is crucial in coming up with ideas," Ms Oppenheim told delegates at the conference. She also advised lobbying the central units within government - for example, the social exclusion unit or the women's unit - to put your charity's issues on the government's agenda.

As well as No 10, Ms Oppenheim suggests getting to know civil servants in the Treasury who are responsible for spending in the departments relevant to your cause. "They usually welcome outside input," she said. "People are often ground down by day-to-day activities, whereas you are freer to look ahead. There are still openings for second-term ideas, and the earlier you put your ideas across the better."

However, she also warned against sending in truckloads of information to make your point - two sides of A4 highlighting key points are more likely to win favour. Despite this minimalist approach, Ms Oppenheim also advised: "Couch your message in an eye-catching way."

Forming alliances with other charities is also more likely to add legitimacy to your call to action. Facilitating meetings that the government could not be seen to chair is another good way of putting forward ideas. Having a relationship with a thinktank - to combine campaigning with research - is recommended.

Ms Oppenheim said the government does take notice of backbenchers, but they have a harder time when there is a large majority. "However, right now is a good time to lobby them, as the government wants to nurse its own in the run up to an election."

Another effective method of tapping into the conscience of decision makers is through the media. "If people like Polly Toynbee say something, people sit up and listen," said Ms Oppenheim.

And her final word of advice is not to concentrate all your efforts on the central hub of power. "If you choose your issue and timing well, you can have a good response, but No 10 is influenced by and responsible to other places, so it is also important to focus on those."

The Prime Minister's office consists of:

 Private Office - which is run by civil servants, who deal with the PM's diary and letters

 Policy Unit - which mainly employs political appointees, who give the PM advice on policy

 Political Office - which consists of party workers, paid for out of party funds, who write speeches and maintain links with the party

 Press Office and Strategic Communities Unit - which is headed by Alastair Campbell and mostly staffed by civil servants, who handle relations with the media and outside world

 Research and Information Office - which is run by a mixture of special advisers and civil servants, who provide the PM with information

webTitle: Obituary: Jack Hemingway

fields.headline: Obituary: Jack Hemingway
fields.trailText: Jack Hemingway, who has died in New York aged 77, was the eldest son of the novelist Ernest Hemingway and long acted as his emissary
fields.body:
Jack Hemingway, who has died in New York aged 77, was the eldest son of the novelist Ernest Hemingway and bore a striking resemblence to his father. However, despite having grown up under the shadow of a famous writer, notorious drunk and hunter, Jack carved out a life which reversed some of the values of his distant, disengaged father.

He had long been his family's emissary, attending conferences, sitting on the advisory board of the Hemingway Foundation and, with courtesy and good humour, welcoming visitors to the family home at Ketchum, Idaho, with its breathtaking view across Sun Valley. Visitors admired the rich horde of family memorabilia - Hemingway's typewriter, a trunk which had been with the writer in Paris in the 1920s and a handsome fake Picasso hanging in the bedroom - before adjourning to the Olympic bar, one of Papa's favourite hangouts in Ketchum.

But his greatest love was fly fishing and the outdoor life, and after his father's suicide in 1961, he settled in Ketchum. Growing increasingly interested in the problem of conserving Idaho wildlife and environment, he became a persuasive advocate for enlightened policies in a state famed for its hunting and fishing.

Hemingway served as a commissioner on the Idaho Fish and Game Commission from 1971 to 1977 and was instrumental in the adoption of a "catch and release" law, which did much to preserve trout stocks while those in neighbouring states declined.

He was born in Toronto, an easy birth made even more congenial when his mother, Hadley, his father's first wife, was given laughing gas ("Hadley says the whole childbirth business has been greatly over-rated," Hemingway wrote to Gertrude Stein, who became Jack's godmother). Nicknamed "Bumby", Jack spent his early years in Paris and the Austrian Alps. These years are described in A Moveable Feast, Hemingway's autobiography, published in 1964. The book ends with a description of Hadley greeting him at the train station, smiling, "her lovely face tanned by the snow and the sun", and Bumby at her side, "blond and chunky and with winter cheeks looking like a good Voralberg boy." Hemingway had just decided to abandon his wife and child.

Jack was five when his parents divorced. Sent to boarding schools, he only saw his father during summer vacations. As he grew up, they went fishing together and boxed. When Hemingway was too busy at work on a novel, he paid for Jack to stay at a dude ranch in Montana. Sending his love, Hemingway promised to bring his son ammunition for his rifle and asked if he should order some pistol cartridges, too. As a teenager they drank frozen daiquiris together, and spent time in Pamplona and Havana. After attending the University of Montana and Dartmouth College, Jack dropped out before taking his degree and enlisted in the US Army. He served in a military police detachment in North Africa and then, with certain strings pulled by influential family friends, was assigned to the Office of Strategic Services.

With the rank of captain, he was parachuted into Nazi-occupied France on a mission to assist the resistance. He took with him a rod, reel and fly box. On a later mission in November 1944 he was shot in the arm and shoulder, and taken prisoner. He spent the rest of the war in a PoW camp. With a fine war record, "a nice set of visible scars" and the Croix de Guerre awarded by the French government, relations between novelist and son improved.

After the war, Jack Hemingway continued his army career as a security officer in Berlin, and as liaison officer to the Third French Army Corps in Freiburg. After serving on the staff of a special intelligence course at Fort Bragg in North Carolina, Jack left the army. The transition to civilian life was difficult. He had a brief career as a stockbroker and then as a salesman of fishing supplies.

After Ernest's death, Jack was the family member most at ease with the growing public interest in the family. He explored his relations with his father in a 1986 memoir, Misadventures of a Fly Fisherman: My Life With and Without Papa. Before his death he had completed the manuscript of an as yet unpublished second volume of autobiography, A Life Worth Living, and was working on a volume of reminiscences, recipes and tales of travel, with his second wife, Angela Hovey, who survives him.

His first wife, Byra, whom he married in Paris in 1949, died in 1986. They had three daughters: Joan, Margaux, who died of a barbiturate overdose in 1996, and Hadley (Mariel), the actress.

John (Jack) Hadley Nicanor Hemingway, angler and conservationist, born October 10 1923; died December 1 2000.

webTitle: Saga sets aside £1m for dynamic new image

fields.headline: Saga sets aside £1m for dynamic new image
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Saga, a company once associated only with the blue-rinse brigade, is seeking an ad agency to modernise its image, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Saga, a company once associated only with the blue-rinse brigade, has begun a search for an advertising agency to present it as modern and dynamic.

The company, which started out 50 years ago organising holidays for retired people, has approached a number of London-based ad agencies with a brief to promote its financial services division.

It plans to spend more than £1m to change public perceptions of the company.

While many still associate Saga with coach tours to British seaside resorts, the company has extended its scope beyond way beyond its traditional business.

When Saga launched its core offering was holidays for retired people. Since then it has evolved into a corporation that offers everything to the older generation.

It began offering financial services in the 80s after recognising that many financial institutions were ignoring the potentially huge 'grey' market.

It now offers health insurance, home and motor insurance, pet and travel insurance and investments.

Saga magazine has a readership of more than 1m.
