webTitle: How I got published on the net

fields.headline: E-publish and be damned
fields.standfirst: Publishing your novel on the internet means you have no talent. Rubbish, says Mark Piggott, who is sure he will succeed where Stephen King failed
fields.trailText: My first novel came out in October, and the response so far has been unenthusiastic, but not because of its literary merit. Why? Because Behind Blue Eyes was published on the internet. It wasn't as if I published it myself. I answered an advert in the Guardian for new writers, satisfied myself that I wasn't dealing with a vanity publisher, and finally got a contract.
fields.body:
My first novel came out in October, and the response so far has been unenthusiastic, but not because of its literary merit. Why? Because Behind Blue Eyes was published on the internet. It wasn't as if I published it myself. I answered an advert in the Guardian for new writers, satisfied myself that I wasn't dealing with a vanity publisher, and finally got a contract.

Yes, I know, two words: Stephen King. But there is a difference between how he tried to operate and how reedmee.com operates. For all his pulling power, King relied on trust and honesty; and the novel was written over a period of time, which tested both the patience and the memory of the reader. With reedmee.com you read the free sample and if you like it, pay your money, either by credit card, which is instantaneous but makes some people nervous, or by cheque. Then you are sent the whole novel in a format of your choice.

The site can take greater risks with new writers, because there is less financial outlay; yet, ironically, potential profits are greater. Each novel is sold for under £4 of which I, as author, get roughly £1.60. But I'm not in it for the money; I just want to be read. E-publishing has fulfilled that wish, whereas the traditional publishers seem less and less able to take risks.

At the recent Frankfurt book fair there was a first prize of $100,000 for best original e-book. If you take into account the development of hand-held readers from companies such as Palm and Handspring, the eco-friendly saving of paper, and reader-author interactivity, should publishers and bookshops feel threatened?

"We do not see ourselves as replacing traditional publishing," says reedmee.com founder Chris Pickard, who has 18 years of publishing experience under his belt. "Our readers will be able to support new writing talent and read manuscripts which might never have reached the book shelves. If some of our authors migrate to conventional publishing, that's fine."

But is it possible that these authors would never have reached the shelves because they weren't good enough to get a deal anywhere other than the internet? With publishers now in the hands of fewer and fewer companies, and with bookshops under enormous pressure to get customers in and out as quickly as possible, with a Harry Potter or Bill Bryson in their pocket, smaller publishers are struggling to do what they do best: discover new, brave voices, who may not be the next Nick Hornby (or Anthea Turner) but who have something to say, and say it well.

"It's getting harder and harder to get our books on to the shelves," says Hayley Ann, founder of Codex Books, who publishes Billy Childish, Stewart Home and other "off-the-wall" writers. "There are two problems we have with Waterstone's in particular at the moment. First, they aren't taking as many titles from the independents; and second, when those books they do take sell out, they aren't re-ordering, even though they're obviously selling well."

Ann believes the problems at Waterstone's stem from the power of publishing conglomerates. Fewer and fewer companies own more and more publishers, and profit comes first - but hasn't it always? "Waterstone's is owned by HMV Media, and they've been trying to sell it for about a year now. I believe that Tim Waterstone actually wants to buy it back, which would be one solution, but he probably can't afford it. Robert Topping, former manager of Waterstone's in Manchester, feels new management was responsible for a tougher line with independents which has, ironically, led to a decrease in profits. "When Tim [Waterstone] ran things, he left the purchasing of books up to the manager of each shop. With these new, non-book people at HQ running things, profit and productivity always come first. They're talking about banning sales reps from publishers completely, just ordering from catalogues. But publishers and book sellers need to meet, to learn from each other."

But Orion changed their minds, on the grounds that The Provider - about a Scouse gangster who has to find £100k to pay for his daughter's life-saving operation in America - was crap. And they were right. I decided to leave gangster novels to public school boys, and returned to the subjects I knew best: the dispossessed detritus of the society Margaret Thatcher had refused even to recognise. I went back to a book I'd been working on for years, Three Bridges, and got myself an agent.

"Hello Mark, this is Dr Radice here, of Gregory and Radice. I've just finished reading Three Bridges. I can't say I enjoyed it, in fact it was like reading a 500-page suicide note, but it does show you have talent, so if you can come up with something more uplifting I'd like to offer you a deal." A few days later the contract came through the post, complete with film rights options and percentage fees for Russian translations. I had made it.

Or so I thought. Two years and numerous re-writes later, publisher after publisher had turned down the book, with comments such as these: "I found it a fascinating novel, the characterisation is terrific and the plotting works impressively on many varied levels. Mark is certainly talented and there's no doubt that Behind Blue Eyes marks an impressive debut, I'm just not quite convinced that we could do it justice at this stage - it's probably a little too avant-garde for us."

webTitle: The Grinch prospers in quiet box office weekend

fields.headline: The Grinch prospers in quiet box office weekend
fields.standfirst: How the Grinch Stole Christmas keeps going strong for third weekend, but other releases feel the post-Thanksgiving pinch as box office takings dwindle
fields.trailText: How the Grinch Stole Christmas keeps going strong for third weekend, but other releases feel the post-Thanksgiving pinch as box office takings dwindle
fields.body:
The US box office went into its traditional post-Thanksgiving slump this weekend, with no new big releases and grosses down 50%, allowing Ron Howard's How the Grinch Stole Christmas to stay at the top for a third weekend

Screendaily reports that the Dr Seuss adaptation took an estimated $27.1m (£18.79m) third time around, bringing its total gross to a colossal $172m (£119.3m).

Not only is the Grinch on course to become the year's most successful film, but it may soon join the 20 most successful films of all time. It also looks likely to become the first film from either director Ron Howard or star Jim Carrey, hardly box office failures in the past, to earn over $200m.

M Night Shyamalan's Unbreakable continued to move slowly towards the $100m mark, despite a critical mauling. The Bruce Willis vehicle held onto second place with a haul of $15m (£10.4m) to bring its earnings so far to $66.7m (£46.26m).

102 Dalmatians, in third place, felt the pinch with a much-reduced second weekend's take of $8.2m (£5.68m) and all other films in the top ten also suffered.

The only exception was Jay Roach's hugely successful Meet the Parents, which managed a sturdy $3.8m (£2.63m) in the ninth week of a run that has now seen gross profits reach $153.2m (£106.26m).

The only opening was Miramax's reissue of the 1964 Beatles classic A Hard Day's Night, which took an estimated $54,000 (£37,400)on two screens.

webTitle: Frontline warns WH Smith by planning re-tender

fields.headline: Frontline warns WH Smith by planning re-tender
fields.standfirst:
Nov 27: Papers plan to dump WH Smith
Nov 21: Mags accuse WH Smith
fields.trailText:
11am: Frontline has fired a warning shot across the bows of WH Smith, saying it will re-tender its £150m magazine contract, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Nov 27: Papers plan to dump WH Smith
Nov 21: Mags accuse WH Smith
fields.body:
Frontline, the distribution company owned by publishers Emap, Haymarket, BBC Worldwide and Attic Futura, has fired a warning shot across the bows of WH Smith, saying it will re-tender its £150m magazine contract.

Frontline wants the company to guarantee that small retailers will not be cut out of the loop by WH Smith's plan for a centrally-controlled distribution system.

Simon Curtin, managing director of Frontline, said: "We are putting contracts out to tender in the next fortnight.

"A significant factor in making awards will be a wholesaler with a recent track record in delivering high-level services to both small and large retailers."

WH Smith currently distributes 27% of Frontline's magazine business, a contract thought to be worth £150m in revenue and between £12m and £15m in annual profits.

Frontline advised its four publishers that it was in their interests to appoint a wholesaler that backed the Periodical Publishers' Association's (PPA) "Blueprint" plan, designed to keep small retailers in the loop.

The PPA and several publishing companies have protested against plans by WH Smith and Tesco to create a centrally controlled distribution system.

They feel it would put many small retailers and newsagents out of business and damage their sales.

An alternative distribution plan called "Blueprint", put together by the PPA, recommends a compromise plan including a central hub to make the onward delivery of papers and magazines more efficient, but allowing existing regional distribution relationships to stay in place.

It has been endorsed by most newspaper and magazine publishers and even Tesco, but WH Smith is refusing to sign up to it.

WH Smith dismissed as "pure speculation" the notion that Frontline was re-tendering its contract because it was unhappy with WH Smith's plans.

WH Smith confirmed it would be rebidding for the contract, due to be awarded in April, and said it sought to increase its share of the Frontline business from 27% to 43%.

Last week the stakes were raised for WH Smith by a decision from Associated Newspapers, publisher of the Daily Mail, the Mail on Sunday and the Evening Standard, to terminate two-thirds of its supplier contracts with WH Smith.

News International, publisher of the Times, the Sunday Times, the Sun and the News of the World, is also reviewing its relationship with the distributor.

webTitle: Tim Burton sues art

fields.headline: Tim Burton sues art
fields.trailText: Hollywood director Tim Burton is suing a man who he claims stole personal artwork that was accidentally left in his former appartment
fields.body:
Mr Showbiz reports that Tim Burton, director of Sleepy Hollow and Edward Scissorhands, is suing a man who he claims stole a box full of personal artwork from him in 1991.

The Los Angeles Superior Court lawsuit alleges that David Patrick Bontempo took a box containing original sketches and paintings that was accidentally left behind in a community storage area at Burton's former apartment building in Pasadena, California.

Burton received a letter from Bontempo in July this year in which he: "admitted he was in possession of 48 pieces of the stolen artwork."

The director's complaint also states that Bontempo had made an arrangement to auction the material at Christie's in New York and had expressly refused to return any of it. Burton seeks compensation for the loss of his artwork, as well as for the time and money he has spent looking for it, plus further damages.

Burton and Bontempo were unavailable for comment.

fields.standfirst: All the rumours chipped, fried, wrapped in newspaper and sold to the public by a greasy fat man
fields.trailText: Rumours suggesting that Lazio midfielder Pavel Nedved is on his way to Manchester United at the end of the season seem to be wide of the mark. " If there had been an offer, both I and Pavel would have to know about it," said the player's agent Zdenek Nehoda. "What's more, Pavel does not really want to leave Lazio - he would only go for a large sum of money. He's not going to decide until summer, but it looks like Pavel will probably extend his current contract for another two years."

Colin Hendry is expected to join Bolton on a three-month loan deal.

webTitle: The Edge

fields.headline: The Edge
fields.standfirst: The stats that matter, from IQ Sports
fields.trailText: ARSENAL 1 - 0 SOUTHAMPTON
fields.body:
ARSENAL 1 - 0 SOUTHAMPTON

Key man: Oleg Luzhny won all 14 challenges, completed 50 of his 60 passes - including all 10 in the forward third - and set up the winner.
Weak link: Despite a wealth of attempts, 419 minutes of scoreless football has seriously damaged the Gunners' title aspirations.
The Edge: Arsenal defenders won 51 of 55 challenges and allowed only 1 shot on target. Patrick Vieira won 9 of his 10 challenges in midfield.

ASTON VILLA 1 - 1 NEWCASTLE

Key man: Warren Barton won 17 of 19 challenges, made 8 clearances and intercepted the ball 3 times.
Weak link: With no natural strikers, Newcastle produced only a single attempt on goal. Meanwhile, David Ginola had a bit of a nightmare: 18 of his 37 passes went to opposition players.
The Edge: Villa will be feeling unlucky, having made 13 attempts and accurate crosses to Newcastle's 3. But the visitors made up with a battling edge - 131 challenges to Villa's 84 and 22 fouls to Villa's 14.

BRADFORD 2 - 1 COVENTRY

Key man: Dean Windass completed 42 of 55 passes - 18 of 23 in the forward zone - won 11 of 13 challenges and set up the equaliser.
Weak link: Despite a five-man midfield, Coventry had only 42% of net possession.
The Edge: Bradford were the keener chasers, making 157 challenges to Coventry's 81. Robert Molenaar added stability to Bradford's defence, winning 21 of 24 challenges and making 11 clearances.

IPSWICH 0 - 1 DERBY

Key man: Seth Johnson won all his 15 tackles, made 5 clearances and set up the winner for Rory Delap.
Weak link: David Johnson and Marcus Stewart had only two attempts on goal and failed to exploit Ipswich's dominance - the home team had 75% of net possession.
The Edge: Derby battled hard, making 130 challenges to 64 by Ipswich. Chris Riggott and Horacio Carbonari won 42 of 46 challenges and made 30 clearances, as Derby kept their fourth clean sheet in five matches - in that time, they've only conceded to Manchester United!

LEICESTER 3 - 1 LEEDS

Key man: Neil Lennon won 12 of 19 challenges, and was accurate in 51 of 58 passes, including 11 of 11 in attacking third.
Weak link: Only 7 of 35 Leeds crosses found a team-mate.
The Edge: Leicester had 9 attempts in first half, 8 of which were on target: three found the back of the net. Leicester also had more bite in the tackle: they attempted 178 challenges to 99 by Leeds. Harry Kewell, in 30 minutes of long-awaited return, completed 9 of 12 passes, won only 2 of 6 challenges, and had 2 attempts at goal, both off target.

LIVERPOOL 3 - 0 CHARLTON

Key man: Vladimir Smicer completed 12 of 13 passes, 4 of 4 crosses, had a shot and laid on a goal. All this in 21 minutes.
Weak link: Charlton have conceded relatively few goals from crosses this season - only 6 - but today allowed Liverpool to complete 15 of 22 crosses, and score three in the air.
The Edge: Emile Heskey took 6 attempts on goal, scoring once to kill off a Charlton team who had 56% of net possession.

MANCHESTER UNITED 2 - 0 TOTTENHAM

Key man: A goal and assist for Paul Scholes. Interestingly, all his 7 goals this season have been scored at home.
Weak link: Not a single attempt on goal for the declining Dwight Yorke.
The Edge: United had 70% of net possession until the opening goal, then dropped a gear, finishing with 60% for the match. United defence has only allowed 6 attempts on target in their last 3 Premiership games.

WEST HAM 1 - 0 MIDDLESBROUGH

Key man: Rigobert Song is settling in well. He won 12 of 15 challenges, completed 17 of 21 passes, and made 13 clearances.
Weak link: Boro strikers Noel Whelan and Brian Deane did not produce a single attempt on target.
The Edge: The Hammers cruised to their win, more than doubling Boro's totals in attempts and crosses (22 to 5). And not enough is being said and written about Stuart Pearce: he had another battling afternoon, winning 22 of 25 challenges, and making 16 clearances.

webTitle: Coca-Cola forms alliance with Interpublic

fields.headline: Coca-Cola links up with Interpublic for global strategy
fields.standfirst: Coca-Cola targets trend-setters
fields.trailText:
Coca-Cola has announced an alliance with marketing services group Interpublic to develop a global communications strategy for the world's biggest brand. By Claire Cozens.
Coca-Cola targets trend-setters
fields.body:
Coca-Cola has announced an alliance with marketing services group Interpublic to develop a global communications strategy for the world's biggest brand.

The move is an attempt to develop a more unified image for the flagship Coca-Cola brand.

The company spends an estimated $1bn a year on marketing Coca-Cola, but in recent years it has been criticised for putting across an inconsistent message about the brand.

The two companies will set up an advisory council to develop a global "brand essence" for Coca-Cola. This can then be used by local Coca-Cola marketeers as part of the company's new "Think local, act local" strategy.

Stephen C Jones, chief marketing officer for Coca-Cola, said: "Interpublic will act as creative consultant and idea generator at the global level, enabling our marketers around the world to take the core messages about the brand Coca-Cola and ensure their relevance to consumers at the local level.

"This is about telling the Coca-Cola story and ensuring that the basic messages about the world's premier brand have a foundation of consistency."

The new council will generate ideas for all marketing for the main Coca-Cola brand, including sponsorship and sales promotions as well as traditional advertising.

The decision, announced late on Friday, will come into effect early next year.

webTitle: 'Cambridge Two' can stay free, say appeal court judges

fields.headline: 'Cambridge Two' can stay free, say appeal court judges
fields.trailText: Two charity workers jailed in a landmark case for "knowingly permitting" drug dealing at a hostel were yesterday told they could go free.
fields.body:
Two charity workers jailed in a landmark case for "knowingly permitting" drug dealing at a hostel were yesterday told they could go free.

But Ruth Wyner and John Brock will have to wait until next year before they find out whether their convictions will be quashed.

Wyner and Brock - dubbed the Cambridge Two - were sentenced to five and four years respectively after an undercover police operation revealed that heroin was being widely dealt at The Bus day centre in Cambridge.

Although they conceded they knew that some dealing had gone on, the pair were shocked by the extent of the problem. At the trial they were criticised for not sharing what they believed was confidential information about their clients with the police.

In July, after spending 207 days in prison, the pair were given leave to appeal against the convictions and sentences. They were freed on bail but told they might have to return to prison if their convictions were not overturned.

Yesterday three appeal court judges decided to reserve final judgment but Lord Justice Rose said they considered the sentences "far too long".

He said: "We are not minded to send the appellants back to prison". If the convictions are quashed the Crown will not demand a retrial.

The pair walked from court cheered by supporters who had packed the public gallery.

Wyner said: "That's just the best Christmas present anyone could have really."

"The whole thing has cost an enormous amount of public money - well over £1m. I feel things could be done differently. We've been dragged through the courts and prison over the last two and a half years and the effect on my family has been appalling.

"The case is very important to the whole homeless sector - it involves our ability to work safely with drug addicts."

At the trial last year a raft of the centre's policies came under scrutiny. The charity had drawn up a policy banning illegal drugs. But it believed that a policy of confidentiality was necessary to forge an atmosphere of trust. An "open door" policy - allowing visitors to walk in off the street without being checked or searched - was thought to be another vital feature of the centre.

The prosecution argued that the pair were not doing everything in their power to stop dealing. It suggested they could have halted the open door policy and shared information about users with the police.

William Clegg QC, for the Crown, repeated yesterday that the pair must have had a very good idea that "trading in heroin was widespread and epidemic through the entire building".

And he argued that the refusal to give police the names of those selling heroin was "unreasonable".

He added: "You can't, we submit, escape criminal liability by reliance on a code of confidentiality."

Michael Mansfield QC, for Wyner and Brock, argued that the trial judge, Jonathan Haworth, erred in not allowing the jurors to consider whether, in the light of their policies, the pair acted reasonably in not telling the police what they knew about drug dealing.

He told the appeal judges that the case was of "considerable public importance" because the charity was run on similar lines to many other such organisations.

Mr Mansfield said that though Wyner and Brock had been told by police that heroin dealing was going on, they were unaware of the scale. "They felt they had done as much as they could to control the problem."

webTitle: Mersey TV blazes a trail with Hollyoaks story

fields.headline: Mersey TV blazes a trail with Hollyoaks storyline
fields.trailText: 10.45: Mersey TV has cooked up another volatile concoction for Channel 4 soap Hollyoaks, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Mersey TV, the company behind the Brookside gas explosion and the Emmerdale plane crash, has cooked up another volatile concoction for Channel 4 soap Hollyoaks.

Viewers will see Sol Patrick, played by Paul Danan, and his girlfriend, former prostitute Jess (Frankie Hough), trapped in the Hollyoaks local while a fire started by Jess's pimp Steve (Conor Ryan) rages out of control.

The incendiary storyline will play out across the last Hollyoaks episode this year and continue on New Year's day and the following two instalments of the soap.

Mersey TV and founder Phil Redmond have developed a reputation for putting on explosive event storylines.

And in 1994 Mr Redmond was seconded to ITV soap Emmerdale to oversee a Lockerbie-style plane crash that did away with numerous unwanted characters.

Last year Brookside Close, the most dangerous address in soapland, was rocked by a gas explosion.

Hollyoaks itself is no stranger to controversy. Earlier this year the programme provoked outrage by airing UK TV's first male rape scene.

webTitle: Stuart Jeffries meets Emmanuelle Béart

fields.headline: A woman of substance
fields.standfirst: French actress Emmanuelle Béart tells Stuart Jeffries why she has turned her back on Hollywood
fields.trailText: French actress Emmanuelle Béart tells Stuart Jeffries why she has turned her back on Hollywood.
fields.body:
Emmanuelle Béart lights a cigarette and wraps her famous lips around it. Those lips about which I have been advised to ask no questions - certainly none with the word "collagen" in them. She inhales sharply, exhales poutingly and then turns to face me across the table at her publicist's Paris flat.

"It was a strange mixture of a woman who is like porcelain and, at the same time, anchored in the ground," she says. Béart is talking about Pauline, the character she plays in her new film, Les Destinées Sentimentales. But she might also be talking about herself. She looks like porcelain, with her long, thin, elegant neck, slender figure and large grey-blue eyes.

Like her fellow French actress Isabelle Adjani, Béart is ludicrously, even frostily, beautiful - despite her nondescript sweater, dubious feather cut (with its unfortunate fringe), and lack of make-up. I can't help looking at her, not necessarily with desire, but with astonishment to be confronted with someone so exceptionally good-looking.

Les Destinées Sentimentales is an adaptation by the accomplished French director Olivier Assayas of Jacques Chardonne's epic novel set in the Charente region of France over a 30-year period straddling the first world war. It's a very difficult book to adapt for the screen, not least because it has two focuses.

First, there is a topically resonant story of the march of mass production and how this affects porcelain and cognac, two traditional industries in southwest France. Present day McDonald's-despising peasant campaigners would rightly see in this a critique of globalisation.

All very important, of course, but the difficulty Assayas never really surmounts is not only making these issues interesting on screen, but wedding them to the other focus - the story of Protestant pastor Jean (played by Charles Berling), whose marriage to the viperous, damaged Nathalie (played wonderfully by Isabelle Huppert) is falling apart. In the middle of this torment, Jean glimpses Pauline across a crowded ballroom and sees in her the possibility of happiness. Their subsequent 30-year relationship follows Béart from dewy-eyed ingenue to mature woman in a grey-haired wig. It's an unlikely role for Béart to have taken on, because it requires a very modest performance. "I was afraid I wouldn't have the humility necessary to play the role of a woman who is only the wife of someone," she says. "I've played lots of roles that were excessive, women in the fires of passion.

"I found Pauline by abandoning myself to what Olivier wanted. In the ball scene near the very start of the film, I am playing Pauline aged 20. Now I'm 36, so I had to try to recall how I was at 18 years old, when I first fell in love. But it was mannered. "Then Olivier said: 'This really isn't it at all.' It upset me and I went and stood in the corner with my fists clenched. But he was right. What he wanted was for Charles Berling and I to create something on the spot, rather than falling back on old tricks. I had to abandon all of those."

Béart lives in Paris with her partner, David Moreau, and her two children, eight-year-old Nelly and four-year-old Johan. Nelly's dad is the French actor Daniel Auteuil, with whom Béart had a decade-long relationship. She tries to be private but, in France at least, she often fails. "The press follow me. I sue them. That's the deal," she says. She has been an ambassador for Unicef, and, more controversially, has lent her name to protests against anti-immigration legislation.

As an actress, too, she tries to portray herself as anchored, a scrupulous performer who takes succour from the hard work necessary to create a character. In this she's like Robert de Niro, though less butch. He learned to play the saxophone before starring as a jazz musician in Martin Scorsese's New York, New York. Similarly, in preparation for her performance in Claude Sautet's 1992 film Un Coeur En Hiver, she practised the violin for three hours a day for 18 months.

But, unlike the truculent De Niro, she can talk about what she does in sentences. "I have a sense of work, a sense of duty and of things well done," she says, and her description of how she approached the part of Pauline is suggestive. "When I was preparing for this role, I never looked in the mirror. I had no notion of what I looked like. Let the others do the light, the hair, the make-up. The light is elsewhere: the light is in me." How extraordinary that an actress so renowned for her beauty should not look in the mirror for guidance.

Similarly, she doesn't like to see her old films. Why? Another drag and a pouting exhale. "I don't know. Because they're part of the past. I don't see my old films, but I think of the characters I played as friends, like the women I meet in my life who made strong impressions on me. I remember them and they are part of me."

And what a cast of characters they would be if they met for drinks and nibbles. There would be the girl she played aged 10 in her screen debut, a low-budget sci-fi drama called Demain Les Mômes (Tomorrow the Kids), about a group of children living in the aftermath of a nuclear holocaust. There would be the vengeful, enigmatic mountain girl of Claude Berri's 1986 Manon des Sources. There would be the recalcitrant artist's model from Jacques Rivette's 1991 film La Belle Noiseuse, a four-hour picture in which she was mostly nude, while Michel Piccoli's dubious painter did her picture, his creative (and no doubt other) juices flowing once more after years of liquidity problems.

There would also be several characters she probably wouldn't count as friends, English-speaking ones mostly, but some characters from her early 1980s soft-porn flicks, too. And there would be a great many sophisticated Frenchwomen whom she would clasp proudly to her bosom - the violinist in Un Coeur En Hiver, the sensual amanuensis in Sautet's Nelly and Monsieur Arnaud, the love-torn woman in Régis Wargnier's 1995 melodrama Une Femme Française.

It has been some career. But these are just memories. Now Emmanuelle has become Pauline, so much so that the actress who incarnated her has disappeared entirely. "When I do an interview it always has the resonance of the character I have just played. I've been speaking to you as Pauline. If we do another interview, no doubt I'll be speaking like another character."

That old ruse: the professional actress hiding behind her masks. "I'd like to do an interview with the real Emmanuelle Béart, please. Perhaps in a month?" I suggest. She switches from French to English. "OK. No problem. I'll ask her if she's free," she says coquettishly. "She might not be."

Béart speaks English well - most of it learned during her misbegotten dalliance with Anglo-Saxon cinema, which started in 1987 with Date With an Angel. It continued with Brian De Palma's Mission: Impossible in 1996, in which she played Tom Cruise's moll. For an actress who had by then played many meaty, mature roles, this seemed a barmy choice - made stranger because Juliette Binoche and Anne Parillaud had (understandably) turned it down as too demeaning. Her peformance got a real pasting.

"Mission: Impossible was really a curiosity for me," says Béart. "I always say 'Why not?' I am a voyager - and the voyage cannot mean that I stay at home."

Critics were scarcely any kinder about her performance in Elephant Juice, the Amy Jenkins-scripted 1999 film about thirtysomething Londoners in which Béart played a sophisticated Frenchwoman, very much against the grain of the rest of the picture. "I haven't seen it," she says flatly.

"It's not in my character to regret things," says Béart of these films, but then adds: "I have no more desire to play in Hollywood. I think my best work has been in France with great men. It's been my great fortune to work with really great men - with Olivier Assayas, Raoul Ruiz, Jacques Rivette. I am tutored by them.

"I think especially of the late Claude Sautet, from whom I learned such a great deal. I always recall he said that talent is 2% talent and 98% work. I always keep that in my head." She must have kept that in her head when she worked on Ruiz's adaptation of the last volume of Proust, Le Temps Retrouvé, two years ago.

"When we filmed one scene, Raoul said, 'I want to do it with you really tired.' So we did 40 takes and at the 40th I said, 'I'm really tired, I want to go to bed.' And he said: 'That's it. That's perfect.' And that last take was the one he used.

"He's one of the most brilliant men I have met in my life. He's absolutely capable of talking of the most intimate, fragile things. I need to work with people like that."

What are her ambitions now? "I have no particular desire to work at the moment, but that will pass. I will meet someone and have the desire to see them again, and end up working with them. That's what happened with Raoul and Olivier."

As I leave, she says, almost flirtatiously, "Say something nice to me in English." All I can manage is: "I usually really hate interviewing celebrities, but you weren't so bad." "That'll do," she says. "You can go now." I wonder if this Pauline, Emmanuelle, whoever she was, will want to see me again. Probably not.

 Les Destinées Sentimentales opens on December 8.

webTitle: Lastminute boss bullish despite losses

fields.headline: Lastminute boss bullish despite losses
fields.standfirst: Dec 4: Lastminute losses soar
fields.trailText:
12.15pm update: Lastminute.com boss Brent Hoberman said today his company was 'a calm ship in a storm' despite today's announcement of deepening losses, writes Dan Milmo
Dec 4: Lastminute losses soar
fields.body:
They were the king and queen of the dot.com revolution, and after eight crushing months on the market their confidence remains undented.

After seeing £600m wiped off the value of his company since it floated in March, chief executive Brent Hoberman, who launched Lastminute.com in 1998 with Martha Lane Fox, insisted the company was a shining beacon for others.

He said: "The shake-out which is occurring makes us a calm ship in the storm. It is businesses like ours with long term growth prospects which will survive.

"We want to be judged on the quality of our businesses and what we do."

The 31-year-old Etonian distanced his company from the bloodbath in new economy stocks, which has seen Lastminute's share price plummet 40% over the past six weeks.

He has also reassured investors that delays in launching a new website have not affected the company.

"The impact was definitely overstated. It is a strong positive that we were able to beat our revenue forecasts on our old website. People should look to the effects of our new site over the next year," said Mr Hoberman.

The Lastminute boss denied the hold-up had been a disaster. The £8m refit contributed to full-year losses of £35.75m.

The much-vaunted relaunch was constantly pushed back from its summer deadline due to technical hitches, only for the site to crash minutes after it was unveiled last month.

Lastminute's difficulties contributed to analysts' jitters over the company, which is not expected to make profit for several years.

Mr Hoberman said he made "no apologies" for being a business-to-consumer internet company, and said the business had been unfairly lumped in with its under-performing peers.

Lastminute has healthy cash reserves of around £100m to cushion the bumpy ride ahead, but with the US economy heading for a "soft landing" at best and internet stocks continuing to spiral downwards, the company may struggle to pull away from the pack.

However, early trading showed signs of a recovery in Lastminute's shares, which rose 7.7%, or 4p, to 77p.

Lastminute's difficulties contributed to analysts' jitters over the company, which is not expected to make profit for several years. Mr Hoberman said he made "no apologies" for being a business-to-consumer internet company, and said the business had been unfairly lumped in with its under-performing peers. Lastminute has healthy cash reserves of around £100m to cushion the bumpy ride ahead, but with the US economy heading for a "soft landing" at best and internet stocks continuing to spiral downwards, the company may struggle to pull away from the pack. However, early trading showed signs of a recovery in Lastminute's shares, which rose 7.7%, or 4p, to 77p.

webTitle: EM.TV sells off minority stake to Kirch

fields.headline: EM.TV sells off minority stake to Kirch
fields.trailText: 10.30am: EM.TV has confirmed the expected sale of a minority stake to media giant Kirch Group, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
EM.TV, the German company that bought Muppets producer Jim Henson earlier this year, has confirmed the expected sale of a minority stake to media giant Kirch Group.

The Kirch Group will hold 16.74% of EM.TV's equity and 25% of the firm's voting rights. In addition, Kirch is to acquire 49% of EM.TV's shares in Formula One holding company SLEC for £382m.

EM.TV founder and chief executive Thomas Haffa will remain the largest shareholder in the group.

The two companies will work together closely in future, with EM.TV focusing on its original core business of children's television.

It will also take full control of the children's TV programme library formerly owned via a joint venture with Kirch.

EM.TV's deal with Kirch comes after the troubled media company slashed full-year profit forecasts and reported a loss in the third quarter of this year.

The firm's earnings before interest, taxes, debt and amortisation for the first nine months of the year showed a loss of £5m.

The value of EM.TV's share price, once on a par with some of the biggest companies in Germany, has plunged nearly 90% since February.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Independent producers fight for their rights

fields.headline: We will fight for our rights
fields.standfirst: Britain's leading independent producers want one thing from the communications white paper: the rights to their programmes. In an open letter to the government, Tom Gutteridge, Denise O'Donoghue, Jimmy Mulville, Charles Brand and Paul Smith argue that it is the producers who put the creative into "creative industry"
fields.trailText: Britain's leading independent producers want one thing from the communications white paper: the rights to their programmes. In an open letter to the government, Tom Gutteridge, Denise O'Donoghue, Jimmy Mulville, Charles Brand and Paul Smith argue that it is the producers who put the creative into "creative industry".
fields.body:
The publication of the communications white paper is just a few days away, and we hope that the government has got its priorities right. If the intention is to support and encourage the growth of Britain's creative industries, it needs to make sure it knows what a creative industry really is. In the area of television, successive administrations have got it badly wrong.

In the past, the term "television industry" has been synonymous with "broadcasting". Of course, broadcasters have always been the lifeblood of the television producer. They broadcast what we create and reap rewards from our programmes, either in advertising revenue or, in the case of the BBC, in the millions of viewers who tune in and justify the licence fee.

But although many broadcasters have successful producing arms, a broadcaster's primary task is to sit in the distribution chain, not drive the creative hub. That's our responsibility - both independent and in-house producers. We believe that the government should understand that there is a distinction between the generators of creative property (the producers, some of whom are also broadcasters) and the media distributors.

Media distribution includes publishing, internet, narrowcasting and the many forms of new media. If the government wants to support television's "creative industry" it needs first to look to the content generators; from our success and strength everything else will flow - better programmes, international sales and creative diversity.

We need to look at the ways in which Britain, as a centre of the English-speaking world, can take advantage of the massive worldwide increase in demand for creative media - currently the world's fastest expanding industry.

To use the language of the 1998 Competition Act, broadcasters in the UK are in a dominant market position. As a result, they have a legal responsibility to avoid abuse of that position. When we produce programmes for ITV we use an agreed terms of trade which was approved by both the office of fair trading and the then monopolies and mergers commission.

We are thus more than happy with the current ITV Network Centre arrangements, whereby independent producers and ITV companies retain all the rights to their productions beyond the ITV broadcast. The ITV viewers get the programmes, ITV companies get the ad revenue and we get the chance to exploit our brands both here and overseas.

This environment can create phenomenal success, as the international and domestic exploitation of Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? proves. Indeed, the successful indies have demonstrated beyond question that they are more than capable of distributing, reformatting, merchandising and, in short, creating successful enterprises from our creative inventions.

Sadly, it is only on ITV where we enjoy these terms: no wonder, really, for these terms of trade were designed to suit both the independents and the ITV companies' own producers. Elsewhere, the broadcasters have insisted on obtaining all rights in programmes in exchange for the commission.

Now many of us enjoy excellent relationships with our commissioners. But when it comes to negotiating our rights contracts, we still encounter real resistance. It's hard to understand why. Independent producers like us are seeking to embrace the new media opportunities not just by creating television programmes, but also by developing and managing media brands derived from the intellectual property that we, after all, created in the first place.

Of course, the broadcast television programme is often the most important derivative (and can drive brand exploitation in other media), but usually other "products" (video, publishing, pay per view, merchandising, internet) are substantially more lucrative extensions of the same brand than the original terrestrial broadcast. These brand derivatives can generate significant new revenues for the television industry, for the benefit of broadcasters, producers and distributors. If only we could be allowed to exploit them.

For years now, the BBC and Channel 4 have tried wherever possible to control all rights in a programme "brand" (including copyright, distribution rights, trademarks, secondary rights and other rights not directly connected to broadcasting) when in fact all they have really needed is a right to broadcast.

Most independents have been unable to do anything about it: they find it hard to retain ownership or to control rights in the programmes they produce, or even in the underlying ideas and formats they have created.

This is unfair, and it is also costing Britain dearly. Millions of pounds worth of inward investment and exports are lost as a result. The broadcast programme pays only a token gross margin to the producer (usually a margin of between 6 and 12%) from which the producer has to fund central overheads, research and development of new programmes, international development and exploitation and other costs. That's why the creative industry is scarcely an industry at all.

If other means of brand development are denied to producers then we have no way to increase our margin, thus endangering research and development of new programme ideas. Our net margin falls to a little over break-even (at best). As a result, very few independents are publicly owned - most recent acquisitions have been by broadcasters, who can only gain from owning ideas factories.

We believe that a substantial amount of outside investment would be available for the creative side of the television industry if only intellectual property could be retained by the creators as an automatic right. This new money could relieve pressure on the licence fee and on advertising revenue.

Investors require a return, however, and to give them this, the independent sector must be allowed to generate the kind of gross margins available to virtually every commercial enterprise in the world. As no one wants to see the cost of production rise, the only way to achieve this is to allow the independents to own, control and exploit their own brands.

This would immediately result in city and international investment in our creative sector; a substantial increase in income from international sales and licensing of rights overseas; and the beginnings of a competitive and thriving secondary television market.

We fail to see how this would disadvantage the broadcasters. When broadcasters control the rights in an independent production, nine times out of 10 they are not focused on, nor capable of, fully exploiting brands as well as the producing company.

They have no financial imperative (as they currently do not need the revenues for their survival); their concern is to build their own brand, rather than the programme's; their distribution arms are flooded with programmes and rights most of which they have little interest in exploiting; many producers do it better and more efficiently - we have a passion and a hunger which no broadcaster could ever match.

We know that the generation of additional revenue is essential to the future survival of the BBC, and that the licence payer deserves to benefit from exploitation of programmes which the licence fee has funded. We believe that the BBC should share in the revenues from brands it has helped to develop - we actually want to increase the BBC's external revenues to encourage it to commission more programmes.

Channel 4's remit also means that in the future it may need more than just its advertising revenue to survive. But why does this mean that the BBC should have an automatic right to do the exploiting? We sincerely believe that if only broadcasters trusted the producers to build their own brands, the entire television sector would benefit. And then, at long last, the term "creative industry" could at last take on real meaning.

 Tom Gutteridge is chairman of Mentorn Barraclough Carey; Denise O'Donoghue and Jimmy Mulville are joint managing directors of Hat Trick Productions; Charles Brand is managing director of Tiger Aspect Productions; and Paul Smith is managing director of Celador Productions.

webTitle: Assessing election campaign advertising

fields.headline: The ads that don't add up
fields.standfirst:
Political parties spend millions on election campaigns but it could be money down the drain

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Winston Fletcher Political parties spend millions on election campaigns but it could be money down the drain
fields.body:
There is wonderful irony in the news that the Tories last week tried to slash the limit on campaign spending proposed by the political parties, elections and referendums bill. At every previous general election the Tory wallet has, of course, been far fatter than Labour's. The legislation was designed by the government to hobble this inbuilt Tory advantage. But the boot is now firmly on the other foot. The Tories are now so skint that they are scared Labour will easily outspend them next time round - which is why they tried to chop the new curb from £20m to £15m or even less.

But the fundamental question neither party is asking is whether any of this will make a jot of difference to people's voting behaviour. In 1997 the Tories spent nearly twice as much as Labour, and much good it did them. Does anyone really change their vote simply because they see rival party billboards slinging mud at each other?

Contrary to popular belief, political advertising - selling politics like baked beans, as critics claim - isn't a modern phenomenon. It dates back to Roman times. In Victorian Britain it was commonplace. And there were questions in parliament about candidates' expenditure being too lavish during the 19th century.

But modern political campaigning began in earnest the United States after the second world war. In 1948 a leading American businessman offered the Republican presidential candidate, Thomas Dewey, a complete, professional campaign for the first time using television as well as all other media. Dewey rejected the offer - and lost. These two facts may, or may not, have been connected. It was a risk General Eisenhower, the Republican candidate four years later, was unwilling to take. Using heavy advertising, based on the catchy slogan "I like Ike", Eisenhower romped home. Afterwards Rosser Reeves, the chairman of Ike's advertising agency, boasted: "If only Dewey had used these advertising techniques he too would have been president." That was neither honest nor truthful. Eisenhower was a sure-fire winner, Dewey an almost equally certain loser.

Politicians, however, are rarely interested in such subtleties. They fell for Reeves's boast hook, line and pollster. The era of all singing and dancing political razzmatazz had arrived. But while Ike's slogan was positive, today most political advertising is depressingly negative. So why don't politicians promote their policies, instead of just rubbishing their opponents? The explanation usually given is that voters now have such a lousy opinion of politicians that pejorative advertising is the only kind they will believe.

There may be a grain of truth in this, but it is not the whole truth. Today the gulf between most opposing parties is quite narrow. All parties support high employment, low inflation, better health, more education and so on - so the differences between them concern means rather than ends. Differences of means are difficult to dramatise in a few words on a billboard. And when a party tries to present its policies, more often than not they sound like motherhood and apple pie: warm and cosy, but undifferentiating and uninspiring.

Moreover it's a mistake to think all political advertising is aimed at winning over voters from the other side. Often it is primarily intended to hearten established supporters and reassure wobblers. There is no better way of rallying your own troops, as generals have always known, than by vilifying the enemy.

In politics this is relatively easy, not least because the Advertising Standards Authority has always refused to control election campaigns on the grounds that this would constitute interfering with the democratic process. And anyway it takes time to prove ads untruthful. So what could the ASA do? Throw out the government when the election was over?

Interestingly however, in countries with proportional representation negative advertising is far less common. When several parties are in with a chance it is almost impossible for them all to sling muck at each other.

Does negative advertising work? Studies have shown it is better remembered than positive advertising, but about three-quarters of voters dislike it a lot. Psephologists have, however, pointed out that their declared antipathy does not appear to be reflected in their behaviour at the ballot box. And I suspect the researchers have paid too little attention to the fact that much, if not most, political advertising is simply designed to bolster existing support, an effect which is all but impossible to measure.

Like the public, politicians universally claim to deplore negative advertisements. Yet they relentlessly go on using them. So politicians must be convinced they work - but nobody knows for sure. Focus groups and other research techniques are used increasingly, but they are far from foolproof. In the authoritative 15-year study How Voters Decide, by Hilde Himmelweit, Patrick Humphreys and Marianne Jaeger, neither the word advertising nor any of its synonyms is mentioned even once.

One fundamental difference between political and other advertising lies in its discontinuity. Commercial advertisers can, and do, test their advertising by desisting from it in comparable regions of the country, for measured periods. They can then assess sales in the areas where advertising has continued and in those where it hasn't. Such experiments cannot be carried out at general elections. Even if a party were to stop advertising in some regions and not in others - which would be a brave, not to say suicidal, decision - who can say whether the results would still be applicable in utterly different circumstances five years later?

The only known test was carried out some time ago in Illinois, when one candidate deliberately withdrew his advertising in certain areas. It was a local election, the turnout was very low, and Illinois isn't Britain, so the results must be treated with caution. Moreover the report on the test begins: "No classic study of voting behaviour has found political advertising an important determinant of voting behaviour." None the less the Illinois test suggested that in areas where he advertised, the advertisements increased the candidate's support by about 3%.

The chances are, then, that advertising probably encourages a small percentage of voters to change sides. Simultaneously, and probably more importantly, it activates the activists and supports the preconceptions of supporters.

In a close call, such as the US presidential race, a handful of votes can make all the difference as we have seen. In a landslide, like our own 1997 election, the advertising was almost certainly irrelevant, a waste of hard cash. But nobody can ever be absolutely sure, in advance, whether an election will be a walkover or a photo-finish. So the politicians have no choice but to go on spending. If the pollsters are right, and Labour is going to walk away with it again, the new limit will make little or no difference, and both parties are about to throw millions down the drain.

 Winston Fletcher is communications director of advertising agency FCB Europe.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Maggie Brown on religious broadcasting

fields.headline: Losing our religion
fields.standfirst:
As Christmas approaches, the bishops of the Church of England are keeping a close eye on the BBC's religious programming. Maggie Brown reports on the struggles between entertainment and enlightenment

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: As Christmas approaches, the bishops of the Church of England are keeping a close eye on the BBC's religious programming. Maggie Brown reports on the struggles between entertainment and enlightenment.
fields.body:
The bishops of the Church of England will be laying aside their Bibles this Advent and scanning the text of the Radio Times instead. "The broadcasters know we expect to see the same quality and quantity of religious broadcasting over Christmas and the New Year, which was so welcome over the millennium," warns the Bishop of Wakefield, the Right Rev Nigel McCulloch.

"You don't have a feeling there is anyone in the BBC championing these programmes," says the Bishop of Liverpool, the Right Rev James Jones. "It is incumbent on public service broadcasters to provide proper funding and places in the schedules."

Last year, a bumper Songs of Praise with 60,000 trusty singers brought joy to the bishops - but also fanned the flames of disquiet because it showed what a power religious television can still be on BBC1. When Joan Bakewell quit Heart of the Matter over its ever-later time slot - it was then axed - she sent a shock wave through the faithful.

The Bishop of Wakefield's words carry particular force. He sits in the House of Lords and is the head of the general synod's new broadcast monitoring group, which in the New Year will draw together its first report, dwelling on quality, funding and scheduling, not just quantity.

In a separate move, the Archbishop's council has just fielded a group of five bishops, including the Bishop of Liverpool, for a frank first meeting with the media. The monitoring is designed to keep independent tabs on religious broadcasting trends, after last February's synod (the governing body of the CoE) gave unanimous backing to a regretful motion, based on a report by ex-BBC producer Nigel Holmes called Losing Faith in the BBC.

The key fact unearthed by Holmes was that while hours of output on BBC1 and BBC2 had doubled over the previous 10 years, religious programming had declined by one third. This is not contested by the BBC, though many were puzzled by the report's failure to link this trend to the decline in church attendance in this country and by the cleanish bill of health it gave to ITV.

Nor is it a purely Church of England matter any more. Neville Nagler, director general of the British Board of Deputies, says: "Religious output? It's a bit thin. There is a growth in interest in society in spiritual matters. But this is not being reflected by the broadcasters." The huge debates sparked by the plight of the conjoined twins and the murder of Damilola Taylor are just the most recent examples.

Dr Jim McDonnell, director of the Catholic Communications Centre in London, who welcomes the CoE initiative provided it's not purely negative, similarly observes that BBC television is "weak in religious news coverage".

Religious correspondent Emily Buchanan, he says, "finds it hard to get stories onto the news agenda. Religion is an important area of life. There could be much more insight into the connection between religion and politics in the rest of the world. Everyman editor Ruth Pitt insists it is flourishing in its post-10.30pm slot, and says she has been charged with devising a broad range of ethical programmes, including a series for next autumn on ... Islam.

Yet since the synod's vote, BBC director of television Mark Thompson has questioned, in his Banff speech, whether it will make sense in the future to guarantee a slot for all the BBC's "less popular" genres on BBC1. Thompson says he has not received a single complaint about moving Everyman and, with BBC1's new strategy settled, all religious programmes are being looked at. It might move again, to BBC2 (in a more accessible 9pm slot).

Thompson says he'll consider what she says.

With the communications white paper due next week, promising lighter touch regulation, ITV confirms it is lobbying to have the requirement to screen religious programmes - historically written into ITV licences - dropped from the wording of the new act.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Can Emap jump its Q on to the net bandwagon?

fields.headline: Can Emap jump its Q on to the net bandwagon?
fields.standfirst: Emap has waited a long time before launching its stable of five music magazines on to the web. Perhaps too long ... Amy Vickers reports on a late bid to be the best
fields.trailText: Emap has waited a long time before launching its stable of five music magazines on to the web. Perhaps too long ... Amy Vickers reports on a late bid to be the best.
fields.body:
Some say it's 12 months too late, others say the timing couldn't have been better. But despite differing views over the company's strategy, most people are agreed that Emap Digital Music is finally making moves in the right direction.

This week, the Emap Digital Music project team, effectively the new media division of Emap Performance, launched the first of seven planned websites that take the suffix 4music.com. The strategy is still being thrashed out and Performance has not confirmed whether the 4music.com brand will be applied to all its stable of music magazines (Q, Smash Hits, Mojo, Kerrang! and Mixmag) and radio station Kiss.

At this stage, Emap is only happy to talk about definite plans for Q, its flagship music magazine which sells almost 200,000 copies each month, and Mojo, which will be given its first website before the end of the year.

Q4music will replace the token effort that was Qonline. Between now and next June (or thereabouts) Jerry Perkins, the man charged with setting up and managing Emap Digital's music sites, is working overtime to them off the ground. He has a tight schedule. By anybody's reckoning, seven sites in seven months is quite a tall order.

A partnership with HMV to integrate e-commerce across the sites in the form of "buyers' guides" - essentially reviews of the best albums to have in your collection - has given Emap a good platform on which to build sustainable revenue streams. But it's got a lot of lost ground to claw back, given that it is at least two years behind strong competition, such as IPC's NME and Miller Freeman's Dotmusic.

Additionally, the online music market has exploded in the past year with countless new entrants, such as Peoplesound, Hobomusic, Music3w, Music33, Music365, Popworld and Worldpop, all vying for a piece of the action.

Q4Music and the other planned Emap Performance sites are steering clear of getting embroiled in the music download market, preferring to be a shop, a source of information, and the odd audio and video clip.

As this comes in the wake of Emap slashing its three-year digital investment by 30% to £120m, the company is a bit sensitive about how the market perceives it is spending its dwindling pot of digital cash.

Critics have questioned whether £9m for seven websites over a three-year period is enough to give Performance the online businesses it wants, particularly if it is not going to spend heavily on marketing, preferring instead to leave the promotion of the websites to its offline media properties.

Perkins insists the quiet way is the right way. "We're already reaching 30% [3m] of all active music consumers through our magazines, so there's no point running a large above-the-line ad campaign. We're not here to spend, we're here to build sites."

However, one observer makes the point that unless Emap makes some marketing investment in non-Emap media then it could end up just shouting to those who are already converted fans. "The danger is that it will fail to attract new audiences because there are so many other music websites out there. The extreme case is that it may start to cannibalise its offline audience. You have to try to grow the market and go beyond existing boundaries."

Mark O'Donoghue, chief operating officer at dotmusic.com, questions the fragmented approach. "It's quite a good looking site but it's not enough on its own. Emap should be able to drive all Q's existing readers to the site but I'm not sure to what degree it plans to redirect traffic between all the different sites. It could end up remaining a fragment ed experience."

The main criticism coming from the industry is targeted at Emap Performance's late entry into the online market. Perkins acknowledges that the music titles have been slow to take advantage of the opportunity offered by the market, but says there's still time. "We know we haven't got first mover advantage, so what we're aiming for is first prover advantage where we fuse great editorial with recommendations of what to buy."

Neil Robinson, media network director at NME.com, is convinced Emap will have its work cut out because of its lateness to market. "It's far more saturated than it was four years ago and the job is going to be made even harder because they're trying to build new, separate brands, rather than doing what we did and building the strongest brand into an umbrella brand." NME.com, which was recently relaunched, claims it reaches some 1.3m unique users a month.

Ben Drury, head of music at BTOpenworld and part of the launch team on dotmusic, agrees that the brand extensions using the 4music.com moniker could be more trouble than they're worth. "Emap might be better served joining the titles together online," he says. Asked whether he thinks Emap's delay in launching strong online music properties will count against it, Drury replies: "It's too little, too late. There's not much room left in the online music space for new entrants.

"Q4Music is a site that underwhelms me as there's nothing on there that other sites haven't already done, and a real lack of rich media. It should have been up there two years ago. After all this time and after the mess that was Qonline, I would have hoped that Emap would break new ground."

In contrast, Ernesto Schmitt, president of peoplesound.com, agrees with the team at Emap. "It's not too late as there's still a dearth of quality editorial on the net. While there is too much content online, what's lacking is properly managed editorial." Implicitly recognising this, Emap has pulled in heavyweight music journalist Paul Du Noyer, a former Q and Mojo editor, who moved across the group earlier this year to take on the job of editorial director of the Emap Digital music project.

Du Noyer is full of the right buzzwords, saying he wants the sites to be "great knowledge, lightly worn" and that the fusion of "editorial" (he has banned the word content) and commerce should be like "oil and water" because the two cannot really be mixed without compromising objectivity.

Du Noyer is keen to point out that even though the USP of the planned music sites will be the buyers' guides, his emphasis remains on integrity. "We'll have the edge over retail sites as our philosophy is that it's quality, not content. We've been in the market for 20 years and we know about good editorial. It's time to take this learning online."

One of the plans intended to add a sense of community to Q4music, in addition to the ubiquitous chatrooms, votes, crosswords and classifieds, is to build on the personalities of Q writers, giving them their own home pages.

One of the main strengths of the site will be the widely-respected album reviews, of which a database of 20,000 has been built for launch. Around 20% of site content will be taken from Performance's magazines with the newly recruited online editorial teams developing the rest.

While Emap is at pains to emphasise editorial integrity, rivals have raised a few eyebrows on hearing of its strategy to be the "greatest music buyers' guide in the world".

Robinson of NME.com says: "I'm not entirely convinced by the retail/media hybrid model. E-commerce is an important factor in driving revenues but the main thing is to excite and entertain music fans, and then let them decide whether they wish to go on to buy relevant products."

Drury of BTOpenworld agrees. "There's a fine line between editorial integrity and commercialism. By diluting editorial into a shopping experience, it could be seen to threaten the integrity of the reviews. From my experience, the best way to drive sales is through clever integration with content."

Defending Emap again, Schmitt from peoplesound.com says the buyers' guides are a sensible move but that it is important to dovetail them with quality editorial. Like other potential competitors, he welcomes the entry of Emap into the market, saying the more the merrier given that a lot of the smaller players will not survive the shake-out.

Robinson says he looks forward to Q and the likes of Mojo being in the same market, and dotmusic.com's O'Donoghue is glad Emap is finally here, despite his concern that the lack of consolidation in its strategy could be confusing for consumers.

The bottom line seems to be that Emap stands as good a chance as any other online music player that has recently hit the market. But then no one knows what the next six months has in store for anyone in the e-commerce sector, least of all the swathes of music sites out there jockeying for market share in the swelling online music business.

webTitle: GWR splits operations into five divisions

fields.headline: GWR restructures business into five divisions
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Commercial radio broadcaster GWR is reorganising its operations into five divisions focusing on areas including new media, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
GWR Group, the commercial radio broadcaster, is reorganising its operations into five divisions focusing on areas including new media and further acquisitions in the sector.

Ralph Bernard, GWR chief executive, will head the programming division, with a brief to ensure the firm's content is rolled out on to all appropriate distribution platforms.

Classic FM managing director Roger Lewis is to take responsibility for all commercial activities, including growing audiences for existing GWR services and extending the company's on-air brands into new revenue areas.

Steve Orchard, GWR group operations and programming director, is to head a new UK Local Radio division focusing on acquisitions and integration in anticipation of the relaxation of ownership rules in the communications white paper.

Mr Orchard's programming deputy, Dirk Anthony, has been appointed group programme director, responsible for the UK, and Wayne Lowery is to become local radio sales director within this division.

GWR's digital and new media operations are to be consolidated into one division under commercial director Simon Ward.

Mr Ward, who already heads GWR new media unit ecast Ventures, will be responsible for identifying potentially profitable initiatives.

Patrick Taylor, GWR deputy chief executive, will take on additional responsibility as head of the newly-created human resources division.

GWR is also creating three new boards to oversee this new structure. Mr Bernard is to chair the programming board, with Mr Lewis heading the commercial board and Mr Patrick overseeing the human resources board.

Mr Bernard said: "The new structure emphasises the three pillars on which our business is built: our programming success, our commercial customers and the people who work for us. The new boards will encourage rapid reaction to changes and opportunities in the key areas of our business."

webTitle: Honoured by Europe, actor berates British

fields.headline: Honoured by Europe, actor berates British
fields.trailText: Movie stars are renowned for the size of their egos, but the legendary Irish actor Richard Harris gave a truly novel performance this weekend by being ungracious in victory, rather than defeat.
fields.body:
Movie stars are renowned for the size of their egos, but the legendary Irish actor Richard Harris gave a truly novel performance this weekend by being ungracious in victory, rather than defeat.

As he received a lifetime achievement award from the European Film Academy, Harris used his acceptance speech to take a swipe at the British film industry for failing to give him a similar honour.

The 70-year-old Hollywood star, known for his youthful hellraising as much as his performances in films including Camelot, This Sporting Life and more recently Gladiator, said he was thrilled and humbled and hoped the sight of his trophy might jog a few British memories.

Collecting the award at a glittering ceremony in Paris, Harris said: "I want to congratulate you on choosing me. It is something that the British Academy [of Film and Television Arts] has failed to do annually."

He grumbled: "It is always the French. I got best actor at Cannes but the British seem to have forgotten me. Maybe now they will remember me."

No doubt Harris felt he had the last laugh as the British contingent left the event empty handed.

The box office hit Billy Elliot went unrecognised despite being tipped for a hat-trick of awards; it was seen as a hot contender for best film, with 14-year-old star Jamie Bell and his co-star Julie Walters nominated in the best actor and best actress categories.

The British animator Nick Park's first feature film, Chicken Run, was also defeated in the best film category as the Danish director Lars von Trier repeated his Cannes triumph with Dancer in the Dark.

Park's leading lady, pop star Bjork, was named best actress.

Frenchman Sergi Lopez was named best actor for his performance in Harry, He's Here to Help, while the French action hero Jean Reno and Italian actor-director Roberto Benigni, best known for his film Life is Beautiful, shared the European Achievement in World Cinema Award 2000.

The European Film Awards were created in 1988 as a counterpart to the Oscars. This year's ceremony was hosted by the actor Rupert Everett and television presenter Antoine de Caunes.

Frenchman Sergi Lopez was named best actor for his performance in Harry, He's Here to Help, while the French action hero Jean Reno and Italian actor-director Roberto Benigni, best known for his film Life is Beautiful, shared the European Achievement in World Cinema Award 2000. The European Film Awards were created in 1988 as a counterpart to the Oscars. This year's ceremony was hosted by the actor Rupert Everett and television presenter Antoine de Caunes.

webTitle: Lastminute losses soar

fields.headline: Lastminute losses soar
fields.trailText: 10am: The chairman of lastminute.com has admitted "there is still a lot to do" after losses increased sevenfold to £36m, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The chairman of lastminute.com has admitted "there is still a lot to do" after losses increased sevenfold.

The company, one of the most hyped dot.com stock, saw its full-year losses deepen from £4.5m last year to £35.7m, eating into the company's £100m cash reserve.

Revenues for the group remained small, rising to £3.7m from £0.1m on the back of a seven-fold increase in subscriber numbers to 2.8m.

It has been a bad year for the dot.com icon, with a controversial flotation, slump in share price, and a much-delayed new website.

However, Allan Leighton, Lastminute chairman and ex-boss of the Asda supermarket chain, said the results showed "solid growth".

He said: "Lastminute.com, like all good ideas, is a very simple, totally consumer-focused concept. We have already built barriers against competitive response and are performing ahead of plan."

Lastminute was founded by dot.com upstarts Martha Lane Fox and Brent Hoberman and floated in March this year at the height of the internet boom.

At its height the company's shared were worth a sensational 555p valuing the company at a colossal £788m.

The share price has since plummeted, hitting an all time low last month of 71.5p, partly because of delays in launching a new website and doubts over the company's revenue model, which is based on transaction fees.

However, Lastminute's stock rose 5%, or 2p, to 75p this morning thanks to the boost in subscriber figures and losses that did not exceed analysts' expectations.

Analysts will now wait to see how Lastminute performs over the Christmas period with its revamped website, and how it fares in the European market after spending £59m on French rival Degriftour in August.

webTitle: Media Guardian: My New Media

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Antony Ellis
fields.trailText: Antony Ellis, chief executive of taste.co.uk
fields.body:
Favourite sites?

Definitely Ft. It downloads via my Palm Pilot every day. I like websites which change your behaviour and make life easier. I used to listen to Radio 4 in the car but I now travel by motorbike and listen to BBC online live at work.

Last online purchase?

Air tickets to Scotland from EasyJet. It was simplicity itself. I trust EasyJet because it's a strong brand. It's important for the consumer to have a strong brand to trust in.

Most recent technological faux pas?

Like 95% of the western population I didn't know how to change my home page. My content director taught me how and it's easy when you know how.

Main news sources on the web?

Ft and BBC Online. Also the Economist online and Revolution.

Most persistent spam emailer?

Smartgroups is fantastic but they need to cut down the amount of times they communicate to me. You register, thinking it will be helpful, and then receive all these dreadful emails. I keep getting sent my horoscope.

Time spent on web?

A fair amount but in fits and starts.

Next clickmango?

Perhaps Boo. It's re-launched but hasn't changed its model. It's just new ownership. Any new media company that doesn't adopt real-world business principles and relies purely on internet advertising revenues for its business plan will be in danger.

Least useful site/s on web?

Something very current like The trainline. It's a great site but it's not getting a lot of traffic. Anything linked to railway networks at the moment is going to struggle.

Most useful site/s on web?

Streetmap. I use it all the time and it's wonderful for getting to meetings. It's such a time-saver.

What screensaver do you use?

I don't use them.

Most irritating thing about the web?

The most irritating thing is access. Access to the internet should be more simple. I don't want to always use a PC. We should link the internet through television and entertainment devices. I think the future is interactive TV.

Do you bother with old media?

Very much so. I wake up to John Humphrys each morning. I read the Financial Times and buy the London Evening Standard every day. Old media will continue, but supported by new media.

 Antony Ellis is the chief executive of Taste, a joint venture between Carlton TV and Sainsbury's to be launched this month.
