webTitle: Media Guardian: Simon Rogers' column

fields.headline: I am not a number - well, not entirely
fields.trailText: I used to think I was a name. Nowadays, like the Prisoner, I'm just a number. Actually, we're a number now: 22.1m. It's a nice round figure and is the latest monthly page impression for Guardian Unlimited from the ABC.
fields.body:
I used to think I was a name. Nowadays, like the Prisoner, I'm just a number. Actually, we're a number now: 22.1m. It's a nice round figure and is the latest monthly page impression for Guardian Unlimited from the ABC.

On one level it's a useful, and humbling, comparative figure - more than most other newspaper sites, less than the BBC. But after the celebration party has faded from memory, that number - and, more importantly, how it breaks down - still has relevance for us.

Colleagues who work on the paper sometimes complain that they feel as if they're in a vacuum, buffered from feedback. Sure, they get letters and emails from irate readers. But how many people actually looked at that in-depth analysis they slaved over for two days? Well, I can tell you. One of the key features of editing a website is the ability to find out exactly how many people look at every page on the network. And some of it is scary.

For instance, did you know that quite a few more people look at our interactive crossword than at all our columnists put together? Or that our news quiz is bigger than the breaking news headlines?

If we produce a special report on a newsy issue, that will be our biggest hit in a week. So, as you read this, our US election race report is probably the biggest news section on the site (unless something more interesting has happened since). Of course, once that race is over those impressions will go down markedly.

The problem with stats, however, is that you can't take them at face value. If we just ran what was most popular then maybe we would only produce a crossword and some breaking news headlines. But then what would be unique about the site that you couldn't get elsewhere?

At the same time, say we put a huge effort into putting an enormous legal judgment on the site to go with a big story, or we've got leaked documents that add authenticity to an investigation - should they go up? Of course. But look at the stats and they might barely feature.

Does that matter? The newspaper might print the full text of a significant prime ministerial speech and never know whether a single reader has looked at it. But the editorial reason for putting it there is totally valid - and the same applies online. Often, readers simply like the idea that something is there; that it gives the feeling of depth and mass-information that made people want to come to the site in the first place. A site is surely a sum of its parts - comprising a whole that people like.

And what users look at is not always what you might expect. I used to think that people would just automatically look at copy that we produce during the day, simply because of its sheer exclusivity. Of course, that was never the case. People look at what interests them and it's no longer enough simply to have something that's not in the paper. It has to be worth it.

There's also the fact that the vast majority of pages viewed are looked at by only a few people. Of course, what it's really about is that people are diverse. A good site should give people tangents to go off and explore on a whim, guiding them with the navigation and links but, more importantly, providing opportunities to pick their way around an increasingly enormous internet.

One of the most important skills in editing a paper was always an unerring sense of what the readers want, ensuring that they will come to you because they feel at home. Which is, after all, something developed over hundreds of years of newspaper editing. The simple act of choosing the stories that matter and explaining why they do.

Over-reliance on statistics is like relinquishing that role of bothering to find out what your readers want. It's saying that your judgment matters less. Besides being a dereliction of an editor's duty, it's also bound to be commercially suicidal. The reason why personalisation of news has yet to take off is because the majority of users want their news edited.

None of this stops me being a slave to the numbers. It's fascinating to see exactly how many impressions a piece that we spent hours putting together actually got. It teaches us what works and what doesn't. But they're useful only up to a point. Beyond that, it's back to good old-fashioned judgment. If you just based your site solely on the stats, why would you need to be an editor to perform your job? A computer could do it much better.

 Simon Rogers is deputy editor of Guardian Unlimited.

webTitle: Sex offender monitoring programme under strain

fields.headline: Sex offender monitoring programme under strain
fields.trailText: A new public protection system to manage the most dangerous sex offenders after their release from prison is already under strain because the numbers involved have trebled in the past year.
fields.body:
A new public protection system to manage the most dangerous sex offenders after their release from prison is already under strain because the numbers involved have trebled in the past year.

Home Office officials have told probation officers that around 30 offenders a month are now being identified as potentially dangerous: likely to pose a risk to the public, or in need of protection themselves on release.

The new system was put in place in April last year after the high profile release of sex offenders such as Sidney Cooke and Robert Oliver sparked vigilante protests.

An early warning system was set up, under which prison and probation authorities and the police advise Home Office ministers of their plans to handle the release of inmates deemed still to be particularly dangerous two months before they are due to leave jail.

Although the offenders have finished their sentences they agree to live in probation hostels with specific monitoring and supervision arrangements.

But a rise in the number of such dangerous offenders being released from 10 a month when the scheme got under way last year to about 30 a month now is putting it under great strain.

Paddy Doyle, a senior official in the Home Office's dangerous offenders unit, last week heard complaints from probation officers that it was becoming increasingly difficult to place all the offenders in appropriate accommodation because of the numbers involved.

The number of offenders deemed to be dangerous and living in London has now passed the 900 mark and the new Criminal Justice Act, which reached the statute book on Friday, will place a new duty on police and probation services to make arrangements for assessing and managing all convicted sex criminals and violent offenders on their patch.

Mr Doyle said the Home Office was also setting up a new unit to oversee the release plans for each prisoner who was deemed to be dangerous. A report on each one goes to the prisons minister, Paul Boateng.

So far only 40 sex offender orders have been made under the new system since its introduction last April. These require convicted sex offenders to register for at least five years and to comply with other conditions, which may include electronic tagging, to protect the public from serious harm.

As it costs an average of £24,000 a month for a police surveillance team to monitor just one offender round the clock, different methods of keeping track of these dangerous ex-prisoners are being developed around the country. In some areas the police and probation will offer a violent offender a "tenancy agreement" before they come out, under which they agree to curfew and tagging restrictions.

Harry Fletcher, the assistant general secretary, of the National Association of Probation Officers, said there was not enough money to provide the kind of monitoring of offenders that was needed.

"The probation service's liaison arrangements with the police are very good but unless resources are dedicated to this task I fear that something awful will happen."

webTitle: Police release film of Damilola

fields.headline: Police release film of Damilola
fields.standfirst: More on the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: Police today released CCTV footage of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor filmed just an hour before he was murdered.
fields.body:
Police today released CCTV footage of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor filmed just an hour before he was murdered.

The video shows him making his way to an after-school computer class at the library in Cronin Street, Peckham, south-east London.

Damilola, dressed in a distinctive silver padded jacket, is clearly seen hopping playfully between decorative stones and running along the lines in the paving of the square close to the library.

The CCTV footage begins at 3.44pm last Monday. Just over an hour later, police found Damilola bleeding to death in the stairwell of West Hordle Promenade, a short distance from his home.

At a Scotland Yard press briefing, Detective Superintendent David Dillnutt said: "When he arrived at the library, he was on his own, but there were a number of people in the area around the library and the square and the sports centre.

"Although a lot of people have helped us so far, more information is needed.

"We know he left the library at 4.25pm and walked across the square and across the front of the sports centre, but where did he go from there?

"I would ask any children and adults, did they see Damilola? Did they see him talk to anyone? Did they see anyone attacking him?

"However irrelevant you might think the information may be, please come forward."

Mr Dillnutt said that speculation about the motives for the attack, including one theory that Damilola had been caught up in turf war between rival young crack-cocaine dealers, was "less than helpful".

He added: "We are keeping an open mind. If people have any information then they should come forward.

"I'm hoping that, by releasing this CCTV footage, we can jog people's memories, that people will ask themselves did they see him in the streets nearby?"

He said that detectives were still keen to interview a group of six to 10 boys, aged about 14, who were seen in the square near the library as Damilola left.

Video footage of him leaving the building was not of sufficient quality to enable identification of the youths.

webTitle: Private parties

fields.headline: Private parties
fields.standfirst: The division between public policy and its operation has grown wider, as the Serps fiasco has shown, writes Hywel Williams
fields.trailText: Rational myth claims that government is a contract. Romantic Tories - when they existed - said it was a contract between the past, the present and the future. More secular liberals see it as a done deal. Individuals give up some rights (such as the native capacity to be my neighbour's beater) and keep other ones (such as the right to self-protection when my neighbour tries to beat me up). Government is the sum total of rights transferred-and exists to protect the rights retained.
fields.body:
Rational myth claims that government is a contract. Romantic Tories - when they existed - said it was a contract between the past, the present and the future. More secular liberals see it as a done deal. Individuals give up some rights (such as the native capacity to be my neighbour's beater) and keep other ones (such as the right to self-protection when my neighbour tries to beat me up). Government is the sum total of rights transferred-and exists to protect the rights retained.

Modern managerialism in government ignores the romance of the former myth but builds on the latter. For both left and right, government is a "service provider" which has customers and consumers.

A myth may grow in the telling. But that does not make it true - as the cruel incompetence of Serps reform has shown. A private sector business which behaved in this way would end up in the courts, sued for damages and forced into bankruptcy.

It is a dubious feat of political anorakia to remember that Norman Fowler was secretary of state for social services in 1986 - the year of the Serps policy change. Sir Norman retains a precarious niche in memory lane for the "crikey" of his startled response when apprised by informed officials of the finer details of oral sex as he prepared to launch the first anti-Aids campaign. That famous exercise in awareness, with its falling tombstones, was alarmist rather than informative. But when it came to Serps there were neither beats on the drum nor dissemination of intelligence. The Tories had decided that the state earnings-related pension was too expensive. In 14 years' time, therefore, the rights of surviving spouses would be halved. Like Newton's God who said "Let Nature be", the ministerial fiat sounded in the clear air.

But the second stage, the important one where policy becomes practice, never happened. No one told those affected that they had 14 years to prepare for the change.

The story is partly a Tory one of credulity about government and the ease of change; 1983-87 were the high-noon years. The monetarist folly was past and the European demons lay ahead. These were the privatising years - another change whose full consequences are also only being recognised a decade and a half later.

But the tale is one of three Labour years as well as of 11 Tory ones. So it's a question of how Britain is governed as well as who does it.

The divide between policy and operation, between theory and practice, is a new, self-serving, truth of the British constitution. The growth of quangos and agencies has eased its reception. Lines are now blurred between what is, and is not, a governmental act. Evasion displaces responsibility. The doctrine was famously used by Michael Howard when home secretary to sack Derek Lewis as director of the prison service, to deny his own accountability and thereby stay in office.

The same bogus distinction is now used by Norman Fowler and Alistair Darling as a clause of self-exculpation. A little thought could clear their minds of cant. A policy is an intent - and in law intention is father to the deed. Paternity has responsibilities. The line which leads from policy to administration, to deeds of commission as well as of omission, really does exist however winding the trail. The commonsense incredulity which greeted Michael Howard's disavowal is appropriate here as well.

But the mess is also a civil service question. Suspicion of politicians' easy convictions is natural to officialdom. The Whitehall service remains what it was after the mid-19th century reforms: a body of intelligent meritocrats. Once they served an aristocratic governing class - now they serve the bourgeois heirs. But if the class divide is gone the one of temperament, the distinction between professionals and amateurs, remains. A politician may be in full-time employment but a minister is always casual labour, a part-timer with excuses for distraction.

We should often celebrate civil service inertia. Mandarin piety acts as a brake on the enthusiasms of the swivel-eyed in all parties of government. This is especially important in a democratic despotism which gives large parliamentary majorities to parties with a slim majority of the popular vote. In terms of mandate, after all, New Labour's condition in 2000 is reminiscent of the Tories' in 1986.

But the Serps fiasco is an example of inertia translated into irresponsibility. And here another divide comes into play. Those charged with the practical implementation of policy exist in the regional office - not in the private office. It's quite easy for the senior official to plead ignorance of failure further down the line - and, like the minister, evade responsibility.

Now the government has given those affected another 12 years to prepare. But the awkward duet between minister and official, with its muffled tones and concealed dissonance will continue. The pensioners of 2012 have been warned of what's in store. But all of us can be wiser after this event - and be wary of government's myths.

webTitle: Media Guardian: New Media Diary

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: Amy Vickers
fields.body:
 The frenzy that hit London on Tuesday night when Madonna parachuted into Brixton was absolutely nothing compared to the frantic amount of activity going on in front of computer screens. The next day when Microsoft was boasting 9m users (a neat round figure!), a few muted voices were unconvinced.

Many of us spent Tuesday night staring at a jigsaw piece, attempting to reload and getting refused by the server. When the webcast finally came through, it was a sequence of dark, grainy, stuttering images. Blink and you'd miss Madge's best moves. So come on Microsoft, you can tell us: how many individuals actually managed to watch the webcast?

 Sometimes it's hard to be a woman (in new media). Particularly hard is choosing which of the innumerable female networking groups to support. Especially now. Thursday night was the battle of the girl parties with perhaps one of the biggest coincidences in history (or was it?).

Former members of e-women, the networking group disbanded in September after the founders had a public cat-fight, were forced into taking sides when the aptly renamed e-womenforum and the breakaway outfit Phoenix Network decided to go head-to-head. Members were torn. "Which is the more politically correct," said one such member, "going with the one that they all fell out with or going with the tofu crowd?" Decisions, decisions.

 Speaking of networking groups, a new group cropped up last week called Utterly. It all started a few weeks ago when one Sarah Uttley from ITEuropa sent an email to the new media cognoscenti and committed the cardinal sin of forgetting to blind copy recipients. Spotting every single email address of the agency great and good, the head-hunting emails started flying almost instantly and lots of jobs were touted around.

As a result, networkers from Nettec, Scient, Viant, Pixelpark and Oasis Communications all got together last week and formed Utterly. And so a new networking event has started. Because this industry certainly needs a few more.

 Word reaches us of the backroom antics of Freeserve lawyers Herbert Smith who have been working overtime on the intricacies of a possible buy-up by Wanadoo. Praying for the deal to go though is Emap, a company with a huge smile on its face ever since Wanadoo's name was connected with Freeserve.

Why? Emap has a £8.5m joint venture in France with Wanadoo to do a couple of websites. You wouldn't know this though if you spoke to Emap Digital staff, who are biggin' up the connection and letting people think that Wanadoo is a joint venture between Emap and France Télécom. It'll take more than that to rescue Emap's share price.

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: UpMyStreet sets up TV 'car boot sale'

fields.headline: UpMyStreet sets up TV 'car boot sale'
fields.trailText: 8am: BSkyB's Open has launched a TV-based 'car boot sale' using online classified resource UpMyStreet, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
BSkyB's interactive service, Open, today launches the ultimate service for couch potatoes - a TV-based "car boot sale" service.

For the first time, punters will be able to put their unwanted goods up for sale for free, simply by tapping away on their remote controls.

The service is provided by UpMyStreet, an online local information resource in which both News International and Open have stakes.

UpMyStreet has assembled a team of classified partners including property listings service assertahome and MultiMedia Television's job channel, car listings service Exchange & Mart and a general listings from AdTrader to beef up its service for TV.

Its ambition is to blow apart the whole classified advertising industry and change the way people advertise personal goods by taking on market leader Loot and other online buy and sell services.

Open's managing director, Jon Florsheim, said: "This unprecedented service is set to challenge the way local information is accessed in Britain."

Open claims it reaches more than 11m people in more than 4m homes.

Launched in October 1998, UpMyStreet received a cash boost of £9m in May from News International for a 21% stake, and a further £3m from NM Rothschild.

Open jumped into bed with UpMyStreet last summer when it took and undisclosed stake in the company in return for developing and hosting this particular classifieds service.

webTitle: New knifing as Damilola inquiry seeks gang

fields.headline: New knifing as Damilola inquiry seeks gang
fields.standfirst: A 13-year-old was stabbed in a London street yesterday afternoon, less than a week after Damilola Taylor was killed as he walked home from school. Meanwhile, a gang of youths has become the focus of the murder investigation.
fields.trailText: A 13-year-old was stabbed in a London street yesterday afternoon, less than a week after Damilola Taylor was killed as he walked home from school.
fields.byline: Nick Hopkins,  Patrick Wintour  and Claire Harte
fields.body:
A 13-year-old was stabbed in a London street yesterday afternoon, less than a week after Damilola Taylor was killed as he walked home from school.

The black boy was walking with an Asian friend in Hackney Wick, north-east London, when they were approached by two youths who stole a mobile phone and cash from the Asian boy, also aged 13.

A passerby intervened and the robbers left, but they returned when the two boys were on their own, punching the Asian and stabbing his friend with a knife, leaving him seriously injured. London Ambulance Service said he had cuts to his stomach but his condition was stable.

Meanwhile a gang of youths aged 10 to 14 has become the focus of the Damilola Taylor investigation. The youths were loitering in Peckham, south London, on the night he was stabbed and bled to death.

Witnesses have told Scotland Yard detectives that between six and 10 boys were outside the library where the 10-year-old had joined an after-school computer class last Monday.

An anonymous 999 call reported a bottle fight between youths shortly before the time Damilola was attacked, but police officers who went to the scene found no evidence of the incident.

Detective Superintendent David Dillnutt said: "We are still seeking witnesses at the library from about 3.35pm when Damilola arrived. There was a group of youths outside _ this is a particular square where children meet."

Police believe a woman in a red anorak with a small child was also outside the library, and would be a valuable witness. The fresh appeal for information came following the arrest and release on Saturday of two boys, aged 12 and 13, and a 39-year-old woman.

During a press conference yesterday Mr Dillnutt dismissed reports that Damilola's family believed their son, who was born in Nigeria and had moved to the UK four months ago, was being bullied by West Indian youths. "We have no evidence of this. The family is not saying this is a racial incident or a racist attack.

"We simply do not know if there is a link between the bul lying that had been complained of by Damilola's family and his death."

Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the Metropolitan police, acknowledged that there were tensions on the estate where he was killed.

"What is being said is that there is a certain amount of tension between racial groups," he told London Weekend Television. "We must not deny that, but we must also not build that up into a situation where there's more violence."

Sir John said 70 officers were on the case.

All of Damilola's classmates at Oliver Goldsmith primary school have been seen by detectives, and 100 adults have come forward with information. He died in a stairwell on the North Peckham estate minutes after being stabbed in the leg as he walked home.

A memorial service for the boy was held yesterday in Peckham.

The government will this week announce plans to ex tend youth curfews to anyone aged up to 16.

Local councils and the police have the power to impose curfews on children aged 10 and under. However, this power has not been used on a single occasion in two years. Ministers hope their plans, to be spelt out in the Queen's Speech, will help communities tackle anti-social behaviour. The police have powers to take home anyone believed to be under 16 in an area covered by a curfew order; if no parent is at home, the police can detain the youth overnight.

Ministers will also review policy on the carrying of knives by re-examining the Offensive Weapons Act. A knives amnesty following the murder of London teacher Phillip Lawrence in 1995 proved only a partial success. More than 40,000 weapons were handed in, but the number of attacks involving knives has continued to rise.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Will WH Smith undermine newspapers' circulations?

fields.headline: Breakfast will never be the same without a paper
fields.standfirst: A new plan by WH Smith threatens local newsagents. But, asks Roy Greenslade, will it also undermine circulations?
fields.trailText: A new plan by WH Smith threatens local newsagents. But, asks Roy Greenslade, will it also undermine circulations?
fields.body:
David Squirrel and Jeff Edwards are, in many ways, very similar people. Squirrel is 33, married with three children and gets up for work every morning at 5am. Edwards is 32, married with one child and another on the way, and is usually up at 5am too. They both take pride in serving the people of Kemp Town, Brighton.

Squirrel runs a traditional corner newsagent's shop known simply as The Kiosk, and let me declare an interest: he supplies me with my daily pile of papers. Edwards is the customer services manager of my local Safeway supermarket, and I sometimes shop there too, although not for papers. These two men now find themselves, though not by dint of anything they have done or even seek to do themselves, in opposing camps.

There are fears that a new distribution arrangement for magazines being negotiated by WH Smith could well drive Squirrel and his ilk out of business. WH Smith's plan seeks to overturn the complex geographically specific wholesale distribution system by supplying two giant supermarket chains, Tesco and Safeway, on a national basis.

Rival wholesalers, such as Menzies, Dawson Holdings and a number of smaller independents, see this as the thin end of a nasty wedge. They believe the creation of exclusive contracts for national distribution between conglomerates such as WH Smith and Tesco would eventually imperil the future financial health of both smaller wholesalers and the myriad newsagent's shops which sell the bulk of Britain's newspapers and magazines.

It is a complex argument but, in brief, the fear is that newsagent's would be forced out of business because smaller wholesalers would need to increase their carriage charges, or reduce margins, because they would be excluded from much of their lucrative business by the new arrangements. Newspapers would then suffer "collateral damage" once small newsagents were forced to close. At the end of this process, there is a belief that everyone would have to go to a supermarket to obtain their paper.

This is the reason why Associated Newspapers, publishers of the Mail titles, has decided to terminate its current distribution deal with WH Smith. News International, owner of the Sun, News of the World, Sunday Times and the Times, is considering its position too.

Despite repeated assertions by WH Smith that its new venture is for magazines only, and that it will make distribution more efficient and less costly, and is aimed at giving customers a better deal, national newspaper managements are alarmed.

However loud their pleas for the rest of British industry to modernise and streamline, they do not share WH Smith's view that the newspaper industry's current distribution methods require reform. Circulation directors regard the David Squirrels of this world as the key to selling copies because they maintain a close, daily relationship with readers. He is certainly a good example, offering a personal service to many hundreds of customers.

From his tiny shop, Squirrel sells some 800 papers a day, six days a week, and 1,200 on Sundays. His six morning staff, teenagers and adults, deliver to 385 households every day. Two deliverers go around in the evenings with the Evening Argus and the Evening Standard. On Sunday mornings, I often see him at 6am dealing with skyscraper-high quires of papers on the pavement outside his shop.

He is concerned about the WH Smith initiative but, like so many in his trade, is uncertain about its ramifications. What he does know is that without newspapers he would have no business, despite selling cigarettes, sweets and a bewildering array of groceries.

Squirrel has newspaper-selling in his blood. His grandfather worked in the trade in London, as did a couple of uncles. He has been running his kiosk business for five years and has dramatically increased sales since he first took over. "I have an extraordinarily good rapport with customers," he says. "But when things go wrong I've got nowhere to hide."

About the only thing that can go wrong is late supplies, or a shortage, which means that his livelihood is in the hands of his wholesaler, Surridge Dawson. Generally, he says, the deliveries are on time and "they've got better in the last six months."

For Edwards at Safeway, newspapers represent a tiny proportion of his store's turnover. Even so, he reckons to sell 450 papers a day and about 400 on Sunday. Those sales are probably helped by the fact that the store is located in a busy shopping street and surrounded by a residential area.

Many fewer are sold in supermarkets where people cannot pop in and out easily. With a rack placed prominently near the entrance, it is possible for customers to enter and buy a paper or magazine, along with cigarettes or a sandwich, without the need to go through a turnstile or use a wire basket.

Edwards has not studied newspaper-buying habits too closely, but he thinks very few of the people who call in to pick up a paper then proceed to buy groceries. "We don't sell papers to lure customers," he says. "They are there as part of our all-round service."

One service Safeway does not offer, of course, is home delivery. What newspaper owners dread most is the thought of any diminution of deliveries because they are the bedrock of all circulations. Squirrel knows that all too well. His team delivers 80 papers to one block of seafront flats alone. "People love their newspapers," he says, "and I think they love their newsagents too."

webTitle: Food tsar to tackle Scots' obesity and heart disease

fields.headline: Food tsar to tackle Scots' obesity and heart disease
fields.trailText: Scotland is to get a food tsar to tackle growing health problems, related to poor diet and obesity.
fields.body:
Scotland is to get a food tsar to tackle growing health problems, related to poor diet and obesity.

A three-year survey published today reveals that 62% of men and 54% of women in Scotland are classed as either overweight or obese. Despite health campaigns, even young Scots are storing up trouble for the future.

To better promote health, lifestyle and diet changes, the Scottish health minister, Susan Deacon, is appointing a national coordinator to be in the post soon.

Researchers, who questioned more than 13,000 Scots, discovered that about one in five could be officially classified as obese.

Despite Glasgow's informal status as the coronary heart disease capital of Europe, there was little difference in diet between regions or across social class. The study, led by Sir Michael Marmot, found about a quarter of Scots suffering from a cardiovascular disorder; the levels being far higher than those in England. Researchers put this down to inactivity, hard drinking, poor diet - particularly the "deep-fried culture", and smoking.

A Scottish executive spokeswoman said: "The state of the nation's health as revealed in the survey is in line with everything we have said is a priority for us; it gives us a really accurate picture to work from."

The survey also revealed that young Scots, particularly girls, are taking less exercise than did previous generations. The amount of exercise taken by boys stays roughly steady through the childhood years, at 15 hours a week; girls only manage seven hours by the time they reach 14 or 15.

But Professor Marmot, who works at University College London, said that the drop in exercise should be looked at in broad terms. "Taking the issue of obesity and exercise, it is not enough to say to people: 'you must do more exercise'. There is also the whole question about where that fits into people's lives. Are there sports facilities available, is it safe for people to ride bikes?"

There was, however, a glimmer of hope in the survey. It revealed a rise of 6% in the amount of fresh fruit and vegetables eaten by Scots.

webTitle: 'Unacceptable delays' in cancer testing

fields.headline: 'Unacceptable delays' in cancer testing
fields.trailText: The NHS's care of cancer patients may have been compromised by "unacceptable delays" at a leading bone cancer unit in reporting the results of post-operation tests, a report reveals today.
fields.body:
The NHS's care of cancer patients may have been compromised by "unacceptable delays" at a leading bone cancer unit in reporting the results of post-operation tests, a report reveals today.

A combination of failures at the Royal National Orthopaedic hospital in Stanmore, north-west London, over at least five years contributed to such a backlog on samples from around the country that its testing service was considered "potentially unsafe" even by its management.

Consultants had to wait up to year to get results, the report found. One patient committed suicide after waiting five months for a test that showed his operation had been unsuccessful. The hospital says tests are now reported within three months, with the aim of making this two months, and it has also set up a results hotline for anxious patients.

Today's report concludes that between 1991 and 2000, 15% of tests on tumours or tissue removed in bone cancer operations were either not reported or suffered unacceptable delays. Attempts to remedy this began in 1995 following concerns raised by a cancer specialist, but by September 1999, with delays up to nine months, managers conceded an investigation was needed. Investigators from outside concluded that the care of only three patients had been demonstrably affected, but one senior surgeon told them he believed his service to patients had been compromised because he was having to make decisions when "[an] important part of the jigsaw was missing".

Jacky Sherman, chief executive of the hospital trust, will today apologise to the three patients and their families, to whom it has offered counselling, and promise the highest standards in future; it has already acted on some of the report's recommendations.

A coroner linked the suicide of one man to a five-month gap between his operation and being told there was still evidence of cancer; test results were ready in three months, but it was a further two months before he was told.

Another man ended chemo-therapy four months after a tumour was removed from his leg and three months before a lab report on the tissue removed indicated that complete removal of the cancer was "at best dubious"; after further surgery and radiotherapy his leg was amputated above the knee. A woman finished chemotherapy after the removal of a leg tumour, but six months after the operation she was told she might need radiotherapy. Neither of these two has yet displayed signs of secondaries.

Overall, investigators from the local Brent and Harrow health authority said that psychological effects on patients and their families "were almost inevitable", although the extent could not be quantified.

The investigation revealed personality clashes and lack of leadership by top managers. Jean Pringle has been removed as head of the histo-pathology department, which provides the "essential and irreplaceable" testing service. Investigators formed the opinion Dr Pringle was highly regarded as a diagnostician and her medical skills were valued by colleagues, but they criticised blurred responsibility between hospital management and that of the Institute of Orthopaedics at University College, London, which employed Dr Pringle, and where she had academic responsibilities. The two had "conflicting agendas and priorities".

The report has ordered a full review by the hospital of its management, while the new NHS watchdog, the commission for health improvement, will make sure improvements have been carried out next year.

Today's verdict, coinciding with an attempt by Tony Blair to reassure the public the NHS can cope with a winter crisis, follows last month's revelations of failure at another supposed beacon of excellence, the Oxford heart centre. The Guardian also reports today on feuding and lapses at a hospital in Plymouth.

webTitle: Eidos keeps close watch over Tomb Raider movie

fields.headline: Eidos keeps close watch over Tomb Raider movie
fields.standfirst: Has Lara had a boob job?
fields.trailText: 9am: Lara Croft creator Eidos is keeping a close eye on the making of the Tomb Raider Hollywood film, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The company behind the Tomb Raider franchise has been bending Hollywood's ear about the movie version of the smash hit game.

Eidos is working hard to ensure the US-funded blockbuster does justice to cyberbabe Lara Croft, the legendary heroine of the series who has become the country's most unlikely pin-up.

Jeremy Heath-Smith, development head of Eidos, regularly visits the film set at Pinewood Studios to ensure that Kung Fu-kicking Lara has lost none of her edge, after becoming worried that her street-cred might be in danger.

He said: "Everyone was very nervous about the film, but we have made sure that she is portrayed in the way we intended.

"We have worked very closely with the film makers, who have worked so hard to get the look and feel spot-on. There will be no disappointments."

Hollywood starlet Angelina Jolie is taking the title role in the film, which finishes its five-month shoot in December after filming in London, Cambodia and Iceland.

It is directed by UK film-maker Simon West, whose credits include the Nicolas Cage hit, Con Air.

The cast list also includes Red Dwarf star Chris Barrie as Lara's butler, and ultra-louche Carry On actor Leslie Philips as a villain. Ms Jolie's father, Jon Voight, pops up as Lara's dad.

"The quality of the cast gives it real credibility and Simon West has done a great job," added Mr Heath-Smith.

The track record for film adaptations of computer games is far from impressive, with Super Mario Brothers and Mortal Kombat crashing at the box office.

Eidos will receive a much-needed shot in the arm from the film, after a spate of boardroom resignations and profit warnings damaged it share price.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Brand Aid

fields.headline: Brand Aid
fields.standfirst: Bisto
fields.trailText: Bisto
fields.body:
What is it? Britain's favourite gravy. Delia Smith would turn her nose up in disgust, but millions have grown up on roast dinners drowned in the brown runny stuff.

What's the problem? Roast dinners are not what they used to be. The busy housewife (or husband) of the noughties is as likely to serve roasted vegetables as roast beef, and there's not too much call for gravy to go with your modern European cuisine.

So what are they doing? Reviving the famous "Ahhh Bisto" line in a bid to create a wave of gravy nostalgia in the run-up to Christmas. A new £8m campaign created by Saatchi & Saatchi shows a modern family enjoying a sit-down dinner. The ad ends with the daughter - a modern-day Bisto kid - uttering those immortal words, "Ahhh Bisto."

Why? "It's all about tapping into the latent affection people have for gravy," says Ginnie Knox, brands director of Bisto owner Centura Foods. "It's a part of people's family ritual and we want to play on that."

History: The birth of Bisto was announced in a full-page ad in the Daily Mail on February 4, 1910. But it was not until 1919 that the trademark ragamuffin children began to sniff the air ecstatically as the aroma of gravy wafted towards them.

The kids were phased out of Bisto's advertising in the 50s, as Britain's increasing prosperity made them seem outdated. But audience research conducted 20 years later showed that the Bisto kids still had a place in the nation's hearts and they were revived, appearing on TV for the first time.

Who buys it? Busy modern mums (or dads). Bisto powder is aimed at conservative cooks, while the pricier granules are aimed at a more sophisticated market.

What about the competition? Bisto has a whopping 62% of the total gravy market, worth £90m a year. Supermarket own brands have 26% and rival brand Oxo has 8%.

What the experts say: Hugo Ehrnreich, a consultant with market research company Datamonitor, says: "Bisto's image is based around the family roast and that's a problem because people are getting together less and less for family meals. Bisto is a convenience food, which means it should fit in well with current trends, but dried foods are not the most dynamic category."

The future: Britain returns to its culinary roots, forgoing stir fry and soy sauce for soggy sprouts in gravy.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Is the Telegraph's reporting subjective?

fields.headline: A strange kind of truth
fields.standfirst: The Daily Telegraph turned a pair of young men, responsible for two deaths, into glorious victims. Was it because one went to Eton, asks Ronald Stevens, or because it has given up on objective journalism?
fields.trailText: The Daily Telegraph turned a pair of young men, responsible for two deaths, into glorious victims. Was it because one went to Eton, asks Ronald Stevens, or because it has given up on objective journalism?
fields.body:
Early one morning last September, in the small town of Sunningdale, Berkshire, a BMW coupé hit a Nissan hatchback head-on, ricocheted into an estate agency office and burst into flames. The occupants of both cars died instantly.

Road accidents have to be pretty spectacular to attract the attention of national newspapers, but this one was reported at some length by the Daily Telegraph - and with a noticeable lack of detachment and judiciousness. Clearly, the paper could not apportion blame before the police investigation or the inquest. Equally, it had no business trying to arouse its readers' sympathy for some of the people involved, but not the others. Yet that is what it did.

Brothers, aged 19 and 22, were in the BMW, and an elderly couple in the Nissan. According to Thames Valley Police, the BMW was spinning out of control when it hit the Nissan and this, together with the fact that the Nissan was propelled backwards for 20 metres, clearly suggests that the BMW was being driven dangerously.

But the Telegraph did everything it could to discourage such uncharitable thoughts about the brothers. The headline on the story told us that the younger one had been "Prince William's schoolmate" at Eton, though he was not even in the same year. The idea, perhaps, was that by dragging in this irrelevance, some respectability would rub off on him.

There were a couple of inconvenient facts that the paper did not overlook: first, the two men had been out all night when the accident happened at 5am (though there was no suggestion that they had been drinking); and second, the headmaster of Eton refused to make any comment, on the grounds that they had not been formally identified. Others, however, felt no such inhibitions, and what they said completely outweighed the headmaster's silence.

"They were both talented and clever," according to one friend. "They were both very popular with everyone around here, and we are all devastated. The way people who knew them have been turning up in tears shows how highly they were regarded. They were great lads. It's a real tragedy and we're all going to miss them."

But what of the elderly couple in the Nissan? Were they popular and highly regarded? Perhaps, or perhaps not. We do not know, because all the Telegraph told us about them was that they lived in Feltham. Not even their names or their ages. Were poor relations ever as poor as this?

It is not often that newspapers publish eulogies of the perpetrators of a crime and say next to nothing about their victims. And it is very unlikely that the Telegraph would have done so in this case if different people had been involved.

Just suppose that the Old Etonian had not been one of the brothers, but the man in the Nissan. Suppose that the brothers had not been well educated ex-public schoolboys but half-literate products of the local comprehensive. Would the tearful tributes of their friends have been published in those circumstances? Or would the paper have left it to the reader to conclude that they were a pair of young tearaways whose recklessness had caused the deaths of two innocent people?

There is little doubt that this is how the story would have been written, and exactly why the Telegraph's news values were so blatantly inverted is a matter for conjecture. Perhaps it was the Eton connection: Charles Moore, the editor, is an Old Etonian. Perhaps it was the royal connection, slender though it was: the paper seems to become more monarchist every month. Or was it just sloppy journalism? Whatever the reason, it did itself no favours when it reported the Sunningdale accident in such selective and tendentious terms.

The managing editor, Susan Ryan, appeared to concede as much when challenged about the story. She said that it could, and should, have been "more sensitive".

Certainly, one of Ryan's predecessors, the redoubtable Peter Eastwood, would never have allowed such a lopsided and inadequate story to appear in the Telegraph; and he would have prevented it because he knew that Lord Hartwell, the proprietor in those days, insisted on balance and fairness. The paper may have been duller than it is now, but it prided itself on the even-handedness of its news columns.

Newspapers, and especially daily newspapers, are not works of perfection: they have to be produced too quickly for that, and they inevitably contain inaccuracies and rough approximations to the truth which would never stand up to forensic attack. Nor would anyone want them to be flavourless fact sheets on the American model.

The Telegraph was no less Tory, bourgeois and patriotic 20 years ago than it is today. What has changed is that the paper no longer feels that it has an obligation to its readers to give both sides of the case. For Lord Hartwell this was a matter of duty; for Conrad Black it seems an optional extra, usually ignored.

Thus, the Telegraph's hostility to the European Union and most of its activities is not only unremitting, which is obviously legitimate, but is rarely qualified by any countervailing facts. The EU is represented as wholly malign or ridiculous, whereas it is, of course, no different from most other organisations: it has its good and bad points, and what the paper should be doing is helping its readers to strike a reasonable balance.

It should also be above the sort of playground abuse that frequently pollutes its business pages. The city editor, Neil Collins, evidently has little time for the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, or the president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg. But that does not excuse the puerile vulgarity of calling Byers "Bozo" and Duisenberg "Dim Wim". If Charles Moore cared more for the standing of his paper, he would stamp hard on this.

Like its rivals, the Telegraph likes to boast about its commercial performance. Every month it announces how much its circulation exceeds that of the Times, though without any disclosures about how many of its sales are accounted for by cut-price copies. Still less does it remind anyone that not so long ago its circulation was nearly half as big again as it is now.

Those were the days when contentious issues were reported with objectivity, and partisanship was confined to leader and feature articles. They were also the days when the couple from Feltham would have been given at least equal treatment with the youngsters who killed them. Is there a moral here?

fields.bodyText: Early one morning last September, in the small town of Sunningdale, Berkshire, a BMW coupé hit a Nissan hatchback head-on, ricocheted into an estate agency office and burst into flames. The occupants of both cars died instantly. Road accidents have to be pretty spectacular to attract the attention of national newspapers, but this one was reported at some length by the Daily Telegraph - and with a noticeable lack of detachment and judiciousness. Clearly, the paper could not apportion blame before the police investigation or the inquest. Equally, it had no business trying to arouse its readers' sympathy for some of the people involved, but not the others. Yet that is what it did. Brothers, aged 19 and 22, were in the BMW, and an elderly couple in the Nissan. According to Thames Valley Police, the BMW was spinning out of control when it hit the Nissan and this, together with the fact that the Nissan was propelled backwards for 20 metres, clearly suggests that the BMW was being driven dangerously. But the Telegraph did everything it could to discourage such uncharitable thoughts about the brothers. The headline on the story told us that the younger one had been "Prince William's schoolmate" at Eton, though he was not even in the same year. The idea, perhaps, was that by dragging in this irrelevance, some respectability would rub off on him. There were a couple of inconvenient facts that the paper did not overlook: first, the two men had been out all night when the accident happened at 5am (though there was no suggestion that they had been drinking); and second, the headmaster of Eton refused to make any comment, on the grounds that they had not been formally identified. Others, however, felt no such inhibitions, and what they said completely outweighed the headmaster's silence. "They were both talented and clever," according to one friend. "They were both very popular with everyone around here, and we are all devastated. The way people who knew them have been turning up in tears shows how highly they were regarded. They were great lads. It's a real tragedy and we're all going to miss them." But what of the elderly couple in the Nissan? Were they popular and highly regarded? Perhaps, or perhaps not. Newspapers, and especially daily newspapers, are not works of perfection: they have to be produced too quickly for that, and they inevitably contain inaccuracies and rough approximations to the truth which would never stand up to forensic attack. Nor would anyone want them to be flavourless fact sheets on the American model. The Telegraph was no less Tory, bourgeois and patriotic 20 years ago than it is today. webTitle: Leader: Something rotten in the Sunshine state

fields.headline: A whiff of corruption
fields.standfirst:
Something rotten in the Sunshine state

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Something rotten in the Sunshine state.
fields.body:
In Florida, almost one month after the US presidential election non-result, the plot thickens. Numerous, continuing legal actions have failed so far to resolve the central issue: whether Democrat Al Gore or Republican George W Bush won the state's popular vote and thus its crucial 25 electoral college votes. But the court cases have shone a spotlight on the manner in which the poll was conducted and left many awkward questions.

Antiquated equipment, badly designed ballot papers and inefficient vote-counting machinery all contributed to the confusion. Contradictory state laws on the use of absentee ballots, on the time allowed for recounts and whether they may be undertaken by hand have been ruthlessly exposed and dissected by squads of lawyers and judges. The common thread here appears to be incompetence. On this basis, Mr Gore continues to try to force hand recounts in key counties. Mr Bush continues to oppose him, hoping meanwhile that the US supreme court will rule in his favour this week.

But as public scrutiny of Florida's deeply flawed electoral process intensifies, the focus is broadening, moving beyond the fate of votes counted (or miscounted or mislaid) to the fate of votes that were never cast at all. As Julian Borger's investigation, which we publish today, shows, black and other minority citizens on whom the Democrats were counting faced unusual obstacles in exercising their democratic rights.

Florida's Republican secretary of state, Katherine Harris, backed by Mr Bush's brother, Florida's governor, Jeb Bush, launched a systematic purge of the electoral rolls earlier this year. The result was the exclusion of unknown thousands of voters on the erroneous grounds that they were convicted felons; because they had allegedly not voted in previous elections; because they had moved home; or because officials were told to impose stringent polling-day identity checks, while lacking the time to conduct them properly.

Some disenfranchised minority voters also complain of police harassment. The US justice department is reportedly investigating these matters. It should also look at the pre-count "correcting" of 15,000 absentee ballots by Republican poll volunteers. And Mr Gore should bite the bullet and ask the courts to take a closer look at the pre-poll activities of Ms Harris, Jeb Bush and others. For what is alleged here goes far beyond incompetence. Put bluntly, it stinks.

webTitle: US inquiry into claims black voters were stripped of rights

fields.headline: US inquiry into claims black voters were stripped of rights
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The US justice department announced yesterday that  it had launched an inquiry into claims that thousands  of black Floridians were stripped of their right to vote by  a state government run by Governor Jeb Bush, the  Republican presidential candidate's brother.
fields.body:
The US justice department announced yesterday that it had launched an inquiry into claims that thousands of black Floridians were stripped of their right to vote by a state government run by Governor Jeb Bush, the Republican presidential candidate's brother.

The inquiry, led by the department's civil rights division, has been under way since Thursday and is focusing on allegations by black community leaders that in the run-up to the election minorities were targeted by police intimidation and administrative measures which had the effect of disproportionately disenfranchising black voters.

The Washington Post reported yesterday that its computer analysis found that the more black and Democratic a precinct, the more likely it was that a high number of presidential votes were not counted.

Arguments continued yesterday in a Tallahassee courtroom over the fate of disputed ballots that may decide the final outcome of the presidential election after the vice-president, Al Gore, challenged certified results awarding George W Bush victory in Florida.

Yesterday, Warren Christopher, the former secretary of state leading Mr Gore's legal battle, hinted for the first time that the Democrats might be preparing to accept defeat. He said that the vice-president, "when the time comes", will "concede in a very gracious way".

The certified results give Mr Bush a 537-vote lead. But this margin between the two men is potentially dwarfed by the disenfranchisement of black Floridians, who voted by a ratio of more than 10 to one for Mr Gore.

The Gore campaign has so far avoided starting a legal battle over racial disenfranchisement, focusing instead on an appeal for a hand recount of votes in Democratic counties in the hope of bringing a rapid yield of sufficient votes to tilt the outcome.

However, the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People (NAACP) yesterday announced that it would bring its case to court on the strength of 300 pages of testimony and 486 plaintiffs.

Black leaders say voters were intimidated by police action near polling stations in several locations. In one electoral precinct, highway patrolmen set up a disruptive checkpoint on a road leading from black suburbs to a polling station. Elsewhere, police questioned black voters on the way to the polls about their criminal records, the NAACP claims.

However, far more black Floridians lost their voting rights as a consequence of measures taken by the Florida state government, and in particular by Governor Bush's political lieutenant and secretary of state, Katherine Harris.

In June, Ms Harris sent out a list of more than 700,000 convicts and ex-convicts deemed ineligible to vote under a 19th-century law which disqualifies felons for life. Interviews by the Guardian have confirmed that the names of many black voters were wrongly added to the list, which included ex-convicts whose rights had been restored.

The wrongly disenfranchised include a black man disqualified from voting because he walked out of a community service job collecting rubbish in 1959. The man, Wallace McDonald, 64, was told he had been excluded from the electoral rolls on the grounds that he was an escaped felon.

Florida leads the nation in its number of disenfranchised adults, and the zeal with which felons have been stripped of their votes has disproportionately affected black voters. Human Rights Watch estimates that 31% of black voting-age men in Florida have been disenfranchised.

Thousands more black residents lost their votes on November 7 because their names had been purged from voter rolls on the basis of technicalities, such as changes of address. Several told the Guardian that they had voted regularly in federal elections, but had arrived at polling stations last month to find their names had been erased.

They had the right to challenge their removal from the roll, and to enter an "affidavit ballot" confirming that they were registered in that precinct. But they were denied that opportunity in several polling stations because staff were overwhelmed by the number of disenfranchised voters.

All those interviewed said that the purging of the voters' roll appear to have disproportionately affected black voters.

webTitle: How Florida played the race card

fields.headline: How Florida played the race card
fields.standfirst:
700,000 people with criminal past banned from voting in pivotal state

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: 700,000 people with criminal past banned from voting in pivotal state
fields.body:
As the struggle over dimpled chads and voting machines grinds on in the courts, evidence is emerging that the US presidential race was irrevocably tainted before a single ballot was cast - by the systematic and unconstitutional denial of voting rights to thousands of black Floridians.

Across Florida, black residents who had taken part in earlier elections without any problems went to vote on November 7 to find a bewildering array of hurdles between them and the ballot box. For many, the day's events were a reminder that Florida is an integral part of the deep south, with a long record of segregation and resistance to black voting rights.

The state is under investigation by the justice department for infringing the rights of its minority citizens, but cases of black disenfranchisement have played almost no role in the challenge by the vice-president, Al Gore, to the election results. Ballots cast can be recounted and yield quick results, while votes denied are difficult to measure and hard to claim. But in the longer term, they have far graver implications for US race relations and the health of the nation's democracy.

In most cases investigated by the Guardian, the obstacles to black voting rights were clerical and administrative. In a handful of instances, however, they were less subtle.

On election morning, Darryl Gorham was driving some neighbours to vote in Woodville, outside Tallahassee. They turned a bend in the road about a mile before the polling station and came across a scene straight out of the segregation era.

Roadblocks

"There were four Florida highway patrolmen standing in the middle of the street, Mr Gorham said. "They were stopping everybody. They had seven or eight cars stopped on the side of the road and waiting. They inspected the headlights, tail-lights, indicators, licence, registration, tags, everything ... I've lived in Florida most of my life, but I have never ever seen a roadblock like that."

Mr Gorham is convinced that the white policemen were trying to slow down the flow of black voters in a historically tight election. He said: "It took maybe 15, maybe 20 minutes. But many people were taking time out from work, or going to work, and it was making them late. Some just turned round and went back."

Major Ken Howes, a spokesman for the Florida Highway Patrol, said the four policemen had set up the checkpoint without authority from senior officers. An internal investigation has been launched but Major Howes insisted the sergeant in charge had not intended to affect the vote.

Robert Chamber, a black resident who lives nearby, is sceptical of the claims of ignorance. He believes the checkpoint's message was quite clear. "It is putting fear in people's hearts," he said. "It means: 'We'll catch them before they get there.' The racism here may be underground but it's strong. There are places around here we just know not to go."

There is some hard evidence to back up Mr Chamber's fears. According to a study by the Southern Poverty Law Centre, the largest concentration by far of neo-Confederate white supremacist groups such as the League of the South is centred on the Florida panhandle and the state's western coast.

Marvin Davies, a veteran of the 1960s civil rights struggle, said: "Florida has always been a microcosm of hate ... Both racism and hate are a very viable part of this culture."

Woodville was not the only alleged police intimidation in Florida. However, by far the greatest damage to minority rights appears to have been inflicted not by men in uniform, but by bureaucrats in suits, quietly and almost invisibly, months before the election.

During the presidential campaign, it became clear that Florida would be piv otal and that civil rights groups were making unprecedented efforts to mobilise minority voters behind the Democrats. Under the banner of an anti-fraud campaign, Governor Jeb Bush, the brother of the Republican presidential candidate, and his now-famous secretary of state, Katherine Harris, implemented a series of administrative steps which may well prove to have swung the election.

In June, the division of elections in Ms Harris's office drew up a list of more than 700,000 Floridians permanently disqualified from voting - more than any other state - because of a criminal past, and sent it to county election supervisors.

The idea was to enforce strictly an 1868 law disqualifying felons and ex-felons from voting for life. The law was originally part of the southern backlash against voter registration among freed slaves after the civil war, and was based on the assumption that black residents got in trouble with the law more often than their white counterparts.

That assumption holds true today, in a state where African Americans make up 13% of the general population but 55% of prison inmates. According to Human Rights Watch, around a third of African American men in the state were disqualified from voting because of a past conviction, mostly resulting from the "war on drugs" that has been raging in urban America for two decades.

But Ms Harris's list went further than simply upholding a 19th-century law. It included several thousand people who should not have been disqualified, either because they had gone through the arduous process of having their rights restored or because they had never been convicted of a felony in the first place.

The list was so riddled with errors that Palm Beach and Duval election boards simply ignored it, leading to Republican allegations that more than 300 ex-felons had voted in those counties. But their numbers appear to be far outweighed by those wrongly disenfranchised elsewhere.

When he was 23, Wallace McDonald fell asleep on a bench in Tampa waiting for a bus. He was arrested for vagrancy and obliged to pay for his misdemeanour by working on a municipal rubbish truck. Disgusted with his sentence, the young McDonald walked off the job, an offence for which he was fined $30.

That was in 1959. Forty-one years on, Mr McDonald received a letter from the Hillsborough County election supervisor, Pam Iorio, informing him that as an ex-felon his name had been removed from the voters' roll.

"I could not believe it, after voting for all these years since the 50s, without a problem," he said, pointing out that even by Florida's harsh standards his offence did not amount to a felony. "I knew something was unfair about that. To be able to vote all your life then to have somebody reach in a bag and take some technicality that you can't vote," Mr McDonald said. "Why now? Something's wrong."

He is in good company. The Rev Willie Dixon received a full pardon for drug offences in 1985, and has since become a youth leader and bible preacher, a pillar of the Tampa black community who has voted in every presidential election. Until he received one of Ms Iorio's letters.

Kelvin King never received a letter. He was also released in 1985, after becoming another statistic in the drug war. He got his registration card and had voted in the three presidential polls held since his release from jail. This November, he was ejected from a polling station after his name turned up on the blacklist.

"The lady on the desk just told me I was a felon. It was a bit of a shock," Mr King said. "I suppose I was disgusted at myself for what I had done in the past, but I assumed it had been taken care of."

In her Tampa offices, a defensive Ms Iorio, a Democrat, pointed the finger of blame at Tallahassee. "Yes, there were errors on the list," she said. "There were instances of mistaken identity and people who should not have been on it. Something doesn't work right in the system."

But the county election supervisor defended her use of Ms Harris's list. Anyone wrongly listed as a felon had ample opportunity to appeal, she argued.

Mr Dixon did manage to have his criminal taint removed but Mr McDonald was not so fortunate, despite the best efforts of his lawyer. Mr King never had a chance.

It is not just ex-convicts who found themselves excluded. Civil rights groups have been inundated with complaints from mainly black voters that they had not found their names on the voters' roll.

Again, many of the disenfranchised appear to have fallen prey to the Florida government's zeal in applying electoral regulations. Under federal law, states can purge citizens from the rolls if they fail to participate in two consecutive federal elections and if letters sent to their address are returned.

But once more, Ms Harris's office appears to have gone beyond the letter of the law, ordering a comprehensive purge of the rolls in October, provoking several hundred complaints from would-be voters who said their names had been erased despite a consistent voting record.

Discrimination

Once again, the vast majority of those complaining are black. It may be that low-income minority families are less settled and more likely to change address but community leaders are convinced their disenfranchisement reflects deeper discrimination. They can point to the case of Kandy Wells, a black woman who registered in Tampa on the same September day as her white husband. He received his voter's card two weeks before election day. Mrs Wells is still waiting for hers.

"You've got to remember that only 40 or 50 years ago blacks couldn't vote," she said. "Things like this have been happen ing in Florida all along. It's just that this time it's so close and they got caught."

Black voters across the state have also claimed that they were subjected to more stringent identity checks than their white neighbours, leading to longer delays. In Miami, Haitian immigrants were routinely denied their right to bring an interpreter to the polling booth to help translate the ballot.

In theory, the "errors" should have been corrected on election day, but in many places officials were so overwhelmed by the problem that the instant appeals mechanism collapsed. In Tampa, lines to Ms Iorio's office were overwhelmed as voters tried in vain to call from polling stations to have themselves reinstated. Again, low-income minority neighbourhoods were worst affected, magnifying the impression that Florida was practising selective disenfranchisement.

Governor Bush's administration has dismissed claims of discrimination as yet another Democratic ruse aimed at undermining the election result. And the De mocratic party is clearly reluctant to pick up the banner of its black supporters.

But the angry mood among black Floridians is unlikely to be dispelled without an examination of what happened on November 7 and beforehand. It is a reckoning that is likely to last far longer than the recounts squabble, because it lies at the heart of black experience in the south.

In Marvin Davies's eyes, the battle over the Florida election is simply the continuation of the earlier, bloodier struggles of the 1950s and 1960s.

"When you go into that ballot box, the black man has the same power as the white man, so the white man will use all his money and all his power to stop the black man getting there," Mr Davies said.

Roadblocks "There were four Florida highway patrolmen standing in the middle of the street, Mr Gorham said. "They were stopping everybody. They had seven or eight cars stopped on the side of the road and waiting. They inspected the headlights, tail-lights, indicators, licence, registration, tags, everything ... I've lived in Florida most of my life, but I have never ever seen a roadblock like that." Mr Gorham is convinced that the white policemen were trying to slow down the flow of black voters in a historically tight election. He said: "It took maybe 15, maybe 20 minutes. But many people were taking time out from work, or going to work, and it was making them late. Some just turned round and went back." Major Ken Howes, a spokesman for the Florida Highway Patrol, said the four policemen had set up the checkpoint without authority from senior officers. An internal investigation has been launched but Major Howes insisted the sergeant in charge had not intended to affect the vote. Robert Chamber, a black resident who lives nearby, is sceptical of the claims of ignorance. He believes the checkpoint's message was quite clear. "It is putting fear in people's hearts," he said. "It means: 'We'll catch them before they get there.' The racism here may be underground but it's strong. There are places around here we just know not to go." There is some hard evidence to back up Mr Chamber's fears. According to a study by the Southern Poverty Law Centre, the largest concentration by far of neo-Confederate white supremacist groups such as the League of the South is centred on the Florida panhandle and the state's western coast. Marvin Davies, a veteran of the 1960s civil rights struggle, said: "Florida has always been a microcosm of hate ... Both racism and hate are a very viable part of this culture." Woodville was not the only alleged police intimidation in Florida. However, by far the greatest damage to minority rights appears to have been inflicted not by men in uniform, but by bureaucrats in suits, quietly and almost invisibly, months before the election. During the presidential campaign, it became clear that Florida would be piv otal and that civil rights groups were making unprecedented efforts to mobilise minority voters behind the Democrats. Under the banner of an anti-fraud campaign, Governor Jeb Bush, the brother of the Republican presidential candidate, and his now-famous secretary of state, Katherine Harris, implemented a series of administrative steps which may well prove to have swung the election. In June, the division of elections in Ms Harris's office drew up a list of more than 700,000 Floridians permanently disqualified from voting - more than any other state - because of a criminal past, and sent it to county election supervisors. The idea was to enforce strictly an 1868 law disqualifying felons and ex-felons from voting for life. The law was originally part of the southern backlash against voter registration among freed slaves after the civil war, and was based on the assumption that black residents got in trouble with the law more often than their white counterparts. That assumption holds true today, in a state where African Americans make up 13% of the general population but 55% of prison inmates. According to Human Rights Watch, around a third of African American men in the state were disqualified from voting because of a past conviction, mostly resulting from the "war on drugs" that has been raging in urban America for two decades. But Ms Harris's list went further than simply upholding a 19th-century law. It included several thousand people who should not have been disqualified, either because they had gone through the arduous process of having their rights restored or because they had never been convicted of a felony in the first place. The list was so riddled with errors that Palm Beach and Duval election boards simply ignored it, leading to Republican allegations that more than 300 ex-felons had voted in those counties. But their numbers appear to be far outweighed by those wrongly disenfranchised elsewhere. When he was 23, Wallace McDonald fell asleep on a bench in Tampa waiting for a bus. He was arrested for vagrancy and obliged to pay for his misdemeanour by working on a municipal rubbish truck. Disgusted with his sentence, the young McDonald walked off the job, an offence for which he was fined $30. That was in 1959. Forty-one years on, Mr McDonald received a letter from the Hillsborough County election supervisor, Pam Iorio, informing him that as an ex-felon his name had been removed from the voters' roll. "I could not believe it, after voting for all these years since the 50s, without a problem," he said, pointing out that even by Florida's harsh standards his offence did not amount to a felony. "I knew something was unfair about that. To be able to vote all your life then to have somebody reach in a bag and take some technicality that you can't vote," Mr McDonald said. "Why now? Something's wrong." He is in good company. The Rev Willie Dixon received a full pardon for drug offences in 1985, and has since become a youth leader and bible preacher, a pillar of the Tampa black community who has voted in every presidential election. Until he received one of Ms Iorio's letters. Kelvin King never received a letter. He was also released in 1985, after becoming another statistic in the drug war. He got his registration card and had voted in the three presidential polls held since his release from jail. This November, he was ejected from a polling station after his name turned up on the blacklist. "The lady on the desk just told me I was a felon. It was a bit of a shock," Mr King said. "I suppose I was disgusted at myself for what I had done in the past, but I assumed it had been taken care of." In her Tampa offices, a defensive Ms Iorio, a Democrat, pointed the finger of blame at Tallahassee. "Yes, there were errors on the list," she said. "There were instances of mistaken identity and people who should not have been on it. Something doesn't work right in the system." But the county election supervisor defended her use of Ms Harris's list. Anyone wrongly listed as a felon had ample opportunity to appeal, she argued. Mr Dixon did manage to have his criminal taint removed but Mr McDonald was not so fortunate, despite the best efforts of his lawyer. Mr King never had a chance. It is not just ex-convicts who found themselves excluded. Civil rights groups have been inundated with complaints from mainly black voters that they had not found their names on the voters' roll. Again, many of the disenfranchised appear to have fallen prey to the Florida government's zeal in applying electoral regulations. Under federal law, states can purge citizens from the rolls if they fail to participate in two consecutive federal elections and if letters sent to their address are returned. But once more, Ms Harris's office appears to have gone beyond the letter of the law, ordering a comprehensive purge of the rolls in October, provoking several hundred complaints from would-be voters who said their names had been erased despite a consistent voting record. Discrimination Once again, the vast majority of those complaining are black. It may be that low-income minority families are less settled and more likely to change address but community leaders are convinced their disenfranchisement reflects deeper discrimination. They can point to the case of Kandy Wells, a black woman who registered in Tampa on the same September day as her white husband. He received his voter's card two weeks before election day. Mrs Wells is still waiting for hers. "You've got to remember that only 40 or 50 years ago blacks couldn't vote," she said. "Things like this have been happen ing in Florida all along. It's just that this time it's so close and they got caught." Black voters across the state have also claimed that they were subjected to more stringent identity checks than their white neighbours, leading to longer delays. In Miami, Haitian immigrants were routinely denied their right to bring an interpreter to the polling booth to help translate the ballot. In theory, the "errors" should have been corrected on election day, but in many places officials were so overwhelmed by the problem that the instant appeals mechanism collapsed. In Tampa, lines to Ms Iorio's office were overwhelmed as voters tried in vain to call from polling stations to have themselves reinstated. Again, low-income minority neighbourhoods were worst affected, magnifying the impression that Florida was practising selective disenfranchisement. Governor Bush's administration has dismissed claims of discrimination as yet another Democratic ruse aimed at undermining the election result. And the De mocratic party is clearly reluctant to pick up the banner of its black supporters. But the angry mood among black Floridians is unlikely to be dispelled without an examination of what happened on November 7 and beforehand. It is a reckoning that is likely to last far longer than the recounts squabble, because it lies at the heart of black experience in the south.
