webTitle: Coca-Cola targets trend-setters

fields.headline: Coca-Cola targets trend-setters
fields.trailText: 8am:Coca-Cola is targeting trend-setters with the launch of its new energy drink, Burn, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Subtlety is not a something associated with Coca-Cola. But for the first time ever the company is keeping a zipped lip on the arrival of its latest soft drink, Burn.

The company has decided against traditional press statements and promotions and is instead trying to create a buzz about the new brand by introducing it slowly to opinion-formers and trend-setters rather than letting every Tom, Dick and Harry know about it through a big marketing campaign.

And unusually, the product - an energy drink to rival Red Bull - is being kept out of shops with availability restricted to clubs and bars.

The low-key launch has so far been restricted to a few trendy events in London.

It has been being promoted at a party organised by DJ magazine for the country's top 100 DJs at the trendy Covent Garden club The End and an after-show party for singer Gabrielle's concert, held at the hip south London venue the K Bar.

And last Thursday night Burn cocktails were served at a star-studded party held by lingerie specialists Agent Provocateur to launch its new perfume.

Burn is the first Coca-Cola brand to be aimed deliberately at a niche market. It has been formulated to mix with spirits such as vodka and will only be available in clubs and bars, not in shops.

Only five venues will stock Burn in the run-up to Christmas and the identity of the so-called "style bars" is being kept tightly under wraps. The hope is that the rarity of the drink will give it cult status among young people.

The strategy is designed to give the drink kudos in the hope that it can challenge the dominance of Red Bull, an energy drink that became a popular cocktail ingredient because of its capacity to keep drinkers awake into the small hours.

Coca-Cola is keen to diversify away from its eponymous cola brand as young people seek new and more interesting drinks. Burn is being developed in the UK and Australia and if successful will be launched in other markets including the US.

webTitle: Two candidates in running for BBC head of marketing

fields.headline: Two candidates in running for BBC head of marketing
fields.trailText: 8am: Two candidates in the running for the BBC head of marketing job - insider Jane Frost and Channel 5's Jim Hytner, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
BBC head of corporate marketing Jane Frost and Channel 5 marketing director Jim Hytner are among the candidates still in the running to take over from BBC head of marketing Matthew Bannister.

Ms Frost is understood to be the only remaining internal candidate for the top marketing post after Sally Osman was handed the number two job of head of communications last month.

Mr Bannister leaves this month and the BBC is keen to fill the post as quickly as possible. But a BBC spokesman said no decision was expected until after Christmas.

Mr Hytner, who has been formally interviewed by headhunters, joined Channel 5 in 1997 from BSkyB where he was marketing director. He joined Sky in 1994 as advertising and media director and was made marketing director in 1996.

Mr Bannister announced his resignation from the BBC in October, just six months after he took on the job.

His departure comes at a difficult time for the BBC, which is in the middle of a major overhaul of its marketing activities, including a review of its advertising agency roster.

webTitle: Hospital's macho culture goes on trial

fields.headline: Hospital's macho culture goes on trial
fields.standfirst: Surgeon to tell tribunal of sexual and racial harassment
fields.trailText: Surgeon to tell tribunal of sexual and racial harassment
fields.body:
As patients and visitors bustle through the squeaky automatic doors into Plymouth's Derriford hospital, they are greeted by a warm, almost spotlessly clean reception area dominated by a private cafe serving hot drinks and healthy snacks.

But all is not entirely well at Derriford, and this week a symptom of what appears to be an underlying sickness will erupt into public view.

On Friday, a consultant surgeon of white, English origin will claim that she was racially victimised by a fellow consultant after being sent home after a row over an alleged racist remark.

Judy Evans, a plastic surgeon, who was sent home from Derriford last June, is expected to appear at a preliminary employment tribunal hearing, where she will allege sexual discrimination against the hospital trust.

She will also allege "victimisation under the terms of the Race Relations Act" against one of her former colleagues in the plastic surgery department.

It follows an incident last February when a black junior doctor was allegedly told by a senior consultant after making a minor mistake: "You are not operating on bloody Nigerians now. These are my patients - they are normal human beings."

The junior, a trainee plastic surgeon, was a British woman of Nigerian ancestry who had already been the butt of some unthinking racism and was horrified by the remark. She was backed up by Dr Evans.

Shortly afterwards, colleagues alleged that Dr Evans' work was below standard and she was put on "gardening leave" while managers ordered an investigation.

The tribunal is expected to highlight a macho "old guard" of consultants and managers who have already embroiled the trust in legal proceedings.

In January, two Asian surgeons took Derriford to an employment tribunal claiming that they had not received merit awards - financial bonuses paid to consultants on top of their salaries - because of their race.

The bonuses, granted under a points system decided by a series of committees, could add up to £58,000 on top of a consultants' basic salary of £62,000.

Jagdev Mohan, a brain surgeon of Indian origin, and Maher Halawa, an Egyptian-born orthopaedic surgeon, alleged that a small circle of white male doctors used the merit scheme to reward friends.

Mr Mohan told the hearings: "The major problem is that we are not in the favoured circles. The old pals' act does not work for us as it does for the white majority."

After five days of embarrassing evidence, the hospital settled the case out of court and agreed to reform the merit scheme.

The worst manifestation of unacceptable behaviour appears to have put patients' safety at risk.

In January Martin Cusack, then the trust's deputy chief executive, circulated a memo to all staff warning against "unprofessional" or "inappropriate" behaviour in theatre.

He specified "practical jokes, strong language, sexual innuendo" and warned that such behaviour "can deliberately or inadvertently affect the safety and well being of patients and staff".

The Guardian has learned that the "boys' club" culture manifested itself in remarks such as the phrase "bedroom view" - used by doctors to describe a prostrate woman.

Several staff have complained about one doctor, who remarked within earshot of an 84-year-old woman being treated for cancer: "Sometimes it's like being a vet - a cow can't tell you what's wrong with her either."

A senior hospital management insider admitted to the Guardian: "There is a real culture problem; it is very old-fashioned, very doctor-dominated."

While stressing the trust's concerns were confined to a minority, the source blamed a cosy network involving some senior consultants: "There has never been any competition in the internal market because Derriford is too far away."

Historically, Derriford - which opened in 1981 - has been under-resourced, say insiders.

The hospital, at the far southwestern end of the country and a long way from metropolitan areas, did not provide specialist treatments on offer to patients elsewhere.

"People here were victims of a classic NHS postcode lottery," a senior insider said.

In the last five to 10 years, Derriford has gone through rapid expansion and it now offers some of the specialist services hitherto unavailable locally.

But the rapid growth has brought its own problems. For basic treatments, the hospital serves a population of around 430,000 in Plymouth and the surrounding areas of south Devon and Cornwall.

But for specialist operations, such as kidney transplants, it serves up to 2m people across a vast swath of southwest England.

With a backlog of patients seeking access to the services it now provides, the hospital is frantically trying to catch up with demand.

"The expansion of services they provide has produced a tension in Derriford," said Plymouth GP Peter Williams, who like his fellow GPs takes the brunt of patient anger.

"We don't know whether the reason they haven't performed brilliantly is because they haven't managed the pressures very well, or because they haven't been resourced properly for those services."

The trust's new chief executive, Paul Roberts, acknowledged the scale of the problems facing Derriford.

He declined to comment directly on allegations of a racist and sexist old boy network, but made pointed reference to the government's national plan - a vision for the NHS which attacks "old-fashioned demarcations" between staff and services, and aims to tackle the "disempowerment" of patients.

"The sort of changes we need to make are about cultural and organisational changes," he said. There was the need to end a culture in which a "small minority of people are fighting their corners".

There are 11 clinical directorates covering areas such as heart and lung, cancer care, and paediatrics.

Mr Roberts envisages simplifying this to four divisions based around the patients' needs rather than doctors' convenience.

He also expects much-needed funding from the government's national plan.

One of his crucial problems is nurse recruitment. Last week it emerged that a shortage of specialist nurses meant brain surgery at the hospital had to be cancelled.

GPs like Dr Williams fear Derriford being swamped this winter. Its bed occupancy rates run at 95%, against a national rate of 84%.

The hospital has already had six red alerts this year, and a crisis such as a flu outbreak could put unbearable strain on bed availability.

But there is no shortage of government help, including £800,000 to get vulnerable and elderly patients out of hospital and into care.

There is also a silver lining in the recent approval for Derriford to become a teaching hospital, in partnership with two other southwest hospitals.

Teaching hospitals, with their ethos of research, are exciting places to work and will attract staff, Mr Roberts hopes.

However, trying to solve waiting list problems has already claimed the scalp of his predecessor.

In some cases, the date patients were put on a list was altered to hide the fact they had been waiting over the government's limit of 18 months; patients were moved on to "suspended" lists; and 90 patients, who were mostly waiting for treatment from Dr Evans, were found to have simply "disappeared" from the lists.

Chief executive Arthur Wilson resigned in June. An NHS taskforce has now been sent in to help reform the hospital's management of waiting lists.

In the meantime, Dr Evans has become a martyr in the eyes of Plymouth's public but her future remains unclear.

In her department, plastic surgery, the rift between her supporters and critics has fostered a poisonous climate in which trivial differences of opinion have become potentially explosive.

There has even been a row over the background tapes played in theatre, with colleagues frowning upon some of the surgeons' taste for loud rock music as they operate.

Dr Evans' supporters concede there are problems with specific areas of her practice. But in February an inquiry team found no problem with the majority of her work.

The trust's quandary is how to reinstate her without bringing to a boil the rivalries in the department.

Like everything else that Derriford needs, solving that predicament will not be an easy task.

webTitle: Strengths and weaknesses of the mental health NSF

fields.headline: Strengths and weaknesses of the mental health NSF
fields.standfirst: Sophie Petit-Zeman explains why the mental health NSF has received both praise and criticism
fields.trailText: Why the mental health NSF has received both praise and criticism
fields.body:
Under the NSF, those working in mental health in England will, for the first time, share goals and performance standards. Strategies and money to improve and support the workforce are key backups. What's best for users is at the heart of the plans - and carers get cared for, too. The Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health (SCMH) is keen to see more thought about involvement of minority ethnic and special needs groups. The centre has also raised specific concerns about each of the seven standards, set out below.

More generally, emphasis in the early years is on expensive projects - such as those for people with severe and enduring mental illness. Cliff Prior, chief executive of the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, recognises that the massive programme of change has to start somewhere and that competing needs and thinly stretched resources won't make life easy. However, he's concerned that: "Schemes to help the very ill, such as providing more secure beds, are vital, but use up money quickly. Relatively small numbers of people will benefit and others may feel they're not seeing improvements." In its defence, the Department of Health says that rapid improvements for those who otherwise heavily and repeatedly drain resources across health and social care may be cost-effective, as well as humanitarian. Moreover, the money allocated to caring for the mentally ill and the priorities determining where this goes are constantly changing.

What are its strengths?
The NSF places mental health at the top of the agenda for both health and social care. It is strongly evidence based and comprehensive. Spanning mental health promotion, primary care and secondary care, it sets standards, milestones and outcome indicators. It draws attention to the connections between life adversities and mental ill health, and suggests ways to tackle both. It puts primary care at the heart of the system and emphasises 24-hour service access.

Local agencies will share agendas, while clinicians and managers will have the flexibility to adapt these to specific needs. Integration of the care programme approach (CPA) and care management should lead to better co-ordinated care - the CPA specifies that a key worker must be allocated to each person discharged from psychiatric hospital, and that a package of multi-disciplinary care must be set up; care management requires a local authority care manager, often a social worker or occupational therapist, to organise range of services to meet the needs of the service user; while standard six, caring for carers, targets friends and families looking after people covered by the CPA. Partnerships led by social services should help to coordinate the needs of users and carers, resolve conflicts between them and adapt what's on offer to people as their needs change.

The NSF's overarching values - social inclusion, care in the least restrictive settings possible, user choice, support for carers and consideration of the needs of those from minority ethnic groups - have been widely welcomed. According to the SCMH: "Most stakeholders in mental health care should be able to unite around these values."

The NSF contains examples of good practice and service models. Both should help to promote the NSF's objectives as they are disseminated and implemented.

What are its weaknesses?
Lead responsibility for standard one - promotion of mental health, social inclusion and reduction of discrimination - rests with health authorities. "There is a major problem here, in that the NHS has no real delivery system, or levers to deliver a broad public mental health agenda or the required anti-discrimination measures," says a spokesperson for the SCMH. There is a worry that social services may end up feeling that this area of the NSF isn't their job, despite being best placed to make an impact.

Standards two and three - primary care and access to services - are ambitious. Extending specialist services, such as psychological therapies, to those with common mental health problems, at the same time as helping people with severe and enduring mental illness, may stretch limited resources too thinly. Encouraging people in mental distress to use NHS Direct has also raised concerns. However, the DoH says that people do use it as a first port of call, and it is largely appreciated.

Standards four and five - dealing with severe and enduring mental illness - may also be overambitious, setting expensive high targets for better use of mental health beds and places. The SCMH questions whether it's appropriate for the NHS to lead on these standards, and whether the focus on risk and safety is useful. "There are other aspects to mental health care, such as employment, housing and finance," says an SCMH spokesperson. However, who's formally at the helm should become less important as joined-up strategies come into play.

Standard six - caring for carers - raises the question of resources again. Local authorities will get £160m between 1999 and 2002 for the support of all carers, but there are fears that this may be swallowed up by those caring for the elderly - with little left over for people caring for the mentally ill.

Standard seven - suicide reduction - is a milestone that has been widely criticised. The DoH stresses that this target should be met as standards one to six are implemented, but there is some feeling that additional resources should have been earmarked for standard seven alone.

webTitle: How the NHS plan aims to improve mental health services

fields.headline: How the NHS plan aims to improve mental health services
fields.standfirst: Sophie Petit-Zeman examines the government's pledges to reform mental health services
fields.trailText: Sophie Petit-Zeman examines the government's pledges to reform mental health services
fields.body:
The government says it is committed to modernising mental health services. In September 1999, it launched the mental health national service framework (NSF) for services in England for the next 10 years. The NHS plan allocates more than £300m extra by 2003-04 to "fast forward" the NSF.

Which areas of mental health care will be affected and how?
The plan targets eight areas of mental health care:
 Most mental health problems are managed in primary care. To alleviate the strain on GPs, the plan says 1,000 graduate primary care workers and 500 community staff will be on hand to help GPs, accident and emergency departments and NHS Direct. However, at a time of such recruitment pressure, there are questions as to where all these new staff will come from.
 Over the next three years, 50 early-intervention-in-psychosis teams will be established to support young people, mainly those with schizophrenia, and their families.
 335 crisis resolution teams will be set up. By 2004, the aim is for mental health service users to have access to crisis help at any time.
 For people with severe mental health and other problems, such as addiction and chaotic lifestyles, who are not in touch with mainstream services, 170 new assertive outreach services should be in place by April 2001 and 50 more are promised over the next three years.
 By 2004 there will be women-only day centres in every health authority.
 By 2004 support for carers is to be increased, with 700 staff boosting respite care and strengthening support networks.
 By 2004 up to 400 people in secure hospitals who do not need to be there should be rehoused. The government has earmarked £25m to provide 200 long-term secure beds and employ 400 community staff to support them.
 Prison services are to be strengthened. 300 extra staff will support new NHS and prison partnerships, with the aim that no one with a serious mental illness should leave prison without a care plan and care coordinator.

What are the plan's main strengths and weaknesses?
Service users need to be clearer about the care they can expect, providers about doing their bit and inspectors about what needs to be monitored. However some fear that blanket rules will reduce innovation and sensitivity to local needs.

The Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health (SCMH) is concerned about the use of graduate helpers for primary care, suggesting that they may prove to be unstable and keen to move on. It questions the need for women-only services, and whether there will be enough extra staff. It says crisis intervention often fails and that the nature of carer support needs to be more carefully defined. It is unclear how scaling down high security provision fits with government plans to increase places for those with severe anti-social personality disorders who are deemed to put the public at risk. The focus on improvements for prisoners has been welcomed, but the SCMH asks why the changes focus on the seriously ill. It points out that all people in prison, regardless of their degree of mental distress, share basic rights to health care.

How has the plan been received?
Cliff Prior, chief executive of the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, has been appointed to the NHS modernisation board to oversee implementation. He says: "These plans are backed up by some hard cash and a welcome recognition of the role of carers." However, he adds: "There must also be a commitment to long-term training of health and social services staff and a high-profile public campaign to end the stigma surrounding mental illness." Strategies to recruit and train staff need careful planning and more thought needs to go into the incentive scheme, where rewards or punishments are given to green, yellow and red (good, OK and bad) services.

Has the plan missed anything out?
The SCMH would like to see improvements in hospital ward quality, a higher profile given to mental health promotion and recognition of the challenges posed by interaction between providers.

The plan allocates an extra £300m for mental health serices by 2004. The SCMH doubts this is enough. It is also unclear whether the plan will be partly financed by the general (non-mental health) NHS budget.

webTitle: Seven standards of the mental health NSF

fields.headline: Seven standards of the mental health NSF
fields.standfirst: Sophie Petit-Zeman examines seven standards that will effect users, carers and providers
fields.trailText: Sophie Petit-Zeman examines seven standards that will effect users, carers and providers
fields.body:
What are the seven standards?
The seven standards tackle five areas: health promotion and stigma, primary care and access to specialist services, needs of those with severe and enduring mental illness; carers' needs and suicide reduction.

Standard one addresses mental health promotion and strategies to combat discrimination.

Standards two and three set out how primary care should work, including onward referrals, access to round-the-clock care and NHS Direct.

Standards four and five describe effective services for those with severe and enduring mental illness, including crisis plans, round-the-clock care access, in-patient treatment and rehabilitation care.

Standard six establishes annual checks for carers of those with severe and enduring mental illness, and a written and implemented care plan.

Standard seven looks at suicide prevention. It's really a composite of standards one to six, with additional guidelines to ensure staff can assess suicide risk, learn lessons from local suicide audits and be supported in preventing prisoner suicide.

What do they mean for staff?
Delivering the standards requires close cooperation between NHS staff and those working in social care. Lead roles are taken in standards one and seven by health authorities, in standards two and three by primary care groups, in standards four and five by NHS trusts and in standard six by local authorities.

There are big workforce issues. Meeting the standards will mean improving education and training, as well as recruiting new staff and retaining them. A workforce action team is up and running, and it recently highlighted some areas which are ripe for change. Personnel planning and development need to be better managed, integrated with broader service and financial planning, and less rigid, to make best use of staff skills. Education and training need to be developed, with a special look at flexibility and career shifts. It's unclear how quickly changes will affect staff. Final recommendations from the workforce action team, which are due in spring 2001, should clarify matters.

What do they mean for users and carers?
Partnerships between providers, users and carers are vital to ensure services meet needs. It will be interesting to see how this happens, but the NSF pledges strong user and carer involvement as the seven standards are rolled out, especially in:
 planning, providing and evaluating education and training
 influencing the research agenda, including developing research tools with users to assess their views on how services can best meet needs
 developing and evaluating occupational activities
 clinical audit, such as satisfaction with the care programme approach (CPA). The CPA is a system for people being discharged from psychiatric hospital, which specifies that a key worker must be allocated and package of multi-disciplinary care must be set up.

webTitle: Demands grow on mid-range charities

fields.headline: Demands grow on mid-range charities
fields.trailText: There was a time, not so long ago, when to have suggested that the Guardian should encourage its readers to give to charity would have provoked a healthy debate. To have proposed that the newspaper run its own appeal would have risked revolt, says David Brindle
fields.body:
There was a time, not so long ago, when to have suggested that the Guardian should encourage its readers to give to charity would have provoked a healthy debate. To have proposed that the newspaper run its own appeal would have risked revolt.

Today, as the Guardian launches its third Christmas appeal, there is no issue. Charities have become an essential pillar of modern society and the argument that their work for the disadvantaged and oppressed is "letting the state off the hook" is rarely voiced beyond the extreme left.

Charities are big business. Depending how you count it, their overall income is anything up to £21bn a year. They employ 500,000 paid staff.

Yet this is not growth for growth's sake. Charities have assumed a rapidly expanding role as providers of services on behalf of government. As the state has withdrawn from direct provision of care, support and advice for those in need, so it is charities that have stepped in to fill the void.

The importance of this role has been acknowledged by the government, which has signed a "compact" with the voluntary sector in recognition of its status as an independent partner. Ministers, from Tony Blair down, have called for a new era of giving and a revived culture of "civic patriotism".

All is not rosy in the charity garden, however. As needs multiply, at home and overseas, many charities are struggling to keep their heads above water - and some are questioning their strategies.

Research to be published this week by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations will confirm that medium-sized charities bore the brunt of a slump in charitable giving in the 1990s. While donations have now started to rise again, they remain well below previous levels and mid-range charities still find themselves squeezed by the fundraising power of their big name competitors.

But these have been suffering, too. A collapse of charity shop income has hit Oxfam and Scope, triggering shop closures and job losses. The NSPCC's failure so far to get anywhere near the £250m target for its Full Stop campaign - the biggest fundraising appeal in history - has shown that size is no guarantee of success.

Latest figures from an index kept by Barclays bank and NGO Finance magazine suggest that the top 100 charities have weathered the storm, posting an overall 9% increase in income for 1999-2000. Significantly, though, one of the best performers was Age Concern (England), which returned an 88% rise in trading revenue largely thanks to its insurance and financial services.

Last year, Guardian readers raised more than £200,000 for four charities. This year, the aim is to do better still. Once again, one of the charities has been chosen from among the winners of a Guardian award for smaller charities, announced in October, and the other three have been selected from charities applying to be considered for the appeal in categories of domestic poverty, overseas aid and the environment. Preference was given to medium-sized applicants.

There is a wide spread: the smaller charity, young and innovative, goes into primary schools to work with children with behavioural problems; the domestic charity works with women fleeing violence and abuse at home; the overseas aid organisation takes help straight to people who suffer the twin agonies of poverty and disability; and the environmental charity provides invaluable assistance to developing countries seeking to defend themselves at law against exploitation or pollution.

Over the next month, the Guardian will report on the work of these four charities. Please read about what they are doing, please reflect on it - and please give generously.

ADD

When Lao Son was injured by a landmine, he lost much more than his sight and job. He was abandoned by his wife and children and he lost his name. To everyone in his village, he became "Avka" - blind man.

But his skills and knowledge survived. His job as a surgical assistant in Kampong Speu, west Cambodia, allowed him to contribute to a tuberculosis self-help group. It changed the way the villagers saw him and they sought his advice. He is no longer called Avka.

The group was just one of thousands supported by Action on Disability and Development, which helps poor, disabled people improve their lives and society's attitude towards them in 12 of the poorest African and Asian countries. Founded in 1985, ADD helps disabled people's groups with equipment, training and seed money - there is a strong focus on disabled women, many of whom have been victims of sexual abuse.

ADD also assists in lobbying governments to improve disabled people's rights. It supports groups such as Sudan's Kassala Society of the Disabled, which runs an orthopaedic workshop for landmine victims, staffed by disabled people.
Raekha Prasad

FIELD

Formed in 1989 by a group of international lawyers to protect the global environment. It recruits and trains young lawyers from around the world and provides legal assistance to governments and non-governmental organisations.

For developing countries much of this legal support is free, the main aim being to protect a country's ecosystem from damage through commercial exploitation or pollution.

The legal team are drawn from a range of backgrounds and share the belief that the most pressing global environmental problems - climate change, loss of biodiversity, pollution of shared water resources and the thinning of the ozone layer - can best be tackled through development and implementation of international law.

FIELD programmes promote long-term strategic research and advice on biological diversity and marine resources, climate change and energy, and trade investment and sustainable development.

Its lawyers provided legal back-up for 42 countries from the Alliance of Small island States (Aosis) at the Hague summit on climate change last month.

FIELD is holding a London briefing on December 19 on what really happened at the summit. Call 020-7637 7950 for details.
Keith Perry

Place2Be

Founded in 1994, offers emotional and therapeutic support to children in schools. Counsellors give private assistance to children with a wide range of behavioural problems. They offer children an adult to talk to who is neither teacher nor parent.

Counsellors help children with their emotional reactions to the trials of school years, including divorce, deprivation, abandonment, long-term illness in the family, domestic violence, homelessness, physical or sexual abuse, and the trauma of being a refugee.

Of the children seen last year, the charity reported a positive change in 82%, and no school dealing with Place2Be excluded a child.

By next September the charity hopes to be represented in 40 schools in the boroughs of Brent and Enfield in London, Medway in Kent, and in Nottingham.

Place2Be was a winner this year of the Guardian charity award for smaller organisations.
Paul Kelso

Refuge

Refuge is a lifeline for thousands of women and children in Britain for whom emotional and physical abuse is part of everyday life.

Since opening the world's first women's refuge 29 years ago in London, the charity has led the struggle against domestic violence, providing support and raising awareness.

One in four women will experience physical abuse at the hands of a partner during her lifetime. Five thousand women seek help from Refuge every week by calling the charity's 24-hour National Domestic Violence Helpline. The service, which costs £550,000 a year and depends on charitable donations, is stretched beyond its limits. It is able to deal with just a fifth of the calls it receives each week.

Refuge also operates a network of safe houses and provides outreach services for women from minority ethnic groups.
Rebecca Allison

webTitle: Watch on sex offenders under strain

fields.headline: Watch on sex offenders under strain
fields.trailText: A new public protection system to manage the most dangerous sex offenders after their release from prison is already under strain because the numbers involved have trebled in the past year. Alan Travis reports
fields.body:
A new public protection system to manage the most dangerous sex offenders after their release from prison is already under strain because the numbers involved have trebled in the past year.

Home Office officials have told probation officers that around 30 offenders a month are now being identified as potentially dangerous: likely to pose a risk to the public, or in need of protection themselves on release.

The new system was put in place in April last year after the high profile release of sex offenders such as Sidney Cooke and Robert Oliver sparked vigilante protests.

An early warning system was set up, under which prison and probation authorities and the police advise Home Office ministers of their plans to handle the release of inmates deemed still to be particularly dangerous two months before they are due to leave jail.

Although the offenders have finished their sentences they agree to live in probation hostels with specific monitoring and supervision arrangements.

But a rise in the number of such dangerous offenders being released from 10 a month when the scheme got under way last year to about 30 a month now is putting it under great strain.

Paddy Doyle, a senior official in the Home Office's dangerous offenders unit, last week heard complaints from probation officers that it was becoming increasingly difficult to place all the offenders in appropriate accommodation because of the numbers involved.

The number of offenders deemed to be dangerous and living in London has now passed the 900 mark and the new Criminal Justice Act, which reached the statute book on Friday, will place a new duty on police and probation services to make arrangements for assessing and managing all convicted sex criminals and violent offenders on their patch.

Mr Doyle said the Home Office was also setting up a new unit to oversee the release plans for each prisoner who was deemed to be dangerous. A report on each one goes to the prisons minister, Paul Boateng.

So far only 40 sex offender orders have been made under the new system since its introduction last April. These require convicted sex offenders to register for at least five years and to comply with other conditions, which may include electronic tagging, to protect the public from serious harm.

As it costs an average of £24,000 a month for a police surveillance team to monitor just one offender round the clock, different methods of keeping track of these dangerous ex-prisoners are being developed around the country. In some areas the police and probation will offer a violent offender a "tenancy agreement" before they come out, under which they agree to curfew and tagging restrictions.

Harry Fletcher, the assistant general secretary, of the National Association of Probation Officers, said there was not enough money to provide the kind of monitoring of offenders that was needed.

"The probation service's liaison arrangements with the police are very good but unless resources are dedicated to this task I fear that something awful will happen."

webTitle: Head of BBC religious unit quits 'over poor slots'

fields.headline: Head of BBC religious unit quits 'over poor slots'
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The Church of England yesterday warned the BBC that it would scrutinise religious programming with renewed vigilance after the decision by the Rev Ernie Rea, head of the corporation's religious broadcasting unit, to retire early, allegedly in protest at the downgrading of coverage.
fields.body:
The Church of England yesterday warned the BBC that it would scrutinise religious programming with renewed vigilance after the decision by the Rev Ernie Rea, head of the corporation's religious broadcasting unit, to retire early, allegedly in protest at the downgrading of coverage.

Mr Rea, who held his post for 11 years, was unavailable for comment yesterday but was known to be concerned that a reorganisation this year to create a new department of religion and ethics would result in fewer programmes and less peak-time scheduling.

The BBC yesterday confirmed a Sunday Times report that he was leaving and said he planned to make his announcement today.

A spokesman said: "Ernie has done a fantastic job in serving viewers and listeners with quality religious broadcasting. That role will continue because the BBC is absolutely committed to religious broadcasting."

The Church of England in particular has voiced concern that religious programmes are being shifted to unpopular broadcasting slots and that there has been a dumbing down of their content. Its general synod in February called for more religious programmes at peak times.

Mr Rea, in an interview on Radio 4's Sunday programme in July, said he wanted programmes from his department to have greater impact and admitted that there had been scheduling problems. "I think there are dangers inherent...the religious specialisation needs to be affirmed and protected," he said.

The Sunday Times quoted an unnamed colleague of Mr Rea as saying: "There is a sense that religion is pretty low down the list of priorities, especially with the likes of Greg Dyke. Jane Root [controller of BBC2] does not want any of the traditional Christianity at all; she just wants new-agey stuff."

Mr Rea is a Northern Ireland presbyterian minister who has worked for the BBC for 22 years. He introduced programmes such as radio's Moral Maze and gave the Everyman and Heart of the Matter series more prominence - although the latter's presenter, Joan Bakewell left this year, claiming that it was being scheduled too late to gain an audience.

At 55, Mr Rea might have expected several more years in the post, and his departure will surprise the corporation.

Bill Beaver, the Church of England's head of communications, said: "We will view Ernie Rea's departure with considerable concern and disquiet.

"He has made a considerable contribution to the quality of life in this nation, and we will be addressing the matter at the highest level over the next few weeks.

"The downgrading of religious programming runs absolutely counter to all the research which shows that people appreciate and enjoy imaginative, high-quality religious broadcasting."

The BBC spokesman insisted that religion was still prominent in schedules, pointing to 600 hours of radio programming and 110 hours of television devoted to it this year.

webTitle: Lego shortlists two for new media campaign

fields.headline: Lego shortlists two for new media campaign
fields.trailText: 8am: Toymaker Lego has shortlisted two advertising agencies to pitch for its multimillion pound new media business, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Lego is determined to ditch its heritage as merely a maker of plastic bricks and is ploughing resources into its new media division.

Lego Media International has shortlisted two advertising agencies to pitch for its multimillion pound business.

For the first time, it is looking for an agency to create campaigns that will run across its key markets including the UK, US and Germany.

Lego Media, which has its worldwide headquarters in London, was set up in 1996 to develop new products for children including interactive software, TV programmes, books, magazines, films and music.

Whichever agency is appointed to the business will play a key role in promoting these ventures.

Lego's objective is to build on the natural fit between Lego play materials and its media products.

Through Lego Media International the company recently set up Lego Media Production and has recruited children's TV executives from both ITV and the BBC.

The new operation intends to develop and invest in a wide range of different projects including entertainment shows, animation, factual programmes and live action.

Lego Media refused to comment.

webTitle: Channel 5 woos teens with two US imports

fields.headline: Channel 5 woos teens with two US imports
fields.trailText: 8am: Channel 5 is lining up two new US high school dramas to entertain teenage viewers on Saturday evenings, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 5 will be upping the teen angst and high school drama element of its Saturday night schedule from early next year, with US imports Young Americans and Popular.

The two teen dramas will go out in the same 5.55pm Saturday slot Shannen Doherty vehicle Charmed has occupied this year, starting with Young Americans from January 13.

Young Americans comes from the US producers behind Dawson's Creek and centres around a working class teenager, played by newcomer Rodney Scott, who wins a scholarship to an exclusive New England boarding school.

But the show may not go beyond its initial eight episodes after it failed to make a big impression ratings-wise on the WB network in the US this summer.

Popular, now in its second series in the US, is another teen high school drama that goes out on WB. This Heathers-esque drama about clashing school cliques will follow Young Americans on Saturday nights from March 10.

Both shows are already on air on UK pay-TV channels, Young Americans on Trouble and Popular on Sky One.

webTitle: Has Lara Croft had a boob job?

fields.headline: Has Lara Croft had a boob job?
fields.standfirst: You decide: click here
fields.trailText:
8am: Lara Croft's bottom and breasts have been remodelled for the new Tomb Raider game, reports Caroline Furneaux.
You decide: click here
fields.body:
Lara Croft's breasts have always been unfeasibly large, but the question that hangs over the launch of the latest Tomb Raider game is whether she has had a boob job.

Bosses at Eidos, the computer games company that created her, admit that they have tinkered with her physical attributes to better "define her character".

"Whilst they have got larger, they have not got extreme," said Jeremy Heath-Smith, head of global development.

The image of Lara, which is one of the company's biggest marketing tools, has been refined each time a new Tomb Raider game comes out.

But this time it appears that Eidos has given her an impossible physique. Her breasts are so oversized, it would seem impossible for her to stand up, let alone leap through jungles and across mountain ranges with gun holsters strapped to her thighs.

Mr Heath-Smith, said: "It is almost as if she has had a bit of plastic surgery. They have got more defined. As we have moved into the PlayStation technology, we have improved our knowledge of the hardware and been able to define her character better.

"We have defined and smoothed them and made them more whole."

Apparently modifications have also been made her posterior.

He added: "For the new Tomb Raider chronicles game, it is the first time she has had a proper bum. We haven't just taken a cursor and made her a couple of sizes bigger. It is almost an optical illusion."

His comments make fascinating classroom reading in the light of the government's latest plan to bring computer games into schools.

webTitle: Germany launches BSE ad campaign

fields.headline: Germany tackles BSE with new TV ads
fields.trailText: 8am: A TV ad campaign just launched in Germany encouraging consumers to eat more beef could prove a PR disaster, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Germans could be heading for the same public relations disaster over beef as the British government.

The German government has just launched a new TV advertising campaign encouraging people to eat more beef, just days after the shock discovery of its first ever cases of BSE-infected cattle.

The German food marketing association, CMA, has asked one of its ad agencies to handle an campaign promoting German beef.

The ads are launching despite the fact that an earlier campaign praising German beef under the banner, "Meat. Pure pleasure", was dropped after BSE was discovered in a calf.

They will feature testimonials by well-known German cooks and special call centres for consumers.

CMA also plans a sales promotion push in Germany and other markets informing consumers about the advantages of German beef.

"Even though Germany is no longer considered a BSE-free country, it is necessary to inform consumers at length about the high quality and safety standards of German beef," said a CMA spokesman.

"The consumer should be aware that CMA understands their concerns, but that it is not necessary to panic when buying and eating German beef."

Efforts to reassure consumers that beef is completely safe to eat will be familiar to UK meat-eaters.

But the early campaigns in the UK extolling the virtues of beef backfired once the gravity of BSE and the link with the human form of mad cow disease was established.

webTitle: Guardian Media: My media

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Jon Culshaw
fields.trailText: Jon Culshaw
fields.body:
Newspapers: I glance through all of them. I like the Mirror and the Sun's sense of humour. I will look over the likes of the Guardian and the Telegraph on a train journey - which could last for several years these days. I check the Financial Times to see if I can understand anything that is written in it but I never can.

Magazines: I look at FHM, Heat and Later. I like the conflicting advice section in Later when Jeremy Clarkson or Chris Moyles give advice.

Radio: Radio 1, Capital FM and Virgin. Chris Tarrant is one of the best personality DJs ever. I also like Sara Cox's sense of humour and warmth. Chris Evans does a fantastic show. He has a great broadcasting sense and talent. I also like Brian Perkins on Radio 4. When you listen to him you get a sense of a real national institution.

Television: I watch the Big Breakfast and really admire Johnny Vaughan. We were wearing exactly the same shirt when I was filming as him outside the Big Breakfast. Trigger Happy TV was a real treat. I only watch soaps in a professional capacity if I have to learn a new impression such as Phil Mitchell or Mark Fowler. For enjoyment, Ali G is still going strong.

Books: I'm not really a reader but wish I was. I'm too easily distracted - but I did like Time for Bed by David Baddiel.

Films: The last films I saw were Some Like It Hot and Breakfast at Tiffany's after they were digitally re-done. It was brilliant to see them at the cinema. I've just bought The Talented Mr Ripley, Private Parts and Swingers on DVD.

Adverts: I'm looking forward to seeing the new one on racial equality. I think that will have a great impact. I hate "Whassup!" now. Every pillock in the land is going "Whassup!"

New media: I have got a Wap phone but I never got beyond page four in the instructions. I don't use the internet much. I get bored waiting for it to load.

 Dead Ringers impressionist Jon Culshaw stars in the new Tango advert.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Media Monkey

fields.headline: Media Monkey
fields.trailText: • It's not really OK at the Express, part one. While Posh Spice (sorry, Mr Desmond, Victoria Beckham) was shown around the Star showbiz desk last week, husband David met the fearless staff of the Express sports department.
fields.body:
 It's not really OK at the Express, part one. While Posh Spice (sorry, Mr Desmond, Victoria Beckham) was shown around the Star showbiz desk last week, husband David met the fearless staff of the Express sports department.

"You're the ones who've been turning me over, aren't you," he squeaked, grinning. As the hapless hacks hung their heads in shame, the paper's new favourite footballer added astutely: "You won't be doing that any more, will you?" Indeed, they were forced to concede, they won't.

 Part two. Editorial executives at the Express went to Richard Desmond with a request to replace Rachel Ellis, the departing health correspondent. It was, they pointed out, an important post and Ellis, who had handed in her notice before the OK! buyout, should be replaced as quickly as possible. The new proprietor didn't quite see it that way: "Why do we need a health reporter? Get it off the internet, it's free," he barked.

 Part three. A puzzling one. Apparently Lord Hollick deliberately retained the group's 18% stake in the Press Association when he negotiated the sale of his papers to Desmond. But surely it isn't possible that Desmond didn't know what PA, the hacks' bible, was?

Monkey fervently hopes that it is no shock to him that instead of receiving the service free as a shareholder, the Express titles must now pay around £1m a year for it. What a good job he arrived prepared to invest.

 Part four. After Desmond banned staff from using courier bikes (taxis are now apparently the preferred option), Rosie Boycott was overheard dictating an email in which every second word was "fucking". When asked why she had resorted to such extremes, she is said to have replied: "It's the only language he understands ..."

 Oh OK, just one more then. Monkey's online revelation on Friday of the identities of the mystery 25 Express employees who received a £40,000 kiss-off from Lord Hollick caused mutiny at the Grey Lubianka.

Sadly, space restrictions prevent a full list here, but for any remaining Express staffer who feels such largesse should be spread about, the lucky few are named and shamed here. A limited-edition Media Monkey badge will go to anyone who can tell us the connection between the 25. (No, Clive, not you.)

 Stuart Murphy, the impossibly youthful head of BBC Choice, has commissioned a series about the world's most notable lavatories - a sort of Whicker's World of Bogs. It seems that the idea came to him when he was spending a few hard-earned pennies in the little boys' room of Bertorelli's West End restaurant. "It's great - you do it up against a mirror as the water cascades down." Thank you, Stuart.

 It appears that Piers Morgan is preparing for lean times. On Monday night, the Mirror editor was spotted dining at Monkey's local Vietnamese canteen (the Viet Hoa on Kingsland Road in Hackney, since you ask) where you'd be hard-pressed to find a meal for over a fiver.

For amusement, he and his blonde, fluffy cardigan-wearing companion were reading aloud to each other from small paperbacks. If it weren't for his suit, you'd think he was reliving his student days. Or living the life of a bohemian intellectual in prewar Paris.

 The BBC's Alan Yentob and Channel 4's Michael Jackson, faced an embarrassing dilemma last week: whether to attend Madonna at Brixton Academy or the C4-presented Turner Prize dinner. Yentob cancelled his audience with the arts world, but forgot to secure an invite to the gig.

Undaunted, he called his old mate Jacko and asked for his. But sadly Michael decided to ditch his own dinner leaving Alan facing an early night. Next time Alan, call the FT where the staff are so, er, achingly hip that when an unwanted ticket was auctioned it raised a measly £70.

webTitle: TV independents fight for rights

fields.headline: TV independents fight for rights
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The brains behind hit TV shows such as Have I Got News for You, Robot Wars, and Mr Bean have begun an unprecedented campaign against broadcasters who cream off the profits from their ideas.
fields.body:
The brains behind hit TV shows such as Have I Got News for You, Robot Wars, and Mr Bean have begun an unprecedented campaign against broadcasters who cream off the profits from their ideas.

Four leading television production houses are demanding an inquiry by the office of fair trading into what they claim are restrictive practices at the BBC and Channel 4, which retain most or all of the spin-off benefits from programmes produced by the independents.

The four believe broadcasters abuse their dominance in the marketplace to squeeze as much profit as possible, instead of allowing independent producers to reinvest the cash in new ideas. They want ministers to protect their position in a white paper - the basis for a future communications bill - due to be published in the next two weeks. It is understood that Tom Gutteridge of Mentorn Barraclough Carey will go further and demand the OFT inquiry, on behalf of the four independent production houses, at a meeting with officials of the Department of Trade and Industry this week.

In an open letter in Media Guardian today, they call for ministers to act. "The creative industry is scarcely an industry at all," say Mr Gutteridge, Denise O'Donoghue and Jimmy Mulville of Hat Trick, Paul Smith of Celador, and Charles Brand of Tiger Aspect - between them responsible for some of the biggest hits of recent years.

They argue that, if they were allowed to retain all the rights to market their programmes abroad and profit from spin-offs such as merchandising, Britain's independent production base would explode in size. At the moment, only ITV allows programme producers to keep all their rights. Celador has been the highest profile beneficiary: it has made huge sums from overseas sales of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?

The "big four" say other broadcasters should be allowed simply to purchase a "right to broadcast".

The current system is not only unfair but is costing Britain dearly, they say. "Millions of pounds worth of inward investment and exports are lost as a result."

webTitle: Publishers aim to cash in with internet audio books

fields.headline: Publishers aim to cash in with internet audio books
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Two of Britain's biggest audio book publishers are hoping to raise sales by breaking into the internet MP3 market with cut-price sound versions of bestsellers and classics.
fields.body:
Two of Britain's biggest audio book publishers are hoping to raise sales by breaking into the internet MP3 market with cut-price sound versions of bestsellers and classics.

Works by Margaret Thatcher, Oscar Wilde, Dick Francis, Chris Stewart and Charles Dickens are likely to be among the first to go online - at prices a third lower than for the companies' cassettes or CD-roms.

Lady Thatcher's voice, reading from The Downing Street Years, is among those expected to be advertised on selected websites. The books will be in encrypted form, downloadable as files for MP3 players.

Penguin and HarperCollins are joining forces with Didio, a digital audio company, to launch the venture in the first quarter of the new year, it emerged yesterday.

"Interest is not going to be huge," Anna Hopkins, head of audio publishing at Penguin, said. "But I see the number of downloads overtaking sales of physical copies fairly soon.

"Research indicates that the market is going to explode in the next few years."

Much of the project's planning has gone into finding an encryption technique that stops files from being downloaded without payment or copied between users.

The security and transaction technology comes from Magex, the digital commerce company launched by NatWest. Promotional research for Magex claims that the global downloading market will be worth $700bn (£486bn) by 2004.

Ms Hopkins said: "Encryption has been our biggest worry. Our hope is that we will always be one step ahead of the code crackers."

Some 500 titles, 300 of them from Penguin, will be the first to go online on book sales websites such as Penguin and Bol.

Simon Gibbs, Didio's chairman, said: "We will be launching with more audio book titles than any high street shop."

Titles will include Gervase Phinn's Over Hill and Dale, Chris Stewart's travel bestseller Driving over Lemons, Sue Townsend's Adrian Mole stories, and a children's title by Allan Ahlberg.

Royalty negotiations for authors for some other titles are still under way.

webTitle: Police in Damilola inquiry seek gang of youths

fields.headline: Police in Damilola inquiry seek gang of youths
fields.trailText: A 13-year-old was stabbed in a London street yesterday, less than a week after Damilola Taylor was killed as he walked home from school.
fields.body:
A 13-year-old was stabbed in a London street yesterday, less than a week after Damilola Taylor was killed as he walked home from school.

The black boy was walking with an Asian friend in Hackney Wick, north-east London, when they were approached by two youths who stole a mobile phone and cash from the Asian boy, also aged 13.

A passer-by intervened and the robbers left, but they returned when the two boys were on their own, punching the Asian and stabbing his friend with a knife, leaving him seriously injured. London Ambulance Service said he had cuts to his stomach but his condition was stable.

Meanwhile a gang of youths aged 10 to 14 has become the focus of the Damilola Taylor investigation. They were loitering in Peckham, south London, the night he was stabbed.

Witnesses have told Scotland Yard detectives that between six and 10 boys were outside the librarywhere the 10-year-old had joined an after-school computer class last Monday. An anonymous 999 call reported a bottle fight between youths shortly before Damilola was attacked, but police found no evidence of the incident. Detective Superin tendent David Dillnutt, overseeing the inquiry, said: "We are still seeking witnesses at the library from about 3.35pm when Damilola arrived _ this is a particular square where children meet." Police believe a woman in a red anorak with a small child was also outside the library. The fresh appeal for information came follow ing the arrest and release on Saturday of two boys, aged 12 and 13, and a 39-year-old woman.

During a press conference Mr Dillnutt dismissed reports that Damilola's family believed their son, who was born in Nigeria and had moved to the UK four months ago, was being bullied by West Indian youths. "We have no evidence of this. The family is not saying this is a racial incident or a racist attack. We simply do not know if there is a link between the bullying that had been complained of by Damilola's family and his death."

Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the Metropolitan police, acknowledged, how ever, that there were tensions on the Peckham estate where he was killed. "What is being said is that there is a certain amount of tension between racial groups," he told London Weekend Television. "We must not deny that, but we must also not build that up into a situation where there's more violence." Sir John said 70 officers were on the case. All of Damilola's classmates had been seen, and 100 adults have come forward. A memorial service was held yesterday.

The government will this week announce plans to extend youth curfews to anyone aged up to 16. Ministers will also review policy on the carrying of knives.

webTitle: Hague pledges £8bn tax cuts

fields.headline: Hague pledges £8bn tax cuts
fields.standfirst:
Traditional Conservative election package is aimed at solving the party's internal squabbles
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText:
William Hague will this week try to reanchor the
dangerously adrift Conservative party by offering a
traditional agenda of £8bn worth of tax cuts, matched
by £8bn in spending cuts, within the first three years of
a Conservative government.
fields.body:
William Hague will this week try to reanchor the dangerously adrift Conservative party by offering a traditional agenda of £8bn worth of tax cuts, matched by £8bn in spending cuts, within the first three years of a Conservative government.

Central Office is desperately hoping that the package, backed by a speech from Mr Hague, can lift Tory morale and end the impression that the Conservatives have given up the next election as a lost cause.

The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, confirmed the party's plight by admitting yesterday that damaging personal counter-briefing was going on within the shadow cabinet and insisting "we have a duty to get ourselves seriously together".

Former chancellor Ken Clarke also issued a statement insisting he had never said he would challenge Mr Hague for the leadership, while Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, was reported to have admitted that the Conservatives have been "a dead patient for the past eight years".

Central Office was also pulling out all the stops to prevent the deselection of the respected pro-European MP Ian Taylor. His local party meets tonight to debate a call for his deselection. The former Conservative chairman Chris Patten said the party "could say goodbye" to winning the next election if he is rejected.

The package of spending cuts produced yesterday reveals that the shadow cabinet has so far identified only £5.3bn in cuts, leaving a £2.7bn gap on the Tories' own figures.

The shortfall masks continuing disputes over the direction of policy, including crime spending, farm support and the future of the married couples' allowance.

The social security secretary, Alistair Darling, called the Tory package bogus, saying that the savings the Tories had identified in social security had fallen by £900m since the last time the party offered a figure. Labour repeated that Mr Portillo would still need £16bn of spending cuts if he is to meet his pledge of ensuring public spending rises by 2% over the three-year period, rather than the annual 3.3% planned by the government.

The package, the first time the Tories have assembled all their spending savings in one place, is also designed to prove that the Conservatives would match Labour's record planned spending on the NHS and schools.

Mr Hague will tomorrow tell the Institute of Economic Affairs, a free-market thinktank: "Labour are trying to force voters to choose between lower taxes and better public services. But they underestimate the intelligence of the British people. They know there is plenty of scope to save money that is currently being wasted on bureaucracy, political gimmicks and bad government."

The cuts package centres on £2.1bn saving in the social security budget, including privatising industrial injuries benefit (saving £160m), and requiring all lone parents with children aged 11 or over to seek work (£500m). A further £330m a year would be saved by cutting the period before which any jobseekers allowance claimant must accept a job offer.

They also promise a £1bn cut in welfare fraud over and above the substantial savings budgeted by the present government. The Conservatives say they would target housing benefit fraud by giving benefits inspectors the same powers as tax investigators. Labour claims it is planning similar measures in a bill to be published along with the Queen's speech.

Mr Portillo and Mr Hague also propose to save £400m a year by privatising the New Deal for the unemployed and rewarding private contractors for the number of successful job placements achieved.

The Conservatives claim they will save £1.8bn by 2003-4 on the costs of Whitehall administration, mainly by a policy of zero recruitment and a reduction in costs apart from wages. Abolition of the regional development agencies and the transfer of their functions to local councils would save £200m annually, the Tories claim. A further £205m would be saved by not setting up English regional assemblies. Labour countered it had made no commitment to establish such assemblies.

webTitle: EU: Germany demands more voting power

fields.headline: Germany demands more voting power
fields.standfirst:
Schröder says bargaining will be tough

Special report: European integration
Special report: the European Parliament
fields.trailText: Schröder says bargaining will be tough
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Gerhard Schröder was standing firm last night on his demand for more voting power for Germany in the EU as tensions grew over this week's landmark Nice summit.

After failing to reach agreement in talks with the French president, Jacques Chirac, the German chancellor signalled tough bargaining when leaders gather on Thursday.

Last night, as Robin Cook joined fellow EU foreign ministers for a final negotiating session in Brussels, there was no sign that key problems were any closer to being resolved.

In London, sniping continued between the government and the Tories over what was at stake in what is widely billed as the EU's most significant treaty since Maastricht.

The latest draft of the Nice text, distributed by the French presidency, offers no solution to the vexed issue of voting weights, which are crucial to the balance of power among the EU's four big countries.

The French and German leaders predicted after meeting in Hanover that they would eventually reach agreement. But that could mean more pressure on Tony Blair to give ground on majority voting, which he has vowed to resist on tax, social security and other key areas.

Germany, with more than 20m more inhabitants than France since reunification, wants more votes in the EU council of ministers.

"I cannot agree a system of vote weighting which gives Spain or Poland - just think of the relative gross domestic product - just as many votes as Germany, which has double the population," Mr Schröder said in an interview published today in Der Spiegel. "Everything would fall apart."

Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, repeated that majority voting was vital to avoid gridlock when up to 13 new members join the EU in the coming years. Chances of success at the summit were only 50-50, he told Die Welt.

Leaders must also reach agreement on the size of the commission and arrangements for "enhanced cooperation" or flexibility, allowing more integrationist-minded countries to forge ahead.

The Conservatives claimed that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, was willing to abandon the veto so Britain could be forced to bail out countries suffering economic difficulties due to the single currency.

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, described the proposals as "fiscal federalism," but this interpretation was rejected by the Treasury.

One of the reforms to be discussed at Nice would allow aid to be given in the event of natural disasters like floods, but Mr Maude said the clause permitted fiscal transfers where a member state is threatened by difficulties caused by "exceptional circumstances beyond its control".

The Tory attack was blunted by veterans of the Major and Thatcher administrations railing against the current party line on Europe.

Lord Brittan described the Conservatives' current stance as "irrational, counter-productive and against the national interest."

Chris Patten, the former party chairman and now a European commissioner, said Britain needed a government that engaged constructively with Europe, which he suggested the current Tory leadership was not doing.

The former foreign secretary, Lord Hurd, told Sky News that Nice would not undermine British sovereignty.

"The idea 'veto good, majority voting bad' is grossly oversimplified," he said.

Where member states stand:

Areas where members are unwilling to surrender right of veto:

Britain: Tax, social security, immigration and border control policy.

France: Trade policy where cultural identity and film industry might be damaged by agreements with US. Aspects of immigration policy.

Germany: Immigration policy - fears an influx from eastern Europe. Transport policy.

Italy: None - willing to surrender national veto.

Greece: Transport policy, regional aid and trade policy.

Spain: Regional aid, environmental and trade policy.

Portugal: Regional aid and tax policy.

Austria: Immigration, environment and transport policy.

Sweden: Tax policy, some areas of social security policy, Euro MPs' pay and conditions.

Finland: Pay and conditions for Euro-MPs.

Netherlands: Tax, social security and immigration policy.

Denmark: Tax, social security, immigration, international law enforcement, pay and conditions for Euro-MPs.

Belgium: None - willing to surrender veto altogether.

Luxembourg: Tax policy.

Ireland: Tax, aspects of social policy and international agreements on foreign and security matters.

Andrew Osborn

webTitle: Spies seek access to all phone, email and net links

fields.headline: Spies seek access to all phone, email and net links
fields.standfirst:
Home Office considers sweeping plan that violates privacy laws

Net news
fields.trailText: The security and intelligence agencies are demanding the right to access records of every phone call, email, and internet connection made in Britain, the Home Office confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
The security and intelligence agencies are demanding the right to access records of every phone call, email, and internet connection made in Britain, the Home Office confirmed yesterday.

The sweeping proposal - a threat to the right of privacy enshrined in data protection and human rights legislation - is revealed in a classified document written by Roger Gaspar, deputy director general of the national criminal intelligence service (NCIS).

He said he had drawn up the plan on behalf of MI5, MI6, GCHQ, customs and excise, and the Association of Chief Police Officers. "Legislation should require every CSP (communication service provider) to retain all communications data originating or terminating in the UK, or routed through the UK networks, including any such data that is stored offshore," he told the Home Office.

"A clear legislative framework needs to be agreed as a matter of urgency.

"The data on individual communications should be retained in the interests of justice, to preserve and protect data for use as evidence to establish proof of innocence or guilt. For intelligence and evidence gathering purposes, to maintain the effectiveness of UK law enforcement, intelligence and security agencies, to protect society."

He added: "In the interests of verifying the accuracy of data specifically provided for either intelligence or evidential purposes, CSPs should be under an obligation to retain the original data supplied for a period of seven years or for as long as the prosecuting authorities direct."

The document continues: "Informal discussions have taken place with the office of the data protection commissioner [Elizabeth France]. Whilst they acknowledge that such communications data may be of value to the work of the agencies and the interests of justice they have grave reservations about longer term data retention."

Mr Gaspar compared the proposed new data bank - which would cost an estimated £3m to set up and £9m a year to run - to the national DNA database.

The Home Office said yesterday it had received representations from law enforcement agencies. It added: "We are considering their representations. However no decisions have been taken." A spokeswoman said the plan would require new legislation.

John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, said yesterday: "The security services and the police have a voracious appetite for collecting up information about our private lives, but this is an extraordinary idea.

"This would violate the principles of the Data Protection Act and the Human Rights Act and the government should reject this idea now. If it goes ahead we will challenge this in the courts in this country and the European court of human rights."

The government has already increased the powers of the police and the security and intelligence agencies to monitor emails and other forms of communications through the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act. This allows the agencies to collect "communications data" - websites and email addresses used by individuals - without obtaining any warrant.

It also allows the police to demand the keys to encrypted data and provides for connection data held by internet service providers to be made available to NCIS.

The government said it needed the new powers in the war against paedophiles, drug traffickers, and organised criminal gangs.

fields.bodyText: The security and intelligence agencies are demanding the right to access records of every phone call, email, and internet connection made in Britain, the Home Office confirmed yesterday. The sweeping proposal - a threat to the right of privacy enshrined in data protection and human rights legislation - is revealed in a classified document written by Roger Gaspar, deputy director general of the national criminal intelligence service (NCIS). He said he had drawn up the plan on behalf of MI5, MI6, GCHQ, customs and excise, and the Association of Chief Police Officers. "Legislation should require every CSP (communication service provider) to retain all communications data originating or terminating in the UK, or routed through the UK networks, including any such data that is stored offshore," he told the Home Office. "A clear legislative framework needs to be agreed as a matter of urgency. "The data on individual communications should be retained in the interests of justice, to preserve and protect data for use as evidence to establish proof of innocence or guilt. For intelligence and evidence gathering purposes, to maintain the effectiveness of UK law enforcement, intelligence and security agencies, to protect society." He added: "In the interests of verifying the accuracy of data specifically provided for either intelligence or evidential purposes, CSPs should be under an obligation to retain the original data supplied for a period of seven years or for as long as the prosecuting authorities direct." The document continues: "Informal discussions have taken place with the office of the data protection commissioner [Elizabeth France]. Whilst they acknowledge that such communications data may be of value to the work of the agencies and the interests of justice they have grave reservations about longer term data retention." Mr Gaspar compared the proposed new data bank - which would cost an estimated £3m to set up and £9m a year to run - to the national DNA database. The Home Office said yesterday it had received representations from law enforcement agencies. It added: "We are considering their representations. However no decisions have been taken." A spokeswoman said the plan would require new legislation. John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, said yesterday: "The security services and the police have a voracious appetite for collecting up information about our private lives, but this is an extraordinary idea. "This would violate the principles of the Data Protection Act and the Human Rights Act and the government should reject this idea now. If it goes ahead we will challenge this in the courts in this country and the European court of human rights." This allows the agencies to collect "communications data" - websites and email addresses used by individuals - without obtaining any warrant. It also allows the police to demand the keys to encrypted data and provides for connection data held by internet service providers to be made available to NCIS. The government said it needed the new powers in the war against paedophiles, drug traffickers, and organised criminal gangs. GCHQ already has the capacity to monitor all calls made on mobile telephones.

webTitle: GM hen's eggs put on cancer cure trail

fields.headline: GM hen's eggs put on cancer cure trail
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: A hen genetically modified to produce anti-cancer proteins in her egg whites could be about to cause a stir in the pharmaceutical industry.
fields.body:
A hen genetically modified to produce anti-cancer proteins in her egg whites could be about to cause a stir in the pharmaceutical industry.

The chicken, dubbed Britney, is expected to be formally introduced to the world in Edinburgh on Wednesday by her makers at the Roslin Institute, in Scotland. Scientists at Roslin cloned Dolly the Sheep in 1997, but they are also among the world leaders in the "pharming" of animals.

Until now Britney - revealed in the Mail on Sunday - has been kept in the dark of the henhouse, and yesterday there was no information either from Roslin nor the institute's commercial partner in the project, a US firm called Viragen, about the proteins such hens could provide.

Viragen is working with the UK Cancer Research Campaign on a treatment based on the human immune system.

The use of genetically engineered farm animals to make such proteins is becoming commonplace: goats and sheep in Europe and the US are under trial for various milk-based products.

Until now hens have not laid any golden eggs for the pharmaceutical companies. Britney's 250 eggs a year could provide the building blocks for drugs to treat melanoma and ovarian and breast cancer.

However, Viragen and the Roslin researchers have yet to reveal how. And any useful product could be years away from the pharmacy.

"There's no evidence they have done anything yet. There is no peer reviewed paper that I am aware of. Presumably on Wednesday everything is going to be revealed," said Gordon McVie, director of the Cancer Research Campaign. "All they need to do is show they've done it with one protein. Then the technology is there to be used. Well, name your favourite protein."
