webTitle: Sex offender monitoring programme under strain

fields.headline: Sex offender monitoring programme under strain
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: A new public protection system to manage the most dangerous sex offenders after their release from prison is already under strain because the numbers involved have trebled in the past year.
fields.body:
A new public protection system to manage the most dangerous sex offenders after their release from prison is already under strain because the numbers involved have trebled in the past year.

Home Office officials have told probation officers that around 30 offenders a month are now being identified as potentially dangerous: likely to pose a risk to the public, or in need of protection themselves on release.

The new system was put in place in April last year after the high profile release of sex offenders such as Sidney Cooke and Robert Oliver sparked vigilante protests.

An early warning system was set up, under which prison and probation authorities and the police advise Home Office ministers of their plans to handle the release of inmates deemed still to be particularly dangerous two months before they are due to leave jail.

Although the offenders have finished their sentences they agree to live in probation hostels with specific monitoring and supervision arrangements.

But a rise in the number of such dangerous offenders being released from 10 a month when the scheme got under way last year to about 30 a month now is putting it under great strain.

Paddy Doyle, a senior official in the Home Office's dangerous offenders unit, last week heard complaints from probation officers that it was becoming increasingly difficult to place all the offenders in appropriate accommodation because of the numbers involved.

The number of offenders deemed to be dangerous and living in London has now passed the 900 mark and the new Criminal Justice Act, which reached the statute book on Friday, will place a new duty on police and probation services to make arrangements for assessing and managing all convicted sex criminals and violent offenders on their patch.

Mr Doyle said the Home Office was also setting up a new unit to oversee the release plans for each prisoner who was deemed to be dangerous. A report on each one goes to the prisons minister, Paul Boateng.

So far only 40 sex offender orders have been made under the new system since its introduction last April. These require convicted sex offenders to register for at least five years and to comply with other conditions, which may include electronic tagging, to protect the public from serious harm.

As it costs an average of £24,000 a month for a police surveillance team to monitor just one offender round the clock, different methods of keeping track of these dangerous ex-prisoners are being developed around the country. In some areas the police and probation will offer a violent offender a "tenancy agreement" before they come out, under which they agree to curfew and tagging restrictions.

Harry Fletcher, the assistant general secretary, of the National Association of Probation Officers, said there was not enough money to provide the kind of monitoring of offenders that was needed.

"The probation service's liaison arrangements with the police are very good but unless resources are dedicated to this task I fear that something awful will happen."

webTitle: Man tells radio show how he killed mother

fields.headline: Man tells radio show how he killed mother
fields.trailText: Detectives and a coroner are investigating a man's tearful claim on a radio phone-in programme that he ended his terminally-ill mother's life after what he took as hints from medical staff.
fields.body:
Detectives and a coroner are investigating a man's tearful claim on a radio phone-in programme that he ended his terminally-ill mother's life after what he took as hints from medical staff.

The caller was traced at the weekend to the address in north Derbyshire from which he rang BBC Radio Sheffield during a discussion on the Dutch government's recent decision to legalise euthanasia.

The station's logbook of call details was surrendered after South Yorkshire police obtained a court order, following a day of discussion between officers and the BBC.

The man was asked by the programme's presenter, Rony Robinson, if he understood that giving details could get him into trouble. He replied that he did, but that ending his mother's "terrible" suffering was worth facing a possible court case.

Derbyshire police interviewed the man yesterday and said that the case was being handled "very sensitively", with particular concern for the feelings of the family.

A spokesman said that the coroner of the Hundred of Scarsdale had been informed and was also considering the case.

The man, who gave his name on air as John, described how he had given his dying mother an overdose of liquid morphine four years ago. He detailed his mother's agonising condition - blind, incontinent and no longer able to eat or speak. "I don't regret it," he said. "It was the right thing to do. She was in a terrible state. It wasn't my mother."

He described how he had turned to a doctor and nurse on a house call and begged them: "Can't you do anything for her?

"Their eyes both turned to a bottle of liquid morphine which was on the shelf," he told listeners. "It was obvious what the implication was."

Mr Robinson - an experienced and popular broadcaster whose phone-in the previous week on organ donors had prompted a surgeon to ring in from an operating theatre - gently reminded the caller of the implications. But the man said he knew he could be in trouble, but was certain he had done the right thing.

"I suppose I could still face court action but it was worth it," he said.

Gary Keown, managing editor of Radio Sheffield, said that the interview had been highly emotional and dealt with very difficult circumstances. Police had become involved, he said, after a news agency picked up the broadcast and rang the South Yorkshire force for a comment. The BBC asked that the detectives' request for logbook details be put in writing, which led to the court order.

The investigation is expected to consider details of the morphine dose, which can be a difficult problem in cases of extremely severe pain.

In May last year Newcastle upon Tyne GP David Moor was acquitted of murdering a pensioner patient with morphine, after medical disagreements in court on issues including the risk of death from heavy painkilling doses.

webTitle: Officehours: Are temps are really lazy?

fields.headline: Are temps really lazy?
fields.standfirst: Do temporary workers sit around doing nothing or are they misunderstood? Annabelle Thorpe  finds out
fields.trailText: Do temporary workers sit around doing nothing or are they misunderstood? Annabelle Thorpe finds out.
fields.body:
Temping is not what it was. Once upon a time, you could slink in late, leave dead on time, take an hour for lunch, spend most of the day on the phone to your friends and still get a healthy pay cheque at the end of the week. At least, that's how a lot of employers saw it. All too often temps were dismissed as lazy, incompetent and more trouble than they were worth.

Over the past few years, much has changed. Temps these days are more likely to be graduates hoping to gain experience in competitive professions such as the media or IT businesses. A recent survey by the recruitment agency Career Moves found that 98% of temps questioned said they worked to the best of their ability, with 83% prepared to work overtime. But have temps changed that much? Or is the temptation to relax when you're only there for a week or two, too much to overcome?

"It's hard not to generalise when it comes to temporary staff," says Marjorie Bailey, human resources director at a large legal firm, "but we find that there are two types - those who think that all you have to do as a temp is turn up and get paid and those who are committed, work hard and produce the goods." Often the first type are those on short-term bookings, who don't get involved with the job, or get to know anyone. "We understand it can be difficult to care about the job in that situation," says Bailey, "but we expect a professional attitude from all our temps."

Ask any temp and they'll tell you that asking for a professional attitude is all very well, but it has to come from both sides. All too often temps are left to fend for themselves, given inadequate instructions or explanations for their work - or simply not given enough to do.

"I've been placed in loads of companies where I've been sitting around twiddling my thumbs," says Chloe Morris, who has temped in between travelling for two years. "It can get really awkward because I can't magic work out of thin air. When you work somewhere permanently there are all sorts of administrative tasks that you do independently. When you temp, you're totally reliant on other people to create your workload."

This type of misconception is certainly part of the reason that temps are often dismissed as lazy, but in an increasingly flexible workplace, perceptions are now changing, as Richard Grace, co-managing director at Gordon Yates, will testify. "The use of temps has become a more accepted way for companies to source jobs," he says. "In parallel, more and more people are choosing to temp as a career in its own right. A good temp can adapt very quickly and efficiently to a role, without needing to be nurtured. This ability is building a strong reputation for temps and creating a more positive perception among employers."

Certainly the temp industry is unrecognisable from the way it was 10 years ago due, in no small part, to the influx of temps from Australia and New Zealand who are happy to work hard to fund their travelling - and who have increased the numbers, and therefore the competition. "It's time to shake off the misconception that temping is a last resort for the unemployable," says Caroline Foot, joint managing director of Career Moves. "Many ambitious young people will apply for temporary work to get a foot in the door and then make an effort to impress their workmates in the anticipation of a useful reference or a permanent contract."

These days a temp is likely to be looking for a fast-track route to a well-paid career - and there's little room for slackers. "The standard of temping has definitely risen," says Morris. "A lot of temps travel and they work hard so that they can be assured of immediate work when they come back. I have worked with a few temps who haven't pulled their weight and they don't last. Companies know there are a lot of hard-working, professional temps out there, and if your attitude isn't right, you won't keep the job."

webTitle: Officehours: The inside track

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst: Working in TV
fields.trailText: Working in TV
fields.body:
Mention secretarial advancement and, invariably, Ulrika Jonsson's name comes up. The TV presenter got her big break when she was plucked from behind a secretary's desk and invited to read the weather on TV-am. But she is something of an exception, and the conversation usually peters out after discussion of her inspiring example.

Nevertheless others still seek secretarial jobs in TV in the hope of them leading to bigger things. Such expectations usually end in disappointment: hopefuls sit unnoticed in some peripheral department waiting for lightning to strike, or wander the corridors when they should be at their desks, and drive everybody mad.

Oddly, those media professionals who did begin as secretaries often had no ambitionswhen they entered a TV company. I know of one producer who worked as a secretary at a regional TV company for two years before she was assigned to the newsroom. She found she loved the atmosphere, and when she was moved on she went into work in the newsroom on her days off. When a vacancy arose for a trainee news producer, she was first in line.

Now head of outside broadcast, she often interviews applicants for trainee posts who have never set foot in the newsroom. This doesn't create a good impression.

It is often said that a secretarial job at the BBC is a good way into TV. In the 60s, there was some substance to this, as jobs were created faster than people could be found to fill them. Now the transition is not so smooth. The BBC will expect evidence of interest in TV (even an amateur show-reel) if not actual experience. Insiders get no favours.

There is one strong advantage in taking a secretarial job in media, however. You can find out if you like it. One woman I know made the jump from secretary to production assistant at the BBC, only to find she didn't enjoy it. She left to become PA to the MD at an advertising agency and had a far better time.

webTitle: Officehours: Sec's tips

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 14. Net jargon
fields.trailText: 14. Net jargon
fields.body:
If your second home is in cyberspace, this week's column is not for you. It is dedicated to those members of society who still shop in high streets, phone a friend instead of emailing, and think spam is that unpleasant luncheon meat which featured in school dinners. For us non-geeks, the internet is a daunting breeding ground of unfathomable jargon. So here are a few explanations to help you integrate with your net-head colleagues.

 Chat rooms. As they sound, you log on and "post" (send) your comments, thoughts, etc to online "friends". Chat rooms have their own acronyms - WFM (works for me), TANSTAAFL (there ain't no such thing as a free lunch), and the unnerving NIFOC (naked in front of computer), which is probably more information than you needed.

 Emoticons. Cutesy conglomerations of symbols such as brackets and colons, which, when viewed from the side, represent faces smiling, crying, shouting, etc. Novices overuse them and old hands see them as the online equivalent of furry dice hanging from your rear-view mirror.

 FAQs. Frequently Asked Questions. Many sites have FAQ boards, and they're great for getting info on a particular subject. A word of warning - when you join an online newsgroup (discussion groups around specific topics, from patchwork- quilting to bomb-making) read the FAQs first. Newsgroup nerds don't take kindly to repeated questions, and you may get "flamed".

 To flame. To give someone abuse. If someone "flames" you in a newsgroup or in a chat room, take a deep breath before responding. Never post messages in anger - you may get into a regrettable "flame war" WHICH CAN END UP WITH A LOT OF SHOUTING (typing in capitals).

 Spam. The junk mail of the internet, and companies regularly download email addresses and whizz out thousands of unwanted adverts. Newsgroup users distort their addresses very obviously, so janet@turnerplc.com would enter her address as janet@ takethisout.turnerplc.com, or even the affectionate janet@die-spammer-die.turnerplc.com. Genuine users will delete the insertion when responding, but mass spam mailouts will not be able to.

 And before you get excited if someone calls you a "cracker" or asks if you have a HotBot, remember that a cracker is a criminal hacker, and a HotBot is, sadly, just a web search engine. Enjoy your trips to cyberspace and hey, HAND! (Have a nice day.)

Genuine users will delete the insertion when responding, but mass spam mailouts will not be able to.  And before you get excited if someone calls you a "cracker" or asks if you have a HotBot, remember that a cracker is a criminal hacker, and a HotBot is, sadly, just a web search engine. Enjoy your trips to cyberspace and hey, HAND! (Have a nice day.)

webTitle: Blackpool's coastline passes water quality tests

fields.headline: Once more unto the beach
fields.standfirst: Blackpool's coastline passes water quality tests
fields.trailText: Blackpool illuminations should have an extra shine tonight, after the resort's three beaches all passed bathing water quality tests for the first time.
fields.body:
Blackpool illuminations should have an extra shine tonight, after the resort's three beaches all passed bathing water quality tests for the first time.

Results released today by the environment agency show the tarnish on the Golden Mile has been lifted - although work is still needed to match Europe's leading resorts.

The town's north, south and central beaches, which all failed the EU's basic mandatory tests last year, now go on to tackle the more demanding Blue Flag checks.

The environment secretary Michael Meacher said: "Blackpool's success is part of the best-ever results for UK bathing waters in terms of these mandatory standards. But to achieve the cleanest, best quality water in Europe, we must now meet the much tougher standards required by the Blue Flag guidelines."

Blue Flag status, marked in guidebooks and on beach billboards, is awarded after stringent tests on faecal streptoccoci bacteria. The standards passed by Blackpool, and other leading British resorts, monitor lower-grade sewage contamination as well as oil and chemical pollutants.

Mr Meacher said an £8bn spending package on water quality improvement was showing results, with a further £600m pencilled in for the next five years.

Improvements are targeted on coastal sewage discharge, which has plagued resorts such as Blackpool and Scarborough, and problems with storm overflows which get overwhelmed and back up into sewers.

Today's results show much the most striking improvements are in the north-west - from 68% to 82% compliance - and a rise from 91% to 96% in the south-west, home of the country's most popular bathing beaches.

Those still on the failing list include Marske, on the Tees estuary, Tynemouth sands, Staithes in North Yorkshire, Ilfracombe's Capstone beach and Lynmouth in the south-west, Morecambe south beach, in the north-west and two of Windermere's three main bathing areas in the Lake District - Fellfoot and Lakeside YMCA.

webTitle: Separatists seized in Indonesia

fields.headline: Separatists seized in Indonesia
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Indonesia intensified its crackdown on the separatist movement in Irian Jaya yesterday, the day after eight people died in a clash with police, arresting 47 activists in a pre-dawn raid on its temporary headquarters.
fields.body:
Indonesia intensified its crackdown on the separatist movement in Irian Jaya yesterday, the day after eight people died in a clash with police, arresting 47 activists in a pre-dawn raid on its temporary headquarters.

More than 200 armed riot police stormed the arts centre in the provincial capital Jayapura which the Papuan Taskforce had used as a base to organise independence rallies on Friday.

The arrests brought the number of separatists detained in Jayapura since Wednesday to 61. Two of their leaders have been charged with subversion.

The Irian Jaya police chief, Brigadier General Sylvanus Wenas, said the taskforce was occupying the arts centre illegally, adding: "We decided enough was enough."

He denied that his officers used excessive force, but television pictures showed several people being led out of the building covered in blood.

"The takeover was brutal, we were still sleeping when they came," a detained activist was quoted as saying. "They beat some of our friends until their heads bled."

Friday's rallies marked the 39th anniversary of an unrecognised declaration of independence by the Irianese, who share the island with independent Papua New Guinea. They passed peacefully except in the western town of Fakfak, where two people were killed when, according to the police, members of the taskforce attacked a group of officers.

On Saturday police officers shot dead six independence supporters and two passersby during a clash in the south-eastern town of Merauke. Police sources said the officers responded when tribesmen opened fire with bows and arrows.

Indonesia took over Irian Jaya in 1962 and formally integrated it seven years later, after a restricted ballot widely regarded as rigged.

The separatist movement has gained coherence since a people's congress earlier this year.

webTitle: New light shines in the stars

fields.headline: New light shines in the stars
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Astronomers are claiming to have identified a new member of the solar system.
fields.body:
Astronomers are claiming to have identified a new member of the solar system.

It orbits the sun beyond Neptune and is the brightest object in the sky after Pluto - the ninth planet, which was the last to be discovered. The object could be half the diameter of Pluto and would only be visible once every few centuries, astronomers believe.

A team from the University of Arizona announced their discovery on Saturday after telescopes were trained on the object for several days.

It has been temporarily christened 2000 WR106, while experts try to decide whether they are looking at a planet or an asteroid.

WR106 was spotted on November 28 by Arizona's Spacewatch team - which searches the skies for potentially hazardous objects. It was spotted again the next night, and the third. By December 1, researchers had decided they were not looking at a fixed star, but at an object following a huge orbit around the sun.

webTitle: Officehours: WPM

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: • WPM would like to extend a belated hand of friendship to secretary Angela Hudson who this week received a whopping £2.25m bonus thanks to her boss's generous share options allowance. Having stuck with John Duffield through the thick and thin years of his financial company, Hudson benefited when it was taken over by the German money giant Commerzbank. Ange has quickly moved to a swanky mansion near Winchester, Hants but - good on that gal - has decided to keep her secretarial position at Jupiter.
fields.body:
 WPM would like to extend a belated hand of friendship to secretary Angela Hudson who this week received a whopping £2.25m bonus thanks to her boss's generous share options allowance. Having stuck with John Duffield through the thick and thin years of his financial company, Hudson benefited when it was taken over by the German money giant Commerzbank. Ange has quickly moved to a swanky mansion near Winchester, Hants but - good on that gal - has decided to keep her secretarial position at Jupiter.

On hearing the news, WPM has been making frequent visits to her pigeonhole to see if her boss has been similarly generous with his Christmas bonus. No news as yet, but there is still plenty of time for him to act. In the meantime, if Ms Hudson needs a shopping partner on whom to lavish her newfound fortune, WPM would be more than happy to oblige.

 Oh, how we love our superiors. Preaching, teaching and mentoring us through the daily grind. But let's not kid ourselves. WPM would sell her granny for a quick buck, so why should her boss get special treatment?

Which is why it's so delightful to hear of the boss auction that has been organised for this week by DeskDemon.com, a web service for PAs, office managers and secretaries, in conjunction with the online auction site ebay.co.uk.

Further investigation by WPM suggests the five-day event won't be a tasty little earner for her (it costs £5 to put your boss up for grabs) but the nice bone in her body is pleased to hear that her hard-earned cash will be going to a good cause, since all proceeds raised will go to Ovacome, the ovarian cancer charity. Desk- Demon will also match any funds raised through the event.

All bosses are eligible, provided they agree to being sold as a PA for a day to the highest bidder. But the sure-fire way to get rid of yours is to indulge in a spot of "boss swapping", and auction him or her to a different department. As far as WPM is concerned, if you're going to do something, you ought to do it properly. Any cut price tickets to Uzbekistan on auction? I know just the taker ...

 WPM is delighted to hear news of the burgeoning corporate gift business and looks forward to tearing the wrapping off the many goodies that admiring colleagues and grateful readers are sure to be sending (usual name and address supplied below). No bribe is too large or small but - since you're asking - a new BMW, a London loft flat kitted out with Ligne Roset furniture and an all-expenses-in holiday to the Virgin Islands have yet to be ticked off the WPM Christmas list. Well, what are you waiting for? Less than 20 shopping days, etc. etc.

 OK, so maybe she's going soft in her old age but WPM's website of the week is Charitycards, where fundraising cards for office and home are on offer. You pay the same price as you would normally pay in the high street and know precisely how much will be received by the participating charities (which is inevitably higher than the contribution received after high street sales).

When you buy, you nominate your favoured charity to receive the royalty or elect to share it equally between the charities represented on the website. This Christmas, 66% of the retail price of all sales of charity produced Christmas cards is paid by the site to the relevant charity's trading company. For the rest of the year the site will also service your birthday/ anniversary/ Valentine greeting needs.

 Office Hours is seeking a diaryist who can submit a weekly column to the section documenting the joys and traumas of secretaryhood to the masses. Though it will be hard to compete with WPM's side-splitting wit, the column needs to be a funny rendition of a secretary's week, her co-workers and her boss.

If you are interested, please email two 350-400 word diaries to office.hours@theguardian.com, no later than December 15.

 Creative offices inspire creative people. That's the gospel of the Times & Gestetner Digital Office Collection, on show at the Royal College of Art, London today (admission free). According to the exhibition, your boss is missing a trick if he doesn't have a real grass lawn in reception or a graffiti wall encouraging staff to express themselves at lunch.

As a snapshot of 100 of the UK's most creative working environments, the designers claim it's the best way to improve staff morale and increase productivity. So, henceforth WPM washes her hands of all complaints about the quality of her writing. Any moans about this column should be sent to our unimaginative office designer.

webTitle: Officehours: What to get for Christmas

fields.headline: Buying power
fields.standfirst: Christmas can be a traumatic time for the poor PA, burdened with choosing the perfect presents for company clients, the boss's wife, kids and mistress ... Laura Barton reports
fields.trailText: Christmas can be a traumatic time for the poor PA, burdened with choosing the perfect presents for company clients, the boss's wife, kids and mistress ... Laura Barton reports.
fields.body:
Margaret can type at 70wpm. Her tea-making skills (white, one sugar, thanks Margaret) are second to none. She's never frolicked on the photocopier with Peter from the accounts department, never filched so much as a With Compliments slip from the office stationery cupboard. She is, in short, the perfect PA. "An angel," her boss calls her.

But never does Margaret's employer value her more than at this time of year. As the PA to an executive at a bank in the City, Margaret is responsible for purchasing the Christmas corporate gifts. And - as she'll have you know - it's an important job. The gifts you give your clients, or even your rivals, speak volumes about your company's image.

Margaret has been at the helm of corporate gift-buying for six years, but, she confesses, "I screwed up big time for the first three. I didn't get the right things. I got what I thought was really nice wine, but I didn't want to spend too much, I was trying to economise. I think it's instinctive, because I am a housewife. But I got screamed at: 'We are not housewives Margaret, this is corporate image!'"

Now she spends between £50 and £150 on each client, sending out 250 presents each year. "I've learnt that you can't scrimp, because what we'd be saying is 'We don't value you as a client.' I am quite choosy now: whereas some companies might think it is impressive to send say, an entire crate of wine, I'd rather give something which is small but exquisite."

This year, Margaret has done all the shopping on the net. "I tried to do the same last year, but it just seemed impossible. I don't know whether there wasn't the selection, or perhaps I just wasn't so adept at using the internet ..." This time round though, she's hit lucky with the website globalgiftz.com, which boasts a rather fine line of unusual luxury items. There are cufflinks from Sphinks, scented aromatherapy cushions from Crabtree & Evelyn and Green's Select hampers, of which Margaret has ordered several. She believes it gives clients a break from the standard bottle of vino or box of swanky chocolates, and allows her to avoid the chaos of high street shopping in the festive season.

Then there are the employees. In the lead up to Christmas, businesses receive loads of catalogues and free samples of pens, mugs, manicure sets and tea towels, which, for a small sum, can be imprinted with the company logo. Bizarrely, employees are rarely grateful to receive such tokens of affection. It is indeed a curious fact that a cheap ballpoint pen emblazoned with the company motto does little to inspire loyalty, or even festive cheer among workers.

Frantic and distracted businessmen frequently turn to their trusty secretaries and PAs to sort out their personal gifts, too. Elaine, a secretary for a company in Liverpool, is always in charge of buying Christmas and birthday presents for her employer's wife. "Last year, he gave her perfume. That was easy." It's harder choosing gifts for his two daughters. "They're what you would call spoilt teenagers. Very difficult to buy for. They already have everything they want."

Harder still is picking a present for his girlfriend. "He said he wanted to give her underwear, so I got out the Rigby & Peller catalogue." And did he, er, specify any particular requirements? - "Elaine, fax this report to our New York office, find me the file on the Jones account, and I'd like you to buy a red PVC basque for my bit on the side." "No, he just gave me some measurements, and told me she was dark-haired and olive-skinned. So I bought some creamy lacy underwear."

Adding to the responsibility is the burden of knowledge that she is somehow aiding her boss's infidelities. "I feel for his wife," she confides "because I've been in that position."

Alex, a PA to an advertising executive, agrees. "It always seems sad that his girlfriend gets the racy underwear and his wife's getting the same old bottle of Chanel No 5 year in, year out. I don't even know if she wears Chanel." Would she ever suggest an alternative gift? "Oh no. She'd probably get suspicious wouldn't she? He's been buying her perfume for donkey's years, and suddenly she's getting La Perla knickers. Any woman in her right mind would know there was something funny going on."

Behind the facade though, there is little doubt that the Missus has twigged that it's not her beloved husband who nipped into the local perfumery in his lunch break. "I'm sure she knew," says Linda, who has worked in the PR department of a glass manufacturer in the north west for 11 years. She, too, has felt the strain of her buying power. "It was difficult, you were buying a present for someone you may have met only a handful of times, and you are mak ing what is supposed to be a personal preference for her. But he just left it to me, and she seemed to like whatever I got."

Not all gifts are so successful. A survey carried out in 1999 by Office Angels revealed that two-thirds of corporate gifts are thrown away, and 20%will be rewrapped and given to other people. The most loathed presents include cheap wine (although surely it brings back fond memories of the office party?) and novelty Christmas tomfoolery, such as those really wacky Santa Claus ties, and those vastly amusing musical socks. You simply never tire of hearing a tinny rendition of Jingle Bells swirling round your ankles. But perhaps the most utterly despised present is the office "humour" books, from the You Don't Have To Be Mad To Work Here, But ... stable. Yeah, and my other gift's a Porsche, right?

What to get ...

The client

Hampers jam-packed with the finest delicacies are widely available. Visit globalgiftz.com to view its online catalogue, which includes items from Crabtree & Evelyn. Carluccio's offers gourmet hampers from £28 to £200, stuffed with pastas, sauces, chocolates, antipasti, olive oil, and so on. Call its mail-order service on 020 7580 2552.

The employee

82% of employees say they would rather their boss simply gave them a gift voucher for Christmas. Take heed.

The opposition

You want to remind them of your inherent superiority, but don't forget it's the season of goodwill. Why not invest in an anti-stress massage for your rival? Aveda Stress Relieving Treatment (£25) is available from Concept Salons nationwide (call 020 7410 1600 for details).

The wife

The lady doesn't always love Milk Tray. Have a gander at the Space Boudoir catalogue (price £4, call 020 7229 6533), which has all manner of gorgeous ladylike gifts and trinkets, from bed linen to jewellery to glassware.

The kids

Depending on their age, you can go crazy in the toy department (hamleys.co.uk) or choose some thing eminently more suitable for the aspiring sophisticate. Teenagers are notoriously difficult. Young madams might relish a beauty treatment, such as a manicure (New York Nail Company special manicure, £25, 020 7228 7808) or some funky beauty products, such as Benefit's Kitten (£19.50). The chaps might favour the macho gadgetry available at Firebox.

The mistress

Perfume? Again? Treat her to a day at a health spa (Champneys' tailor-made Experience Days cost £195, call 01442 2911 111), or a romantic champagne flight in a hot air balloon, from £295 for two people, available from Red Letter Days (call 0870 444 9000).

The secretary

Luxury breaks on Necker Island cost £7,195 per person, from Elegant Resorts (0870 333 3390).

webTitle: Art-fearing Britons don't know Hurst from Hirst

fields.headline: Art-fearing Britons don't know Hurst from Hirst
fields.trailText: Britons are so uninterested in modern art that they cannot tell the difference between the shark-pickling Damien Hirst and World Cup hero Geoff Hurst, a survey has shown.
fields.body:
Britons are so uninterested in modern art that they cannot tell the difference between the shark-pickling Damien Hirst and World Cup hero Geoff Hurst, a survey has shown.

Many people remain unconvinced that piles of bricks and unmade beds constitute art. One in three of those questioned had never been to a gallery while 41% said modern art made them switch off because they did not understand it. Half of the 1,000 people surveyed by Pizza Express to launch its Prospects 2001 art prize, said they could not differentiate between Brit art's Hirst and footballer Hurst.

The results reflect concerns about the unpopularity of modern art aired by Tate director Sir Nicholas Serota last month. He suggested many were sceptical because they were not given enough opportunities to experience it.

Tate Modern, in London, attracted 6m visitors in its first three months. But other collections are withering because curators cannot afford new exhibits, Sir Nicholas suggested.

webTitle: Obituaries: Italian photographer Mario Giacomelli

fields.headline: Mario Giacomelli
fields.standfirst: Italian photographer who was passionate about the land - its textures, shapes, colours and the people who inhabited it
fields.trailText: Italian photographer who was passionate about the land - its textures, shapes, colours and the people who inhabited it.
fields.body:
The photographer Mario Giacomelli, who has died, aged 75, synchronised his convictions with his images. A conservator of traditional Italy, in particular his home region of the Marche, he celebrated its landscapes from almost every angle. The one he made his own was the bird's eye view, taking in fields and copses, lakes and mountains; he experimented with patterns and designs, part natural and part man-made, as when he famously selected wintry ploughed furrows whose repetition formed an abstract and an actual representation.

He appeared to love what was most traditional, not only in Italy but elsewhere. He spent time in Africa and India, as well as France and Switzerland. This work appeared in magazines and exhibitions from Chicago to Tokyo, Ottawa to Paris, Spain to Wales and in smaller galleries and publications all over Italy.

Born in the town of Senigallia in east-central Italy, he never much enjoyed school; he left at 16 and alternated working in a typography shop and learning about the subject with war service in the Italian army.

Giacomelli, self-taught in typography and photography, rose in the profession largely through self-discipline and application. Post-war, he worked independently for more than a decade before joining the La Bussola group of photographers in 1956 and then the national ANSA agency. He specialised in black-and-white land scenes, devising his own way of shooting, using the little-known Kobell Press camera. From the mid-1950s, Giacomelli began to win photographic prizes and exhibit in group shows. The earlier exhibitions tended to specialise in characteristically post-war "humanistic" or "concerned" photography, such as What is Man? which originated in Frankfurt and went on a world tour.

In 1975, the British photographer Bill Brandt selected Giacomelli for his major exhibition, The Land: 20th Century Landscape Photographs, shown at the Victoria & Albert Museum, London.This was followed, three years later, by another far-reaching show on the same topic: The Spirit of New Landscape, curated in Maine.

In 1980, Giacomelli showed again with Bill Brandt and the Romanian photographer, Alexandros Macjauskras (in Brussels and Parma), and was taken on by the influential gallerist Agathe Gaillard in Paris. He also published his first and only solo book, Mario Giacomelli, fotografe, edited by Angelo Schwarz. By the mid-1980s, he started a round of retrospectives with one for the Ffotogallery in Cardiff. A rash of major text evaluations of him appeared, written by such known names as Mark Haworth-Booth, Petr Tausk, Jean-Claude Lemagny, Claudio Adorni and the French novelist Herve Guibert. Giacomelli's most characteristic work is not only about the landscapes he most loved, often sculpted by centuries of agriculture. It is also about the people he loves, whose typical distance belies the affinity and frequently, the affection he clearly experienced for them.

The sensitivity with which, for example, Giacomelli documented the sick at Lourdes alternates with the popularity of his joyous, widely reproduced image, which was again taken from above, of seminarians exuberantly celebrating together - their black cassocks contrasting starkly with the white stone of the yard where they almost appear to be dancing.

The photographic critic - and Giacomelli's friend -Sandro Genovali, said: "He didn't want to document reality: he wanted to transform it."

Giacomelli preferred to allow his images "to surface from unconscious to conscious life" and as he grew older, his focus came ever closer. In latter years, he would work to capture the grain of the wood, the texture of the soil. He also believed that the occasion on which the photograph was taken was not necessarily close to the time when it should be seen and sometimes he deliberately withheld images from enlargement or publication.

He is survived by his wife, Anna and children Rita, Neris and Simone.

Mario Giacomelli, photographer, born August 1 1925; died, November 25 2000.

webTitle: Abduction fears after schoolgirl fails to phone home

fields.headline: Abduction fears after schoolgirl fails to phone home
fields.trailText: Text messages to a missing teenager's mobile phone have gone unanswered for over a week, police said yesterday, increasing fears that she may have been abducted.
fields.body:
Text messages to a missing teenager's mobile phone have gone unanswered for over a week, police said yesterday, increasing fears that she may have been abducted.

Detectives are checking four possible sightings of Leanne Tiernan, 16, as alarm grows following her failure to respond to the messages and an appeal on television by her family. Yesterday, Michelle Tiernan, 19, retraced her sister's steps in a police reconstruction of her walk following a Christmas shopping trip in Leeds eight days ago.

The schoolgirl has no record of running away and no known serious problems either at home or school.

West Yorkshire police are following up other responses to the appeal by Leanne's mother, Sharon Hawkhead, 39, and Michelle.

Det Supt Chris Gregg, leading the hunt, appealed for residents in the family's home area of Bramley to search garden sheds and garages, particularly near the wooded footpath at Houghley Gill where the teenager is thought to have vanished on November 26.

Photographs of a gold wishbone ring and titanium body bar (used for navel piercing) similar to those Leanne had bought earlier in the day at Argos in Leeds have been distributed locally. Detectives have also appealed to a man in his 30s seen walking a dog at Houghley Gill, shortly after Leanne parted from a schoolfriend at a nearby bus stop.

Leanne's father Michael, who is divorced from her mother, arrived in Leeds yesterday after cutting short a holiday in Tenerife where he had been told of his daughter's disappearance.

Ms Hawkhead said: "When I last saw her, she was fine and happy and bubbly. All her clothes are in the house, all her make-up, her hairbrush, her hair spray and everything."

webTitle: Unofficial aid adds to Harry Potter cult

fields.headline: Unofficial aid adds to Harry Potter cult
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Four Harry Potter books, an imminent eight-hour Harry Potter radio broadcast and a Harry Potter movie in production. Now, as if by magic, Harry Potter - the study aid.
fields.body:
Four Harry Potter books, an imminent eight-hour Harry Potter radio broadcast and a Harry Potter movie in production. Now, as if by magic, Harry Potter - the study aid.

Exploring Harry Potter by Elizabeth D Schafer is billed as many things - part literary criticism, part guide, part compendium of the children's publishing sensation - and is aimed at parents, teachers, student readers, librarians and researchers.

But it is also, as the publishers Ebury Press acknowledge on the cover, "NOT approved by JK Rowling", who created the boy magician.

Among the highlights of the 479-page work, the first in a series of "Beacham's sourcebooks for teaching young adult fiction", is an extensive and occasionally incongruous timeline which mixes historical events, happenings in Harry Potter's life, and dates of publication.

Starting in 2700BC, recording when Dedi, an Egyptian conjurer, performed magical illusions with animals, the timeline ends in the autumn of AD2003, when "book seven will probably be published".

On the way it takes in the year 990 (when Hogwarts, Harry's school, was established by Godric Gryffindor, Salazar Slytherin, Helga Hufflepuff and Rowena Ravenclaw), April 14 1865 (Abraham Lincoln assassinated), and 1929 ("probably the year that Hagrid was born; also the year that the American stock market crashed).

Then there is July 31 1980 (Harry Potter was born to James and Lily Potter), 1991 (JK Rowling moved to Oporto, Portugal and met her future husband; Harry played in his first Quidditch match), June 3 1995 (lightning killed spectators at a soccer match near Puerto Lempira, Honduras - the lightning was blamed on witchcraft), July 1997 (the British publication of the first book, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone), and September 1997 (Harry's seventh term at Hogwarts begins).

The book also offers a biography of JK Rowling, a guide to mythology, biblical references, science, magic and witchcraft. There is a chapter by chapter guide to the books, divided into synopsis, themes, symbols, myths and legends and vocabulary development.

Ms Schafer, who has a doctorate in the history of science and technology from Auburn University in Alabama, said Harry Potter represented nothing less than the essence of being human. "He shows that anything is possible if you work hard enough and believe in yourself."

Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: I woke to the dazzling early light of the tropical coastline and looked down on to the Aberdeen peninsula. The Royal Navy had arrived. Five ships were lying at anchor dotted across the bay. More than 500,000 west African troops took part in the first and second world wars and a Remembrance Day service was to be held at the Freetown military cemetery by the sea.
fields.body:
I woke to the dazzling early light of the tropical coastline and looked down on to the Aberdeen peninsula. The Royal Navy had arrived. Five ships were lying at anchor dotted across the bay. More than 500,000 west African troops took part in the first and second world wars and a Remembrance Day service was to be held at the Freetown military cemetery by the sea.

About 250 of us stood among the haphazardly laid-out gravestones. British and Sierra Leone military stood to attention in the front rows. We civilians stood behind them. Elderly Muslim veterans dressed in white and gold robes sat or stood beside the memorial to comrades in arms. British snipers guarded us from the top of nearby giant storage tanks. British soldiers in camouflage gear with guns at the ready surveyed the sea. A Sierra Leone military band seated beneath the only shade-tree played Remembrance Day hymns.

Because Freetown is in exactly the same time zone as the UK, at that very moment at the Cenotaph in Whitehall and in churches and at war memorials across the United Kingdom people were choking back tears to just the same music. The helicopter-carrier HMS Ocean, anchored out in the bay, fired a gun to mark the two minutes' silence.

When a handful of young kids paddled up in their canoes the soldiers became extra alert. They had reason to be cautious. The Revolutionary United Front rebels control thousands of cocaine-addicted, scrambled-brained child soldiers. For seven years, the RUF tactic has been to raid a village and round up boys and girls aged 10 and upwards.

The children are immediately injected in the temple with crack cocaine or skin scraped from leg or chest and the drug rubbed straight into the bloodstream. Soon after the kidnapping, drug-confused youngsters are forced to chop off a limb from one of their relatives before being taken away to be trained to fight and kill. But the local youngsters who sat quietly in their gently rocking canoes were no threat. They had simply come to listen to the singing.

The next day, 500 troops in amphibian craft accompanied by helicopter gunship air cover landed on the beaches of Aberdeen peninsula for a royal tournament display. I was conducting a British Council democracy skills training workshop for women and we all ducked in unison as a low-flying helicopter roared over the seminar room. Thousands of Sierra Leoneans on the beach cheered and shouted: "God bless our mother country, God bless Britain."

A couple of days later I attended a special session of parliament. I sat behind the UK high commissioner, Alan Jones, and the commander of the British forces in Sierra Leone, Brigadier David Richards. The praise for Britain was so warm and effusive it was almost embarrassing. But it was deeply touching.

A Muslim MP said: "The British are a special people ready to live and to die for what they believe in, rather than for short-term gain." He mentioned the British belief in fair play and justice and added in for good measure the spirit of King Arthur. An MP stood up and said: "I could see the great spectacle on the beach from my window. When I saw the British forces landing - nothing could be more reassuring. If I may quote Wellington, 'I don't know what they do to the enemy, but by God they put the fear of God in me.'"

Members of parliament from all the political parties offered paeans of praise to Britain. They thanked Tony Blair. They thanked Robin Cook. They thanked Britain's UN ambassador, Jeremy Greencroft. They thanked the Department for International Development. They even praised the deputy prime minister, John Prescott. It must be one of the few rave reviews our minister for transport and wet and every other controversial thing has had this year.

webTitle: G2: Profile of the Lawrences' solicitor

fields.headline: For the people
fields.standfirst:
Imran Khan had only been a solicitor for 18 months when the Stephen Lawrence case dropped into his lap - and transformed his life. Now he's started up a firm specialising in 'dead and buried' cases. Fiona Bawden meets him

Special report: Stephen Lawrence
fields.trailText: Imran Khan had only been a solicitor for 18 months when the Stephen Lawrence case dropped into his lap - and transformed his life. Now he's started up a firm specialising in 'dead and buried' cases. Fiona Bawden meets him.
fields.body:
The Stephen Lawrence case marked a turning point in the way police investigate racist crimes. It was also a watershed for Imran Khan, the solicitor who will always be most closely associated with the case of the black teenager who was stabbed to death at a London bus stop.

Imran Khan had been a solicitor for just 18 months when the Lawrence case dropped into his lap. At the time, he was working as a criminal defence solicitor at a law firm in the east end of London, JR Jones. In different circumstances, he might have been defending one of the five youths suspected of the murder - if the police had actually succeeded in charging anyone. In the 12 months before the Lawrence inquiry reported in 1998, he had defended in seven murder cases.

After the Lawrence case, he started receiving letters, every day, from victims and their families, asking for help. They ranged from people whose relations with the police had just started to sour in the immediate aftermath of a crime, to those who felt completely failed by the state justice system and wanted to bring private prosecutions.

Among those who approached the firm were the family of the murdered black doctor, Joan Francisco. They suspected that her killer was a former boyfriend, Anthony Diedrick, and turned to JR Jones when the police failed to find evidence linking him (or anyone else) to the crime. In 1998, they won civil damages from Diedrick for the killing and in 1999 he was convicted of Francisco's murder. Only after the family had forced the police to reopen the investigation was a vital piece of forensic evidence found, previously missed.

Inspired by such cases, and with the added impetus of the Human Rights Act, which came into force two months ago, Khan has just left his high-street firm and set up a niche legal practice in central London, Imran Khan & Partners, to handle what he calls "impact" cases. "We are going to be taking on cases that are dead and buried, resurrecting them and trying to make an impact with them," he says.

He is already representing the family of the Asian youth Zahid Mubarek, who was beaten to death last March by a fellow prisoner the day before he was due to be released from Feltham young offenders institution. The family want someone to be held accountable for locking their 19-year-old son, a petty thief, in a cell with a known violent racist who revered the killers of Stephen Lawrence.

Khan is also acting for a black mother whose five-and-a half-month old baby, Ames Glover, was snatched from the back seat of a car in Southall 11 years ago. He was never found. The case attracted almost no media interest and no outpouring of public sympathy. Just as with the Lawrence case, says Khan, the police initially treated the family with suspicion. "For two days, they were too busy looking at them to go out looking for suspects."

He is considering whether the investigation could be resurrected and whether there are grounds for a complaint against the police. More than a decade later, the child's mother, Shanika Edwards, is hoping that someone may finally have to answer for what went wrong with the investigation and that she might even find out what happened to her child. If she does, it will be as a direct result of the Lawrences' doggedness.

"She said she was coming forward now because of them," says Khan. He believes that the Lawrence case has inspired many people who had otherwise given up hope of justice. "It is a potentially massive area. In the past, victims of crime would never go to a lawyer. They would go to their MP or to a support agency, but never a lawyer. And even if they did, the lawyers would say, 'There's nothing we can do'."

The Lawrence case changed all that. It demonstrated that there may be plenty a lawyer can do. In Khan's office, the words "it can't be done" are banned. Victims' families are no longer prepared to be fobbed off or ignored by the authorities.

Two decades ago, most lawyers didn't know how to fight clinical negligence cases. Now, even some doctors acknowledge that such cases play a key role in making the NHS accountable. Khan is hoping for a similar shift in culture among other bodies, including the police and prison service. The knowledge that a victim's family's solicitor is watching what they do will, he hopes, help to ensure that the police conduct all investigations in a methodical and even-handed way, rather than allowing prejudice to colour what they do.

There are some inherent difficulties to be overcome, not least the problem of funding. Much work has to be done free of charge because there is no state help available. "That's why I've gone grey," says 36-year-old Khan. "You end up working longer and longer hours." At his new firm, the work will be cross-subsidised by more mainstream civil liberties cases for which there is state funding, such as immigration and actions against the police, and by the criminal defence work he still does.

Another difficulty is the lack of any formal rules of engagement. The police may not like solicitors acting in their traditional role of protecting defendants' interests, but defence solicitors are at least grudgingly accepted and everyone knows what the ground rules are supposed to be. Solicitors acting for victims or their families, like Khan intends doing, are on wholly uncharted territory. In the Lawrence case, says Khan, the police didn't trust him or accept that he had any right to ask questions on the family's behalf.

On the other hand, if the police try to be too helpful, they might end up revealing information which could compromise the integrity of any subsequent prosecution - the last thing a family would want. Khan admits that if such information were revealed to the victim's family in a case where he was acting for the defendant, he would have to "exploit it to the full". What is needed, he says, is a code of conduct so that all parties know what their roles are supposed to be.

Now, he says, he has QCs chasing him, pleading for work. Some may be motivated, he acknowledges, by a desire to be on television.

But he doesn't hold that against them if they are right for the job. "This area is fashionable at the moment. We have got to make sure that it is not just a fad but that it continues. webTitle: Inquiry after jets fly within 100ft

fields.headline: Inquiry after jets fly within 100ft
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText:
An investigation is under way into how a packed
holiday jet came within "milliseconds" of a midair
collision with a US military plane over
Northamptonshire, in one of the UK's closest near
misses in 20 years.
fields.body:
An investigation is under way into how a packed holiday jet came within "milliseconds" of a midair collision with a US military plane over Northamptonshire, in one of the UK's closest near misses in 20 years.

An aircraft proximity (airprox) report has been filed with the civil aviation authority concerning the incident involving a Britannia Airways Boeing 757, with 234 passengers on board, and the US air force F15 fighter, the CAA confirmed last night.

It took place eight miles west of Daventry on November 22 and was deemed to be so "significantly serious" that a second inquiry has been launched - by the air accidents investigation branch. It is understood that at one point the two planes were only 100ft from each other.

"The report from the pilot or the air traffic controller must have suggested it was a particularly serious incident for this to happen," a CAA spokeswoman said.

The Britannia Airways jet was en route to Paphos, Cyprus, and was under London area air traffic control as it flew at 10,000ft at 10.17am.

Investigations will focus on why the USAF fighter-bomber, which was based at RAF Lakenheath, in Suffolk, did not show up on the commercial jet's traffic collision avoidance system (TCAS).

A Britannia spokeswoman said flight BY444A was travelling at 600ft a second when the F15 was seen from the flight deck. "It was in very close proximity, and obviously it was a very serious incident.

"The passengers were unaware of the situation. There was a lot of cloud in the area at the time. I cannot confirm whether there were any avoidance measures taken.

"The TCAS system was checked for faults at the time and again on landing, but none were found. Military planes usually do show up on the system, and we would like to know what happened in this case. It is of concern to all airlines that this sort of situation could have occurred."

David Learmount, a safety specialist with Flight International magazine, said the incident was of particular concern because the Daventry area was among the busiest controlled airspaces in England, forming the hub of the main north/south airways for the British Isles.

All airliners are legally required to have a TCAS system, and other air traffic that enters controlled airspace has to be fitted with a transponder unit which gives out an identification signal at the very least, he said.

"It is clear that the pilot did get a real fright. He knew he went very close. It was the kind of close that any manoeuvring you did would not have made a difference.

"What this means is one of three things: either the TCAS system on the Britannia jet was turned off, the transponder on the F15 was turned off, or it was faulty. It does not matter which was the case, it was wrong."

He added: "The other question which still remains is that there is no question that the Britannia flight would have been in touch with air traffic control, but why didn't they know about the military aeroplane?"

The incident is certain to fuel fears about overcrowded skies in Britain and will give ammunition to opponents of the government's plan to part-privatise the national air traffic control system.

Mr Learmount, however, insisted that there was no reason to panic about the possibility of such events becoming more common under the proposed arrangements.

"There is no evidence in the aviation industry to suggest that privatisation leads to danger," he said.

webTitle: Four feared dead as light plane crashes in woodland

fields.headline: Four feared dead as light plane crashes in woodland
fields.trailText: Police last night used thermal imaging equipment to search for victims of a light aircraft crash in which four people were thought to have died.
fields.body:
Police last night used thermal imaging equipment to search for victims of a light aircraft crash in which four people were thought to have died.

The Piper Arrow plane took off from Thruxton airfield, Hampshire, yesterday and crashed at around 3.30pm, 20 miles away on Lambourn Downs, near South Fawley, in Berkshire.

Detective Superintendent John Donlon, of Thames Valley police, said he was still unable to confirm exactly how many people were on board the aircraft, but it was believed there were four.

"Some bodies have been recovered, but we are still making a search to see what we can find," he said. "Thruxton should have a manifest which tells exactly who was on the plane and we are checking that at the moment.

"The aircraft came down in the middle of a wooded copse. We believe part of the aircraft came off half a mile away from that copse area. Our first priority is to search for anyone else. Our primary concern is to make sure there is no one else out there hurt."

A police helicopter and thermal imaging equipment were drafted in as a large number of police officers searched the area on foot.

John and Philip Goddon, who witnessed the crash, said that the plane had passed just metres above the row of farmworkers' cottages in which they lived. John Goddon said: "As we looked up, it started doing a loop-the-loop. Some bits came off and it just spiralled down to the woods.

"It must have gone threequarters of a mile before it hit the ground. Half the wing came off as it was spinning out of control."

His son Philip added: "We were nearly under it. We ran back down to the farm and got into one of the sheds because we were worried we might be hit by debris."

Ashley Wilkie, 10, who was playing near the Downs at the time of the crash, also saw the plane. "It only had half of its wing. The plane just fell apart and the pieces were falling everywhere," he said.

The crash will be investigated by the air accident investigation branch of the Department for Transport.

webTitle: Israel drops resistance to violence inquiry

fields.headline: Israel drops resistance to violence inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel stopped trying to block the international fact-finding mission led by the former US senator George Mitchell yesterday as a Palestinian electrician became the latest innocent victim of snipers.
fields.body:
Israel stopped trying to block the international fact-finding mission led by the former US senator George Mitchell yesterday as a Palestinian electrician became the latest innocent victim of snipers.

An aide to the prime minister said Israel would cooperate with the mission "fully and entirely transparently."

Shahada al-Jafari, 26, an electrician with two children and a third on the way, was shot dead by a sniper as he leaned out of a fifth-floor window in a half-built block of flats near Ramallah.

The Israeli army said his death was a mistake. Its rare admission of error came four weeks after the security forces began hunting down leaders of the Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement.

Mr Mitchell is expected to submit his report on the nine weeks of violence, which has claimed almost 300 lives, in March.

The building where Jarafi was shot has become notorious in the past nine weeks: overlooking a key junction on the outskirts of Ramallah, it has been regularly shelled and machine-gunned by Israeli forces trying to take out the Palestinian snipers firing from its upper storeys.

Because it was the first Saturday of the holy month of Ramadan, there was no stone-throwing or shooting, and the junction was considered safe enough for more than a dozen men to turn up for work.

Jafari stopped by the window for a chat with a linesman perched on a telephone pole below his window.

Azzam abu al-Wafa, 20, his assistant, said: "All of a sudden I saw smoke. He grabbed me, and threw me on the floor, and said: 'Ah, something hit me'."

At first the army said that its snipers had shot Jafari after mistaking a drill in his hand

That version is at odds with the story told by the other workers on site, including Mr Wafa.

"Our kind of job does not need a drill or a hammer," he said.

"If a sniper can distinguish between the eye of a child and the eye of a man from 300 metres, then surely he can tell the difference between a drill and a gun."

Later yesterday the army offered a different version of events: that the dead man bore a resemblance to known Palestinian gunmen.

"The Palestinian who was shot was identified in one of the Palestinian shooting positions in the building, and was thought to be one of the shooters. He was then fired on by an IDF force," said a statement yesterday.

It repeated a standing warning to Palestinians to stay away from the killing zones.

Outside his parents' home in Beituniya, the mourners were turning Jafari into a martyr yesterday. Posters of him were plastered all along the road.

The martyrs of Ramadan are said to be doubly blessed, but such traditions bring no comfort to the electrician's widow.

Nanees Jafari holds out little hope that the violence will bring about a Palestinian state.

"The killing will end one day, maybe in two, three, or four months, maybe a year," she said. "And after that ... people will dance and have fun. But the people who have lost someone will never stop crying."

 The Lebanese interior minister, Ghazi al-Ariri, has accused the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak of trying to distract attention from Israel's internal political crises by threatening to attack Lebanon and Syria.

He was quoted in the newspaper al-Mustaqbal yesterday as saying: "Israel is threatening us because it wants to get out of the crisis it is stuck in."

webTitle: Comment: Nice - a cock-up waiting to happen

fields.headline: Nice? It's just another cock-up waiting to happen
fields.standfirst:
The trouble with the EU is that there is no plan, only muddling through

Special report: the European Parliament
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The trouble with the EU is that there is no plan, only muddling through
fields.body:
The simple points are often the most difficult ones. Here are some very simple points. The trouble with the European "project" is that there isn't a project; the trouble with the federal superstate conspiracy is that there isn't a plan, let alone a conspiracy; and the trouble with Nice this week is not that it will agree on too much, but that it will disagree about almost everything that matters.

Take one small item from the bottom of this summit agenda: the charter of fundamental rights, otherwise known (in conspiracy-speak) as the superstate's embryo constitution. Have we, British timbers duly shivering, anything to fear from it? It's hard, from the text, to think so - for the words on paper are bromide and windy aspiration mixed. You may, if you don't like trades unions, grow mildly pensive. You may even dislike a rights-based culture which invents the "right" of Joe Public to demand that EU officials are always cheery and polite when you meet them over the counter or call them on the phone. But where's the harm or the threat? If Tony Blair signed on the dotted line on Friday, nothing would change in the way we govern ourselves or go about our business.

Yet he won't, in any meaningful sense, sign. It may be a rather vapid document designed, almost as a PR exercise, to remind current or future member states - especially the new countries of newish democratic provenance queuing to get in - that their citizens need treating with respect, but it is yet another hot potato.

Why this charter, when there's already a European charter of human rights? Wouldn't the judges in Luxembourg - as opposed to the judges in Strasbourg - soon start to throw their weight around? Could it really be the first rough draft of a Euro-constitution? And even if it isn't, surely the lawyers will soon start to cite chunks of it as they spin their interminable webs? The best we can hope for from Nice is that the assembled leaders will "solemnly proclaim" the 55 articles as things which are supposed to happen already and should, on the whole, wherever possible, go on happening. More verbal sludge.

I went, the other day, to a special international conference on this docile document. There were leaders there from the Council of Europe (the second, older European body we did so much to create after the war and then consigned to Brit oblivion). One of them was quite keen on the charter because it might, indeed, form the basis of an EU constitution some day. One German from the European parliament was less keen on that. Another - an expert who'd help put the articles together - thought it should at least have the background force of law. A battling Austrian reacted in horror.

In sum, at the heart of this mini-debate, there wasn't a whiff of consensus. Public relations or public policy? A step on the road to integration or a vital tool for drawing lines against further integration? Legally clear or just solemn'n'binding? These weren't sceptical Englishmen clutching their Daily Mails to quivering bosoms. They were, all of them, mainland Europe movers and shakers. They agreed about very little - only that the "secret text" had been drawn up lugubriously over many months by a multinational team of experts (including British experts, announced on appointment) so obsessed with security that they'd posted their various versions on a website as they went along.

Yet what is this feeble charter, seen from our island home? Another sinister plot; another twist of the federal ratchet. Mr Blair dives for cover. And the simple point grows its own complexity. We can't believe that there is no hidden agenda. We see another malign length of rope woven by our European partners to drag us ever deeper into the quagmire. We are suspicious in principle because we know there's a conspiracy. Fear comes easy: understanding is more difficult.

But reflect. This isn't an attitude that remotely transfers to other large, diffuse organisations full of disagreements. We don't think that there is a Conservative party "plot" to package and promote Euro-hysteria because we know that the present, inchoate bunch of shadows couldn't organise a piss-up in William Hague's favourite brewery. Political parties ought to be tightly-knit propaganda and policy machines, but in fact they're squabbling agglomerations of malcontents and back-stabbers. There might - at a stretch of the imagination - be a plot to topple Mr Hague. There couldn't be a party plot to gull you and me. The boys aren't up to it.

And if that is true of the Tories, it is true of other organisations all around. A plot to bury global warming? Not when John Prescott stomps centre stage. A plot to drive people on to the roads? That must be the Railtrack conspiracy. A plot to spread BSE? A plot to make sure American democracy hangs by a chad? Most of the time - as journalists or readers - we scoff at conspiracy theories: most of the time we know a cock-up when we stumble on to a slow train from Nottingham. But the slow train from Brussels is curiously different. There, only there, we are victims in waiting as the strands of doom enfold us.

In reality, Nice is yet another cock-up waiting to happen. Reweighting national votes will be a temporary bodge - as usual. Refettling the commission will flout every normal canon of effective administration - as usual. Cutting back the ve toes will be torrid illogic - as usual. The problem for the Europe we have, whether at its heart or at its crotch, is that there is no settled plan and thus no possible plot. There is only muddling through - as usual. Bring the "experts" together and dissonance reigns.

That is what makes this non-debate so damnably difficult for Tony Blair. The phobes can construct their awful visions, but he can only throw his two pennyworth about second chambers into the melting pot. He can neither propound nor defend a defined position, because no such position exists. Maybe Chirac is right - or perhaps Jospin will win the argument. Maybe France and Germany will get it together - or Germany's greater population (and burgeoning economic empire to the east) has finally unbalanced that partnership.

A booklet out this week from the Foreign Policy Centre makes the point more eloquently than any polemicist. The foreign ministers of France, Sweden and Germany, the premiers of Britain and Italy, outline their visions: and they are all different. The Europe of Nice is a building-site waiting for new master builders, clutching the euro as an act of faith and hoping that monetary union will bring other changes of clarity and constitutional reform in its wake. No need to despair; every need to become engaged. But simple understanding? That is where, alas, we may lose the plot.
