It may be a rather vapid document designed, almost as a PR exercise, to remind current or future member states - especially the new countries of newish democratic provenance queuing to get in - that their citizens need treating with respect, but it is yet another hot potato. Why this charter, when there's already a European charter of human rights? Wouldn't the judges in Luxembourg - as opposed to the judges in Strasbourg - soon start to throw their weight around? Could it really be the first rough draft of a Euro-constitution? And even if it isn't, surely the lawyers will soon start to cite chunks of it as they spin their interminable webs? The best we can hope for from Nice is that the assembled leaders will "solemnly proclaim" the 55 articles as things which are supposed to happen already and should, on the whole, wherever possible, go on happening. More verbal sludge. I went, the other day, to a special international conference on this docile document. There were leaders there from the Council of Europe (the second, older European body we did so much to create after the war and then consigned to Brit oblivion). One of them was quite keen on the charter because it might, indeed, form the basis of an EU constitution some day. One German from the European parliament was less keen on that. Another - an expert who'd help put the articles together - thought it should at least have the background force of law. A battling Austrian reacted in horror. In sum, at the heart of this mini-debate, there wasn't a whiff of consensus. Public relations or public policy? A step on the road to integration or a vital tool for drawing lines against further integration? Legally clear or just solemn'n'binding? These weren't sceptical Englishmen clutching their Daily Mails to quivering bosoms. They were, all of them, mainland Europe movers and shakers. They agreed about very little - only that the "secret text" had been drawn up lugubriously over many months by a multinational team of experts (including British experts, announced on appointment) so obsessed with security that they'd posted their various versions on a website as they went along. Yet what is this feeble charter, seen from our island home? Another sinister plot; another twist of the federal ratchet. Mr Blair dives for cover. And the simple point grows its own complexity. We can't believe that there is no hidden agenda. We see another malign length of rope woven by our European partners to drag us ever deeper into the quagmire. We are suspicious in principle because we know there's a conspiracy. Fear comes easy: understanding is more difficult. But reflect. This isn't an attitude that remotely transfers to other large, diffuse organisations full of disagreements. We don't think that there is a Conservative party "plot" to package and promote Euro-hysteria because we know that the present, inchoate bunch of shadows couldn't organise a piss-up in William Hague's favourite brewery. Political parties ought to be tightly-knit propaganda and policy machines, but in fact they're squabbling agglomerations of malcontents and back-stabbers. There might - at a stretch of the imagination - be a plot to topple Mr Hague. There couldn't be a party plot to gull you and me. The boys aren't up to it. And if that is true of the Tories, it is true of other organisations all around. A plot to bury global warming? Not when John Prescott stomps centre stage. A plot to drive people on to the roads? That must be the Railtrack conspiracy. A plot to spread BSE? A plot to make sure American democracy hangs by a chad? Most of the time - as journalists or readers - we scoff at conspiracy theories: most of the time we know a cock-up when we stumble on to a slow train from Nottingham. But the slow train from Brussels is curiously different. There, only there, we are victims in waiting as the strands of doom enfold us. In reality, Nice is yet another cock-up waiting to happen. Reweighting national votes will be a temporary bodge - as usual. Refettling the commission will flout every normal canon of effective administration - as usual. Cutting back the ve toes will be torrid illogic - as usual. The problem for the Europe we have, whether at its heart or at its crotch, is that there is no settled plan and thus no possible plot. There is only muddling through - as usual. Bring the "experts" together and dissonance reigns. That is what makes this non-debate so damnably difficult for Tony Blair. The phobes can construct their awful visions, but he can only throw his two pennyworth about second chambers into the melting pot. He can neither propound nor defend a defined position, because no such position exists. Maybe Chirac is right - or perhaps Jospin will win the argument. Maybe France and Germany will get it together - or Germany's greater population (and burgeoning economic empire to the east) has finally unbalanced that partnership. A booklet out this week from the Foreign Policy Centre makes the point more eloquently than any polemicist. The foreign ministers of France, Sweden and Germany, the premiers of Britain and Italy, outline their visions: and they are all different. The Europe of Nice is a building-site waiting for new master builders, clutching the euro as an act of faith and hoping that monetary union will bring other changes of clarity and constitutional reform in its wake. No need to despair; every need to become engaged. But simple understanding? That is where, alas, we may lose the plot. peter.preston@theguardian.com

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Jab on horizon for leukaemia
A vaccine may soon be possible for childhood leukaemia after research showed that many more babies are born with the gene linked to the illness than go on to develop it.
fields.body:
Jab on horizon for leukaemia

A vaccine may soon be possible for childhood leukaemia after research showed that many more babies are born with the gene linked to the illness than go on to develop it. About 1% of newborn babies have the gene - but this is 100 times the cancer incidence. Scientists said a second "event" after birth could trigger the disease.

Showjumper falls ill abroad

The British showjumper John Whitaker, 45, was in critical condition yesterday after suffering an aneurysm in Stockholm, Sweden, the venue of the International Horse Show.

Cowboy garages to be hammered

Car repairers may be graded under a "three spanner" scheme that could mean undercover agents weeding out the cowboys, the trade secretary Stephen Byers said yesterday. Every year 1.3m people complain about repairs and 40% of garages provide poor service. Problems include "shoddy workmanship, with women especially getting a raw deal", Mr Byers said.

Heathrow close to busiest

Heathrow had 30.8m passengers in the first half of this year, 11.5% up on its 1999 half-year, putting it ahead of Dallas/Fort Worth and making it the world's fourth busiest airport.

Two win £7.1m lottery jackpot

Two people shared Saturday's £7.1m lottery jackpot. They matched balls 2, 19, 28, 37, 46, 47. The bonus number was 38. No one won the £250,000 Thunderball jackpot. The numbers were 6, 9, 19, 26, 28. The Thunderball was 4.

webTitle: G2: Will British policemen carry guns?

fields.headline: Gun law
fields.standfirst:
Britain's police are famed for walking the streets armed with nothing more lethal than a truncheon. But now, for the first time, bobbies on the beat in two violent districts of Nottingham are carrying guns. John Kampfner asks, is this the shape of things to come?

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Britain's police are famed for walking the streets armed with nothing more lethal than a truncheon. But now, for the first time, bobbies on the beat in two violent districts of Nottingham are carrying guns. John Kampfner asks, is this the shape of things to come?
fields.body:
From deep inside Sherwood forest, a revolution in British policing has begun. But its leaders deny it is any such thing. "There is nothing exceptional in what we're doing," says Assistant Chief Constable Sean Price. "This is not a Genghis Khan approach. We're only doing what the police have always done - deploying the level of force appropriate to the threat."

From his desk at Sherwood Lodge, the headquarters of Nottinghamshire police, Price is masterminding Operation Real Estate. At its heart is a strategy that, so far, every other police force in Britain has balked at - putting armed officers on the beat.

The decision was taken in February, when rival gangs shooting out a territory dispute left several people injured. Locals knew what was going on but were frightened to get involved. "I knew at the time this was the thin end of the wedge," says Price. "If we hadn't got a grip quickly, it would have got out of control."

Six officers, operating in pairs and armed with Walther P990 pistols, were deployed on the Meadows estate and nearby St Ann's, and have been there since. Supported by two "armed response vehicles" - ARVs - in which Heckler and Koch MP5 submachine guns are kept, they help unarmed officers to work the beat from dusk until the middle of the night.

Armed policing is, in itself, not new in Britain. It is a part of daily life in Northern Ireland, and people on the mainland are used to seeing armed officers at airports, City of London checkpoints and siege incidents.

But since Nottinghamshire police put armed officers on the beat, forces around the country have been watching closely. The officers and community leaders I spoke to in Nottingham admit there is no going back.

And the precedent it sets for the rest of the country is not lost on the local population. "This is a watershed," says Delroy Brown, a community leader at the Afro-Caribbean national artistic centre in St Ann's. The district is racially mixed, but most of the recent violence has involved black youths.

Brown does not dispute the need to do something, but wonders whether the police have thought through the race-relations implications of their actions. "This marks the paramilitarisation of the police. If they are armed, within five years you will see a disproportionate number of black youths being killed by mainly white officers."

The police are sensitive to such fears. They insist the decision was taken only after considerable consultation with the council and residents. Price is adamant that the community is united across all ethnic groups - white, black and Asian - in supporting the move. He and his officers on the ground say there was no racial element in the violence and there is no racial element in the response.

According to Inspector David Powell, chief inspector of operations, the use of guns is only part of a broader strategy of combating criminality and drug dealing. The police and the council are targeting resources at the youngest gang members - around 12 years old - in an effort to stop a downward spiral into crime.

"We're trying to give communities the confidence to stand up against violent behaviour," he says during a guided tour of the locations in St Ann's and the Meadows where the shootings occurred.

At first glance the Meadows seems an unlikely guinea pig for tough policing. There are no high-rise blocks: it is a collection of one- and two-storey houses subdivided into flats, with small paths and cul-de-sacs. But for all the people-friendly intentions, the design has only encouraged criminality. Getaways are easy along the maze of narrow, dark pedestrian lanes.

He shows me the spot in Abbotsford Road where one victim was shot in January as he was cycling home after midnight. Three youths had been trailing him in a Vauxhall Cavalier. One of them shot him in the stomach with a shotgun, causing serious injuries. It was one of nine shootings in just over a fortnight.

"We're trying to wean residents off a culture of acceptance, from just shrugging their shoulders," Powell says. His force is developing "information-sharing protocols" - encouraging people to snitch, sometimes through a third party if they are not comfortable approaching the police.

In both districts the trouble only begins at night. At dusk the six officers assemble at the force control room. They check their weapons and ammunition as they receive their instructions. Then they make the 20-minute drive into the city. Some nights they are armed, some not. When they are, they are under orders not to hide their weaponry as they tread the narrow alleys of the Meadows, and the wider, more exposed streets of St Ann's.

The streets are very empty. For weeks now, there has been little for them to do. The show of force seems to have persuaded the gangs that used to roam the streets to keep out of sight - at least for the time being.

Black community leader William Stewart wonders whether, long term, it will work. "It's heavy-handed," he says. The strategy will not tackle the real problem: "None of us, least of all the police, is getting through to the kids. The ones involved in crime are the ones who are not being reached." We are sitting in the local pub, The Poets' Corner. Its owners have agreed with police that it should open only in daytime. At nights the potential for violence is too great. The evening before we met, the greengrocer's next door had been burned down.

Nottingham is not exceptional. Its gangland problems do not rival those of Manchester or other major cities. Many locals point out that Nottingham is a vibrant city, with a resurgent cultural life and new buildings going up. According to Alan Simpson, MP for Nottingham South, increasing disparity in wealth in the city is one of the main causes of the problem.

The police, he says, "have been hung out to dry. They're trying to tackle a problem that's as much economic as anything else. Many of the regeneration and retraining schemes for areas like St Ann's and the Meadows are short-lived. The money moves on as quickly as it arrives."

Several community leaders I speak to, as well as the local Baptist and Anglican priests in St Ann's, say that while the police were assiduous in consulting about Operation Real Estate in general, they were not entirely open about the specific decision to bear firearms.

The police say that some people are being selective with their memories; that everything was done to inform them, from pieces in local papers and community newsletters to public meetings. It was only when the issue came to national prominence that "certain people in Nottingham, who had been behind it, began to criticise it for their own political agendas," says one police official.

The problem for the police now is that they could be locked into a strategy from which there is little escape. Each Friday, Price and his team carry out a progress report, partly on the basis of intelligence gleaned from the community. For the past few weeks he has concluded that the threat of violence has receded, and ordered his men to leave their weapons in the ARVs. But this, he makes clear, can change week by week.

So far, so good. Crime rates are down, criticism is muted. The figures are impressive. Since the operation began there have been only a handful of shooting incidents. More than 150 arrests have been made; a number of trials are about to begin. About 15 guns have been recovered.

But as with any deterrent, it only works if the other side knows that you are prepared to use it. And what if the unthinkable happens - someone is shot by the police during the operation? "The first time anything goes wrong it'll be the last time the strategy has any credibility," says Simpson.

Dr Karim Murji, a criminologist at the Open University, believes British policing is at a crossroads. "This debate about guns is part of the mythology of British policing," he says. "We are in fact much further down the line than most people realise. The experience of the last two decades shows that it's impossible to roll back on arming levels once they have been established."

The main worry seems to be that we will go the way of the US, where easy access to weapons produces a more trigger-happy police culture. But what about Europe? It is perfectly normal in, say, France or Germany, to see a couple of armed officers, pistols in holsters, walk into a café or bar. If this were to become the norm in Britain, would it really be as bad as we imagine?

Intriguingly, there are now fewer police in Britain being given firearms training than there were in the 1980s. The number of officers authorised to carry guns has declined from 13,000 in 1983 to 6,300 in 1998. However, the number of armed operations has grown steadily, mirroring the growth in the criminal use of guns. Forces are specialising, providing more intensive training for what is, in effect, a new elite type of officer.

Two centuries of tradition have left Britain almost unique in the way it polices its communities. Police organisations, from the Association of Chief Police Officers to the Police Federation, are officially sceptical about a move towards the regular use of weapons. The last survey conducted by the federation showed a wide of range of views among officers about who should be trained to use arms and who, if anyone, should carry them. The majority remained doubtful about the effectiveness of regular armed policing, and wary of its social consequences.

But this latest incremental step is one of the most significant yet. "Whether they admit it or not, they are making a statement here in St Ann's," says Brown. "We are being used as a laboratory for a bigger experiment."

It is easy to see what would constitute failure here: a breakdown in community relations, perhaps following a fatal shooting by police. But what if the Nottingham experiment is deemed a success? What if crime rates stay low and most members of the community say that - for all their initial fears - they now feel safer with armed police and want them to stay?

Then, for all the attempts by Nottinghamshire police to play down what they have done, they will have set an example that other forces will inevitably follow.

webTitle: Leader: Tory tax claims fail close scrutiny

fields.headline: Election battle cries
fields.standfirst:
Tory tax claims fail close scrutiny

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Tory tax claims fail close scrutiny.
fields.body:
Late last year a Gallup poll in the Daily Telegraph found only 5% of people believed they had "a very clear idea" of what the Tories stood for. William Hague will attempt to give them a clearer idea tomorrow, in what is being billed as a crucial pre-election speech on Tories and taxation.

He faces a daunting challenge, given the torturous zigzag Tory policy has followed since the last election. At Blackpool in 1997, the message was unequivocal: in Mr Hague's words then, they had lost power not just because they were arrogant, selfish and conceited, but also because they were harsh, uncaring and greedy. But two years on, again at Blackpool, all this changed, with their common sense manifesto bristling with extreme rightwing ideas, including tougher welfare rules, longer prison sentences, a reduced role for the state and local government, and lower taxes.

From the leaks to yesterday's and today's papers, more confusion looks likely. Yesterday's papers talked about cuts that would come from "savings - not cuts to public services, which the Tories guarantee to protect". Who are they trying to fool? All the old and tired predictables that surface in every public expenditure review are brought forward: Whitehall waste, social-security fraud and a bureaucratic recruitment freeze.

You do not save £8bn in public spending, as even the Tories concede, by such measures. Real programmes have to be attacked. And indeed yesterday's list included scrapping the New Deal, reducing the housing programme, cutting the already reduced time unemployment benefit is paid. Since when were training programmes, housing and welfare payments not regarded as services?

Cynically, the Tories do not mind being seen to cut welfare, or Labour's anti-poverty programmes that should make Britain a fairer society. What they are at pains to avoid is being seen to be cutting health or education, the public's top two spending priorities. Yet the Tories are already committed to abolishing Labour's £3bn standards fund, which has been the driving force behind the literacy and numeracy strategies, as well as the reduction in class sizes in the first three years of primary school.

There is another element of blatant dishonesty in the current debate: the idea that rolling back the welfare state would have immediate tax benefits. It does not. Michael Portillo, when chief secretary, always emphasised the long-term timescale of any such change. Pension policy changes, for example, do not affect existing pensioners, only future claimants. Indeed, the government actuary, in response to a Tory question, has suggested that the Conservative plan to offer current workers an opt-out from the state basic pension scheme would not start saving the government money until it had been running for 35 years.

Anonymous Tory spokesmen complained yesterday about a Labour government that had increased spending from 35.2% to 37.8% of gross national income. Do they have no sense of history? Margaret Thatcher, their heroine, inherited 33.3% and ended her first term spending 39.1%. As we have noted before, Labour should be accused of spending too little - less than the previous five administrations stretching back 35 years - not too little.

Three other warnings: First, not all manifesto commitments are honoured. Second, some of the most important policy changes - the withdrawal of long-term nursing beds - happened without any announcement. Third, watch for tax cuts that help the rich but hurt the poor, as happened in a succession of Tory changes between 1983-95.

Michael Portillo, when chief secretary, always emphasised the long-term timescale of any such change. Pension policy changes, for example, do not affect existing pensioners, only future claimants. Indeed, the government actuary, in response to a Tory question, has suggested that the Conservative plan to offer current workers an opt-out from the state basic pension scheme would not start saving the government money until it had been running for 35 years. Anonymous Tory spokesmen complained yesterday about a Labour government that had increased spending from 35.2% to 37.8% of gross national income. Do they have no sense of history? Margaret Thatcher, their heroine, inherited 33.3% and ended her first term spending 39.1%. As we have noted before, Labour should be accused of spending too little - less than the previous five administrations stretching back 35 years - not too little. Three other warnings: First, not all manifesto commitments are honoured. Second, some of the most important policy changes - the withdrawal of long-term nursing beds - happened without any announcement. Third, watch for tax cuts that help the rich but hurt the poor, as happened in a succession of Tory changes between 1983-95.

webTitle: Parents' fight to free jailed daughter

fields.headline: 'Lori is no terrorist ... she's guilty of speaking loudly for the poor'
fields.standfirst: Jailed American's parents fight to free her from Peruvian prison
fields.trailText: Jailed American's parents fight to free her from Peruvian prison
fields.body:
Mark Berenson could see no reason to decline when he was invited to take part in an academic conference in Peru. As a professor of statistics and the author of several standard works on his subject, there was nothing to stop him.

Nothing, that is, except his daughter Lori. "She wouldn't let me go. She said: 'It's too dangerous, you'll stand out like a tall American and they'll shoot you first and ask the questions second.' So I didn't go."

He didn't, but some time later she did. Now his 30-year-old daughter has been living in a prison cell for the past five years.

Peru says that Lori Berenson is a guerrilla, guilty of treason. Her parents, Mark and Rhoda, say that she is being used as a symbol of Peru's commitment to crushing terrorism and its determination to stand up to the United States. Each of them has visited her about 40 times in the past two years, every round trip costing $1,400.

The Berensons live in a pleasant flat in Gramercy Park, Manhattan, the very picture of liberal respectability. The sitting room, which opens on to a terrace, contains four chess sets, a gallery of family photographs and an L-shaped sofa inhabited by a large brown teddy bear.

But this image of decent lives spent as college professors - Mrs Berenson taught physics - is shattered by the Free Lori Berenson posters spilling out of cardboard boxes in one corner of the room and the letters of support for their daughter scattered on a glass-topped table.

Both parents retired early so that they could concentrate on trying to win Lori's freedom. Now her 58-year-old father has time for little else, and Rhoda Berenson can switch off just long enough to read a book on her frequent flights. He seethes and erupts, she maintains a shoulder-shrugging mock bemusement.

Indignities

"I used to think of myself as a caring person," Mr Berenson says, waving away arguments and counting off indignities on his fingers. "But I was a couch potato and I have to be honest and say: 'Would I have personally been there for someone else's daughter?'"

Rhoda, 57, might have been. Just as the Berensons rely on the support of others now, she was involved previously in Amnesty International and the American Civil Liberties Union.

Lori Berenson was clever at school - everybody's favourite, says her father; never a rebel, says her mother - and her classmates included the actress Jennifer Aniston and Chastity Bono, Cher's daughter. But the young Lori was less interested in nascent celebrity than in developing her social conscience. At 14 she recorded a voiceover for the international relief agency Care and when she went to college became active in Latin-American causes.

She visited Nicaragua and made two more trips to Central America before dropping out of school and into what she considered real life. She went to El Salvador in 1992 and then, two years later, Peru, where she intended to work as a journalist.

There she moved into a house in Lima where her fellow occupants included members of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA).

Mrs Berenson says: "She has leftist ideological views that she shares, sometimes parallel to MRTA, but she's not a person who believes in violence and terrorism."

It is an evaluation sharply at variance with that of the Peruvian government. The police raided the house on November 30 1995, and by next day one person was dead, three were badly wounded, four hostages were freed and 21 alleged members of MRTA were under arrest.

Elsewhere in the city there was a general sweep for suspects. Lori Berenson, who by this time had moved out of the house, was arrested on a bus and six weeks later received a life sentence for treason, plotting to attack the Peruvian congress, transporting weapons, and instructing militants. She was convicted by masked military judges who considered evidence kept secret from her lawyer.

Now her sentence has been overturned, clearing the way for a new trial in an open civilian court on the lesser charge of terrorism, probably at the end of this month.

"The script is in, it's 20 years," says Mark Berenson. His wife sees more reason for hope, especially since President Alberto Fujimori decamped to Japan after his right-hand man was filmed passing a bribe to a Peruvian congressman three months ago.

"I think it certainly looks good for Peru," Mrs Berenson says. "The problem for Lori is that she's in the middle of a trial based on laws put in place by the old regime. She's still in a situation where she hardly gets to see her lawyer and hasn't been able to put together a defence for that reason.

"It looks good for the future but Lori is still in the present. She's still the symbol."

The Berensons differ on points of emphasis but are solid on the matter of their daughter's innocence. "Sure she is," says Mr Berenson. "Oh definitely, definitely," says his wife. "Yes, she's guilty of speaking loudly and arguing for the poor."

Innocence

This last reference is to the fixed image the most Peruvians have of Lori Berenson as a raving leftie, which goes some way towards explaining the lack of support there for the campaign to free her. She was filmed at the time of her trial railing against poverty and shouting: "There are no criminal terrorists in the MRTA. It is a revolutionary movement."

Her parents say that this was because she had spent days listening to the suffering of a mistreated fellow prisoner.

The Berensons say they have good pensions - and they need them. They have spent more than $700,000 in support of their daughter, of which just under $100,000 came from donations. The couple were too bashful to raise money until Lori's third year in jail.

Ever the statistician, Mr Berenson rattles through the precise levels of support in the US Congress: broadly, they are backed by nearly all the Democrats and nowhere near as many Republicans.

Mrs Berenson, too, makes use of her skills; she recently published a book about the case. "And now I have nothing to do," she says sarcastically.

Her husband agrees: "She has nothing to do. Nothing to do."

webTitle: Mexican rebels ready to talk about ending war

fields.headline: Mexican rebels ready to talk about ending war
fields.trailText: The leader of the Zapatista rebels said at the weekend he was ready to travel to Mexico City and negotiate with the country's new president, Vicente Fox, for an end to the seven-year clash between the government and guerrillas.
fields.body:
The leader of the Zapatista rebels said at the weekend he was ready to travel to Mexico City and negotiate with the country's new president, Vicente Fox, for an end to the seven-year clash between the government and guerrillas.

The rebels took up arms under the leadership of "Subcomandante Marcos" on New Year's Day 1994 and this weekend's surprise move towards peace negotiations brings to an end a four-year stalemate during which dozens have died.

In his inaugural speech last Friday, Mr Fox promised to promote a law guaranteeing indigenous rights - a key demand of the Zapatistas - and a deliver "new dawn" in the conflict-torn state of Chiapas.

In a dramatic midnight announcement, he ordered troops to be pulled back in the southern state, just hours before Mr Marcos was due to appear in public for the first time in more than a year.

"The resumption of talks between the federal government and the Zapatista army is possible," Mr Marcos said on Saturday at his headquarters in the jungle village of La Realidad.

He said he would lead a delegation of 24 Zapatista commanders to Mexico City in February to lobby in favour of the indigenous rights bill. Mr Fox has promised to send the bill to the congress tomorrow.

The bill was elaborated from the San Andres accords signed in 1996, but the then government's failure to present it to congress prompted Mr Marcos walk out of the negotiations and take his rebels back to their jungle hideouts.

"The country needs this law that will not only respond to indigenous demands but will be a great step forward for the peace process," Mr Marcos said on Saturday.

Although he set several conditions for a return to the peace table, including the permanent removal of seven specific military camps near Zapatista strongholds, his general tone was positive.

"You start from zero in terms of credibility and trust," he said, reading an open letter to Mr Fox, whose inauguration ended the 71-year-old regime of the Institutional Revolutionary party.

Although he added a few gibes at the new president's "contradictions and frivolities", Mr Marcos described the initial troop withdrawal as "a sign of greater commitments to come."

He welcomed the naming of Luis Alvarez, 85, as Chiapas peace commissioner. The former senator is a long-standing supporter of the indigenous rights bill.

Mr Fox received the news while on a whirlwind tour of the country during the second day of his marathon inauguration celebrations. "With great happiness we have heard that the Zapatistas have accepted dialogue. There's a new way of thinking," he said.

More than 50 army checkpoints in Chiapas were being dismantled, along with several small roadside encampments, as troops in some key conflict zones were returned to barracks in response to the presidents' orders.

In addition to serving a military function, the checkpoints have a reputation for harassing communities with Zapatista sympathies.

Ever since he won the presidential election in July, Mr Fox has made it clear that he wants to rid Mexico of the negative reputation associated with the Chiapas conflict. The election of a pro-peace governor of the state in August increased the hope that progress was on the way.

Meanwhile Mr Marcos has been under pressure to try a new tack, given the failure of the Zapatista uprising to deliver improvements to the indigenous communities the rebels claim to represent.

The path to peace

Jan 1 1994 Zapatistas seize Chiapas towns and demand improved rights for Indians

Jan 12 President Carlos Salinas declares ceasefire

Feb 21 Peace talks start in San Cristobal de las Casas. Zapatistas reject peace offer

Dec 1 President Ernesto Zedillo accepts rebel demand for church-led mediation commission

Jan 15 1995 Subcomandante Marcos and interior secretary Esteban Moctezuma meet in Chiapas. Two days later, government orders army pullback

Feb 8 Peace effort sours

Feb 9 Thousands of soldiers enter rebel territory

Feb 16 1996 Two sides sign San Andres agreement to expand Indian rights

Sep 2 Rebels quit peace talks

July 2 2000 Vicente Fox wins presidential election

Aug 20 Anti-PRI candidate Pablo Salazar wins Chiapas governorship, vows to eliminate anti-rebel paramilitary groups

Dec 2 Marcos conditionally accept resumption of peace talks. Plans Mexico City visit

webTitle: Colombian judge seeks US asylum from death threat

fields.headline: Colombian judge seeks US asylum from death threat
fields.standfirst: Bogota says danger is past, so she must return home
fields.trailText: Seven years after the death of the world's most notorious cocaine trafficker, the name Pablo Escobar can still inspire terror. The judge who signed his arrest warrant in 1987 has applied for political asylum in the US, claiming that she is still marked for death.
fields.body:
Seven years after the death of the world's most notorious cocaine trafficker, the name Pablo Escobar can still inspire terror.

The judge who signed his arrest warrant in 1987 has applied for political asylum in the US, claiming that she is still marked for death.

After she approved the warrant charging Escobar with the murder of a prominent journalist, Consuelo Sanchez was sent to a diplomatic posting in the US to protect her from death threats. She has spent 12 years in America, and has two daughters born there.

Escobar was shot dead by security agents in 1993 and the Colombian government says that Ms Sanchez is no longer in danger. Last week the foreign ministry terminated her job as consul in Washington and ordered her to return.

She says that Escobar's surviving allies will kill her if she goes back.

"The ... order for me to return home to my country is the signature on the death warrant prepared for me by the Colombian drug cartel in 1988 and remaining in force today," she wrote in her asylum application.

"I'm not just trying to keep my job. The only thing I have asked the president and the courts is for them to protect my life, which is a fundamental right. This is a question of human rights," she said in a telephone interview.

Ms Sanchez was the youngest judge in Colombia when she started investigating the death of Guillermo Cano, a newspaper director shot in 1986.

She was immediately threatened by Escobar and other drugs barons who feared extradition to the US.

In one message "the Extraditables" warned her that if she charged Escobar "[You would] commit an error that would stain your life and would plague you until your dying day. You are perfectly aware that we are capable of executing you anywhere on the planet".

Escobar's appetite for violence as an instrument of intimidation and revenge was demonstrated in a national terror campaign in the late 1980s as part of the drug barons' fight against extradition. Scores of Colombians, including ministers, presidential candidates and judges, were shot or bombed. Mafia gunmen tracked down and shot a former justice minister who had been posted to Hungary for his protection.

Four days after signing Escobar's warrant, Ms Sanchez resigned from the judiciary and was sent to the US. Two other judges and a lawyer who worked on the case were murdered by Escobar's men.

The Medellin cartel collapsed after Escobar's death in December 1993, but only one major drug trafficker has been successfully extradited for trial in the US.

Last November 6 people were killed and 40 injured by a car bomb which exploded in Bogota days after 40 suspected drug traffickers were arrested pending extradition.

Meanwhile judges, reporters and human rights researchers are still regularly attacked by the mafia, leftwing rebels and paramilitaries, Jose Miguel Vivanco of the monitoring group Human Rights Watch said.

"Many officials investigating narcotics, human rights abuses or corruption are subject to threats, persecution and harassment. Sometimes the only solution is for them to leave the country," he said.

webTitle: Mandela attacks 'black stooges' deserting ANC in droves

fields.headline: Mandela attacks 'black stooges' deserting ANC in droves
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela has been accused of "playing the race card" when he called supporters of the official opposition party "black stooges [of] white bosses" in the runup to tomorrow's elections to a new level of big-city government.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela has been accused of "playing the race card" when he called supporters of the official opposition party "black stooges [of] white bosses" in the runup to tomorrow's elections to a new level of big-city government.

His denunciation of black supporters of the Democratic Alliance reflects the African National Congress's annoyance that the white-oriented opposition is apparently likely to do well in the ballot to decide who will govern the "megacities", which incorporate previously white-only cities and their surrounding black townships into single administrations.

Opinion polls show the alliance, an amalgamation of the old liberal Democratic party and the formerly apartheid National party, close to victory in Johannesburg, Cape Town, Pretoria and Durban. To the ANC's chagrin, it seems to be picking up support in townships such as Soweto, where there is a growing disenchantment with corruption in the new establishment.

"You must not be misled by a party that only cares for blacks on the eve of the elections. No white party can run this country ... no matter how they cover up by getting a few black stooges," Mr Mandela said at a rally in Johannesburg. The DA responded that more than half its candidates were black.

"President Mbeki is so unpopular that the ANC decided not to wheel him out for the attack but to allow him to hide behind the old man," it said. "The difference between the ANC and us is that they are not interested in blacks at any time during or outside the elections."

According to an opinion poll by Markinor, support for the ANC in Johannesburg has dropped below 50% for the first time: 44% compared with 33% support for the alliance.

In Cape Town, the alliance led 40% to 28%, but one in five voters said they were undecided. The contest is also close in Pretoria and Durban.

The real embarrassment to the ANC is that the alliance is picking up votes among black people at all when it includes some of the most notorious apologists for apartheid, and after it ran a thinly disguised racist presidential campaign last year.

But if the opinion polls are correct it has made inroads even in Soweto and other townships which were once considered so solidly ANC that in the last local elections five years ago the opposition parties hardly bothered to campaign there.

Although some Soweto residents say they are disillusioned by the ANC's failure to make good on its promises to provide new houses and jobs and curb crime, the principal concern of many is abuse of power and incompetence, particularly by local councillors.

The ANC admits that there is a problem. An internal audit concluded that one in five of its councillors was either corrupt or unfit to hold office. The party is campaigning on a promise that all such politicians will be fired, as well as a guarantee of free water and electricity to the poorest.

Mr Mbeki's standing has fallen because be questions the link between HIV and Aids, but there is so far no evidence that this is an important factor in the dissatisfaction with the ANC as a party.

The government is also at odds with traditional chiefs, who say that the reorganisation of local government strips them of many of their powers. Mr Mbeki has tried to reassure them that their concerns will be addressed after the ballot, but they remain reluctant to back the ANC.

The unions have urged their members to vote ANC, but some public employees on strike for better pay have other plans.

In Durban, the prominent anti-apartheid activist Fatima Meer says the ANC is losing the Indian vote by failing to address poverty in the community. "Indians as a whole have become disenchanted with the ANC," she said. "The chances of Indians voting for the ANC are very slim. Unless there is some sort of strong alternative, the votes will go to the DA."

But if the opinion polls are correct it has made inroads even in Soweto and other townships which were once considered so solidly ANC that in the last local elections five years ago the opposition parties hardly bothered to campaign there. Although some Soweto residents say they are disillusioned by the ANC's failure to make good on its promises to provide new houses and jobs and curb crime, the principal concern of many is abuse of power and incompetence, particularly by local councillors. The ANC admits that there is a problem. An internal audit concluded that one in five of its councillors was either corrupt or unfit to hold office. The party is campaigning on a promise that all such politicians will be fired, as well as a guarantee of free water and electricity to the poorest. Mr Mbeki's standing has fallen because be questions the link between HIV and Aids, but there is so far no evidence that this is an important factor in the dissatisfaction with the ANC as a party. The government is also at odds with traditional chiefs, who say that the reorganisation of local government strips them of many of their powers. Mr Mbeki has tried to reassure them that their concerns will be addressed after the ballot, but they remain reluctant to back the ANC. The unions have urged their members to vote ANC, but some public employees on strike for better pay have other plans. In Durban, the prominent anti-apartheid activist Fatima Meer says the ANC is losing the Indian vote by failing to address poverty in the community. "Indians as a whole have become disenchanted with the ANC," she said. "The chances of Indians voting for the ANC are very slim. Unless there is some sort of strong alternative, the votes will go to the DA."

webTitle: Leader: Pinochet in the dock

fields.headline: Pinochet in the dock
fields.standfirst:
Human rights extended even before a trial

Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: Human rights extended even before a trial.
fields.body:
The arrest in Chile of General Pinochet is being celebrated by human rights campaigners round the world. Amnesty International rightly expressed satisfaction on behalf of the bereaved that at long last the beginning of justice for the 3,000 people who were killed, tortured or disappeared, can now begin. But his indictment for his role in a series of crimes against his people, has far wider repercussions.

The former dictator's attempts to avoid prosecution, paradoxically, are continuing to pile up vitally important legal precedents that extend the reach of human rights law. First came the Spanish judge's application seeking the extradition of the general from the UK that established the important principle that human rights abuses in one country can be legitimately pursued in another.

Remember, it was our own law lords who established this principle, the dictator only being returned to Chile on the grounds of ill health. Then a succession of defences which the general had erected in Chile to protect himself from prosecution, were removed by the Chilean parliament and courts. What makes the latest ruling even more satisfying is that it was made by a middle-of-the-road, rather than radical judge. Respect for human rights continues to widen and deepen.

No one should assume the trial will be held promptly. His lawyers are already appealing against his arrest. But the general will not be able, as he was in the UK, to use his physical frailty as a defence against prosecution. Chilean law only provides exemptions for people suffering from mental incapacity. Given the general issued a coherent video message just 10 days ago on his 85th birthday, this defence would seem to be ruled out.

The Pinochet apologists - Norman Lamont, Margaret Thatcher and Geoffrey Howe - have yet to comment. Perhaps they will have the grace to acknowledge their error in suggesting his arrest here would only lead to another Chilean army coup.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Pinochet appeal against charges
fields.body:
Pinochet appeal against charges

Lawyers for General Augusto Pinochet have appealed against his indictment on homicide and kidnapping charges, arguing that Judge Juan Guzman denied the former dictator his basic rights by not even questioning him.

Judge Guzman previously ordered medical tests to see if Gen Pinochet, 85, is fit to stand trial. They have not yet begun.
AP, Santiago

Germans arrest far-right vandals

German police arrested two teenagers who vandalised a memorial to Omar Ben Noui, an Algerian immigrant who died while fleeing from neo-Nazis, in Guben, on the Polish border,on Saturday.

In Dresden on Saturday, police prevented a banned demonstration by the far-right National Democratic party.
AP, Berlin

Iraqi u-turn on oil exports

After a two-day production shutdown, Iraq announced yesterday that it would resume exporting crude oil to fulfil contracts signed under the UN-approved oil-for-food deal.

Last week the UN rejected Iraq's proposed oil prices for this month as too low. The pricing was believed to be an attempt to compensate buyers for a surcharge of 50 cents a barrel which Iraq wants them to pay into a bank account it controls. Analysts think Iraq wants to take advantage of high crude prices.
AP, Baghdad

Newspapers shut in Morocco

Morocco's prime minister has banned three weekly newspapers which implicated him in a 1972 assassination attempt on the king.

Abderrahamane Youssoufi said on Saturday that the three papers had carried the allegations that he had a role in the plot to kill King Hassan II, with the intention of destabilising Morocco. Ten newspapers have now been seized and banned this year.
AP, Rabat

Callas sale to raise £600,000

A good luck charm which belonged to Maria Callas - a painting of the Holy Family - fetched 900,000 francs (£83,800) at auction in Paris on Saturday night.

The lots, ranging from personal memorabilia and letters to underwear, are expected to raise more than £600,000.
AP, Paris

Students riot in cheating row

About 200 people were injured when crowds clashed with the Bangladeshi police on Saturday after college officials expelled 13 students accused of cheating in their exams.

A mob of nearly 500 attacked the Barisal government college, 75 miles south of Dhaka, and beat the teachers.
AP, Dhaka

webTitle: Hunger strikers close to death

fields.headline: Hunger strikers close to death
fields.trailText: Hikmet Gelir sits quietly on the floor of a cramped office, a red ribbon tied around her head and a blanket spread over her legs. With three companions she is refusing food in solidarity with her son, who is in a Turkish prison.
fields.body:
Hikmet Gelir sits quietly on the floor of a cramped office, a red ribbon tied around her head and a blanket spread over her legs. With three companions she is refusing food in solidarity with her son, who is in a Turkish prison.

"We don't trust the government," she said. "That's why our children are on hunger strike and so are we."

At least 800 leftwing prisoners are taking part in the hunger strike, which has lasted for more than six weeks. Well over 100 are on a "death fast" - they are taking no food or water, and have signed forms insisting that they want no medical help when they drift into unconsciousness.

Their supporters say that some of them are already suffering severe medical complications, such as nausea, gastric bleeding, loss of memory and loss of vision. "We are entering a critical period in which deaths may occur", said Gokce Yilmaz of the Human Rights Association.

The protest is inspired by government plans for prison reform, which have become the focus of an angry debate.

Turkey's prison system has been in crisis for years. Violence and corruption are routine and prisoners often run the wards themselves. Guns and mobile phones are smuggled in with apparent ease.

The government wants to move thousands of prisoners out of big dormitory wards into new maximum security prisons based on a cell system.

Those due to be moved include members of illegal leftwing and Kurdish groups, as well as rightwing nationalists involved in organised crime.

The authorities insist that the new prisons will be cleaner and safer.

They opened the doors of one freshly painted institution to the media last week to show bright airy cells and courtyards which they say meet all international standards.

"We want prisons where the inmates are treated with dignity", the justice minister told parliament, "and where none of these illegal organisations run their own affairs."

The problem is that leftwing prisoners are convinced that the safety of numbers in the dormitory system is their only guarantee of security. They believe isolation will be the main goal of the new prison regime.

Many prison officers have rightwing sympathies, and the radical left is regarded as the enemy. Last year 10 prisoners in an Ankara jail were beaten to death when paramilitary police quelled a protest about prison transfers. A parliamentary human rights commission said there was clear evidence of torture, but no action was taken.

That comes as no surprise to Kezban Sacilik, one of the thousands of people demonstrating against prison reform in Ankara last week. Earlier this year her son Veli had his arm torn off by a bulldozer which knocked down a prison wall during another prisoners' protest. The arm was later found in the mouth of a local dog, and Veli has been charged with attacking the bulldozer.

"It's a bit like an ant attacking an elephant", Mrs Sacilik said. "How could my son attack this machine? The state should be ashamed of what it's doing."

It is this sustained bitterness and distrust which has provoked the hunger strike in jails throughout the country.

The unrepentant government claims that many prisoners are being forced into fasting. That is why it wants to break the hold of organised groups in the dormitories.

It insists that it has a duty to ensure security in its prisons, and that it can only do that through dramatic change. Its critics say that building new jails will have no effect unless the mentality of the system is overhauled first.

"The Turkish people want security," said Sema Piskinsut, an MP who has written critical reports on jail conditions.

"But they want respect for human rights as well. What worries me is that there is no effort to find a consensus."

webTitle: Walkabout  Australians march for reconciliation

fields.headline: Walkabout  Australians march for reconciliation
fields.trailText: Almost 300,000 people joined marches through two Australian state capitals yesterday calling for the reconciliation of indigenous and white citizens.
fields.body:
Almost 300,000 people joined marches through two Australian state capitals yesterday calling for the reconciliation of indigenous and white citizens.

State and federal ministers from both ends of the political spectrum joined the walks in Melbourne and Perth, an indication of the growing cross-party support for the 10-year-old campaign to reduce the symbolic and material differences between Aborigines and whites.

The police estimated that 200,000 people turned out in Melbourne, including Steve Bracks, the Labor state premier, and Peter Costello, the treasurer in the Liberal federal government.

In Perth, tens of thousands more marched alongside Western Australia's rightwing premier Richard Court, who walked with his adopted Aboriginal daughter Billie.

But the federal prime minister, John Howard, who refuses to offer a symbolic apology for the treatment of Aborigines since white settlement began in 1788, was conspicuous by his absence. He said he had a prior engagement.

Aborigines make up 386,000 of Australia's 19m people and are the poorest, least healthy, and most likely to be jailed.

webTitle: Bottle of rare Italian red fetches £9,000

fields.headline: Bottle of rare Italian red fetches £9,000
fields.trailText: A 109-year-old bottle of exceptionally rare Italian vintage red wine, described by experts as a "work of art", was sold at auction for more than £9,000 yesterday.
fields.body:
A 109-year-old bottle of exceptionally rare Italian vintage red wine, described by experts as a "work of art", was sold at auction for more than £9,000 yesterday.

The bottle of 1891 Brunello di Montalcino Riserva Biondi Santi, one of only seven in existence, was sold to an anonymous Dutch collector for 29.5m lire (about £9,275),

"This bottle is a piece of history," said an expert at the auction, adding that the wine was in excellent condition, although the bottle is unlikely ever to be opened.

The lawyer who bid on behalf of the buyer would reveal little about the new owner's identity.

"I can only say that my client is a Dutch industrialist and a great collector of wine and works of art. Obviously the wine will not be drunk but will become part of my client's collection," he said.

An even older bottle of wine, an 1888 from the same Brunello di Montalcino cellar, failed to make its reserve price at the sale, run by the Pandolfini auction house, although bids reached 19.5m lire.

webTitle: Takeover panel rulings risk Human Rights Act test

fields.headline: Takeover panel rulings risk Human Rights Act test
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The takeover panel's rulings on bid battles could from now on be challenged in court under the Human Rights Act, leading lawyers have warned.
fields.body:
The takeover panel's rulings on bid battles could from now on be challenged in court under the Human Rights Act, leading lawyers have warned.

They say the panel fails the test of independence and impartiality which is required of public bodies under the Act, which brought the European convention on human rights into English law this year.

This could push the panel into becoming a statutory rather than a self-regulated body, something it has so far resisted. It could even mean its duties being taken over by the financial services authority.

Philip Goldenberg, a senior corporate finance partner at City law firm S J Berwin, says the key problem is that the panel is a creature of the City, staffed by City professionals. Even its appeals committee, while chaired by a retired judge, has City figures as its other members.

This does not mean they have failed to act impartially in specific cases.

But as the committee members and staff are members of City firms and bodies affected by its decisions, the panel cannot meet the need for impartiality under the Act.

Independence and impartiality means there must be no possibility that members' careers could be affected by decisions they take, and that it must be possible to appeal to a body which has no relationship with those appealing.

Writing in the legal journal Amicus Curiae, Mr Goldenberg says this is not an issue of the panel's effectiveness. He argues its structure is simply incompatible with the Act.

"The panel has an enormously responsible job to do," he said. "It is unsatisfactory to operate on a basis which is in compatible with the Human Rights Act. It means that in any case it is involved in, what it says and does is open to challenge in the courts."

The City lawyer believes the only way out of this dilemma is for the panel to be constituted in law, something suggested under the EU takeover directive and which it is fiercely resisting.

The panel argues its status as a non-statutory City body gives it the flexibility to deal quickly with the issues that arise during takeover battles.

Mr Goldenberg says the only way around the dilemma is for the panel to become a statutory body. But in that case, there would be a strong argument for giving its duties to the FSA, which has already been allocated responsibility for market abuse in takeovers, under the financial services and markets bill.

The takeover panel would not comment on the issue.

 Special report on the Human Rights Act www.societytheguardian.com/humanrights

webTitle: TV and Radio: Work experience

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous.
fields.body:
Milla Jovovich in Kuffs (Bruce A Evans, 1992)

Who: Ukranian-born model-singer-actress, widely perceived as being very successful at the first, average at the second, and decidedly ropey at the third. Played a ginger alien, complete with Gaultier-designed bandages, in Luc Besson's farcical The Fifth Element (1997) before going on to marry the hirsute director.

He then saw fit to cast her as Joan of Arc, complete with pudding basin haircut, in the equally preposterous Messenger (1999). Jovovich has since filed for divorce. Despite her poor track record, painfully credible director Michael Winterbottom recently opted to cast her alongside Peter Mullen, Sarah Polley and Wes Bentley in his forthcoming nouveau-Western The Claim.

The role: Maya Carlton, the soon-to-be-dumped pregnant girlfriend of George Kuffs (Christian Slater).

Best line: While the pair are dancing around in their underwear in the opening scenes, Maya goes to put some music on and asks, "George, do you want something soft and romantic... or rock'n'roll?" Unsurprisingly, he plumps for rock'n'roll.

Cringe factor: The character is so grossly underwritten - and therefore has so little to say or do - that there's really no room for embarrassment.

Other wannabes: Ashley Judd as "Wife of Paint Store Owner" and softcore porn star Julie Strain as "Kane's Girl".

Critical judgement: Desson Howe in the Washington Post grumbled that "the only joke in this un-comedy is the rock-videoesque Slater-Jovovich affair".

Also not starring in: A 1987 episode of Married_ With Children, and (frolicking through paradise as a scantily clad castaway) 1991's Return To The Blue Lagoon.

Kuffs, 12.15am, Thursday 7 December, BBC1

webTitle: TV and Radio: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Starman | The Fabulous Baker Boys | Mercury Rising | Place Vendôme
fields.body:
Starman

(John Carpenter, 1984)

6pm, Sky Cinema

A surprisingly gentle romantic fantasy from Carpenter, more likely to be found helming crunchy action pics. Jeff Bridges is the space visitor who alters his appearance to that of Earthling Karen Allen's late husband and creates an intergalactic love affair in the process. Charming, although the snappy bits of conflict show what Carpenter does best.

The Fabulous Baker Boys

(Steve Kloves, 1989)

8pm, Sky Cinema

More Jeff Bridges, back here with brother Beau as Jack and Frank Baker, siblings who once had grand piano ambitions, now playing the Seattle nightclub circuit. Into their weary world steps singer Susie Diamond (Michelle Pfeiffer), raising the tempo of their show and putting the forte back into Jack's love life. An engaging tale, with the brothers' embittered relationship as compelling as the romance - and worth watching just for Pfeiffer's sultry Makin' Whoopee.

Mercury Rising

(Harold Becker, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

An autistic boy unwittingly cracks a top secret service code, causing cynical government agent Alec Baldwin to call in the hitmen. So, as Ghostbusters would put it, who you gonna call? Bruce Willis, of course. His FBI man is washed up, over the hill and down the other side, but still able to turn the tables on the smart young goons in a formulaic but efficient drama from the director of Sea Of Love.

Place Vendôme

(Nicole Garcia, 1998)

10pm, FilmFour

Catherine Deneuve's alcoholic Marianne, left with a handful of stolen diamonds on the death of her husband, hatches a plot encompassing profit and revenge on the lover (Jacques Dutronc) who once spurned her. But the involvement of shop assistant Emmanuelle Seigner and her lover (Jean-Pierre Bacri) compromise her plans. Not the most exciting of thrillers, but Garcia's moody direction and astute performances - especially from Deneuve - make this an intriguing tale.

So, as Ghostbusters would put it, who you gonna call? Bruce Willis, of course. His FBI man is washed up, over the hill and down the other side, but still able to turn the tables on the smart young goons in a formulaic but efficient drama from the director of Sea Of Love. Place Vendôme (Nicole Garcia, 1998) 10pm, FilmFour Catherine Deneuve's alcoholic Marianne, left with a handful of stolen diamonds on the death of her husband, hatches a plot encompassing profit and revenge on the lover (Jacques Dutronc) who once spurned her. But the involvement of shop assistant Emmanuelle Seigner and her lover (Jean-Pierre Bacri) compromise her plans. Not the most exciting of thrillers, but Garcia's moody direction and astute performances - especially from Deneuve - make this an intriguing tale.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Weekend TV

fields.headline: Joining the cubs
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV
fields.trailText: Lions - Spy in the Den | Panorama | RUEU?: A Trip around the European Union
fields.body:
Never trust a boulder. That's the lesson to learn from Lions - Spy in the Den (BBC1, Sun), a run-of-the-mill documentary, notwithstanding its ingenious (but oddly cartoonish) central premise - a camera hidden inside a boulder with wheels. Sounds like something that would happen on Scooby-Doo, doesn't it ("and I'd have got away with it if it hadn't been for you pesky kids")?

While the cutesy-wutesy lion cubs capered and canoodled, the boulder saw all, dutifully scurrying after them like a private detective on speed. The bouldercam's camouflage did provide an opportunity to glimpse the everyday life of the lions, something which would have been unthinkable had David Attenborough been hanging around.

But what we - and the boulder - witnessed wasn't groundbreaking or breathtaking. It was lions lyin' around and doin' other lion-ish things. A unique perspective it may have been - a fly-on-the-dung-heap documentary, if you will - but, like its human equivalents, it proved altogether pedestrian, despite the wheels.

Far from pedestrian was an extraordinary Panorama (BBC1, Sun) which carried the first television interview with a supergrass. Or a supergrass in his official grassing capacity, at least. As we know from the shenanigans down Sun Hill way lately, there ain't nuffink worse than a bent coppa - and Neil Putnam was exactly that.

During eight years of a 20-year career, he stole, extorted and dealt drugs - all from the safety of East Dulwich, where the South East Regional Crime Squad was based. Carrying a warrant card with the authority invested in him from on high, and imbued with a trust from the public to do the right thing, Putnam acted with impunity - lining pockets, settling scores and betraying those who believed in him. S

peaking candidly after his release from prison, Putnam may have been an untrustworthy narrator of events, but he was worth listening to, telling, as he did, a story which affects us all. He didn't just relate a tale of corrupt policemen and women doing us all a disservice, he also charted the onset of corruption in himself and others, exposing the anatomy of venality.

While we deplore the unscrupulousness of those who purport to uphold law and order, our ire towards the corrupt is fuelled by a loathing of a weakness we all have - we are all corruptible, whether in financial, emotional or psychological terms. Corruption is an insidious disease, one which creeps up on the unsuspecting whatever their profession or circumstance, and eats away like soul cancer. Putnam's testimony wasn't just an exposé of the outrageous criminal activities perpetrated by certain police officers, it was also an insight into the dark recesses of the human condition. "Apple, Adam?"

RUEU?: A Trip around the European Union (BBC2, Sat) was a wonderful, witty and intelligent documentary following Nick Fraser, erstwhile editor of Storyville, in his attempt to find something European worth believing in. The idea of a united Europe appealed to him; bonheur sans frontières was something he supported. Unfortunately the reality of Europe, the EU, corrupted his reverie, and put paid to any hope that those of you who watched it will sign on the dotted line for further integration with our continental cousins.

It was, of course, unavoidable that the European dream would lose out to realpolitik. As the Human League once sang, "I'm only human, born to make mistakes", but that the EU has managed to compound such an inevitability with astonishing incompetence, stupidity and short-sightedness is evidence that the mechanisms of running Europe - 20,000 bureaucrats, reams of legislation, corridors going nowhere, faulty elevators - defeat their own higher purpose.

A polite bulldog, Fraser repeatedly targeted the EU's weaknesses, highlighting hypocrisies (like the opening of the EU's Centre for Monitoring Racism and Xenophobia in Vienna after crazy right-winger Jorg Haider joined that country's government - akin to asking Norman Tebbit to host a party for Stonewall), quizzing irritatingly evasive politicians, and sometimes just standing in awe at grinding bureaucracy.

Apart from an ill-advised pill motif and silly hallucination sequence, RUEU? was an enjoyable watch, albeit one tempered with sadness at the dark corruption of a bright idea.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Afternoon Play: Into The Ether | Animals That Changed The World
fields.body:
Andrew Dallmeyer's Afternoon Play: Into The Ether (2.15pm, Radio 4) is science fiction, but is based on genuine, if improbable, military experiments in America and the Soviet Union. Deep in an army base at Fort Meade, Maryland, researcher Mary Unsworth begins working with Greg Demchuck, a US Marine. After falling off a ladder he has developed the strange mental capacity to observe distant places. He has, in fact, become the perfect spy.

The Dome at Greenwich is the latest example of the rat's yearning for man's company. The place is apparently swarming with them, which bodes well for its future as a high-technology centre with miles of delicious cabling. As Brian Leith discovers in Animals That Changed The World (9.0pm, Radio 4), rats actively sought us out from our earliest days. We offered them splendid food and shelter, they gratefully slaughtered us with typhus and plague. Zoologist Jill Key rates them second only to mankind as destructive predators..

webTitle: G2: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: The Lake District
fields.trailText: The Lake District
fields.body:
The best-selling Abraham Brothers' picture of all time wasn't one of their famous shots of climbers precariously poised on Lakeland crags but a peaceful scene of a rowing boat on the shore of Crummock Water, entitled, simply, "Solitude". It went all over the world. That's what the more famous of the two brothers, George D Abraham, pioneer climber (and one of the first motorists in Lakeland), told me nearly 50 years ago.

But ordinary photographers nowadays might prefer other scenes, and I know several who claim that the lowly height of Lingmoor Fell (1530ft) is one of the finest viewpoints in the district. (Of course, lowly heights are almost always better grandstands than the high fells.) One photographer friend, a professional, goes up Lingmoor several times each year to take pictures of the changing scene - the magical, close-up views of the Langdale Pikes or Blea Tarn, the luxuriant heather, the colourful woodlands, the little pools, the airy quarries and superb foregrounds for dramatic backcloths.

I went up there from Elterwater the other day, just fitting in the walk between torrential showers, and once again marvelled at the beauty, even on a poor day - especially the sudden view, when emerging from the dark woodlands, of the long length of Langdale far below and the knobbly ridge from Silver How to the Pikes with all its little side valleys stretched invitingly along the horizon.

The green slate quarries are crunching deeper and deeper into the bowels of the mountain - dramatic excavations in places - but, otherwise, the eyesores are largely hidden by the woodlands.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Medical thrillers

fields.headline: Bad medicine
fields.standfirst: TV drama's job is to keep its finger on the nation's pulse. So does the thriller Thin Ice tell us that Harold Shipman and co have destroyed our confidence in the medical profession? By  Jacques Peretti
fields.trailText: TV drama's job is to keep its finger on the nation's pulse. So does the thriller Thin Ice tell us that Harold Shipman and co have destroyed our confidence in the medical profession? By Jacques Peretti.
fields.body:
The time has come for a character like Dr Moss. Five years ago, before Harold Shipman, before the tragedy at Alder Hey Hospital, the medical profession appeared relatively immune from criticism, let alone outside investigation.

Now, however, public drubbing complete, the BMA receives that most ignominious of tributes: a corrupt doctor as the central character of a scathing new black comedy on BBC1.

In Thin Ice, Nicholas Lyndhurst plays the greatest charlatan since Crippen. Smooth-tongued, rich, complacent, immoral - the antithesis, in short, of poor Dr Legg in EastEnders, handing out anti-inflammation pills to Dot on a pittance of an NHS wage.

Moss writes prescriptions like confetti with a flick of the fountain pen. Wealthy old ladies are supplied with Valium and a little pat on the hand. "The trick with private medicine," he says to himself as a smug aside, "is to find out what the patient wants, and then give it to him."

Lyndhurst plays the character with frightening relish, building on his performance as the unctuous Uriah Heep in last year's BBC adaptation of David Copperfield. In Thin Ice, he is truly masterful as the slippery, hand-wringing quack on the border of psychosis.

Dr Moss shares something subtler with Lyndhurst's most famous role to date: as Gary in BBC1's long-running sitcom, Goodnight Sweetheart, about a man caught in a time-portal between the dull present and dodging bombs in The Blitz.

Lyndhurst appears permanently displaced. He has a wartime face - pinched and feminine, with a continually puzzled expression, as if he feels he should always be somewhere else. Preferably 50 years ago. It's an older, uncomprehending version of the space-cadet teenager he first played in Butterflies.

This makes him obvious casting for Thin Ice. Like Gary, Dr Moss was born in the wrong era. His manner is pure 50s - less Holby City than Dirk Bogarde in Doctor in the House.

By subtly echoing the 50s, Thin Ice has - paradoxically - tapped into the most contemporary of concerns. This is because we have returned pretty much to the anxieties of patients in the postwar era: abuse of the patient-doctor relationship; unaccountability; criminal misdiagnosis and petty corruption.

Our concerns revolve less around the Kafkaesque NHS system than the competence and motives of individual doctors. Hospital dramas commissioned in the 80s - still on BBC life-support - seem wholly out of touch with this.

It's hard to imagine how contro versial and hard-hitting a show like Casualty once was - back in the mid-80s, it was a huge factor in turning public opinion against Conservative cuts in the NHS.

Cardiac Arrest attempted to take the arterial realism of Casualty to a new level - doctors shooting up in bandage-strewn corridors. Stressing the stress, but essentially maintaining the dramatic focus on flashing lights and swinging doors.

In the 90s, hospital drama became ER'd - a conduit for glamorous people with impenetrable jargon that could just as easily have taken place on a plane or submarine as in Chicago's County General.

What we need now is not another hospital spin-off, but probably an updated version of Dr Finlay's Casebook, whose odious Dr Snoddy became a national focus for public hatred of the medical profession in the early 60s. The show dealt surprisingly frankly with ethical issues such as abortion and sexual assault, and was roundly condemned by doctors until the day it was taken off the air.

The subtle complexity of the doctor-patient relationship remains more fertile ground for drama than ever. It's likely, however, that modern writers will focus on ghoulish events of the recent past, resurrecting, ironically, the 50s-tinged psycho-doctor: masked killer on the loose, wielding a syringe in the manner of Hitchcock's Frenzy.

There is much to enjoy in Thin Ice. The morbid jokes, such as a dead man's mobile ringing as Moss begins the autopsy, an eerie reminder of the Paddington rail disaster, in which mobiles were said to ring from the twisted wreckage for days after the accident (Dr Moss answers and asks if he may "take a message").

There are unnerving little details: Moss sits in his examination room, wearing the subtlest hint of lipstick - prim as Miss Jean Brodie. When his prescription stamp comes down, we hear the dubbed ring of a cash-till.

There is another level, however, at which Thin Ice is pure rubbish. The increasingly ludicrous plot unwinds like a strange morphine dream. The cor blimey! underworld characters Moss meets as he becomes enmeshed in a bank robbery (yes, afraid so) seem familiar from children's drama, shaking their fist at Grange Hill pupils as they leg it with a packet of Frazzles.

Thin Ice never quite knows whether it is an absurd romp or a darker meditation on the psychosis of a corrupt doctor. What is not in dispute is that it is well-timed. Give Jimmy McGovern the subject of the obscenities that took place at Alder Hey, however, and expect a medical drama befitting our times.

 Thin Ice, tonight, 9pm, BBC1. Mark Lawson returns next week.

webTitle: Law: Marcel Berlins' Writ Large

fields.headline: No money for triplets?
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins, Writ Large: This is a tale of how, through no one's fault, one of the most controversial cases of recent months was reported in a way which misled everyone. It was the claim of the South Yorkshire couple that they should be compensated because the IVF treatment the wife underwent resulted in triplets rather than the one or two babies the couple wanted.
fields.body:
 This is a tale of how, through no one's fault, one of the most controversial cases of recent months was reported in a way which misled everyone. It was the claim of the South Yorkshire couple that they should be compensated because the IVF treatment the wife underwent resulted in triplets rather than the one or two babies the couple wanted.

The judge's decision was reported prominently and correctly in the media as a win for the parents - their contract with the fertility clinic specified that only two embryos were to be inserted so the clinic, by placing three, had breached the contract. So far so good. But the impression given was that the parents were going to get a substantial payout - an outcome which provoked intense criticism from just about everyone I spoke to.

But the reality is different. A week after the judge's highly publicised decision, he released his detailed reasons, which were given very little publicity. It turns out not only that the compensation hasn't yet been decided but that the judge has left open the possibility that the couple may get nothing at all.

I have canvassed the views of a number of lawyers who know their stuff in this field and there seems to be a consensus that the parents are probably not entitled to anything. Why? Because a ruling by the House of Lords last year said, broadly, that an unwanted baby was nevertheless a blessing, not a burden, and that it was contrary to policy to pay compensation to the parents even if the baby was the result of a failed vasectomy or sterilisation caused by medical negligence. (The triplets case is based on a broken contract, not negligence, but I don't see how that changes the general policy.)

And even the few thousand pounds usually awarded to a mother for the discomfort of being pregnant when she didn't want to be doesn't apply to the triplet's mother - she was pregnant anyway. But I bet that the vast majority of people who have got all excited over the case will forever continue to believe angrily that the parents of these triplets have walked away with a large sum of money.

 'The vast majority, especially among the eastern Europeans, are tough-looking, lounging, grinning young men ... their fear of persecution is as nothing compared with their fear of soap and water ... the stench has to be smelt to be believed ... one benefit-drawing, night club-frequenting 'refugee' was the proud owner of a £200 leather jacket," and so on, in a vile tone.

Is this a rant by some unreconstructed Powellite? No, it is a letter to the highly respectable Law Society Gazette from a solicitor; moreover, a solicitor who works for a "franchised" firm that does immigration work and represents asylum-seekers, and is paid with tax-payers' money to do so. Martin R Maloney is basically talking about his clients.

Should we continue to fund someone with such unpleasantly extreme feelings about the people he is supposed to be helping?

 A social worker passes a man lying on the ground, moaning in pain. She looks more closely He is badly bruised all over, bleeding profusely from cuts, both arms are broken, and he is barely conscious.

"My God," says the social worker, "the person who did this to you really needs help."
