webTitle: Arts: The first Russian electronica band

fields.headline: Not very big in Russia
fields.standfirst: The first electronica band to emerge from the former Soviet Union are finding Britain fertile ground - unlike home. Will Hodgkinson reports
fields.trailText: The first electronica band to emerge from the former Soviet Union are finding Britain fertile ground - unlike home. Will Hodgkinson reports.
fields.body:
'Everybody hates us," say Vlad Linder and Dmitry Dubov of Fizzarum, Russia's first ever electronica band. "No one is actually interested in what we are doing. There are no chill-out rooms in clubs - it is all commercial house music and MTV pop. The only places we can play are internet cafes. There is an underground scene but they like only noise. Our melodies are all right, but we use complicated rhythms, which people who like pop music are confused by, so we are in the middle."

The members of electronica bands tend to be pale, weedy types, the kind of boys who escaped from the torments of the football pitch at school by delving into a world of computers, sci-fi and cerebral flights of the imagination. But Fizz-arum look like mafia henchmen: with their crew-cuts, heavy set features and rugby player frames, they don't seem the type to get their heads flushed down toilets.

Perhaps it's just as well. As Linder and Dubov explain through their interpreter, the band's complex, thoughtful style of music, fusing electronic polyrhythms with the pastoral qualities of English folk, has won the band few fans in their home country.

Linder and Dubov, who are visiting England for the first time, are two thirds of Fizzarum. The third member, Dmitry Letakhovsky, is back in their native St Petersburg. That Fizzarum exist at all is a sign of Russia's shifting climate. Linder and Dubov met through a Russian internet forum. After discoveringthey shared a love of technology, they decided to meet up. Back then Linder was using an ancient ZX Spectrum to make music, while Dubov had grown up fascinated by his uncle's Yamaha keyboard.

Ten years ago it was impossible to find out about new technology in Russia; now, through the internet, Fizzarum can purchase the latest Japanese software they need to create their music, which is made entirely through computers. "All the samples are from synthesizers," says Dubov. "With software called QBase we can make live electronic music. We want to show that when the band are playing computers on stage, it is the same as playing guitar or drums. Nothing is pre-recorded. We are also planning to use a theremin."

Neither have they any time for guitar music. "If it is a guitar, it must have some kind of electronic manipulation," explains Linder. Radiohead's Kid A and the new album by Tortoise get the thumbs-up from the two, and their past heroes include Jean-Michel Jarre, Vangelis, Herbie Hancock, Depeche Mode, a Russian band from the 1980s called Zodiac and old Russian cartoons: "The music was always what we like - space age."

When I ask them when they arrived in England they look at each other, nod solemnly, then say: "Tomorrow." Which could be evidence of a bizarre sense of humour, or of something being lost in translation. Their record deal with the British independent label Domino was gained amid similar confusion. One and a half years ago, the band released a single on the Midlands label City Centre Offices. It was heard by Stephen McRobbie of Scottish indie band the Pastels, who passed it on to Domino founder Lawrence Bell. Intrigued, Bell wrote to Fizzarum to suggest that Domino put out a single.

Excitedly misreading the letter, the band thought they had been offered an album deal and were overjoyed. Lawrence hadn't the heart to tell them otherwise, so what was wished for became a reality. "The deal with a British label is all we ever wanted," they say now, with a single already released on Domino and an album, Monochrome Plural, is out today.

Now 26, Dubov spent five years working as a train driver, mostly to save enough money for the equipment he uses to make his music. Since signing the contract, he has quit to devote all of his time to the band. Linder, 22, still works in a coffee shop, but the goal is to tour Europe (a concert in Denmark last year was, up until now, their only foray outside Russia) and ultimately Japan.

"We really like Japanese technology, and we respect the Japanese for all their innovation," they explain. "It is our dream to show them how we have taken control of all these Japanese products." But they have no plans to leave St Petersburg. "The music is a product of the city," says Linder. "How we feel about the buildings and the people is what we say in our music." Despite local indifference to their art, both claim to like the atmosphere of their home town.

It's impossible not to wonder why three young Russian men would develop such a fascination for all things futuristic, technological and distanced from the here and now - at a time in Russia when opportunities previously closed to people like them are opening up constantly. "Modern life is a disappointment," they explain. "Which is why we prefer this kind of music."

 Fizzarum's single Microphorus is out now on Domino's Series 500. The album Monochrome Plural LP is released today on Domino.

webTitle: TV and Radio: The Neanderthal man series

fields.headline: Hirsutes you, sir
fields.trailText: Men dressed as scary animals have an illustrious history on television. In the curly-wurly 70s, the BBC cornered the market in yeti aliens with faulty transportation belts, stuck in that ubiquitous Dr Who quarry outside Reading. It wasn't until TV's Planet Of The Apes, however, that we gained a serious appreciation of actors looming about in 24-tog ape-insulation, hairy fingertips brushing the ground.
fields.body:
Men dressed as scary animals have an illustrious history on television. In the curly-wurly 70s, the BBC cornered the market in yeti aliens with faulty transportation belts, stuck in that ubiquitous Dr Who quarry outside Reading. It wasn't until TV's Planet Of The Apes, however, that we gained a serious appreciation of actors looming about in 24-tog ape-insulation, hairy fingertips brushing the ground.

The ape suit remains an icon of supreme pathos. There's an artist who dresses in one in order to demonstrate the impossibility of human communication. Or something along those lines. Football mascots, roaming along touchlines dressed as purple dinosaurs, touching children and clapping manic paws before an indifferent crowd, exude the deepest aura of sadness.

Into the perilous arena of dressing up as a shag-pile carpet comes Neanderthal (tonight, 9pm, Channel 4), a big new series set in the tundra of the Côe d'Azur 35,000 years ago. "They dominated Europe, ravaged by ice ages and stalked by wild animals," the voice-over begins, sounding like a trail for a Tony Scott movie. "Until they faced the ultimate challenge. The arrival of another species."

Neanderthal is gripping stuff. Gone are the days of historical recreation as a series of fast-cut stills of clashing spears - the TV equivalent of finger-puppet theatre. In Neanderthal, we're faced with nothing short of an entire race of Linda Blairs from The Exorcist, features hideously deformed in the name of historical accuracy.

Whether Neanderthal actually is accurate (or just another snuff movie à la Walking With Dinosaurs, panned by academics) remains to be seen. The make-up is impressive, the mise en scène far superior to a school trip tramping round plastic campfires at The Museum Of Mankind. I'd probably even have paid a cinema entrance fee to catch that touching-faces vibe - sadly missing Raquel Welch in a leather miniskirt. I couldn't help feeling, however, a little nostalgic for those shaky stills of the spears.

webTitle: Analysis: Devolution and the national interest

fields.headline: The national interest
fields.standfirst: Now that the Scots and the Welsh have devolution, do the English want it too? Recent surveys suggest the answer is a firm no thank you
fields.trailText: The debate about devolution appears to be facing up at last to the long unanswered question, what to do about England? William Hague declares that only English MPs should vote on English laws at Westminster. Meanwhile, the junior trade minister, Richard Caborn, urges his party to speed up plans for English regional devolution.
fields.body:
The debate about devolution appears to be facing up at last to the long unanswered question, what to do about England? William Hague declares that only English MPs should vote on English laws at Westminster. Meanwhile, the junior trade minister, Richard Caborn, urges his party to speed up plans for English regional devolution.

So what does England itself make of it all? According to new evidence from the latest British Social Attitudes survey, the answer is not much. People in England are happy for Scotland and Wales to have their own parliament or assembly but see no need of the same for themselves. As yet at least, the Conservatives have failed to make a political tide out of English nationalism. Whatever the illogicality of the present devolution settlement, England itself seems happy for the English question to remain unanswered.

With devolution in Scotland and Wales now an accomplished fact, few people in England continue to oppose it. Even at the 1997 general election only around a quarter of people in England opposed the idea of their near neighbours being allowed some form of home rule. Now just 13% of people in England oppose the creation of a Scottish parliament while 15% take the same view about a Welsh assembly.

But when asked whether they would like devolution for themselves, the answer appears to be a polite, but firm "no thanks". No less than 62% say that England should be governed as it is now, with laws made by the UK parliament. Just 18% believe that England as a whole should have its own parliament with law-making powers in similar vein to the Scottish parliament. And only 15% agree that "each region of England should have its own assembly that runs services like health", a form of devolution that would be similar to that enjoyed by Wales.

So, there is little sign here that resentment at the continued role of Scots MPs in the passage of English legislation is likely to prove a successful rallying cry for Mr Hague. Indeed, despite the lack of Conservative MPs from Scotland or Wales, the Conservative party still has some way to go before it is seen as an English rather than a British institution. Well over half of people in England still regard the Conservative party as at least as much a British as an English party.

True, rather more people (36%) regard the Conservatives as predominantly or wholly English than think the same of Labour (19%). But those who think of themselves as English rather than British are no more likely to say they support the Conservatives than are those who think of themselves as British rather than English - or indeed those who simply think of themselves as being a mixture of the two.

In short the Conservatives show no sign as yet of actually winning over the votes of those who might be thought of as "English nationalists". Mr Hague's apparent failure in this regard is perhaps particularly surprising given that those who are wont to describe themselves as English rather than British are distinctively Eurosceptic. For example around three-quarters of those who describe themselves as English want no truck with the euro, compared with only just over half of those who say they are British.

English nationalists also take a rather less liberal view about immigrants and ethnic minorities. No less than seven in ten believe that immigrants take jobs away from people that were born in Britain compared with little more than one in three of those who think of themselves as British. The Commission for Racial Equality recently got into hot water for suggesting that Britishness was associated with racism. It might in fact have been on safer ground if it had made the same charge of Englishness.

But if there is little sign as yet that devolution has become a rallying call in England, there are some indications that more people in England are now more willing to think of themselves as English rather than British. As recently as 1997 just 7% said they thought they were "English, not British". Now that figure has risen to 17%.

It still pales by comparison with the 32% of Scots who think of themselves as "Scottish, not British", but there are perhaps signs here that at least some people are coming to feel that being English and being British are not necessarily one and the same thing. There is an interesting regional dimension to this, picked up in a BBC survey - see the chart - published in the first of a series of regional monitoring reports supported by the Economic and Social Research Council.

People who think of themselves as being English rather than British show some signs of being less insistent on the maintenance of the Union. They are more likely to back independence for Scotland and Wales than are people in England in general. They are also less likely to express regret at the possibility that Scotland might one day become independent.

Here then perhaps is a small warning sign for those who wish to maintain the Union. If England becomes more aware of its Englishness it may be happy to see the rest of the UK slip away, allowing England to be governed as at present. For the moment that remains a distant prospect. Even among English nationalists 59% still believe the government should do everything it can to keep Britain together in a single state.

 John Curtice is deputy director of the ESRC Centre for Research into Elections and Social Trends.

webTitle: Arts: Rada's new lease

fields.headline: Dickie's delight
fields.standfirst: Richard Attenborough is overjoyed with Rada's new home. Jonathan Glancey pays tribute to a ravishing refurbishment
fields.trailText: Richard Attenborough is overjoyed with Rada's new home. Jonathan Glancey pays tribute to a ravishing refurbishment.
fields.body:
At any one time there may be several dramas being played out on the stages of the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (Rada), in London's old university quarter. But few will be quite so satisfying as the rebuilding of Rada itself, a project that has taken 16 years and demanded infinite patience of its architect, Bryan Avery.

Act one of this behind-the-scenes drama opened in 1984, when Rada considered a move to the much vaunted King's Cross redevelopment area. Its old home, at 62-64 Gower Street, was impossibly cramped and outdated, and King's Cross promised generous space around a new urban park. But the property market crashed soon after and King's Cross sank back into the urban twilight.

Act two was a proposed move to a redundant power station in Hoxton. Given how fashionable this part of London has become recently, it could have been a shrewd move. But where was the money to come from? Rada has never been flush with cash. The very survival of this famous and deeply democratic school has been something of a miracle.

"By the beginning of the 1990s," says Lord Attenborough, Rada's chairman of the past 30 years, "we were almost insolvent and the building was getting a bit wobbly. We were bombed out in May '41. I was a Rada student on firewatch duty at the time. The next day those of us who hadn't yet been called up to fight came in and swept up.

"There was this utterly magical moment when this extraordinary figure in plus-fours and a long white beard came down the stairs, looked at us, and said in a soft Irish lilt, 'We're reopening.' That was George Bernard Shaw, still our most important patron through the financial legacy he left us." Come Heinkel, Dornier or V1, Rada's show went on.

Act three marked the arrival of Dame Fortune in the guise of, first, National Lottery money and, second, the purchase of nearby buildings at Chenis Street. Even without moving, there would be enough space to shape an academy fit for the 21st century. That there are new demands is not in question.

Today's graduates are as likely to be doing voiceovers for commercials or playing character parts in TV dramas as treading the boards reciting Shakespeare. Here, in the new-look academy opened by the Queen last week, students learn every aspect of their craft, from selling tickets and acting as usherettes to putting on the greasepaint and stepping into the limelight.

The rebuilt site is a model of dramatic constraint. It has fronts on two streets - Malet and Gower - and yet, although essentially a long and narrow construction, it is awash with daylight and never once feels claustrophobic. It is almost hard to fathom just how Avery has squeezed so much accommodation into so tight a site.

There are three theatres (admittedly two of them very small), a public café, an abundance of classrooms, rehearsal rooms and dressing rooms. There are big, factory-like workshops for making stage scenery, a TV and radio studio, places for students to perch when learning lines. The academy is as densely packaged as the human body it frames. Yet everywhere there are slits, slants and chutes of light, cut-outs through stairwells together with a lightwell in the heart of the building, that make this compact package of brick, concrete, steel, timber and glass a relaxed and easy place to be.

"I love the way Bryan has kept a sense of our history throughout the building," says Attenborough, pointing out the academy's two bronzes of Shaw by Epstein and Rodin. "It's nearly all new, but it feels like a familiar friend already."

You see the mix of past and present at its best in the new Jerwood Vanbrugh Theatre (designed by Avery with Iain Mackintosh's Theatre Projects Consultants), which replaces the bigger, but less workable Vanbrugh Theatre built here in 1954.

This superb, 200-seat, multi-purpose space for teaching, rehearsals and social events as well as performances may well be ultra-modern, yet its provenance is not too hard to recognise: in proportion, dimension and spirit, this is the ideal theatre that Inigo Jones designed for Sir William Davenport in 1683. In essence, its form is two spheres - stage and auditorium - that intersect at the proscenium. The result is a small theatre that still feels grand and ennobling for both actors and audience.

It is also an architectural expression of Rada's core values: 34 lucky students among the thousands auditioned between November and June each year come here to learn how to become professional actors, all of them able to perform the classics whether they end up as stand-up comics or screen villains in years to come. Here, tradition and modernity are reflected in both the course and its architecture.

The fact that Avery's building is so very open in feel and spirit is another clue to the way Rada works. It is an astonishingly open institution and, as a result, a difficult one to fund day-to-day. "We take students from any background aged up to 30 in our acting and stage management courses," says Nick Barter, Rada's director.

"Once we've offered them a place, we fund them. Other independent colleges accept high numbers of students from overseas whose families are able to pay the fees, which are inevitably high in central London. This is unfortunate because it relates talent to wealth. We just get on the phone - Dickie Attenborough, the students themselves, all of us - and find the money somehow or other. We have one student who has 30 individual sponsors."

This shaky financial set-up, although rather ridiculous given the extent to which Rada contributes to the successes of cinema, showbiz and media, does keep this premier dramatic academy on the edge of its seat. It makes for a sharp, responsive, highly intelligent institution. Now, with £22.5m from the Arts Council Lottery Fund and £8m from private and other donations underpinning the new building, at least its physical setting is certain.

The money has also bought a new 17,000-volume library, a student refectory and other classrooms in recently purchased outbuildings along the road. Most of all, it has kept this institution where it belongs - on the site where it was born almost a century ago.

You see the mix of past and present at its best in the new Jerwood Vanbrugh Theatre (designed by Avery with Iain Mackintosh's Theatre Projects Consultants), which replaces the bigger, but less workable Vanbrugh Theatre built here in 1954. This superb, 200-seat, multi-purpose space for teaching, rehearsals and social events as well as performances may well be ultra-modern, yet its provenance is not too hard to recognise: in proportion, dimension and spirit, this is the ideal theatre that Inigo Jones designed for Sir William Davenport in 1683. In essence, its form is two spheres - stage and auditorium - that intersect at the proscenium. The result is a small theatre that still feels grand and ennobling for both actors and audience. It is also an architectural expression of Rada's core values: 34 lucky students among the thousands auditioned between November and June each year come here to learn how to become professional actors, all of them able to perform the classics whether they end up as stand-up comics or screen villains in years to come. Here, tradition and modernity are reflected in both the course and its architecture. The fact that Avery's building is so very open in feel and spirit is another clue to the way Rada works. It is an astonishingly open institution and, as a result, a difficult one to fund day-to-day. "We take students from any background aged up to 30 in our acting and stage management courses," says Nick Barter, Rada's director. "Once we've offered them a place, we fund them. Other independent colleges accept high numbers of students from overseas whose families are able to pay the fees, which are inevitably high in central London. This is unfortunate because it relates talent to wealth. We just get on the phone - Dickie Attenborough, the students themselves, all of us - and find the money somehow or other. We have one student who has 30 individual sponsors." This shaky financial set-up, although rather ridiculous given the extent to which Rada contributes to the successes of cinema, showbiz and media, does keep this premier dramatic academy on the edge of its seat. It makes for a sharp, responsive, highly intelligent institution. Now, with £22.5m from the Arts Council Lottery Fund and £8m from private and other donations underpinning the new building, at least its physical setting is certain. The money has also bought a new 17,000-volume library, a student refectory and other classrooms in recently purchased outbuildings along the road. Most of all, it has kept this institution where it belongs - on the site where it was born almost a century ago.

webTitle: Women: The passion for fencing

fields.headline: The feel of steel
fields.standfirst: She has won a string of prestigious literary awards in her Australian homeland, but nothing compares to the thrill Helen Garner got when she carried off a bronze medal for fencing. Here she explains why
fields.trailText: She has won a string of prestigious literary awards in her Australian homeland, but nothing compares to the thrill Helen Garner got when she carried off a bronze medal for fencing. Here she explains why
fields.body:
One day in 1958, when I was a small 15-year-old bookworm, a Hungarian wandered into our provincial girls' school, offering fencing lessons. Frantic to avoid the brutality of hockey, I volunteered.

Mr Fadgyas had fenced in the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. He was terribly impressive, but also funny, sweet and patient. We loved and respected him. When he met our mothers, he clicked his heels and kissed their hands. He was a hard-working immigrant in a tracksuit, but to me he would always be a European nobleman - a hero in white jacket, mask and glove.

What he taught was a way of formalising aggression and defence, of making fighting beautiful. The aggression in me was deeply buried. Though I was quick on my feet, I was scared - not of getting hurt, but of attacking. I could learn the moves in class, but in competition I went to water. Once I left home for university, I never picked up a foil again.

Until last July, when I spotted a flyer at the library: "Fencing for Older Adults." Something stirred. I pulled on my trainers and drove to the industrial backstreet of inner Melbourne where the Victorian Amateur Fencing Association has its HQ, on the upper level of a huge warehouse. I clanged up the fire escape and found a vast, bare, white space, daylit through the glass of a sawtooth roof. The whole floor was a line of pistes, the raised 14-metre strips on which bouts are fought. There was nobody around. It had the weird, alluring stillness of a place devoted to a formal discipline.

Four women turned up to learn. The teacher, Ernie, a chunky 70-year-old in glasses and grey tracksuit, was no Hungarian. I was disappointed, until he seized a foil, raised both arms and fell with easy grace into the en garde position. To see that movement can take your breath away - the authority of it, the quiet readiness.

He gave out masks and I pulled one on. The smell of cold wire shot up my nose, so familiar that I thought I was going to faint. "Pick up the foil lightly," said Ernie, "not with a battle-axe grip!" It fitted my hand as if I'd laid it down yesterday. He saluted us: heels together, foil to the nose and down to the floor. When he called out: "En garde!" my body dropped into the posture of its own accord. I was hooked.

After our third lesson, another woman and I sneaked on to the piste. We shaped up. I went for her. She blocked me. I went again. Adrenalin poured through me. I wanted to attack, to be attacked, to have to fight back. The lunges, the sliding clash of metal, the way the sword hand rises as the foil-tip hits the target - it was glorious.

We both burst out laughing. We stopped only because she didn't have a glove: I almost struck her hand and she flinched. We lowered the blades. She pulled off her mask. Her eyes were bright, but I saw with a shock how gentle her face was, how feminine, under the cloud of hair.

Before the Sydney Games, Olympic fencers from all over the world trained at our Melbourne warehouse. I crouched against a wall, in awe of their speed and power. The way the women screamed as they attacked, like wild beasts at the kill, was unbearably thrilling.

Our modest lessons continued weekly. I was vain about the little bruises, like snakebites, on my inner arms. But when the state competition came up, I panicked. I did my level best to wimp out. "I've been sick," I whined to Ernie. "I've missed three classes." He shamed me into a catch-up lesson. "You may be swift," he said sternly, as I stood masked, gloved and panting in his garage, "but you've got to learn to retreat. Retire! Retreat! Retreat! And eat carbohydrates!"

On the day, the air was humid, the mercury sat on 30. As I climbed the warehouse stairs, I could hear the scampering and the thuds, the cries of protest and triumph, the raised voices of the referees, the soft rhythmic beeping of the electronic scorers. The young fencers, some of them Olympians, sorted each other out, received their medals and went home, trundling great buggies of equipment.

Now it was the veterans' turn, a handful of us, mostly well over 50. I knew the others from the class above me, where in practice bouts they all routinely beat me. The wild card was an unknown 45-year-old bloke from a mountain club, heavy-limbed and determined.

I was called. Already dripping in five layers of cotton, synthetic, plastic, metal and leather, I stepped up and plugged the scoring lead into my foil. The mask was heavier than the practice one, its wire darker, its holes smaller, its bib more spongily padded. Oh God. How would I breathe in here? Sweat began to trickle through my hair. I wasn't scared I'd get hurt, but I expected to be soundly thrashed.

At first I was. My ears muffled by padding, I couldn't understand why the curly-haired young referee kept mouthing and gesturing at me. I thought he was rebuking me for something I was doing wrong. I tore off my mask and he looked at me with a crooked smile. "I'm telling you," he said, in the clear, slow voice one uses to a simpleton, " who won each point, and why."

The first penny of the day dropped with a mighty clang. I uttered a crazed laugh and yanked the mask back on. En garde!

I was beaten. I won a bout. I lost again. I faced the huge guy from the mountains. He was like a Sherman tank. He came at me with his blade down low and his left hand dangling loosely at shoulder level. I couldn't deal with the bulk of him, his steady, relentless advance. I forgot about "Retreat! Retire!" and brandished my feeble blade in his face. He swatted me off like a mosquito. He wiped me out. I shook his hand in bliss.

The longer we fenced, the cooler my head became. I felt daring. I didn't care if I lost, but I went all out to win. My mind, normally so scattered and fleeting, tuned itself to my body. I grasped for the first time in my life what tactical thinking might be, how I could vary my attacks, feint and wait and spring a surprise. I saw, in a series of bright flashes, what was required, what I might one day be capable of, if I stuck at this.

I was panting, gasping, sweating. I felt like a million dollars. I could have kept going all day and all night. Between bouts I guzzled water but I was too excited to sit down. I paced around with the mask under my arm. I leaned against the fire escape door to get a breath of air. I was streaming with joy.

And I won a medal. A bronze medal on a long blue ribbon. Typing this, I've still got it on. The maître d'armes (a woman) presented each of us with champagne and yellow roses. Ernie made me eat a muesli bar. We all, even the victorious monster from the mountains, kissed and shook hands. I laughed and cried all the way home.

I'm different since that day. I feel taller, stronger, freer. Suddenly I understand why people scramble and strain in mud on winter Saturdays. The devotion and patience of coaches, their severe heartening - all this is clear to me now. I see the point of sport. At last, at last, I get it.

The language of fencing is old French, beautiful and austere. Ernie uses the phrase le sentiment de fer. The feel of steel. That's what I want. I am learning to fight, but not in the ordinary wretched way of the worst of my personal life - desperate, ragged, emotional. I've found an ancient discipline, with formal control and purpose. I'm 58. Will my body hold out? I hope it's not too late.

webTitle: G2: The Tweenies

fields.headline: Move over Tinky-Winky
fields.standfirst: With millions of pre-school fans and a tour that's outselling Robbie Williams, the Tweenies are like the Teletubbies - only bigger. So who is behind the new fuzzy faces on the block? Matt Seaton investigates
fields.trailText: With millions of pre-school fans and a tour that's outselling Robbie Williams, the Tweenies are like the Teletubbies - only bigger. So who is behind the new fuzzy faces on the block? Matt Seaton investigates.
fields.body:
Britain is in the grip of a new "fab four" fever. Wherever you look - in the singles chart, on clothes racks, in video shops, on Christmas-tree decorations - there are the outsize-booted, fuzzy-faced figures of Milo, Jake, Bella and Fizz: the Tweenies.

The BBC's hit follow-up to Teletubbies, the Tweenies has become such a spectacular success with its pre-school audience that tickets for its live Christmas show have outsold Britney Spears and Robbie Williams. The Tweenies' "UK tour", which opens on Boxing Day, is on target to sell 300,000 tickets. Its single - aspirationally titled Number One - went straight into the charts at number 6 before it was even getting played. (It is a maddeningly catchy, utterly anodyne tune - but when did cynicism ever stop a pop hit?)

When the Tweenies appeared in Birmingham recently to switch on the Christmas lights, they were mobbed by 12,000 screaming infant fans. The organisers, who had expected a turnout similar to last year's sedate crowd of 2,000 pensioners listening to Cliff Richard singing carols, hardly knew what had hit them.

With sales exceeding £110m, revenues from the series have already overhauled what Teletubbies made in its first year. Tinky-Winky, Laa-Laa and friends have gone on to pull in over £1bn in worldwide merchandising sales (of which about £90m has come back to the BBC in royalties), but the Tweenies are catching up fast: by the end of last month, 1.7m Tweenies videos and 800,000 books had been sold in the UK; the website gets 1m hits a month, and the twice-daily programme broadcasts to audiences of 2m.

It has been reported that the second word used by Brooklyn Beckham (that ultimate arbiter of what's hot in pre-school popular culture) after "mum" was not "dad" - devoted and doting father though Becks evidently is - but "Tweenies".

A fair few column inches have been expended on the Teletubbies vs Tweenies debate ("which does your child prefer?"), but the opposition is bogus: both are BBC products, designed to appeal to different age groups.

"The furore over Teletubbies made people watch children's TV again," says one of the Tweenies' makers. "Teletubbies revealed something that most children's TV makers were not aware of, which is that there are actually layers within the pre-school age group.

"Teletubbies was initially intended to span the whole age range, but it actually appealed to kids up to the age of two, two-and-a-half. And suddenly there was this hole - I think that was a revelation to most people.

"And that was where Tweenies came in - to fill that gap for three- to five-year-olds."

Kids' TV used to be presenter-led: the model for programme-making was top-down paternalism (remember Playschool and its successor Playdays?). Teletubbies radically dispensed with that format by fronting the show with four multi-coloured, proto-linguistic aliens, with TV screens where their tummy-buttons should have been.

The Tweenies develops the new formula by creating more strongly characterised muppet-type figures who are, in attitude and effect, kids - just like their four- and five-year-old viewers. Bella is the oldest and - like the Rugrats' Angelica - the bossiest; frizzy-haired Milo is football-mad; Fizz is a girlie girl, into pink and dancing; and mohican-sporting Jake is the youngest of the gang. The quartet have a dog named Doodles for company, while two adult carers, Max and Judy, keep a discreet distance.

Tweenies is a peer-group drama, offering its audience the straightforward reward of identification, while each episode's plot is written as a kind of kindergarten soap - that is its genius. Just add some "skin actors" with strong calf muscles to goof about in the hefty cartoon-sized trainers, and some clever animatronics for their faces, et voilà ... the Tweenies!

So just who is behind our new fuzzy-faced friends? The short answer is Dame Trot and an Ugly Sister. Iain Lauchlan and Will Brenton are two former jobbing actors and panto veterans. For 11 consecutive years (up to and including last year), the pair wrote, directed and starred in the Christmas pantomime at Coventry's Belgrade Theatre - experience which has proved invaluable (and extremely lucrative) in devising the Tweenies' arena show. I met the duo recently at their offices at Elstree studios in Hertfordshire.

Brenton, the younger at 38, with a goatee and long, flowing hair, seems the more dynamic, dominant partner of the duo, taking the lead in answering questions.

Lauchlan, 48, is a curly-haired Scot with a round, friendly face. He had originally started training as a surveyor in Glasgow, before applying to drama school. "I gave up a good career for this," he quips. He got his break and moved south when he landed a couple of parts in the Play for Today series. In one of them his sidekick was a young Pierce Brosnan.

"I bet he's kicking himself now," kids Brenton.

"Yes, what's he done since?" says Lauchlan, with a falsetto giggle that seems to belong to Dame Trot.

The pair first met in the late 80s, when working as presenters on the BBC's Playdays. Presenting children's television was good, steady work, but the sector was seen as a graveyard for an actor with serious ambitions. There are unexpected compensations now - besides the success of Tweenies - because Lauchlan still gets bought drinks in pubs when he is recognised as the actor who did Fingermouse (an 80s remake of Fingerbobs), but in those days it was no joke.

"That feeling of it being second-rate entertainment was always there," says Lauchlan. "It was a struggle. I loved doing presenting and financially it was rewarding, but to be taken seriously you really wanted to do the acting - the theatre and the telly."

Brenton ensured that he diversified: appearing in Blood Brothers in the West End while presenting Playdays. He learned to direct, and went on to direct episodes of Emmerdale Farm and Coronation Street. But children's TV was, it seems, their destiny. The duo had made a successful video, Fun Song Factory, under the aegis of Tell-Tale, but both agree that the crucial event in their careers was external: in a word, Teletubbies.

The Teletubbies phenomenon meant that, for the first time, the Beeb had serious money to invest in a children's series: the Tweenies' first run of 260 episodes was fully funded to the tune of £7.4m. But Tell-Tale had to pitch against more than a dozen others to win the commission.

The vital ingredient in their programme-making philosophy was that children are not "some weird alien breed" but have essentially the same tastes and interests as grown-ups, so their television should be modelled on adult drama: character-based and story-led.

"We looked around and saw kids' programmes with green dinosaurs and purple dragons and thought, 'We don't want to do that,' " Brenton recalls. "Instead we asked what we watched as adults, and it is soaps and sitcoms - so why don't we do a programme where we give pre-school children their peers on screen?

"That was the entire basis: four kids in a room - it was the shortest TV proposal ever."

"It was actually five kids," interjects Lauchlan.

"That's right," concedes Brenton. "There was one who didn't quite make the cut. He was called Sid."

Poor old Sid.

"That's showbusiness."

It certainly is. Tell-Tale's publicist will not be drawn on the nature of its deal with the BBC, other than to say that it "enjoys a healthy percentage split of all profits and ancillary activity". One of Tell-Tale's four partners (Brenton and Lauchlan being the creative team), managing director Karl Woolley, is happy to concede that they are all "well on the way to becoming millionaires". Of course, when you look at the numbers, it's a no-brainer.

"A lot of people are becoming very wealthy off kids' TV. There's no doubt about it," confesses Brenton. "But that doesn't mean kids' TV is therefore all bad. That's one of the battles we constantly have: 'We do Tweenies.' 'Oh, yeah: you're making a fortune.' 'Well, no, we think we make a very good programme.'"

Brenton and Lauchlan are keen to emphasise that the Tweenies had to fulfil a tight brief from the BBC, including educational content. In fairness, the Tweenies has never been subjected to the kind of controversial scrutiny that accompanied the launch of the Teletubbies, with headlines about the dumbing-down of kids' TV.

"I think people live busier lives. Cynicism aside," argues Brenton, "it's very useful to have something you can put on the television that will entertain and educate your child."

So where next for the Tweenies - a movie?

"Could do," says Brenton, hamming the tight-lipped executive.

So have they started writing it?

"Might have."

"Milo might get his own show," speculates Brenton, tongue-in-cheek. "A chat show. It's got to do at least as well as Wogan."

The folk in Light Entertainment had better watch out. Children's television has truly come of age.

 The Tweenies is on weekday mornings on BBC2 and afternoons on BBC1.

"I gave up a good career for this," he quips. He got his break and moved south when he landed a couple of parts in the Play for Today series. In one of them his sidekick was a young Pierce Brosnan. "I bet he's kicking himself now," kids Brenton. "Yes, what's he done since?" says Lauchlan, with a falsetto giggle that seems to belong to Dame Trot. The pair first met in the late 80s, when working as presenters on the BBC's Playdays. Presenting children's television was good, steady work, but the sector was seen as a graveyard for an actor with serious ambitions. There are unexpected compensations now - besides the success of Tweenies - because Lauchlan still gets bought drinks in pubs when he is recognised as the actor who did Fingermouse (an 80s remake of Fingerbobs), but in those days it was no joke. "That feeling of it being second-rate entertainment was always there," says Lauchlan. "It was a struggle. I loved doing presenting and financially it was rewarding, but to be taken seriously you really wanted to do the acting - the theatre and the telly." Brenton ensured that he diversified: appearing in Blood Brothers in the West End while presenting Playdays. He learned to direct, and went on to direct episodes of Emmerdale Farm and Coronation Street. But children's TV was, it seems, their destiny. The duo had made a successful video, Fun Song Factory, under the aegis of Tell-Tale, but both agree that the crucial event in their careers was external: in a word, Teletubbies. The Teletubbies phenomenon meant that, for the first time, the Beeb had serious money to invest in a children's series: the Tweenies' first run of 260 episodes was fully funded to the tune of £7.4m. But Tell-Tale had to pitch against more than a dozen others to win the commission. The vital ingredient in their programme-making philosophy was that children are not "some weird alien breed" but have essentially the same tastes and interests as grown-ups, so their television should be modelled on adult drama: character-based and story-led. "We looked around and saw kids' programmes with green dinosaurs and purple dragons and thought, 'We don't want to do that,' " Brenton recalls. "Instead we asked what we watched as adults, and it is soaps and sitcoms - so why don't we do a programme where we give pre-school children their peers on screen? "That was the entire basis: four kids in a room - it was the shortest TV proposal ever." "It was actually five kids," interjects Lauchlan. "That's right," concedes Brenton. "There was one who didn't quite make the cut. He was called Sid." Poor old Sid. "That's showbusiness." It certainly is. Tell-Tale's publicist will not be drawn on the nature of its deal with the BBC, other than to say that it "enjoys a healthy percentage split of all profits and ancillary activity". One of Tell-Tale's four partners (Brenton and Lauchlan being the creative team), managing director Karl Woolley, is happy to concede that they are all "well on the way to becoming millionaires". Of course, when you look at the numbers, it's a no-brainer. "A lot of people are becoming very wealthy off kids' TV. There's no doubt about it," confesses Brenton. "But that doesn't mean kids' TV is therefore all bad. That's one of the battles we constantly have: 'We do Tweenies.' 'Oh, yeah: you're making a fortune.' 'Well, no, we think we make a very good programme.'" Brenton and Lauchlan are keen to emphasise that the Tweenies had to fulfil a tight brief from the BBC, including educational content. In fairness, the Tweenies has never been subjected to the kind of controversial scrutiny that accompanied the launch of the Teletubbies, with headlines about the dumbing-down of kids' TV. "I think people live busier lives. Cynicism aside," argues Brenton, "it's very useful to have something you can put on the television that will entertain and educate your child." So where next for the Tweenies - a movie? "Could do," says Brenton, hamming the tight-lipped executive. So have they started writing it? "Might have." "Milo might get his own show," speculates Brenton, tongue-in-cheek. "A chat show. It's got to do at least as well as Wogan." The folk in Light Entertainment had better watch out. Children's television has truly come of age.  The Tweenies is on weekday mornings on BBC2 and afternoons on BBC1.

webTitle: Women: The age of dissent

fields.headline: Hands off!
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson: For some of us, the new-style indiscriminate kissing and hugging is rather a worry. And now the festive season is looming, it will be partying, kissing, squeezing, back rubbing/slapping and embracing ad nauseam.
fields.body:
For some of us, the new-style indiscriminate kissing and hugging is rather a worry. And now the festive season is looming, it will be partying, kissing, squeezing, back rubbing/slapping and embracing ad nauseam. My friend Valerie gave up on kissing several years ago at her mother's Christmas party. Her mother kissed goodbye scores of guests she hardly knew, but she did not kiss Valerie, her own child.

Fielding also has problems with physical contact. Is it an innocent greeting, or is it a sexual advance? He hasn't a clue. He wasn't brought up to be touchy-feely. More untouchy-thinky. "Has it crippled us?" he asks poignantly.

Who knows, but all this no-touching business can be dangerous. If Rosemary and I are negotiating a treacherous bit of slippy mud on our dog walk, there is no possible way that we can hold hands for balance. So we often sway about alone and fall while the other stands helplessly by. Not touching.

Last week, the no-touching was almost fatal. Rosemary and her Auntie were on their way to hospital and as they tottered down the stone front steps, with Auntie hooked safely on to the railings and also supported by her stick, Rosemary lost her footing and slid past Auntie, losing her shoe on the way.

Auntie bent to pick the shoe up, began to topple and Rosemary had to break her taboo and grab hold of Auntie before there was a frightful accident. Then they quickly righted themselves, went a bit pink and staggered to the car. Separately.

We find it even more difficult if the kissing/touching person is familiar. Strangers are not quite as upsetting. Yesterday my mother and I had our photo taken. We were instructed to hug each other and smile fondly, and the dog was told to go away. What an ordeal. We laughed in a mocking way and just about managed it, but if only we had been allowed to cuddle the dog instead. So much easier.

I think I am still doing rather better than Rosemary and can now kiss without flinching, but Olga is streets ahead of both of us. Last night at a party, I told her about these touching difficulties.

"That is clearly dysfunctional," she said strictly, kissing everyone. "Things have changed. Several decades ago!"

Not for some of us, they haven't.

webTitle: Pru to back £150m fundraising by Cazenove

fields.headline: Pru to back £150m fundraising by Cazenove
fields.trailText: Prudential is expected to be one of the leading backers of a £150m fundraising by blue blooded broker Cazenove ahead of the partnership's stock market flotation in 2002.
fields.body:
Prudential is expected to be one of the leading backers of a £150m fundraising by blue blooded broker Cazenove ahead of the partnership's stock market flotation in 2002.

Along with other "friendly" insurance groups such as Royal & Sun Alliance and AXA, the Pru is likely to be approached by Cazenove about providing financing to the group early in the new year.

Cazenove, which stunned the City last week by announcing plans to end 177 years of partnership, has rarely called in investors from outside the firm. It is thought to be anxious to ensure that any investors will be sympathetic to its business. The firm, which has once of the most desirable contacts books in the City, wants the investors to take a long-term view.

AXA and Royal & Sun Alliance are thought to be among the insurance groups which own debt in Cazenove and they are expected to be called on again by the firm.

Ahead of its planned flotation in 2002, Cazenove will end its partnership by incorporating and thereby end the unlimited liability of its 80 partners. It is then planning to sell around 15% of its shares in the flotation, giving the firm a total valuation of £1.5bn. In the process, Cazenove is expected to appoint its first non-partner directors to its board. The two posts are likely to become some of the most sought after non-executive positions in the City.

The Pru and the other major insurance groups are expected to be invited to back Cazenove's plans to raise £150m ahead of the flotation. David Mayhew, the partner who is to become chairman of the incorporated firm, acts as an adviser to many of these potential investors already. He has been involved in creating some of the firms, such as insurance group CGNU, through mergers. Even though there are doubts about whether Cazenove will maintain its culture of secrecy and loyalty after the partnership has been abandoned, industry sources do not believe Mr Mayhew have problems in finding backers for the fundraising.

Cazenove wants to use the flotation to make it easier to attract staff by offering share options and expand in Europe.

webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Times
fields.body:
Sunday Times

 David Newlands, chairman of the troubled Tomkins conglomerate, wants its ousted founder Greg Hutchings to reimburse the company. He will try and make Mr Hutchings refund the cost of a housekeeper and travel expenses not connected with company business.

 British families are suffering their first drop in wealth for six years, mainly because of the global slump in technology stocks.

 The government has identified David Varney, former BG boss and a Labour supporter, as its preferred candidate to be the next chief executive of Railtrack.

Mail on Sunday

 Rolling Stone Mick Jagger and rock group U2 have banded together to form a £100m offshore investment trust to buy commercial property.

Observer

 Pressure is mounting for the British government to refuse to underwrite the building of the Ilisu dam in Turkey unless there is a huge increase in compensation for people whose homes will be flooded to make way for the project.

 The £2bn Terminal Five at Heathrow airport is poised to get the go ahead in a key report to be presented to the government before Christmas.

 Sol Melia, the Spanish hotels group, is leading a host of international operators and financiers in the £4bn sell-off of Granada Compass hotels.

Sunday Express

 Stuart Prebble, the chief executive of pay-television group ONdigital is being considered as the head of ITV's digital channels.

 Mr Prebble is expected to spearhead ITV2, the websites and any channels ITV might launch.

Sunday Telegraph

 Deutsche Telecom is preparing to scrap the One2One brand after paying £11bn for the fourth largest UK operator last year. It is likely to rename the operation T-Mobile.

 Graham Parr, chief executive of Arena Leisure, which last week won the broadcasting rights for British horseracing, is preparing to step down to seek new challenges.

 Uniq, the convenience foods group formerly called Unigate, is in talks about a possible management buyout worth £650m.

Sunday Business

 Peter Job, chief executive of Reuters, the news and financial information provider, is expected to be succeeded by internal candidate Tom Glocer, who would be the first American to head the company.

 Financier George Soros has taken a substantial stake in Britain's biotechnology fund, International Biotechnology Trust, just days before the trust's advisers are to announce reconstruction proposals.

IoS

 WH Smith, the newsagent and distributor, faces losing its largest contract, worth £150m, amid the row about its plans for a national system of magazine distribution. Frontline, which represents publishers including Emap and Haymarket, wrote to Smith warning that its contract was to be re-tendered for before the end of the year.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Neanderthal man

fields.headline: No: 1774
fields.standfirst: Neanderthal man
fields.trailText: Neanderthal man
fields.body:
I take it this is the latest must-have on the kiddies' Christmas wish-list. No, it's the new Channel 4 two-part drama-documentary series that - through the use of polystyrene, a few short, stocky actors, a national park in Donegal and ...

An empty Fairy Liquid bottle? No, I was going to say "prosthetic makeup" ... attempts to dispel the myth that Neanderthal man was a stooped, hairy ape who communicated only in grunts.

OK, so explain it to me in words of one syllable. Well, the Channel 4 press release describes it as: "A group of seven Neanderthals - old and young, male and female - live in a cave in southern France 35,000 years ago ..."

With hilarious consequences? Hardly. It says here that "both men and women hunt in the bitter cold, covered in animal furs. Back at the cave, they butcher their carcasses and prepare their skins. The cave is their kitchen, bedroom and toilet."

Excellent! So it's like a crazy real-life docusoap-cum-social experiment meets A Year in Provence? Not exactly.

So what's the idea? These chimps go around hunting mammoths and stuff, and at the end of the week we vote for one of them to be thrown into a pit with a sabre-tooth tiger? No, think more Keeping Up Appearances. The series looks at how the Neanderthals deal with the arrival of their new neighbours, the Cro-Magnons.

Pronounced Bouquet? I'll wager.

And there won't be any snogging in the jacuzzi? No, there won't even be a jacuzzi. This is Ice Age Europe, honey, not some specially built fortress in Bow. There won't be any unicycles, assault courses or pretty young madams photocopying their asses. We're talking cave lions, bears, leopards ...

Are you sure this isn't a Channel 5 production? Maybe I should double check.

And is Davina McCall involved at all? No.

Episode two: Ugh has a tough day at the Vic, and Grunt lets Ian Beale know exactly how she feels.

webTitle: G2: Simon Hattenstone meets Peter Hall

fields.headline: Sir Peter's friends
fields.standfirst: Peter Hall's 10-hour Trojan war epic, Tantalus, has been hailed as an artistic triumph. So why did he fall out with its author, John Barton? Simon Hattenstone meets Britain's most distinguished director as he celebrates his 70th birthday
fields.trailText: Peter Hall's 10-hour Trojan war epic, Tantalus, has been hailed as an artistic triumph. So why did he fall out with its author, John Barton? Simon Hattenstone meets Britain's most distinguished director as he celebrates his 70th birthday.
fields.body:
Sir Peter Hall has just celebrated his 70th birthday with a party. He says it was a wonderful night - his friends and colleagues, three out of the four wives, all there to raise a glass to his achievements.

And what achievements - he founded the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1960 and ran the National Theatre for 15 years. Establishment man, radical sore, Thatcher voter, champion of subsidised theatre, he has been all things to all theatre types.

And he shows no sign of slowing down. He has recently directed an avant-garde anal sex extravangaza at the Gate in London, prepared a Simon Gray play for its forthcoming premiere and hogged the strangest of headlines with his Shadow Arts Council. Now he is preparing to bring his Trojan war epic, Tantalus, nine plays for the price of one, to Britain.

This is where we hit sticky ground. Tantalus is not entirely his. It was written, over a period of 17 years, by John Barton, one of Hall's oldest friends and collaborators. But Barton wasn't at the party, nor was he at the world premiere of Tantalus in Denver, Colorado. Barton and Hall are no longer talking.

Sir Peter tucks himself into the table at a swanky London hotel. We are breakfasting. Hall is that kind of man - a busy beast. He looks like Orson Welles playing Falstaff.

In the 60s, Hall was such a dapper man. There is a famous picture of him straddling his stool à la Christine Keeler, striped socks, striped top, drainpipes, foppish shoes. He smiles into the camera, cigar in one hand, ashtray in the other. All soft leather and self-love. If there was a speech bubble it might read: "Hey guys, what would you give to be me?" Even today, the septuagenarian Goth looks as if he fancies himself. I ask him about Tantalus, and he says it's a long story. "I've known John for 50 years. It's not been a very happy experience for me because we've worked together a great deal."

In short, after Hall and Barton could not find a British backer, they came across a Denver benefactor with millions to spare. Hall wanted to cut Tantalus from 15 hours to 10. Barton says he agreed to trim but threw a wobbly when he discovered it was being slashed by Hall behind his back. He walked out on the director and the epic vision that has defined so much of his life, disowned it.

"He sees it as my adaptation, which it is," Hall says. "He said 'I'll cut anything as you well know, it's just that my stuff doesn't need cutting'." Halls smiles. "No, I'm being slightly naughty, but that was the subtext." Hall is supremely urbane, talks gently, compassionately, with daggers on his tongue.

The play was wonderfully reviewed. Poor old John, I say, moping at home, while Hall basks in the glory. He jumps in before the words are out. "What about poor old Peter? My whole life has been dedicated to trying to serve the dramatist, and I went into Tantalus in order to have another collaboration."

Doesn't he feel as if he's kidnapped Barton's baby? " Yesssss ... of course I do. That's at my worst moment. But I don't believe I have. I think I've put on the stage what he was writing about. I think I've put the strength and the quality of it on the stage. No, I'm deeply sorry that he's not happy, but there you are."

It seems like a clash between two monstrous egos. Who has the bigger one? "That's a very difficult question to answer. I suspect I have," he answers, cutting up his bacon with infinite delicacy. But the thing is, he says, theatre is a collaboration, and Barton just wasn't willing to play the game.

"He has an extraordinary belief in his own strengths as a writer. I don't actually think it's healthy ." Hall speaks a clever, coded language, like a Soviet commissar. The suggestion seems to be that his old mate Barton is unstable, bonkers.

He stresses to me that this is a one-off, that he has worked with all the greats and never had problems. "I've had a wonderful relationship with Sam Beckett, Harold Pinter, Peter Shaffer, David Hare. The way I worked with Pinter is that he can say anything he likes about what I'm doing in the rehesarsal in front of the actors and I can say anything I like about the text, but on the text his word is final, and on the production my word is final should there be an absolute dispute. And I have to say, in 11 productions there never has been."

But in the case of Tantalus, Barton's words weren't final? "Absolutely, otherwise I wouldn't have done it."

He says that when they went out to Colorado the play had no beginning or end, just a wonderful nut in the middle. And, ultimately, the fact that he has liberated the nut more than compensates for the negatives. "It was worth it because it worked. The disadvantages were the risk, the pressure ... I was shit scared, really shit scared, because the stakes were enormous. I didn't want to be the person who entered the Guinness Book of Records for the longest flop of all time. And of course, one doesn't like losing a friend, a man one loves." He seems to have the knack of falling out with people. "Such as who?" he demands.

I tell him I have made a list but am prepared to be corrected.

"Well, I doubt that."

Funnily enough, the first name on the list is Pinter.

"I didn't fall out with Pinter. Harold Pinter fell out with me."

I half expect him to stick his tongue out and go: nanananana. "He thought my diaries treated him with insufficient tact, and he didn't speak to me for about five years. Then one morning I had a letter from him saying 'life's too short, come and have lunch'. And we're firm friends again ... Tell me of this long list."

What about Bill Kenwright, the impresario who bankrolled Hall's attempt to bring high art to the West End? "Oh, absolutely I fell out with Bill Kenwright. He asked me to do something which I found morally reprehensible ."

The V on Hall's forehead becomes more pronounced. It's not so much a receding hairline, as a receding head line. "He asked me to walk out on a production in its last days. I thought it was very naughty ... Be careful with your lawyers, Bill is very litigious."

As he has fallen out with people professionally, so he has privately. Few recent decades have not seen him trade in a wife for a newer model, from the actress Leslie Caron to his personal assistant Jacqueline Taylor, to the opera singer Maria Ewing, and finally to number four, Nicki Frei, to whom he has been happily married for 10 years.

Hall's youngest daughter, eight-year-old Emma, recently asked why he has so many wives. He says he tried to explain to her the complexity of relationships; how for him if they are not all good, they tend to be all bad. "I just tried to tell her what a healthy marriage was ... you have to be happy with each other and if you were unhappy it didn't do either of you any good, and it didn't do the children any good ... She has met all the other children, she has seen all the other wives and she likes all the other wives."

He loves talking about the kids, being a father to young children for 43 years, how proud he is now that most have joined him in the profession, the funny little stories from a complicated domestic history. "Recently Emma was chosen to sing in the choir. I said you have got, really, a nice voice, and she said, 'I've probably got it from Maria! Hehehehehe!"

I tell him I have a daughter of a similar age. He doesn't seem to hear. He tells me how proud he is of his son, Edward, who is directing three of the Tantalus plays. Edward was a bit of a rebel, decided not to go to Oxbridge, opted for somwhere real, like Leeds, before dropping out after two terms. Oh, I say, I went to Leeds. Hall doesn't seem to hear. He tells me how, finally, he is once again close to the wives, how he has loved them all, in different ways.

Hall once said that making love to a woman is the closest most men will get to being an artist. He nods in recognition. Does he regard himself as a bedroom artist? "That's a really good question that is, isn't it? Hehehehe! If you say yes ... hehehe! Ah, yes that's a clever one. I think the words I would apply to the creative arts - integrity, vision, tenderness, warmth, compassion, surprise, shock, perhaps even violence - can all apply to that area."

For a second, he verges on the coy. He nips modestly at his sausage. So is he a good lover? "I've not ever been worried in that area." Ah, that's more like it. Anyway, back to more important matters - he wants more names on the list. Well there is Mick Gordon, the director who also walked out of Tantalus. Hall puts on his best bereaved face. "Mick Gordon's a very, very talented young guy. He did extraordinary work on Tantalus, a lot of research work."

The more he praises, the more I wait for the dagger. "He appeared to be tremendously happy. There wasn't any dispute." He explains how Gordon returned to Britain for a weekend, said 'see you Monday', and that was the last they saw of him. "On Monday a fax arrived from him saying he wasn't coming back, he wasn't happy."

And Gordon had never told him before? "On my father's grave, not a word. At the time he had three plays under his total control. After about eight weeks, I had a letter from him saying one day he'd like to explain. He said he thought the manner of his going was wrong."

What about the Shadow Arts Council debacle? Last year he set up the body to oppose the government's approach to funding. He had been a bit premature hadn't he? " I hadn't. Someone else had. They sent out the letters and it was a bit of a cock up, and the department spun themselves to death."

He says that, actually, the Shadow Arts Council has been fantastically successful, has really made the department of culture sit up and take notice. So all those who railed against their inclusion are now back on the council? "Tom is. I can't remember if Harrison's back on. It was a load of rubbish, all that. They were both at my party on Sunday."

Sir Peter is rushing for a train. He puts on his black coat and black cap and scurries off, legs going all ways, like a hyperactive beetle.

The following day his press officer rings up. She has been having a chat with Sir Peter and he thought it might be helpful for me to see the guest list for his 70th birthday do. A few minutes later, an email arrives.

"Simon, this is the list as promised. It was a wonderfully warm, affectionate evening with old friends and family. If a bomb had dropped on the Ivy on Sunday night it would have wiped out a lot of the theatrical establishment!

Harold Pinter, Tom Stoppard, Richard Eyre, Trevor Nunn, Alan Ayckbourn, Simon Gray. David Hare, Nicole Farhi, Maggie Smith, Judi Dench, Felicity Kendal, Jane Asher, Gerald Scarfe, Harrison Birtwistle, Maria Ewing, Elaine Paige, Michael Rudman, John Gunter, Michael Birkett. And all the children."
fields.bodyText: Sir Peter Hall has just celebrated his 70th birthday with a party. He says it was a wonderful night - his friends and colleagues, three out of the four wives, all there to raise a glass to his achievements. And what achievements - he founded the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1960 and ran the National Theatre for 15 years. Establishment man, radical sore, Thatcher voter, champion of subsidised theatre, he has been all things to all theatre types. And he shows no sign of slowing down. He has recently directed an avant-garde anal sex extravangaza at the Gate in London, prepared a Simon Gray play for its forthcoming premiere and hogged the strangest of headlines with his Shadow Arts Council. Now he is preparing to bring his Trojan war epic, Tantalus, nine plays for the price of one, to Britain. This is where we hit sticky ground. Tantalus is not entirely his. It was written, over a period of 17 years, by John Barton, one of Hall's oldest friends and collaborators. But Barton wasn't at the party, nor was he at the world premiere of Tantalus in Denver, Colorado. Barton and Hall are no longer talking. Sir Peter tucks himself into the table at a swanky London hotel. We are breakfasting. Hall is that kind of man - a busy beast. He looks like Orson Welles playing Falstaff. In the 60s, Hall was such a dapper man. There is a famous picture of him straddling his stool à la Christine Keeler, striped socks, striped top, drainpipes, foppish shoes. He smiles into the camera, cigar in one hand, ashtray in the other. All soft leather and self-love. If there was a speech bubble it might read: "Hey guys, what would you give to be me?" Even today, the septuagenarian Goth looks as if he fancies himself. I ask him about Tantalus, and he says it's a long story. "I've known John for 50 years. It's not been a very happy experience for me because we've worked together a great deal." In short, after Hall and Barton could not find a British backer, they came across a Denver benefactor with millions to spare. Hall wanted to cut Tantalus from 15 hours to 10. Barton says he agreed to trim but threw a wobbly when he discovered it was being slashed by Hall behind his back. He walked out on the director and the epic vision that has defined so much of his life, disowned it. "He sees it as my adaptation, which it is," Hall says. "He said 'I'll cut anything as you well know, it's just that my stuff doesn't need cutting'." Halls smiles. "No, I'm being slightly naughty, but that was the subtext." Hall is supremely urbane, talks gently, compassionately, with daggers on his tongue. The play was wonderfully reviewed. Poor old John, I say, moping at home, while Hall basks in the glory. He jumps in before the words are out. "What about poor old Peter? My whole life has been dedicated to trying to serve the dramatist, and I went into Tantalus in order to have another collaboration." Doesn't he feel as if he's kidnapped Barton's baby? " Yesssss ... of course I do. That's at my worst moment. But I don't believe I have. I think I've put on the stage what he was writing about. I think I've put the strength and the quality of it on the stage. No, I'm deeply sorry that he's not happy, but there you are." It seems like a clash between two monstrous egos. Who has the bigger one? "That's a very difficult question to answer. I suspect I have," he answers, cutting up his bacon with infinite delicacy. But the thing is, he says, theatre is a collaboration, and Barton just wasn't willing to play the game. "He has an extraordinary belief in his own strengths as a writer. I don't actually think it's healthy ." Hall speaks a clever, coded language, like a Soviet commissar. The suggestion seems to be that his old mate Barton is unstable, bonkers. He stresses to me that this is a one-off, that he has worked with all the greats and never had problems. "I've had a wonderful relationship with Sam Beckett, Harold Pinter, Peter Shaffer, David Hare. The way I worked with Pinter is that he can say anything he likes about what I'm doing in the rehesarsal in front of the actors and I can say anything I like about the text, but on the text his word is final, and on the production my word is final should there be an absolute dispute. And I have to say, in 11 productions there never has been." But in the case of Tantalus, Barton's words weren't final? "Absolutely, otherwise I wouldn't have done it." He says that when they went out to Colorado the play had no beginning or end, just a wonderful nut in the middle. And, ultimately, the fact that he has liberated the nut more than compensates for the negatives. "It was worth it because it worked. The disadvantages were the risk, the pressure ... I was shit scared, really shit scared, because the stakes were enormous. I didn't want to be the person who entered the Guinness Book of Records for the longest flop of all time. And of course, one doesn't like losing a friend, a man one loves." He seems to have the knack of falling out with people. "Such as who?" he demands. I tell him I have made a list but am prepared to be corrected. "Well, I doubt that." Funnily enough, the first name on the list is Pinter. "I didn't fall out with Pinter. Harold Pinter fell out with me." I half expect him to stick his tongue out and go: nanananana. "He thought my diaries treated him with insufficient tact, and he didn't speak to me for about five years. Then one morning I had a letter from him saying 'life's too short, come and have lunch'. And we're firm friends again ... Tell me of this long list." What about Bill Kenwright, the impresario who bankrolled Hall's attempt to bring high art to the West End? "Oh, absolutely I fell out with Bill Kenwright. He asked me to do something which I found morally reprehensible ." The V on Hall's forehead becomes more pronounced. It's not so much a receding hairline, as a receding head line. "He asked me to walk out on a production in its last days. I thought it was very naughty ... Be careful with your lawyers, Bill is very litigious." As he has fallen out with people professionally, so he has privately. Hall's youngest daughter, eight-year-old Emma, recently asked why he has so many wives. He says he tried to explain to her the complexity of relationships; how for him if they are not all good, they tend to be all bad. "I just tried to tell her what a healthy marriage was ... you have to be happy with each other and if you were unhappy it didn't do either of you any good, and it didn't do the children any good ... She has met all the other children, she has seen all the other wives and she likes all the other wives." webTitle: Trocadero buyout Board plans to quit stock market

fields.headline: Trocadero buyout Board plans to quit stock market
fields.trailText: Burford, owner of the Trocadero entertainment complex in London's West End, is the latest property group to turn its back on the stock market. The company, chaired by entrepreneur Nigel Wray, is expected to announce this week plans for a management buyout which will value Burford at around £500m.
fields.body:
Burford, owner of the Trocadero entertainment complex in London's West End, is the latest property group to turn its back on the stock market. The company, chaired by entrepreneur Nigel Wray, is expected to announce this week plans for a management buyout which will value Burford at around £500m.

The buyout, lead by chief executive John Anderson and backed by US bank Lehman, will be pitched at between 115p and 120p a share. This compares to Friday's closing price of 105.5p, and the firm's underlying net asset value of 125p.

The Trocadero development has never reached its potential, and Mr Anderson may sell the building if he receives a suitable offer.

Burford's plan to go private echoes similar moves by MEPC, Frogmore Estates and Prestbury, the company run by Mr Wray's long time partner Nick Leslau. Most property executives say their businesses are undervalued by the stock market, trading as they do at discount to asset value.

Photograph: Ian Turner

webTitle: Time Computers in refinancing talks

fields.headline: Time Computers in refinancing talks
fields.trailText: An ambitious expansion strategy and a reduction in the price of home computers has forced Britain's biggest PC retailer into refinancing talks with its bankers.
fields.body:
An ambitious expansion strategy and a reduction in the price of home computers has forced Britain's biggest PC retailer into refinancing talks with its bankers.

Time Computers - which employs more than 2,000 people and now has 180 high street stores across the country - is understood to be in negotiations with HSBC after running into problems with its aggressive expansion strategy.

Established in 1987 by two young entrepreneurs, Time decided to branch out into full scale retailing following the huge success of its original mail order-based offering.

But the expansion has hit difficulties because it has coincided with a slump in the home computer market.

Although sales on the high street are said to be holding up, PC retailers like Time are being forced to slash prices in order to shift stock.

According to industry experts, consumers are proving increasingly reluctant to keep buying new PCs. Many have become wary of buying a new model simply because it contains a new Intel chip or Mircosoft operating system.

Last week Gateway, the north American PC maker, shocked the technology world when it warned it would miss its forecasts for the current quarter after the expected post-Thanksgiving rise in sales failed to materialise. The run up to Christmas is traditionally the busiest time of year for PC retailers.

Directors at Time could not be reached yesterday, and HSBC declined to comment on the talks. However, sources close to the company indicated that Time's problems were of a temporary, rather than terminal, nature. It seems the company requires an injection of funds to see it through the tough conditions on the high street at present.

Separately, it was reported this weekend that Time is suing IBM for alleged fraud in the New York state supreme court. Time is said to be seeking £3m in compensation after receiving what it claims were defective memory chips from IBM.

webTitle: Lloyds TSB may bid for Abbey National

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB eyes Abbey
fields.standfirst: £20bn bid may be mounted
fields.trailText: Senior Lloyds TSB executives were last night locked in an emergency board meeting to decide whether to mount a £20bn bid for Abbey National.
fields.body:
Senior Lloyds TSB executives were last night locked in an emergency board meeting to decide whether to mount a £20bn bid for Abbey National.

Any bid by acquisition hungry Lloyds TSB would scupper the continuing merger talks between Abbey and Bank of Scotland. Details of the Abbey-BoS talks were leaked a month ago, but the two sides have yet to reach agreement on how to create a combined bank.

Lloyds TSB, which bought Scottish Widows earlier this year, is understood to be anxious to avoid a hostile bid for Abbey, which it is thought to have approached about a friendly merger a year ago.

Industry sources believe that Peter Ellwood, the chief executive of Lloyds TSB, is keen to wade into the battle for control of Abbey; he is said to want to use the opportunity to prove his management credentials.

But even if the board concludes that a bid is the correct course of action, it is not expected imminently.

The bank's executives are also expected to discuss whether a bid for a European institution would be more viable course for expansion.

A Lloyds TSB spokeswoman last night refused to comment on "speculation" about the meeting. However, it is believed that the board, advised by investment bank JP Morgan, will weigh up the political reaction to any bid for Abbey.

The combined bank would have a 30% share of current accounts and more than 23% of the mortgage market - along with vast scope for reducing costs, which would mean thousands of job cuts and branch closures.

While the takeover of NatWest failed to prompt a competition investigation into the bids by BoS and Royal Bank of Scotland, banking sources are trying to gauge whether the political environment has altered.

Since the talks between Abbey and BoS were leaked, the City has speculated that Lloyds TSB and Barclays would find it difficult to resist the temptation of bidding for either of the two banks.

Last Friday, Barclays chief executive Matt Barrett ruled out a bid for Abbey but left open the possibility of approaching BoS, which has been shrouded in uncertainty after its failure to take over NatWest in January.

BoS initially issued a sharp rebuttal to the approach from Abbey National.

After talks between their investment banking advisers, the atmosphere between the two boards of management are understood to have improved somewhat. However, industry sources believe that the two banks are concerned that even if they are able to reconcile their differences over who should run a combined bank, their plans will be blown apart by the firepower of Lloyds TSB.

While the Abbey and BoS are thought to have given themselves a further 10 days or so to try to reach an agreement, it is understood that the terms of any possible link-up are far from finalised.

Among the possibilities being considered in order to clinch a deal is the appointment of BoS chief executive Peter Burt as chairman of a combined bank. Ian Harley would become chief executive, the post he holds at present with Abbey. However, it is understood that this is yet to be agreed by both sides - who each appear determined that their management should run the combined entity.
