webTitle: Debate: enlargement of EU

fields.headline: A choice for the Nice conspirators
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the European commission
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The tedious wranglings between Europhiles and Europhobes over the enlargement of the EU tend to concentrate on esoteric debates over qualified majority voting and the composition of the European commission. This has provided a smokescreen to conceal what the enlargement process is really about.
fields.body:
The tedious wranglings between Europhiles and Europhobes over the enlargement of the EU tend to concentrate on esoteric debates over qualified majority voting and the composition of the European commission. This has provided a smokescreen to conceal what the enlargement process is really about.

The planned acceleration of the EU's free market agenda eastwards has serious implications for the environmental and social condition of the entire continent.

A key driver has been the corporate sector, and in particular the little known European Roundtable of Industrialists, ERT. This consists of up to 45 captains of industry from large European transnational corporations. Virtually unnoticed, the ERT has played a central role in the shaping of the single market, the Maastricht treaty and, more recently, the single currency. For them, enlargement offers an enormous market, as well as a reservoir of cheap skilled labour.

Market enlargement has frequently been at the cost of environmental and social conditions across the countries of central and eastern Europe.

Slovak railways are a case in point. In 1998 the Slovak government announced a halving of the 50,000 staff in the rail sector, the country's biggest employer. The next year it signed a loan agreement with the European Investment Bank, which resulted in a massive cut in state subsidies, a 30% rise in fares, and scaling back the rail network. Opponents were told bluntly by the president of the EIB, Brian Unwin, that such measures "mirror those agreed over recent years between the bank and virtually all railway companies" in the eastern European applicant countries.

This rundown of railways meeting local needs has made it potentially far more profitable for western companies to take over local firms. This, hand in hand with privatisation, has allowed global car companies to take over domestic car production, often involving huge tax breaks at the expense of the wider economy. The same process is evident in areas as diverse as banking in the Czech Republic, where international banks are expected to exceed 50% of market share by 2001, to the almost total western control of the beer industry in Hungary and Poland.

Such takeovers and foreign investments do not necessarily bring with them any lasting security. General Electric, for example, has globalised its operations by shifting production to low-wage countries, including eastern Europe. Company director Jack Welch has candidly remarked that "ideally you'd have every plant you own on a barge" - ready to move if national governments try to impose constraints, or if workers demand better wages and conditions. The company recently closed a factory in Turkey to move it to lower-wage Hungary. It has since has threatened to close a factory in Hungary and move it to India.

At the Nice summit this week opponents will be in the streets to contest the EU's present emphasis of restructuring and enlarging in pursuit of further globalisation. A different approach is beginning to emerge from opponents of globalisation and is featured in my report published today, From Seattle to Nice. This calls for the protection and rebuilding of local communities and economies in a way that encourages maximum social and environmental sustainability.

Emphasis in the current EU enlargement on competition for the cheapest must be replaced by cooperation for the best, emphasising the flow of ideas, technologies, culture and information, but with the end goal of strengthening local economies continent wide.

The choice facing decision makers in Nice is to pursue ever more deregulated trade and investment in an EU which sees itself as nothing other than a giant supermarket of 500m consumers, or to adopt a more ambitious vision of a Europe of genuine stability and cooperation, based on rebuilding sustainable local economies. We can only hope the latter approach prevails.

 Caroline Lucas is a Green MEP, a member of the European parliament's trade committee
carolinelucas@greenmeps.org.uk
fields.bodyText: The tedious wranglings between Europhiles and Europhobes over the enlargement of the EU tend to concentrate on esoteric debates over qualified majority voting and the composition of the European commission. This has provided a smokescreen to conceal what the enlargement process is really about. The planned acceleration of the EU's free market agenda eastwards has serious implications for the environmental and social condition of the entire continent. A key driver has been the corporate sector, and in particular the little known European Roundtable of Industrialists, ERT. This consists of up to 45 captains of industry from large European transnational corporations. Virtually unnoticed, the ERT has played a central role in the shaping of the single market, the Maastricht treaty and, more recently, the single currency. For them, enlargement offers an enormous market, as well as a reservoir of cheap skilled labour. Market enlargement has frequently been at the cost of environmental and social conditions across the countries of central and eastern Europe. Slovak railways are a case in point. In 1998 the Slovak government announced a halving of the 50,000 staff in the rail sector, the country's biggest employer. The next year it signed a loan agreement with the European Investment Bank, which resulted in a massive cut in state subsidies, a 30% rise in fares, and scaling back the rail network. Opponents were told bluntly by the president of the EIB, Brian Unwin, that such measures "mirror those agreed over recent years between the bank and virtually all railway companies" in the eastern European applicant countries. This rundown of railways meeting local needs has made it potentially far more profitable for western companies to take over local firms. This, hand in hand with privatisation, has allowed global car companies to take over domestic car production, often involving huge tax breaks at the expense of the wider economy. The same process is evident in areas as diverse as banking in the Czech Republic, where international banks are expected to exceed 50% of market share by 2001, to the almost total western control of the beer industry in Hungary and Poland. Such takeovers and foreign investments do not necessarily bring with them any lasting security. General Electric, for example, has globalised its operations by shifting production to low-wage countries, including eastern Europe. Company director Jack Welch has candidly remarked that "ideally you'd have every plant you own on a barge" - ready to move if national governments try to impose constraints, or if workers demand better wages and conditions. The company recently closed a factory in Turkey to move it to lower-wage Hungary. It has since has threatened to close a factory in Hungary and move it to India. At the Nice summit this week opponents will be in the streets to contest the EU's present emphasis of restructuring and enlarging in pursuit of further globalisation. A different approach is beginning to emerge from opponents of globalisation and is featured in my report published today, From Seattle to Nice. This calls for the protection and rebuilding of local communities and economies in a way that encourages maximum social and environmental sustainability. Emphasis in the current EU enlargement on competition for the cheapest must be replaced by cooperation for the best, emphasising the flow of ideas, technologies, culture and information, but with the end goal of strengthening local economies continent wide. The choice facing decision makers in Nice is to pursue ever more deregulated trade and investment in an EU which sees itself as nothing other than a giant supermarket of 500m consumers, or to adopt a more ambitious vision of a Europe of genuine stability and cooperation, based on rebuilding sustainable local economies. We can only hope the latter approach prevails.  Caroline Lucas is a Green MEP, a member of the European parliament's trade committee carolinelucas@greenmeps.org.uk

webTitle: Letters: The right way to fight HIV

fields.headline: The right way to fight HIV
fields.trailText: Your article (Breastfeeding may guard against HIV, December 1) is misleading. Scientific evidence confirms that HIV is transmitted through breastfeeding, and a breastfeeding HIV-infected mother substantially increases the risk of passing her infection on to her child.
fields.body:
Your article (Breastfeeding may guard against HIV, December 1) is misleading. Scientific evidence confirms that HIV is transmitted through breastfeeding, and a breastfeeding HIV-infected mother substantially increases the risk of passing her infection on to her child.

The policy of the World Health Organisation and Unicef states clearly that HIV-infected women should be advised to use bottlefeeding where it is acceptable, affordable and feasible and where the general risks to the health of the child and mother can be minimised.

This is the situation that applies in the UK. However, the WHO/Unicef recommendations, recently reaffirmed, also indicate that in resource-poor developing countries there may be advantages in women continuing to breastfeed, irrespective of HIV infection.

This is not because breastfeeding "guards against HIV" but because the gain from bottlefeeding of reduced HIV infection is more than outweighed by the heightened risk in poor countries of more infectious diseases in the child and loss of contraception by the mother.

Your reporting of the study by Anna Coutsoudis and her colleagues is, we believe, in error. In Durban, they observed HIV infection rates in babies born to HIV-infected mothers feeding exclusively with breastmilk, bottlefeeding or mixing breast and bottle. At the Aids conference in Durban in July, Coutsoudis reported the lowest risk of HIV transmission to children at 15 months was with exclusive bottlefeeding, higher risk with exclusive breastfeeding and the greatest risk with mixed feeding.

Your reported statement "if you exclusively breastfeed...you have minimal or no risk of transmitting HIV" is incorrect and confusing. Breastfeeding is better only than mixed feeding. In the UK breastfeeding is not recommended for HIV-infected women living here.

However, generally breastfeeding should be promoted and protected, both in the UK and elsewhere. Exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months is better for the child's overall health than mixing breast and artificial feeding and the WHO thus recommends that where HIV-infected mothers have no option but to breastfeed this should be exclusive for no longer than six months. However, it has to be recognised that exclusive breastfeeding is not easy to practise, especially by mothers who have to work.
Angus Nicoll
PHLS Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre
Institute of Child Health
anicoll@phls.org.uk

 People do not die from Aids but from infections to which Aids makes them uniquely susceptible. Of these, tuberculosis is by far the commonest. Before the world commits itself to the billions of dollars needed to treat Africa with anti-virals we should consider giving the much smaller amounts needed to cure TB.
Marie Louise Newell, Peter Davies
TB Alert

webTitle: Letters: Not playing the game

fields.headline: Not playing the game
fields.trailText: As a Dutch national, I am stunned by the knee-jerk reactions to any mention of Europe in Britain (Media analysis, December 2). Does the anti-EU crowd realise that the financial contribution of a small country such as the Netherlands equals the UK's?
fields.body:
As a Dutch national, I am stunned by the knee-jerk reactions to any mention of Europe in Britain (Media analysis, December 2). Does the anti-EU crowd realise that the financial contribution of a small country such as the Netherlands equals the UK's? Given the appalling condition of large parts of Britain's infrastructure, it should probably be hoping for some more international development aid from the EU.
Robin van Koert
London

Can't the redevelopment of Wembley stadium (Wembley in crisis as 30 banks so no, December 2) now be rethought? What is needed is a site easy to access from all parts of the country, with massive parking areas and a handy airport. What a shame it is so difficult to get from London to the NEC site in Birmingham.
Bob Horne
Coventry

If this is a national stadium, shouldn't the government be building it?
Charles Miller
Wigan

I am 44 and it usually takes me 7-11 minutes to complete the quick crossword at the end of the day. I am shocked to think it may take hours in future (Letters, December 2). Can the older readers tell me when I can expect to slow down? Will it be so because I get out of touch with the culture from which the clues are drawn, or will I get understimulated in old age, or will my brain just struggle to stay focused?
Ben Humphries Preston

I notice that the first four titles in the HMV Christmas gift advertisement for video games (December 2) are: Gunman Chronicles, Combat Flight Simulator 2, No One Lives Forever and Command and Conquer Red Alert 2. So much for the season of peace and goodwill.
Bob Bird Great Missenden, Bucks

webTitle: Letters: It's tough on the streets

fields.headline: It's tough on the streets
fields.trailText: As a resident and former councillor I do not recognise your image of Peckham. Yes, we have problems but the overwhelming majority of people living here are honest, hard-working and law-abiding, bringing up their children to be responsible members of society.
fields.body:
As a resident and former councillor I do not recognise your image of Peckham (Murder of a schoolboy, December 1). Yes, we have problems but the overwhelming majority of people living here are honest, hard-working and law-abiding, bringing up their children to be responsible members of society. There is crime, but there are also active churches, thriving small businesses and a vibrant mixed community.

I also object to attempts to blame the local council or the local school as being somehow responsible. Yes, what is left of the North Peckham estate is run-down but it is awaiting demolition before tenants are transferred to newly built low-rise properties. Perhaps a newly arrived immigrant family should never have been put there, but with a dire shortage of council housing, there were no other options available.

As for the school, Oliver Goldsmith, despite its intake of children from diverse backgrounds in one of the poorest areas in London, has relatively little bullying and an improving academic record. Unfortunately its teachers have little control over the parenting or external influences on other youths in the area.

The real issue is not the condition of inner-city social housing or the local school but crime (particularly violent crime). The bulk of people in Peckham do not steal, mug or carry knives but many live in fear of those who do. Calls for more pro-active policing and tougher penalties for those convicted of crime and disorder may trouble the conscience of middle-class journalists, but have mass support from the principal victims of crime: the working class and ethnic minorities.
Mike Gibson
Camberwell and Peckham Labour party

 Our priority is to ensure that vulnerable people sleeping rough get access to accommodation all year round, not just in winter (The cold shoulder, November 29). The government is no longer funding a "winter" strategy because local authorities now have services in place to help people whenever they need it.

Just providing emergency accommodation is not a solution to rough sleeping. Our focus is on resettling former rough sleepers into permanent accommodation and rebuilding their lives away from the street. This in turn frees up hostel beds to help vulnerable people in their first step off the streets. Life on the streets is brutal and dangerous, which is exactly why the prime minister has set the target of reducing the number of people sleeping rough to as near zero as possible.
Louise Casey
Director, Rough Sleepers Unit

webTitle: Letters: The perils of privatisation

fields.headline: Fatal flaws of private deals
fields.trailText: As a former London Underground manager now working in the private sector, I find WS Atkins does nothing to alleviate my concerns about PPP (Tube bidder lauds private sector role, December 1).
fields.body:
As a former London Underground manager now working in the private sector, I find WS Atkins does nothing to alleviate my concerns about PPP (Tube bidder lauds private sector role, December 1). No matter how carefully the contracts are drafted now, in a few years the technical and political environment is likely to have changed significantly and there will be enormous pressure to vary the contract. However, the contractors will then be in a position to hold London hostage.

PFI deals signed by London Underground in the early 90s did not even last their shorter five-year period without major disputes. It is impossible to draft a suitable 30-year contract that will stand the test of time. Remember that 30 years ago the microprocessor and mobile phone had not been invented. I am convinced that any PPP contract will result in a major dispute less than a third of the way through its life. It is a recipe for disaster.
Simon Tompsett
Richmond, Surrey

 Mike Jeffries of WS Atkins supports his case by comparing the number of people acquiring infection in hospital and those killed on the roads. No meaningful comparison can be drawn. Many deaths in the debilitation of old age are infection-related. But it is uncommon for children and young adults to acquire life-threatening infections. By contrast, most road accident deaths involve the young and the healthy and all are preventable. Were the NHS run by private consortia, my guess is the very fact of hospital infection would be denied.
David Wheldon
Bedford General Hospital

webTitle: Letter: First lesson for chief inspector of schools

fields.headline: First lesson
fields.trailText: It is encouraging to read that Mike Tomlinson, the new chief inspector of schools, has adopted "a more emollient tone" towards teachers than did his predecessor. I notice, however, that he hasn't been a teacher since 1977
fields.body:
It is encouraging to read (Ofsted's new chief offers an easier ride, December 2) that Mike Tomlinson, the new chief inspector of schools, has adopted "a more emollient tone" towards teachers than did his predecessor. I notice, however, that he hasn't been a teacher since 1977. He could gain an enormous amount of respect from serving teachers by making it compulsory for all Ofsted inspectors, himself included, to work as teachers for a few weeks a year.
Diane Thurman
Cambridge

webTitle: Predicting next year's economy

fields.headline: Compete with the forecasters
fields.trailText: Mervyn King, the deputy governor of the Bank of England, thinks the economy is likely to see a lot of jiggling about over the next few months. "The committee feel that data over the next few months might bear some resemblance to old-fashioned disco dancing sharp movements in unpredictable directions creating much excitement accompanied by a good deal of noise," he said.
fields.body:
Mervyn King, the deputy governor of the Bank of England, thinks the economy is likely to see a lot of jiggling about over the next few months. "The committee feel that data over the next few months might bear some resemblance to old-fashioned disco dancing sharp movements in unpredictable directions creating much excitement accompanied by a good deal of noise," he said.

Predicting the direction of the economy is always a challenge but next year promises to be particularly taxing for forecasters. Against this background we once again invite you to pit your wits against the experts and come up with your predictions of the economy's path next year.

Send in your best estimates about the shape of the economy in 2001 and you could win £500 worth of book tokens from Palgrave, leading publishers of textbooks, academic and professional books, as well as the traditional magnum of champagne andlunch with the Guardian's economics team.

This year, for the first time, you can send in your entries by email. Online entries will be in the running to win an extra prize - a Palgrave economics dictionary.

We are looking for the most accurate forecast of key economic indicators: growth, interest rates, underlying inflation, unemployment, the current account and the exchange rate. Your forecast should contain six elements:

 2001's annual percentage GDP growth

 Bank base lending rate on December 31, 2001

 Inflation, excluding mortgage repayments, December 2001

 Total unemployed in December 2001 on the seasonally adjusted claimant count

 The UK current account in 2001. (expressed in pounds, not as a percentage of GDP)

 Sterling's value against the euro on December 31, 2001

Answers on a postcard should be sent to: Guardian Economics Competition, Economics Desk, the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

You can also enter the competition online on the Guardian network at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/economy

The deadline for entries is February 1; the usual Guardian competition rules apply. The points system will be explained next week and winners will be decided when the first estimate of 2001 GDP is available, in early 2002.

webTitle: Letter: Gravy gripe

fields.headline: Gravy gripe
fields.trailText: Your leader writer (December 1) might have been wise to check that he was not attacking one of his own columnists before lambasting my light-hearted project on the physics of gravy absorption. Such projects, like my past Guardian columns on the science of cooking, are part of a personal crusade to show that science does not need to be hi-tech to be interesting.
fields.body:
Your leader writer (December 1) might have been wise to check that he was not attacking one of his own columnists before lambasting my light-hearted project on the physics of gravy absorption. Such projects, like my past Guardian columns on the science of cooking, are part of a personal crusade to show that science does not need to be hi-tech to be interesting. It has nothing to do with Bristol University and commercial sponsorship is perfectly appropriate. You would have been better to attack a system where university researchers are forced to spend much of their time seeking commercial funding for serious research, to the detriment of both freedom of inquiry and the time to pursue that inquiry.
Dr Len Fisher
University of Bristol Len.Fisher@bristol.ac.uk

webTitle: B&B sellers set for bottom-rung payout

fields.headline: B&B sellers set for bottom-rung payout
fields.standfirst: Building society lines up to join the stock market's second rank
fields.trailText: Windfall payments for almost 2.7m members of Bradford & Bingley are expected to come in at around £600-£650 when the building society floats on the stock market today.
fields.body:
Windfall payments for almost 2.7m members of Bradford & Bingley are expected to come in at around £600-£650 when the building society floats on the stock market today.

With more than 1m of the society's members having elected to sell their shares immediately, and the fact that Bradford & Bingley will not be big enough as a plc to enter the FTSE 100 index, many analysts were forecasting that the shares would debut at be tween 240p and 260p - near the bottom end of the range predicted by Goldman Sachs, the investment bank advising on the flotation.

The timing of the windfalls could provide a Christmas boost to some traders as a sizeable chunk of the estimated £600m-plus being paid out to those who decided to take the money straightaway is likely to end up in retailers' tills.

Today's flotation comes 20 months after B&B members voted 62% to 38% in favour of a conversion resolution put forward by Stephen Major, a plumber from Northern Ireland. He had claimed that members could receive windfalls of £2,000 each.

The society - which had been targeted by hundreds of thousands of carpetbaggers in the run-up to the vote - acceded to members' wishes, later provoking anger by deciding to award all members 250 shares each, regardless of how much they had tied up with it.

Goldman Sachs's estimate of the value of the shares is be tween 259p and 326p, which would give windfalls of between £647 and £815.

But most analysts believe the shares will debut at the bottom end of this range, or perhaps even lower.

Stockbroker Teather & Greenwood has said it expected the shares to trade at 240p, which would mean windfalls worth £600.

It added that Bradford & Bingley would be in the FTSE 250 index, with Northern Rock, but had no chance of entering the FTSE 100.

Just over 1m people - 38.5% of the membership - elected to sell their shares immediately. Bradford & Bingley is due to put out a statement this morning announcing the price achieved at Friday's auction of unwanted shares aimed at institutional investors.

Cheques for the proceeds, less a £10 selling fee, will be dispatched to these people on December 11. Bradford & Bingley said that provided these were paid in to a B&B account, they would be treated as cash, and people would not have to wait for the cheques to clear.

All those members who elected to keep their shares should have received their "welcome packs", including a nominee statement confirming their shareholding, by today. The packs include a form which members must send back if they want to receive a share certificate. Those who opt to keep their shares in the Bradford & Bingley nominee account can sell them, or buy more, using a post-only share dealing facility.

webTitle: Byers to decide Black Label fate

fields.headline: Byers to decide Black Label fate
fields.standfirst: Crucial week for brewing will bring changes at the bar
fields.trailText: Crucial week for brewing will bring changes at the bar
fields.body:
The fate of some the biggest names in British brewing could be decided this week as another round of consolidation in the industry reaches its conclusion.

The competition commission is set to deliver to trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers its report on the £2.3bn acquisition of Bass's brewing interests by Belgian group Interbrew. The report could recommend the sale of Carling Black Label, Britain's biggest selling lager.

The long running battle for control of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, owner of the Pedigree and Banks brands, may also draw to a close after news that quoted pub company Enterprise Inns has joined forces with Robert Breare, the entrepreneur stalking the Midlands-based brewer.

Mr Byers referred the Bass deal to the competition commission in September after expressing concern that it could reduce competition in the brewing and distribution of beer. Combined with its earlier acquisition of Whitbread's brewing interest, Interbrew - which made its debut on the Belgian stock market last week - has a leading 32% share of the UK beer market.

Industry watchers believe there are various recommendations the commission could reach, from the sale of Carling to forcing Interbrew to shorten supply contracts to tied pubs.

If Carling is put up for sale there will be no shortage of buyers. Last month Carlsberg, the Danish brewer, indicated it would consider buying any Bass brands Interbrew is forced to give up.

A spokesman for Interbrew said it was too early to speculate about the sales of brands. "We are in contact [with the commission] and co-operating in a positive way.

"At this stage of the process it is too early to say if any brands will be sold off. Let us wait for the commission to make its report," he said.

Meanwhile, it emerged yesterday that Enterprise Inns has agreed to buy more than 1,000 of Wolverhampton & Dudley's managed and tenanted pubs - the bottom end of W&D's pub portfolio - for £350m, should Mr Breare's bid for W&D be recommended by the company's board.

In keeping with his recent acquisition of the Oriental Restaurants group, Mr Breare is thought to be only interested in assets which have strong branding. It seems likely he will hang on to the Pitcher & Piano pub chain and the brewing business if he emerges victorious.

With Enterprise on board, analysts reckon Mr Breare could afford to pay up to 500p a share, or £471m, for W&D. Reports this weekend said that Mr Breare has already submitted his offer to NM Rothschild, W&D's advisers.

A spokesman for Mr Breare refused to comment.

Scottish & Newcastle yesterday denied reports that it is in talks with German beer group Beck's over a Europe-wide distribution agreement that could lead to a takeover.

"To suggest we would form a European alliance with Beck's is untrue," she said, adding, "the relationship is that of supplier and customer".

S&N at present distributes Beck's in Britain.

webTitle: Director in luxury car scam flees

fields.headline: Director in luxury car scam flees
fields.trailText: A businessman who failed to appear to be sentenced for his part in a luxury car hire scam is believed to have fled the country.
fields.body:
A businessman who failed to appear to be sentenced for his part in a luxury car hire scam is believed to have fled the country.

An arrest warrant has been issued for Mark Roe, a former professional golfer, who may be in south-east Asia.

A serious fraud office investigation found that Roe and two colleagues amassed about £1m from fraudulent trading as four businesses - Marque One Rentals, Marque One UK Franchising, Elite Rentals and Performance Car Share.

The trio, who regularly used aliases, hired out Ferraris, Porches, Lotus Elites, Mercedes and Bentleys from a base in Hertfordshire. They duped customers out of their deposits by falsely claiming the vehicles had been damaged.

They also refused to pay creditors and adopted "confusing and delaying" tactics to obscure their tracks.

Roe, 32, was sentenced in his absence to two years and three months after previously admitting four counts of fraudulent trading at Luton crown court. He was given a consecutive six-month sentence for an unconnected fraud in Manchester.

Gary Massingham, 33, was sentenced to two years and three months on the same charges, while his father Anthony, 54, who passed himself off as a legal executive named Robert Conroy Associates, was given one year and nine months.

All three were barred from acting as directors until 2007.

webTitle: Councils ignorant of e-government target

fields.headline: Councils ignorant of e-government target
fields.standfirst: The dream of wired local authorities could be jeopardised by widespread ignorance about ministers' electronic service delivery plans for local government
fields.trailText: The dream of wired local authorities could be jeopardised by widespread ignorance about ministers' electronic service delivery plans for local government, writes Simon Parker
fields.body:
Ministers have given councils just five years to start delivering all their services electronically, but the dream of wired local authorities could be jeopardised by widespread ignorance about e-government.

A new survey of more than 200 heads of IT found senior officers and politicians in 75% of authorities have only a patchy or poor understanding of ministers' electronic service delivery plans for local government. This is despite the fact that officers in two-thirds of councils had been briefed on e-government, and a third of authorities had briefed councillors.

Brian Westcott, the consultant who edited the survey for the Society of Information Technology Management (Socitm), said: "IT managers are having to cope with a lack of commitment in some cases. To some extent people don't want to be informed about this. They are still worried about the technology, and think it's still something for tecchies."

Councillors in particular, he said, might not have a good grasp of e-government policy: "A lot of them are old and retired and, with all due respect to them, a bit out of touch with modern technology."

The government wants councils to adopt the "spirit" of a 2005 timetable for all appropriate Whitehall services to be delivered electronically. This target is not yet statutory for local government, and therefore legally unenforceable, but the Socitm findings still underline council concerns about meeting it. An e-government survey released earlier this year by pollsters TBC research found that nearly two-thirds of the 100 officers questioned thought the target could only be met with extra money for IT. Socitm's survey, which also took in the views of over 150 council chief executives, finds the same concern.

These anxieties hide the fact that local government is forging ahead with electronic delivery. The Socitm survey found that 77% of authorities had prepared an e-government strategy suited to local needs, or plan to do so. Around a third had appointed a senior manager as an "e-champion" to oversee the implementation of the strategy across the authority. In nearly 100 authorities, however, the chief executive and head of IT did not agree on whether an appointment had been made. E-champions, believes, Mr Westcott are key to driving change through resisting authorities.

According to Mr Westcott, the government is already taking many of the necessary steps to ensure that councils are wired up by the 2005 deadline. Ministers have announced a £350m fund to support on-line local government, which councils can only access if they have an e-government strategy. By setting targets in the first place, the government has also piled both direct and peer group pressure on authorities to implement electronic delivery.

The obvious next step for ministers is to make those targets statutory - a move that would really ratchet up the pressure on councils to move their services into call centres and onto the internet. The most likely method of doing this would be by incorporating e-government targets into the best value regime.

It is a move that Mr Westcott supports, although with the important caveat that the best value measures should not be so prescriptive that they stop councils tailoring e-government initiatives to the needs of their communities. Once the targets are in place, he argues: "It will be up to local authorities and their heads of IT to lead on this and make something happen."

webTitle: Removal of the national veto

fields.headline: How Britain's thick red line could put talks in deadlock
fields.standfirst:
Negotiators insist removal of national veto is more than a technical move

Special report: European integration
Special report: the European Parliament
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Negotiators insist removal of national veto is more than a technical move
fields.body:
Just over two years ago, in what now seems a much more ambitious era for European federalists, the German finance minister, Oskar Lafontaine, gave a briefing in the margins of a meeting of EU finance ministers that there was a strong case for tax harmonisation across the EU. Coordination was necessary for the protection of the single market, the new euro currency and the free movement of labour, he said.

At the same time, the European commission was pushing for a common withholding tax to prevent individuals who held savings abroad from evading tax.

Transmuted through the British Eurosceptics, these ideas raised the spectre of the EU setting British income tax rates, even though the EU treaty gives the commission no power to interfere in direct taxes. Mr Lafontaine was dubbed the most dangerous man in Europe.

Since then the climate has changed. Mr Lafontaine has quit the German government and the EU's version of a withholding tax has been driven from the field by the chancellor, Gordon Brown

But new proposals on tax, and social security, are to be brought to this week's EU summit in Nice with the support of the commission and the French presidency. They insist the plans are altogether more modest, and technical, than anything proposed by Mr Lafontaine.

Yet Britain, along with Ireland and Luxembourg, has served notice it will refuse to give ground on tax and social security, even if it means deadlock in the marathon talks.

Treasury officials say that at one level the issues are straightforward. "We will not cede any loss of the national veto over tax or social security. It is as simple as that," a spokesman said.

It is the reddest of Britain's so-called red lines in the talks. In reality, the truth is more complex. Significant ground on tax has already been ceded by all countries in the interests of a single competitive market. In 1991, the EU agreed to adopt, with many exemptions, a minimum standard rate of VAT of 15% and minimum rates of excise duty on mineral oils, alcohol and tobacco. This mandate was also used to abolish customs duty within the free trade area.

Similarly, the EU has already used its powers under single market laws to try to remove harmful tax competition. An EU code of conduct group, chaired by the Treasury minister, Dawn Primarolo, is to identify tax measures that "unduly affect" where companies place their businesses.

Now the commission is coming forward with its next phase of proposals the removal of the national veto in specific tax and social security fields.

The EU president, Romano Prodi, is presenting them as largely technical. He said recently: "I have proposed safeguards to ensure that majority voting cannot apply to sensitive decisions such as harmonisation of tax rates. Yet we urgently need to modernise our tax systems so they can keep pace with the revolution in electronic commerce. The unanimity rule makes this difficult.

"More generally we need to rationalise taxation for the benefit of business without changing the rates of and structures of tax systems. It is absurd that a company based in one EU country should have to wait three years to recover VAT from the authorities of another."

Chris Patten, the EU commissioner, also indicated yesterday that there are serious arguments in favour of more majority voting on tax, especially fraud, to make the single market more effective.

To ease British anxieties, the commission has tried to restrict its proposals in specific treaty language. Under article 93 the national veto would be removed so that "in the area of indirect taxation" the EU can "adopt technical updating measures to simplify existing community rules, or to ensure uniform application of existing rules relating to turnover, tax excise duties and other forms of indirect taxation".

In relation to turnover tax, such as stamp duty, this would apply to setting EU wide rules in relation to "refund arrange ments, the determination of the person liable for payment of the tax, fiscal procedures, the definition of concepts in common". Majority voting would also apply if a country sought a derogation from these rules.

In deference to the British, the new article 93, to be negotiated at Nice, would explicitly state it could not apply to rules concerning the location of transactions, the reallocation of tax revenue between member states and the fixing of rates. In relation to excise duties, majority voting would apply to their structure, but not their rates.

The commission also wants powers to introduce majority voting in the introduction of "measures for the sole purpose of preventing fraud, tax evasion and the circumvention of existing rules".

Senior British negotiators are adamant they will not accept these proposals.

One said: "If you have majority voting in any of these areas, we would have had majority voting imposing on Britain the withholding tax - which is designed to prevent fraud - in its original unworkable form."

Britain is fighting a more lonely battle over article 42 to to stop majority voting on the harmonisation of social security. Since much British social security is paid through tax credits, Britain fears concessions in this area could give the commission back door access to our tax system.

However, the commission says it wants majority voting in a limited sphere - how EU member states, when assessing someone's entitlement to benefit, take into account completed periods of residence, employment or insurance, even if the periods were completed in another EU country. In theory, an EU citizen could have all his pension entitlements, from different periods of residence in different countries, gathered together and paid in one country.

Britain dismisses this idea as bureaucratic and unworkable. "Harmonising the accounting of all medical costs at the point of delivery, one commission idea, is inapplicable here since the NHS is free at the point of delivery, unlike in Europe", a British official said.

webTitle: Film: The best mountain-top scene

fields.headline: The best mountain-top scene
fields.standfirst: The Grinch
fields.trailText: The Grinch
fields.body:
Christmas, high above Who-ville. A gaggle of Who teenagers clamber towards the top of Mount Crumpit.

"Last one to the top's a stinky old Grinch!"

As they continue to frolic in the snow, Junie Who (Nadja Pionilla) grows nervous.

"You guys? Where are we? I think we should go back."

"You're scared of the Grinch!"

"Am not!"

Drew Lou Who (Jeremy Howard) begins taunting his friend.

"I think he lives up here in a cave. But he only comes down when he's hungry for Who-flesh."

"You're scared of the Grinch! You're scared of the Grinch!"

Suddenly, Drew realises they have stumbled upon a thick wooden door.

"Go on, touch it! Touch the door!"

Junie pouts at her companion.

"Go on, Drew. Do it for me."

Terrified and whimpering, Drew tip-toes towards the door. Before he can even knock, the door swings open, and a vast, monstrous green head lunges towards him, emitting a deafening howl. Screaming, the children of Who-ville plummet headfirst back down the mountain. As we return to the door, we see the Grinch (Jim Carrey) standing behind the hideous - and obviously plastic - head, with his dog Max barking into a megaphone. He claps his hands in glee.

"Well done, Max! Serves them right, the yuletide-loving cheer-mongers!"

Surveying the mountain, he paces for a second.

"I really don't like 'em. Hmm-hmm. No I don't."

See also: Fantasia, Alive, Frankenstein, Never Give A Sucker An Even Break

Don't see also: Cliffhanger

Pointless trivia: Prior to his well-known role on Happy Days, Grinch director Ron Howard spent eight years starring on the Andy Griffith Show (credited as Ronny).

webTitle: Mortgage aid plan for key workers

fields.headline: Mortgage aid plan for key workers
fields.trailText: Ministers are preparing to unveil plans for mortgage subsidies to help teachers, nurses and other professionals who are priced out of property hot spots, in the face of new research revealing a widening gap between house prices and incomes.
fields.body:
Ministers are preparing to unveil plans for mortgage subsidies to help teachers, nurses and other professionals who are priced out of property hot spots, in the face of new research revealing a widening gap between house prices and incomes.

A new urgency has been added to the government's proposed starter homes initiative with a study by leading housing organisations today warning that England faces an acute shortage of accommodation because more people are living alone.

The research, for the Our Homes, Our Future campaign, shows that in the past 30 years house prices have increased by 135 % and wages by only 60 %.

It warns that special measures are needed to help the 2m people expected to be living alone by 2016 - most of them over 30.

"These people are at particular risk because many of them live in the south-east of England and are reliant on only one income to buy a home in a market already unaffordable to many," it said.

The report, by the Cambridge Centre of Housing, Planning and Research, also warned that key workers in areas of high demand are at risk because their nationally-negotiated wage rates do not adequately reflect higher than average house prices.

With leading housing organisations warning that "targeted" help is now needed, ministers are poised to promise interest-free top-up loans, cash for deposits and help with shared ownership schemes under which a publicly-funded housing association might own half the equity of a home.

The housing minister, Nick Raynsford, has said there is scope for "innovative new thinking" in this area. The government wanted to hear from employers who would make a contribution to a £250m fund - kicked off with government cash - which would be targeted at essential workers.

One idea floated has been for top-up mortgages of up to £50,000 on homes at the lower end of the market costing £125,000 or less. Buyers would have to find a commercial lender to give a £75,000 mortgage, with the government scheme topping this up with £50,000 interest free.

David Butler, chief executive of the Chartered Institute of Housing, which helped fund yesterday's report, warned: "The housing market is failing a significant section of the population.

"Our country's continued prosperity depends on these issues being addressed by targeted intervention at a local level.

Richard McCarthy, chief executive of the Peabody Trust, a large social landlord in London which also helped sponsor the research, warned that in London alone there was now a shortage of nearly 36,000 essential workers due mainly to the lack of affordable accommodation.

The housing minister, Nick Raynsford, has said there is scope for "innovative new thinking" in this area. The government wanted to hear from employers who would make a contribution to a £250m fund - kicked off with government cash - which would be targeted at essential workers. One idea floated has been for top-up mortgages of up to £50,000 on homes at the lower end of the market costing £125,000 or less. Buyers would have to find a commercial lender to give a £75,000 mortgage, with the government scheme topping this up with £50,000 interest free. David Butler, chief executive of the Chartered Institute of Housing, which helped fund yesterday's report, warned: "The housing market is failing a significant section of the population. "Our country's continued prosperity depends on these issues being addressed by targeted intervention at a local level. Richard McCarthy, chief executive of the Peabody Trust, a large social landlord in London which also helped sponsor the research, warned that in London alone there was now a shortage of nearly 36,000 essential workers due mainly to the lack of affordable accommodation.

webTitle: Income faltering as demands grow on mid-range charities

fields.headline: Income faltering as demands grow on mid-range charities
fields.trailText: There was a time, not so long ago, when to have suggested that the Guardian should encourage its readers to give to charity would have provoked a healthy debate. To have proposed that the newspaper run its own appeal would have risked revolt.
fields.body:
There was a time, not so long ago, when to have suggested that the Guardian should encourage its readers to give to charity would have provoked a healthy debate. To have proposed that the newspaper run its own appeal would have risked revolt.

Today, as the Guardian launches its third Christmas appeal, there is no issue. Charities have become an essential pillar of modern society and the argument that their work for the disadvantaged and oppressed is "letting the state off the hook" is rarely voiced beyond the extreme left.

Charities are big business. Depending how you count it, their overall income is anything up to £21bn a year. They employ 500,000 paid staff.

Yet this is not growth for growth's sake. Charities have assumed a rapidly expanding role as providers of services on behalf of government. As the state has withdrawn from direct provision of care, support and advice for those in need, so it is charities that have stepped in to fill the void.

The importance of this role has been acknowledged by the government, which has signed a "compact" with the voluntary sector in recognition of its status as an independent partner. Ministers, from Tony Blair down, have called for a new era of giving and a revived culture of "civic patriotism".

All is not rosy in the charity garden, however. As needs multiply, at home and overseas, many charities are struggling to keep their heads above water - and some are questioning their strategies.

Research to be published this week by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations will confirm that medium-sized charities bore the brunt of a slump in charitable giving in the 1990s. While donations have now started to rise again, they remain well below previous levels and mid-range charities still find themselves squeezed by the fundraising power of their big name competitors.

But these have been suffering, too. A collapse of charity shop income has hit Oxfam and Scope, triggering shop closures and job losses. The NSPCC's failure so far to get anywhere near the £250m target for its Full Stop campaign - the biggest fundraising appeal in history - has shown that size is no guarantee of success.

Latest figures from an index kept by Barclays bank and NGO Finance magazine suggest that the top 100 charities have weathered the storm, posting an overall 9% increase in income for 1999-2000. Significantly, though, one of the best performers was Age Concern (England), which returned an 88% rise in trading revenue largely thanks to its insurance and financial services.

Last year, Guardian readers raised more than £200,000 for four charities. This year, the aim is to do better still. Once again, one of the charities has been chosen from among the winners of a Guardian award for smaller charities, announced in October, and the other three have been selected from charities applying to be considered for the appeal in categories of domestic poverty, overseas aid and the environment. Preference was given to medium-sized applicants.

There is a wide spread: the smaller charity, young and innovative, goes into primary schools to work with children with behavioural problems; the domestic charity works with women fleeing violence and abuse at home; the overseas aid organisation takes help straight to people who suffer the twin agonies of poverty and disability; and the environmental charity provides invaluable assistance to developing countries seeking to defend themselves at law against exploitation or pollution.

Over the next month, the Guardian will report on the work of these four charities. Please read about what they are doing, please reflect on it - and please give generously.

webTitle: Officehours: Charity begins at work

fields.headline: Charity begins at work
fields.standfirst: Get your employer to send you on a day trip. To paint classrooms, perhaps, or clean up the River Thames. Dolly Dhingra talks to employees in the community
fields.trailText: Get your employer to send you on a day trip. To paint classrooms, perhaps, or clean up the River Thames. Dolly Dhingra talks to employees in the community.
fields.body:
Charity and Christmas seem to go hand in hand and, as the season of goodwill approaches, it's easy to relieve a heavy conscience by buying a box of Christmas cards from a favourite charity. But what about the rest of the year? Does goodwill have to go out with the tinsel? Surely we could do more than the yearly token gesture.

Business in the Community is an organisation which aims to do just that. Offering a variety of schemes, it seeks to encourage employers and employees to donate their time and services to aid both the community and charitable groups. And the difference from normal voluntary work? It's all done in work time.

People from occupations across the board are taking part. Lawyers are painting classrooms, secretaries are shopping for the elderly and accountants are busy cleaning the River Thames. Whatever the job, the intention is for charity to become more than worthy. The organisers want the activities to be fun and develop social skills. What's more, employers are bending over backwards to take part. After all, it's good for the community, good for employees and, ultimately, it's great PR.

An already successful scheme, Cares, is a similar charity, enticing corporations from across the country. Imported from the US, Cares has spread to more than 12 UK cities in two years. "It's time for businesses to realise that volunteering their staff to Cares makes for a healthy business," says Julie Unsworth, community excellence manager of Cares in Leeds. "It's not just a 'nice' thing to do. It has great businesses benefits and is a way to invest in people."

Unsworth feels that offering staff up to Cares can sit easily alongside other company perks as a way of developing skills that workers may not acquire in the office alone. "Volunteers have to deal with delegation, motivation and time-management issues and all the while they are increasing morale of colleagues and raising the profile of their company in the community," she says.

With volunteer groups and "action days" available, some businesses are beginning to see company volunteering schemes as a far more constructive and economical way of "bonding" colleagues than the costly corporate "days out" on offer. High-profile companies such as Marks & Spencer, HSBC and Zurich Financial Services count themselves among them.

With word-of-mouth recommendations, charity volunteering is gathering momentum fast, and with the natural enthusiasm of participants, such as that shown by Renee Miller, 30, it's not hard to see why. "I love taking part, it really sparks me up. It's so different to the things I do at work."

A training administrator in the service and quality team of BT Cellnet, she has been involved in Cares since June 1998 and quietly admits that "Sometimes I think I get more out of it than I do my job. I get to meet people I wouldn't normally meet: gangs of young kids, groups of elderly people - it's a great way of networking, and you can bring friends and family to help too."

Currently Miller has her hands full encouraging her colleagues to donate food to put into hampers which will then be distributed throughout the local community. Her past activities have involved organising tour guides for children at Leeds United stadium with ex-football players, and walking dogs for owners who can't manage it themselves.

As volunteers will tell you, any assistance is valued. Pro-help seeks contributions from field specialists (whether it's IT or organising) and Oxfam simply asks for your used stamps and any unwanted coins of any currency, both old and new.

But for those who fancy getting out and about, Julie Saliba, an applications developer at Linklaters and Alliance solicitors, can't enthuse about it enough. In her regular contributions to the homeless at St Botolph's in London's East End, she serves food and organises the administration of advice evenings. "There are so many benefits to volunteering," she says. "Most of the time you get so caught up with work and working life that you forget what really matters. Working with the homeless puts things in perspective because you see how vulnerable people can be. When you see the problems they're up against, your own pale into insignificance."

 For volunteering in schools in London, contact Mike Richardson of The London Accord (0870 600 2482).
 For working with the homeless, contact St Botolph's on 020 7377 2478 or write to 2 White Church Lane, E1 7QR.
 For information on national Cares schemes contact Tina Tietjen (0870 600 2482).
 For Pro-help, contact Annette Gordon (0870 600 2482).

webTitle: West Ham 1 - 0 Middlesbrough

fields.headline: Robson uses his last lifeline
fields.trailText:
West Ham 1 - 0 Middlesbrough
Robson uses his last lifeline.
fields.body:
Their TV repair man not having turned up, the picture at Middlesbrough remains confused. Though it is doubtful whether Terry Venables, had he joined Boro last week, would have arrived in time to alter the course of Saturday's match, he would surely have tried some fine tuning. That would have been a start.

Instead Middlesbrough lost dimly and dolefully, their seventh defeat in eight Premiership games leaving them 19th and level on points with the bottom club, Bradford City. It was par for the Riverside's present downward course, and reports that after the game Robson contacted Venables to persuade him to help out for the rest of the season smacked of panhandling: "Buddy can you spare the time?"

Even before the game Robson's position as manager was verging on the untenable. He was as keen as his friend and chairman Steve Gibson to secure Venables's services. Now, though he is still in charge, his readiness to accept a lesser role under the more experienced man must pose questions about his ability to pull the team around.

"Apart from Terry Venables I don't think there's anyone better than myself to manage this club," he declared on Saturday. "What I've got to do now is work hard with the players and try to get it right. I know that if I don't get it right soon the chairman will sack me."

Gibson's dilemma is that, having kept faith with Robson far longer than most chairmen would have done, he now has to decide whether things can be allowed to slide beyond Christmas before biting the bullet, then firing it.

Middlesbrough face a demanding December with visits to Sunderland and Tottenham and home matches against Chelsea, Liverpool and, crucially, Coventry City, for whom these are equally troubled times. Robson has nothing to offer except blood, toil, tears and sweat, even if he did not put it in quite those words. And on the evidence of Upton Park, phoning a friend will not be enough.

Lack of effort was the least of Boro's difficulties. Lack of any attacking idea apart from hoofing the ball high and long towards the shining head of Brian Deane was the main problem, especially after West Ham had gone ahead a few minutes before half-time.

The goal was a delicious piece of purse-snatching by Paolo di Canio, who had been tightly marked by Robbie Mustoe. When the Italian gathered a ball from Frank Lampard wide on the left there seemed no immediate threat but suddenly he turned inside Mustoe to release a shot so sweetly struck that Mark Schwarzer was beaten at his near post.

A couple of minutes later West Ham lost Lampard and Igor Stimac with, respectively, a cut mouth and a calf injury. In theory this weakened them in midfield and defence, not that one would have known it.

The presence of four centre-backs in Robson's side, one of whom, Ugo Ehiogu, was sent off near the end for a second bookable foul, did give Boro some resilience but their attacks largely amounted to the long stuff. With Stimac gone West Ham had only the diminutive Steve Potts, the veteran Stuart Pearce and Rigobert Song, their energetic though hardly commanding replacement for Rio Ferdinand, to confront Deane. But Deane went unserviced and Pearce dealt with what danger there was.

Harry Redknapp said he hoped Boro would not go down. But he did not do Robson any favours by remarking that Boro had fielded a strong side with "people on the bench who are supposed to be world-class players".

By this he presumably meant Christian Karembeu, who added subtlety to Middlesbrough's movements for the last 27 minutes but again wore the bewildered air of a French gourmet who has wandered into a tripe emporium.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Private parties

fields.headline: Private parties
fields.standfirst: The division between public policy            and its operation has grown wider, as the Serps fiasco has shown
fields.trailText: December 4 2000, comment: The division between public policy and its operation has grown wider, as the Serps fiasco has shown, writes Hywel Williams.
fields.body:
Rational myth claims that government is a contract. Romantic Tories - when they existed - said it was a contract between the past, the present and the future. More secular liberals see it as a done deal. Individuals give up some rights (such as the native capacity to be my neighbour's beater) and keep other ones (such as the right to self-protection when my neighbour tries to beat me up). Government is the sum total of rights transferred-and exists to protect the rights retained.

Modern managerialism in government ignores the romance of the former myth but builds on the latter. For both left and right, government is a "service provider" which has customers and consumers.

A myth may grow in the telling. But that does not make it true - as the cruel incompetence of Serps reform has shown. A private sector business which behaved in this way would end up in the courts, sued for damages and forced into bankruptcy.

It is a dubious feat of political anorakia to remember that Norman Fowler was secretary of state for social services in 1986 - the year of the Serps policy change. Sir Norman retains a precarious niche in memory lane for the "crikey" of his startled response when apprised by informed officials of the finer details of oral sex as he prepared to launch the first anti-Aids campaign. That famous exercise in awareness, with its falling tombstones, was alarmist rather than informative. But when it came to Serps there were neither beats on the drum nor dissemination of intelligence. The Tories had decided that the state earnings-related pension was too expensive. In 14 years' time, therefore, the rights of surviving spouses would be halved. Like Newton's God who said "Let Nature be", the ministerial fiat sounded in the clear air.

But the second stage, the important one where policy becomes practice, never happened. No one told those affected that they had 14 years to prepare for the change.

The story is partly a Tory one of credulity about government and the ease of change 1983-87 were the high-noon years. The monetarist folly was past and the European demons lay ahead. These were the privatising years - another change whose full consequences are also only being recognised a decade and a half later.

But the tale is one of three Labour years as well as of 11 Tory ones. So it's a question of how Britain is governed as well as who does it.

The divide between policy and operation, between theory and practice, is a new, self-serving, truth of the British constitution. The growth of quangos and agencies has eased its reception. Lines are now blurred between what is, and is not, a governmental act. Evasion displaces responsibility. The doctrine was famously used by Michael Howard when home secretary to sack Derek Lewis as director of the prison service, to deny his own accountability and thereby stay in office.

The same bogus distinction is now used by Norman Fowler and Alistair Darling as a clause of self-exculpation. A little thought could clear their minds of cant. A policy is an intent - and in law intention is father to the deed. Paternity has responsibilities. The line which leads from policy to administration, to deeds of commission as well as of omission, really does exist however winding the trail. The commonsense incredulity which greeted Michael Howard's disavowal is appropriate here as well.

But the mess is also a civil service question. Suspicion of politicians' easy convictions is natural to officialdom. The Whitehall service remains what it was after the mid-19th century reforms: a body of intelligent meritocrats. Once they served an aristocratic governing class - now they serve the bourgeois heirs. But if the class divide is gone the one of temperament, the distinction between professionals and amateurs, remains. A politician may be in full-time employment but a minister is always casual labour, a part-timer with excuses for distraction.

We should often celebrate civil service inertia. Mandarin piety acts as a brake on the enthusiasms of the swivel-eyed in all parties of government. This is especially important in a democratic despotism which gives large parliamentary majorities to parties with a slim majority of the popular vote. In terms of mandate, after all, New Labour's condi tion in 2000 is reminiscent of the Tories' in 1986.

But the Serps fiasco is an example of inertia translated into irresponsibility. And here another divide comes into play. Those charged with the practical implementation of policy exist in the regional office - not in the private office. It's quite easy for the senior official to plead ignorance of failure further down the line - and, like the minister, evade responsibility.

Now the government has given those affected another 12 years to prepare. But the awkward duet between minister and official, with its muffled tones and concealed dissonance will continue. The pensioners of 2012 have been warned of what's in store. But all of us can be wiser after this event - and be wary of government's myths.

This is especially important in a democratic despotism which gives large parliamentary majorities to parties with a slim majority of the popular vote. In terms of mandate, after all, New Labour's condi tion in 2000 is reminiscent of the Tories' in 1986. But the Serps fiasco is an example of inertia translated into irresponsibility. And here another divide comes into play. Those charged with the practical implementation of policy exist in the regional office - not in the private office. It's quite easy for the senior official to plead ignorance of failure further down the line - and, like the minister, evade responsibility. Now the government has given those affected another 12 years to prepare. But the awkward duet between minister and official, with its muffled tones and concealed dissonance will continue. The pensioners of 2012 have been warned of what's in store. But all of us can be wiser after this event - and be wary of government's myths.

webTitle: Obituary: Carolyn Ainscough

fields.headline: Carolyn Ainscough
fields.standfirst:
Pioneer in treating survivors of child sex abuse

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Carolyn Ainscough, nationally recognised for her pioneering work with survivors of childhood sexual abuse, has died, aged 43, of a cerebral tumour.
fields.body:
Carolyn Ainscough, nationally recognised for her pioneering work with survivors of childhood sexual abuse, has died, aged 43, of a cerebral tumour. She worked as a clinical psychologist in Wakefield, West Yorkshire, and, with her colleague Kay Toon, developed innovative group work with survivors.

Their book Breaking Free (1993, updated 2000) drew on suvivors' experiences and gave valuable information on assisting people to tackle deep feelings arising from abuse. The book, one of the few self-help books in its field, was followed this year by a Breaking Free workbook.

Carolyn was born in Bolton, Lancashire, and educated at Canon Slade grammar school. She went to St Andrews University in 1976 and became closely involved in the women's group there. Graduating in 1980 in psychology, she trained at Leeds University as a clinical psychologist. Staying on after work placement at the former Stanley Royal hospital in Wakefield, she rose during her 17 years there to become a consultant clinical psychologist with the Wakefield and Pontefract Community Health NHS Trust.

Ainscough and Toon took their skills around Britain by running training courses on issues related to childhood abuse for nurses, police officers, social workers, and doctors. They also set up Abuse Counselling and Training (ACT), a local network of ex-clients.

Ainscough was a lively, outspoken person with a great sense of humour and an infectious laugh. She loved talking and dancing and bliss for her was travelling to the Scottish islands with friends.

She is survived by her parents and brother.

 Carolyn Elizabeth Ainscough, clinical psychologist, born September 16 1957; died October 26 2000

webTitle: E-business: need a leased line?

fields.headline: Starting up
fields.standfirst:
Need a leased line pronto? That'll be a five month wait, guv'nor

Net news
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Need a leased line pronto? That'll be a five month wait, guv'nor
fields.body:
We have had some real fun with suppliers since we started Rools. Some of the most prolonged trials and tribulations have come when we tried to sort out our telecoms.

Like most internet businesses we need a leased line, a permanent connection between ourselves and the net, bringing improved security and performance to our internal network and online service.

It is critical to our business but not to the interior designers, accountants and lawyers sharing our building. There is no leased line in place. If we are going to have one, it has to be installed.

This is where the fun starts. The supplier has to dig up the road and do some internal work on the building. Permission and cooperation must be sought from the council, our landlord and the neighbours. The paper-chasing has taken a very long time, even with two of our already busy team trying to move things along.

We ordered the line in August, when we moved into our new offices. We were warned then that it would take six weeks before installation, so we were expecting to have to wait. The leaves fell off the trees ages ago, we have had three months of solid rain, and everyone has forgotten what it was like to travel on a train that arrives on time - and we still do not have our leased line.

Persistence - an average of six phone calls a day for the past week from our most dogged team member - resulted in a morale-boosting breakthrough last week. A team of five came to survey the dig site.

The visit reminded us of the previous month when we had a leak in the office after a weekend of particularly heavy rain. Over a period of a week, five groups of workmen came to take a look. They surveyed the scene, scratched their chins and went away again. On the final day, one visitor unhelpfully suggested using a heater to dry the damp areas.

Forever the optimists, we thought we had reached the end goal with the leased line the following day when the team returned to dig. It was then that we were told that it would require another, separate team to bring the cable up to our offices on the third floor. And it would be another three weeks before they could do this work.

With luck the leased line may be in by Christmas day, but we have learned not to hold our breath.

One of our early resolutions for the new year is to be a little more sceptical of suppliers' claims for delivery dates.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools, an online payment service for teenagers

webTitle: Theatre review: The Comedy of Errors

fields.headline: Shadows of Shakespeare
fields.standfirst:
The Comedy of Errors
The Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
The Comedy of Errors
The Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Lynne Parker's galloping and hugely entertaining production of Shakespeare's play, in which not one but two pairs of long-lost twins are reunited, takes its cue from old Hollywood movies and the word "comedy" in the title. It is none the worse for it.

The evening lacks the beguiling and bewildering exploration of the discovery of self, or other self, that the narrative's exploration of mistaken identity and twinness allow the very best productions to encompass.

Nonetheless, it does succeed in tempering its exuberant high spirits with a smoky, blues atmosphere so, at times, it is a cross between a Harold Lloyd silent movie and film noir.

The two sound completely at odds with each other, but Parker cleverly marries the different styles so that Ephesus becomes a crazy sunlit place that is touched by encroaching shadows and darkness. The evening begins seriously as Egeon, in search of his lost twin son, is condemned to death, then slips into farce that turns serious, then into nightmare as it gradually unravels.

Parker's production feels like a bright summer's day during which the sun suddenly goes in and only reappears from behind a cloud in the nick of time, and it is underpinned by Freudian ideas of the unconscious. At the end you know for sure that nothing will quite be the same again and that all will have to come to terms with negotiating their new identities.

But it is also an enjoyable romp that would serve as a brilliant introduction to Shakespeare for a child, or anyone who thinks that Shakespeare is a bore. In the second half, Parker slightly overdoes things - at one point, a camel and a medieval knight join the chase - but it is hard not to fall for the infectious high spirits of the tightly choreographed evening or its stylish 1930s setting. This is a production in which there is almost no slack.

There are some good performances, too, with the play's other double acts being added to by the sisterly affections and sharp rivalries of Emily Raymond's sophisticated Adriana and Jacqueline Defferary's Luciana, who is obviously finding it difficult to resist playing with fire and the man she believes to be her sister's husband.

Ian Hughes and Tom Smith's Dromios are well differentiated; David Tennant and Anthony Howell's pair of Antipholus even more so, with Tennant's loose-limbed puzzlement providing some excellent moments of physical comedy.

Blaithin Sheerin's design, which looks like a near eastern village square, does the business too, providing a public space with secret nooks and all the exits and entrances necessary for the madcap comedy that fizzes with life if not the greatest of subtlety.

 Until February 3. Box office: 0207 638 8891.

webTitle: Review: The Willard Grant Conspiracy

fields.headline: The Willard Grant Conspiracy
fields.standfirst:
Union Chapel
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Union Chapel
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The Willard Grant Conspiracy are like a travelling therapy group. This loosely-knit collective orbits around songwriters Paul Austin and Robert Fisher, with Fisher also serving as lead vocalist and raconteur. Behind the measured, sometimes majestic contours of their music, the pair are engaged in a lengthy process of self-healing. Fisher is slogging his way back from years of drug and alcohol abuse. Austin, the adopted child of a fractured marriage, acknowledges that, inside his head, "a few pistons are blown".

The Union Chapel, with its pews, pulpit and leaking roof, seemed custom-made for the band. Fisher, a huge barrel of a man in thick-framed glasses and a lumberjack's check shirt, relished the overtones of sin and redemption so much that he tried making his stage announcements without the microphone, addressing his congregation like a non-conformist preacher until the punters yelled that they couldn't hear. This was a shame - his introductions provide a sense of the primitive, unseen America which fertilises the Conspiracy's music.

With eight musicians squeezed onstage, the songs take a while to achieve lift-off, but when they're flying it can marvellous. Melodic lines bounce between keyboards, mandolin, guitar and viola. Images of death, failure and suffering shudder through the songs like the creaking wheels of an undertaker's wagon. "I'm wicked in the eyes of the world, I'm everything nobody wants," Fisher sings in Wicked. Amid the sparse falling cadences of Massachusetts, he finds himself snowbound and alone: "They say that everything will be all right, it never seems that way this time of night." Time and again, he announces songs about hangings, murders and drunkards. The mere title of Love Has No Meaning says enough.

They make an effort to send us home feeling at least slightly reassured. The Work Song is a communal singalong designed to generate togetherness, while The Visitor is built around raging, Velvet Underground-like crescendos like primal therapy in sound. But you sense the Conspiracy still have many miles to travel.

 Edinburgh Attic tonight; Newcastle Corner House tomorrow; Manchester Hope & Grape Wednesday; then tour Ireland.
