webTitle: Mary Warnock's top 10 philosophy books

fields.headline: Mary Warnock's top 10 philosophy books
fields.trailText: Lady Mary Warnock is a crossbench life peer, moral philosopher and author of a number of books on philosophy, including The Intelligent Person's Guide to Ethics. Her autobiography, Mary Warnock: a memoir, was published earlier this year by Gerald Duckworth
fields.body:
Lady Mary Warnock is a crossbench life peer, moral philosopher and author of a number of books on philosophy, including The Intelligent Person's Guide to Ethics. Her autobiography, Mary Warnock: a memoir, was published earlier this year by Gerald Duckworth.
Buy Mary Warnock: A Memoir at Amazon.co.uk
Buy The Intelligent Person's Guide to Ethics at Amazon.co.uk

1. A Treatise on Human Nature by David Hume
If I had to choose just one philosophical book, this would be it. It covers a huge range of continuing philosophical topics: knowledge, perception, imagination, personal identity, causation, emotions, the foundations of morality and justice. Hume is the most endearing of all philosophers as well as the most sceptical. His scepticism covers even his own conclusions but his thoroughly 18th-century down-to-earth good sense permits him to persevere. I would dearly love to have met him.

2. The Nicomachean Ethics by Aristotle
Aristotle's philosophical interests were extraordinarily wide. He was more of a biological scientist than a metaphysician; everything he wrote is worth study, especially as part of the history of science. The Nicomachean Ethics is not only historically fascinating, but it timelessly points the way to the development of a theory of ethics out of the concept of human beings as essentially rational, choice-making animals. I have learned more from this book than any other.

3. Individuals by PF Strawson
Published in 1959, this was a ground-breaking book of enormous importance to philosophers of my generation. After the second world war, we were not much into metaphysics. But this was a new descriptive metaphysics (to use Strawson's own phrase), not windbag speculation, but drawing general conclusions from how things are. It opened the way of a solution to the problem of personal identity and the relation between mind and body by insisting that persons, being both mental and physical entities, were among the basic particulars in the world, not to be atomised or further divided up.

4. The Bounds of Sense by PF Strawson
Sub-titled 'An Essay on Kant's Critique of Pure Reason', this is an illuminating analysis of Kant's main line of thought in the Critique, and it goes beyond Kant in its marvellously perceptive discussion of the relation between language and the world as we perceive it. Kant was perhaps the first truly professional philosopher. He had an immense influence on all subsequent philosophy but he was also a difficult and rebarbative writer. Strawson's book is not a simplification, but a demonstration of the profundity and significance of Kant's whole philosophical project, that of setting limits to what we can and cannot say and know. An indispensable guide.

5. On Liberty by John Stuart Mill
Unlike Mill's other generally sensible and analytic books (on logic, political theory and utilitarian ethics) this is a passionate cry for the freedom of the individual from the tyranny of the majority, from prejudice, social convention and the bondage of correctness - what might today be thought of as the Daily Mail rule. It is a wrong-headed book in many ways but is irresistible to the young. Moreover it can plausibly be read as one of the most powerful feminist tracts, having been strongly influenced, if not actually partly written, by Mill's lover and later wife Harriet Taylor. At a time of general emancipation women alone were virtual slaves in 1859, when the book was published.

6. Beast and Man by Mary Midgley
A wonderful breath of fresh air and a book for non-philosophers as much as for philosophers. Mary Midgley explores the relation between men and other animals in an original but common sense way which has even more relevance to bioethical controversies today than it had in 1978 when it was published. It forms an introduction to the kind of 'green' philosophy now developing in Europe and America, and it has certainly strongly influenced my own thought, both practical and philosophical.

7. After Virtue by Alisdair McIntyre
An entirely new look at moral philosophy, which is nevertheless, as McIntyre acknowledges, highly Aristotelian. He is a truly original philosopher and all his books are worth reading but this is probably his best. It is of the greatest importance to provide a basis for morality in what is largely a secular age, and the question of what morality is needs a fresh look. This book was one of the first to attempt such a new perception.

8. Sense and Sensibilia by JL Austin
Though in fact a collection of lectures published posthumously, this forms a wholly coherent book, and is the funniest philosophical book in existence (with the possible exception of Susan Stebbing's Philosophy and the Physicists) Largely negative and destructive, it calls attention to the impossible things philosophers may be led to assert, and even claim to believe. The main target is AJ Ayer, and, to a lesser extent, Ayer's hero, Bertrand Russell, and their theory of perception. They both claimed that we do not see trees or tables, as "plain men" suppose, but only "sense data" or "percepts". The whole delightful and iconoclastic atmosphere of immediately post-war Oxford philosophy is contained here.

9. The Object of Morality by GJ Warnock
I make no apology for choosing a book by GJ Warnock, though he was my husband. He was a master of style and clarity, high virtues in philosophical writing. Like Alisdair McIntyre, and like Aristotle, he invites us to look at the nature of that man-made structure, morality, and to contemplate the need we have for it if the world is not to be even more intolerable than it often is. Those who are inclined to deny that morality can exist without a religious foundation should read every word of this book.

10. The Concept of Mind by Gilbert Ryle
Doubtless influenced by the later work of Wittgenstein (notably the thoughts that later appeared as The Philosophical Investigations), this is itself a highly influential and richly enjoyable book. It is a demolition job on Descartes' division of human beings into two substances - mind and body - the mind being, in Ryle's words, "the ghost in the machine". Though often exaggerated, and sometimes quite wrong, this is a wonderfully scintillating, stylish and accessible book. PG Wodehouse was Ryle's stylistic master, and it shows.

webTitle: Review: Patti Smith

fields.headline: Endearing battiness from Patti Smith
fields.standfirst:
St James's Church
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
St James's Church
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Not a concert as such - more a reading of poetry and prose with reminiscence, lectures and a handful of songs. As an adjunct to Tate Britain's William Blake exhibition, long-time Blake aficionado Patti Smith simply takes 90 minutes to show why she adores him. Christopher Wren's candlelit St James's Church, where Blake was baptised, is an ideal venue, the hushed crowd appropriately reverential

Now a widow and light years away from the shrieky harridan of yore, Smith is a most genial hostess. She exhibits an endearing battiness: losing her spectacles; grappling with a wonky microphone stand; knocking over her water; struggling to find her place in the books she reads from as papers and notelets fly everywhere. Sometimes she is almost inaudible above the traffic outside but, oddly, that merely adds to the ambience.

"I have some trepidation about my performance at St James's," she notes, reading from her diary. She has, however, researched diligently. "I like pretending to be a scholar," she chuckles, "it's one of the great joys of my life."

She namedrops her usual raft of influences and contemporaries from Robert Mapplethorpe and William Burroughs to Allen Ginsberg and Ralph Nader, but places them in a Blakian context, arguing that the curmudgeonly Blake was ahead of his time when considering women's and children's rights.

In hectoring hands, this would have been unbearable, but Smith's lightness of touch, all-encompassing enthusiasm and serene speaking voice win through. Indeed, when she sings Somewhere Over the Rainbow and asks the crowd to think of Blake and his wife taking long country walks, or describes her oneiric vision of American folk hero Johnny Appleseed (who wandered across his country planting apple trees), it is immensely moving.

She sings just three of her own songs: a new, unfinished, untitled song which meanders and which she promises to complete properly - and, with an uncanny understanding of her canon, her finest works, Dancing Barefoot and People Have the Power.

At the close, she elects not to do a vociferously requested encore, but instead returns to explain what the whole evening had meant to her. "My only fear," she admits, "was that I would not be able to live up to the occasion. I will always remember this night." She will not be the only one. Lovely.

 William Blake Exhibition until February 11.

As an adjunct to Tate Britain's William Blake exhibition, long-time Blake aficionado Patti Smith simply takes 90 minutes to show why she adores him. Christopher Wren's candlelit St James's Church, where Blake was baptised, is an ideal venue, the hushed crowd appropriately reverential Now a widow and light years away from the shrieky harridan of yore, Smith is a most genial hostess. She exhibits an endearing battiness: losing her spectacles; grappling with a wonky microphone stand; knocking over her water; struggling to find her place in the books she reads from as papers and notelets fly everywhere. webTitle: Pick of the week

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: This week, two 'alternative' flatmates in two contrasting, but very funny, shorts, a beautiful tale of a looting soldier and a locked door, and something to chew over in the drugs debate
fields.trailText: This week, two alternative flatmates in two contrasting, but very funny, shorts, a beautiful tale of a looting soldier and a locked door, and something to chew over in the drugs debate
fields.body:
Superhero Roommate
(Icebox.com)
Superhero Roomate takes the oldest sit-com recipe in the book - take two opposites, rub till funny - and gives it a sniggering sophemoric cartoon twist. Sarcastic slacker Neil spends his days as a cable-TV couch potato until a freak meteor shower turns him into Omega Force. Despite saving the world on a daily basis, our superhero can still find time to nitpick about the bills and masturbate over his uptight flatmate's copy of Maxim ( 'Go AWAY - I'm draining particles !'). This is The Odd Couple for Gen-Xers - go suck up an episode or two before everyone else finds out about it.
 View the film

Ed's Bed
(www.regenerationtv.com)
Shot on the Fisher Price Pixel 2000 Camera, this short took second prize at the Phoenix Film Festival in London earlier this year. As Icebox's Superhero roommate (reviewed above), this film also deals with an eccentric flatmate, but this one is resolutely British: an escapist accountant who dresses in a goblin outfit. Just when our mild-mannered hero in a bit of a fix, assorted geeks wearing goblin marks rush out of the front room to save him. Very funny indeed.
 View the film (12mins 24)

Mother May I Control My Own Consciousness?
(www.culturejam.com
In which modern day America's war on drugs is likened to the fascist regime of Orwell's 1984, or even to the medieval wars of religion. The US government's anti-drugs crusade is "a war on certain mental states, a war over how reality may be perceived: what is at issue is consciousness itself," intones the X-Files-esque voiceover. Produced by the nonprofit Alchemind Society, this 13-minute short leaves itself wide open to accusations that its makers have smoked one joint too many, but get beyond that and you'll find a perceptive and well argued essay, that if nothing else will give some interesting food for thought.
 View the film (13mins 13)

Hero
(AtomFilms)
Yes, this romantic second world war drama is very obviously a Hollywood calling card. But we'll forgive the look-at-me professionalism of this tale of a looting soldier and a locked door, on account of some sterling qualities rare in debut films. Such as a delicate and surprising story, plus a stand-out performance from Julianne Nicholson as a sullen fraulein who has more to hide than the family silver. All that you'll lose viewing it on a 56k modem are the tiny typed homilies on the title and end cards. All that you'll need to know is that heroes aren't only made on the battlefield.
 View the film (14mins 56)

webTitle: City expects rates to be held

fields.headline: City expects rates to be held
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Bank of England will this week leave interest rates on hold for the 10th month in a row and continue to peg them at 6% until after the Budget in the spring, according to City economists.
fields.body:
The Bank of England will this week leave interest rates on hold for the 10th month in a row and continue to peg them at 6% until after the Budget in the spring, according to City economists.

With the Bank's nine-strong monetary policy committee set to announce its latest decision on Thursday, analysts believe that signs of slower domestic and world growth rule out the prospect of an increase in borrowing costs. However, Roger Bootle, economic adviser to services company Deloitte & Touche, said that the Bank was concerned by the possibility of a giveaway pre-election Budget and would not be prepared to reduce interest rates until it knew the contents of Gordon Brown's package.

Mr Bootle said the recent "hawkish" comments by the Bank's governor, Sir Edward George, should not be seen as a sign that rates were on their way up. "The governor's remarks should rather be interpreted as a warning shot across the bows for the chancellor."

Pressure for higher interest rates has eased in recent months, and Mr Bootle said he now expected two quarter-point cuts in rates in the middle of next year, followed by further easing to 5% by the spring of 2002.

Nick Parsons, chief currency strategist at Commerzbank, said: "Our prediction is that we will see a first birthday at 6%, which will be the longest period rates have remained unchanged."

webTitle: Review: Grace x 3

fields.headline: Grace x 3
fields.standfirst:
Green Room
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Green Room
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The Grace of the title is Grace Paley, the American short story writer, whose garrulous fictions of Jewish immigrant life in New York have deservedly earned her a reputation as one of the finest purveyors of the shorter form. What's more, as her stories are alive with debating voices, they are ideal for dramatisation. And, in this solo performance by the American actress Margo Lee Sherman, we are treated to three of Paley's best-loved tales.

With only a wooden chair and stool for a set, Sherman, in a dressing gown, slacks and street shoes, begins with Paley's A Conversation with My Father. In this witty and humane exchange, a young woman writer has fun baiting her traditionalist father with her clever, open-ended stories, while he insists on a little more tragedy, a little more description, and a clearly discernible conclusion.

Sherman catches all the gruff melancholy of this wise but ailing Jewish man, the forlorn expressions, the eyes staring into middle distance, the lingering resistance. Then, with a quick change of posture and tone, Sherman is just as assured as the determinedly insouciant daughter who is lovingly outwitting her dad.

Women of resolution, women who won't be dragged down by their maudlin men-folk, can be found throughout Paley's work, including The Immigrant Story, the evening's second act. The female protagonist is accused by her friend Jack of having a rotten, rosy temperament as she happily equates the history of Europe with a thousand years of cruelty.

Yet her view is endorsed by Jack's story. In slow, sombre tones, Sherman as Jack recounts his father's immigration to wartime America and his mother's arrival later, her head shaven, her younger children absent. As the lights fade, with the realisation of loss, Jack acknowledges it is a terrible thing to grow up in the shadow of somebody else's sorrow.

Yet the greatest creation of the night is the delightfully gaudy Rosie from the final story, Goodbye and Good Luck. A ticket-office girl adored by a famous Yiddish actor, Rosie is a huge-bosomed chatterbox whose obvious charms belie a nifty intelligence. Giving us Rosie's vaudevillian story, Sherman ekes out every emotion like the pleats in her capacious dress, and she twirls on her high heels with the memory of past happinesses. Sherman is also marvellous as the grandiloquent actor who cannot quite fathom the spirited woman he is drawn to.

It's a wonderfully entertaining triptych, and Sherman's impressive performance (alas, her only UK show) successfully animates the felicity, the thoughtfulness and the fight of Paley's remarkable prose.

webTitle: Review: Music for Everyman

fields.headline: Music for Everyman
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
On paper, the Philharmonia's Music for Everyman concert - conducted by Christian Thielemann and intended to raise funds for The Institute of Cancer Research's Male Cancer Research Centre - presented a programme of surpassing conservatism.

Brahms's Violin Concerto was followed by Wagner's Prelude and Liebestod from Tristan und Isolde, and two of Strauss's most famous tone-poems. Yet Thielemann's concert was, in reality, an extraordinary, over-abundant celebration of German romanticism.

The second half was designed as a kind of composite three-movement symphony, beginning with the transfigured lovers of Tristan und Isolde. Thielemann coaxed an instantly compelling sonority from his players. There was no want of the seamlessness which has placed him in the tradition of conductors epitomised by Herbert von Karajan. But Thielemann also shaped individual phrases with a vivid, impassioned muscularity.

Wagner's prelude grew organically from the ambiguity of the opening cello motto to a climax of shocking beauty. Even if Thielemann's Liebestod could not sustain the inexorable momentum of this opening - his expansive tempo sapped the music of its inner dynamism - this was still a performance of ravishing strength.

Richard Strauss's nickname in late 19th-century Germany was Richard the Second. In the tone-poem Death and Transfiguration, the parallels between the two Richards were all too apparent. The trajectory of Death and Transfiguration is almost identical to that of Wagner's Prelude and Liebestod. In place of Wagner's doomed couple, Strauss's music tells of an artist on his death-bed, who is released from the torments of the mortal world in rapturous, heavenly bliss.

Just as in the Wagner, the Philharmonia played magnificently for Thielemann. But in the finale of this bizarre triptych - the high-jinks of Strauss's Till Eulenspiegel - the orchestra bettered even their own high standards.

Relieved by the black humour of Strauss's virtuosic orchestration, they relished all of Till's amoral exploits, from the joy of his conquests to the chilling terror of his hanging.

Brahms's Violin Concerto was similarly revitalised by Thielemann's clarity and energy. And the power of Sarah Chang's no-holds barred violin-playing matched her accompanist's approach, in a fascinatingly visceral performance.

webTitle: Review: Art of Fugue

fields.headline: Art of Fugue
fields.standfirst:
Crucible
Sheffield
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Crucible
Sheffield
Rating: *****
fields.body:
The Art of Fugue is perhaps the one work by Bach over which arguments about "authentic" performance are irrelevant - given that the most authentic thing to do would be to leave it on the shelf.

Compiled over the final decade of his life, it is highly doubtful that Bach intended to hear this austere and ultimately incomplete harmonic treatise performed in public - nor even that he would have agreed with its present title.

Partly because the score is entirely bald of dynamic markings, partly because audiences are understandably reticent to sit through what is, in essence, the same short theme being played over and over again for an hour and a half, the Art of Fugue has never been what one might call a crowd-puller. Yet the enigma of the work is also its most attractive feature.

Having drawn the lines without colouring them in, Bach offers perhaps the greatest blank canvas in the canon. Debates about which instruments to use keep musicologists happily occupied - keyboard and small ensembles are the most frequent options, though it has even successfully been done on recorders.

You could probably perform it on kazoos if you wanted, although the string quartet stands out as perhaps the most appropriate performance ideal, given that each player is exclusively devoted to pursuing a single line of Bach's esoteric score.

There is possibly no finer quartet adapted to this than the Lindsays - not only for the acute brilliance of their playing but the fact that, at home in the Crucible Studio, they perform Bach's rounds in-the-round. Part of the effect of the Art of Fugue is visual - the sheer abstract wonder of the notes mirroring themselves or flipping over and appearing backwards on the page, and something of this is available to the audience if they are seated behind each player's shoulder, watching the thematic baton transfer from one instrument to the next.

The word "fugue" derives from the Latin for flight, and while it might sound like an overstatement to describe the Lindsays' performance as the art of flying, the intelligence of their performance comes with wings attached.

The band effortlessly demonstrate that structural logic can be tempered with sensual delight, alternately caressing or chopping into the line until every note seems both essential and inevitable. Bach may have been surprised to see them do it, but surely he would have been secretly pleased nonetheless.

webTitle: Review: Des

fields.headline: Des
fields.standfirst:
SFX Hall
Dublin
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
SFX Hall
Dublin
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The radical priest Des Wilson was one of a number who were drawn, quite literally, into the line of fire between the British Army and working class nationalists in west Belfast in the early years of the Troubles. From 1966 to 1975, Wilson ministered to the besieged Catholic ghetto of Bally- murphy, where neighbours, friends and fellow priests were shot dead by the army.

Now officially retired, his protestations against these atrocities eventually won him the Sakharov Peace Prize although, back then, he attracted the dangerous contempt of local squaddies and the Church heirarchy.

This production, by Dubbel-joint, is an unashamed tribute to Wilson in the form of a one-man memoir, written by former republican prisoner Brian Campbell. In time-honoured Gaelic iconographic tradition, actor Jim Doran - in vestments and priestly garb - performs at the foot of a massive cross on a high dais. But this isn't churchy agitprop, but rather a deeply moving and convincing testimony.

Under Pam Brighton's pointed direction, Doran gives a performance of great humanity, scattering off a melee of cameos from the sanctimonious Scotsy Bishop to the treacly west Belfast accents of local wisecrackers.

From his early sunny memories of the impoverished Falls, Wilson charts the descent into carnage: his friend Father Hugh Mullan among seven people killed by British soldiers the night internment was introduced; a later massacre in which Father Noel Fitzpatrick was shot dead, described as a gunman on BBC news.

Wilson compiled a dossier of abuses for the Church, after which Cardinal Conway made a statement condemning IRA and loyalist paramilitaries, without mentioning security forces. From Wilson's position, the upper echelons of Church and Army were on more than speaking terms.

Some of the Church's canonical doublespeak and cruelty take your breath away. After Wilson resigned, he was barred from all Church buildings, schools and halls. In one scene, he appeals to a prominent Catholic theologian who referred to the Vatican's seven conditions for justifying a revolution, all of which the IRA's cause satisfied, bar one - it was unlikely to succeed.

The piece steers away from condemning Protestant loyalism (indeed, it advances an almost Protestant argument of individual conscience) and giving any wider analysis. The abrupt cut-off point at Wilson's resignation in 1975 is deeply unsatisfying but, ultimately, this is very effective theatre.

 Until December 2. Box office: 00-353-1-8554090.

webTitle: Mortgage aid plan for key workers

fields.headline: Mortgage aid plan for key workers
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Buying a home
fields.trailText: Ministers are preparing to unveil plans for mortgage subsidies to help teachers, nurses and other professionals who are priced out of property hot spots, in the face of new research revealing a widening gap between house prices and incomes.
fields.body:
Ministers are preparing to unveil plans for mortgage subsidies to help teachers, nurses and other professionals who are priced out of property hot spots, in the face of new research revealing a widening gap between house prices and incomes.

A new urgency has been added to the government's proposed starter homes initiative with a study by leading housing organisations today warning that England faces an acute shortage of accommodation because more people are living alone.

The research, for the Our Homes, Our Future campaign, shows that in the past 30 years house prices have increased by 135 % and wages by only 60 %.

It warns that special measures are needed to help the 2m people expected to be living alone by 2016 - most of them over 30.

"These people are at particular risk because many of them live in the south-east of England and are reliant on only one income to buy a home in a market already unaffordable to many," it said.

The report, by the Cambridge Centre of Housing, Planning and Research, also warned that key workers in areas of high demand are at risk because their nationally-negotiated wage rates do not adequately reflect higher than average house prices.

With leading housing organisations warning that "targeted" help is now needed, ministers are poised to promise interest-free top-up loans, cash for deposits and help with shared ownership schemes under which a publicly-funded housing association might own half the equity of a home.

The housing minister, Nick Raynsford, has said there is scope for "innovative new thinking" in this area. The government wanted to hear from employers who would make a contribution to a £250m fund - kicked off with government cash - which would be targeted at essential workers.

Richard McCarthy, chief executive of the Peabody Trust, a large social landlord in London which also helped sponsor the research, warned that in London alone there was now a shortage of nearly 36,000 essential workers due mainly to the lack of affordable accommodation.

webTitle: Review: Passion and heartache at the Royal Ballet

fields.headline: Passion and heartache at the Royal Ballet
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Englishness turns out to be the underlying issue of the Royal Ballet's latest and quietly triumphant mixed programme, with works from the UK's top trio of classical choreographers - Tudor, Ashton and MacMillan - on show. None of the five ballets are specifically about England but all, in some way, are fed by the temperamental compromise which seems to make English art tick: the national habits of feeling which temper grandeur with irony and limit romanticism with domestic detail.

The centrepiece of the evening is a revival of Antony Tudor's rarely staged Lilac Garden (1936), the work in which Tudor, a former butcher's clerk, staked his claim to become the English Proust of the ballet world. It's a tragedy of social manners in which a woman, Caroline, arrives at a party to celebrate her impending marriage to a man she doesn't love. There she meets not only her real lover but also the discarded mistress of her husband-to-be.

Tudor's vocabulary of simple, resonant gestures handles the situation with fraught but never melodramatic emotion. In Caroline's hysterical attempts to maintain her self-control, and in her fiancé's quietly brutal command over her body, we see a relationship of clenched powerplay. Caroline's brief encounters with her lover are a febrile clash of nerves and passion while the discarded mistress threatens all decorum in her attempts to claw back her former lover. These unhappy protagonists slip between crisis and shadow while their various friends, bright, brittle and knowing, persistently try to draw them back into the social dance.

Sylvie Guillem as Caroline is mesmerising, with her body wired to the tightest possible pitch and oscillating agonisingly between revulsion and desire. Christopher Saunders' fiancé is a man of terrifyingly stiff propriety, destined to be a bully in the drawing room and a shit in bed. It's a measure of Tudor's emotional intelligence that, with the right dancers, this period ballet feels as psychologically loaded as any modern work, and Saturday's fine cast should guarantee its future in the Royal's rep.

The other works in the programme were more familiar, but performed by dancers who made us see the choreography, and sometimes themselves, with new perspectives. In Ashton's glamorously apocalyptic La Valse, we saw Zenaida Yanowksy's long austere body turn almost baroque in its lavish musical response, while Darcey Bussell brought amplitude and magnificence to Monotones II: her high attitude line hovering in the air like a beautiful bird of prey. MacMillan's war requiem, Gloria, had Leanne Benjamin dancing an exquisite angel of death, with Jonathan Cope as the iconic unknown soldier giving the uncanny impression of a body both supercharged with power and refined into ghostly weightlessness.

Finally Ashton's transparent pastoral Symphonic Variations, had a rare cast to do it justice: with limpid, delicate dancing from both Miyako Yoshida and Belinda Hatley, and graceful rectitude from Johann Kobborg and Inaki Urlezaga.

 Until December 20. Box office: 020-7304 4000.
